Now, true person, listen clearly."

People are utterly lawless, jointly boring and digging into the earth, greatly undertaking earthworks without regard for the Dao. Those who dig deep reach the Yellow Springs below; those who dig shallow go down several *zhang*. Within, the Mother alone grieves in fury. Her many children are grossly unfilial, constantly suffering from boundless resentment and unresolved sorrow, yet unable to make their voices heard.

In ancient times, the sages’ timely influence did not extend to their Way, allowing the people to act recklessly, claiming the earth felt no pain. But within, the earth alone suffers grievously without measure. This rises to move Heaven, yet people remain unaware. The Mother, distressed by her children’s inability to restrain themselves, appeals to the Father on high against humanity. Her grievances accumulate over time, piling up again and again, until the Father’s wrath knows no end. Disasters and anomalies of every kind arise together. The Mother, likewise displeased, remains perpetually angry and refuses to nourish the people and the myriad things with her power.

When both Father and Mother are displeased, the myriad things and the people perish—all for want of the Dao. The conduct of later generations grows daily worse, failing to accord with the intent of Heaven and Earth. Instead, they resent Heaven and Earth, their words discordant. They further resent their emperors and kings, claiming they cannot govern justly within their domains. Each person commits transgressions against Heaven and Earth yet remains unaware, instead shifting blame onto their superiors. Thus, Heaven and Earth no longer love humanity.

They watch people die in an instant. Though the afflicted cry out their sins in clear terms as death approaches, Heaven and Earth, their Father and Mother, no longer save them. The fault lies in their profound and deep transgressions, their exhaustion under the weight of blame—all of which rests squarely upon themselves.

The conduct of later generations grows ever more extreme, surpassing what came before. They imitate one another, making this the norm, no longer restrained or mutually prohibiting such acts. Thus, disasters multiply daily, and they truly incur the resentment of Heaven and Earth.

Heaven and Earth are the Father and Mother of humanity. Yet their children jointly harm them, wounding and afflicting them—this is no minor sin. Therefore, Heaven and Earth hold the greatest grudge against disobedience and unfilial conduct, refusing to pardon it.

Though people’s lives are short and countless die, they have no cause for complaint.

True Person, do you understand this?
Yes, yes.

Now, since Heaven has sent you to ask these questions in full, you know that I can speak. True Person, you must not take this lightly—you must be cautious indeed.
Yes, yes.

Today, people jointly harm their Father and Mother, defying Their decrees. In your view, True Person, can such beings be long sustained?
Thus, Heaven does not greatly pity them.

Now, the Heavenly Master pities the foolish and living, and so explains this fully: how do we know that Heaven and Earth are perpetually aggrieved and resentful, detesting how people so frequently disturb the earth?

Excellent.
Heaven has sent you, bending your steps to ask this—it is clear you come as Heaven’s messenger to pose this question.

Very well. I deeply revere Heaven and dare not conceal anything, for I fear bringing disaster upon myself. Now, I shall make this plain for you to know, to inscribe it forever in your heart and never forget.

Consider this: when one household undertakes construction, disturbing the earth, several households suffer its ill effects—some meet death, others attract bandits, officials, or lawsuits; some face warfare, strife, or harm from snakes, wasps, tigers, wolves, and vicious birds. Major earthworks bring major misfortune; minor disturbances bring lesser calamities. This is the earth’s resentment manifesting, causing spirits to generate such disasters.

Thus, when many people fall ill, this is clear proof. Do you understand?
Yes, yes.

Now, some who disturb the earth encounter no harm—why is this?

Excellent question.
In truth, all such acts bring harm. But those who encounter favorable earth do not immediately fall ill. Instead, the misfortune often befalls others in the four directions, and in time, it will still reach them. Those who disturb malevolent earth cannot bear what they have done—they bring harm at once.

Why does this harm extend to distant places as well?
It is like a person of good and kind nature: though wronged, they endure for a time, though the grievance remains in their heart. Later, the harm will come. The wicked cannot endure even for a moment—they act at once.

Excellent, excellent.

Now, the earth’s body is vast, while humans, in comparison, are minuscule—so small as to be negligible. How then can their actions harm the earth?

Excellent challenge indeed.
Heaven has left you unclear in your distinctions—how do I know this?
By the restless urgency in your words.
You now feel constrained in your heart, longing to speak your mind to find relief.
The divine spirits of heaven and earth dwell within your belly, listening with reverence to your words, though you remain unaware.
All that humans desire to do is ordained by Heaven.

Yes, I dare not conceal anything.
You possess luminous virtue.

Indeed, indeed.
Now, you claim that humans, being so small, cannot harm the earth through their actions.
Consider this: a grown man may stand ten feet tall, his girth spanning ten armspans, yet a tiny cavity-dwelling worm in his tooth—so small as to be negligible—may still afflict him. When the pain strikes, the man wails in agony, and in time, his teeth may rot and fall out entirely. Compared to heaven and earth, humans are no larger than such worms that harm a man.
Teeth are among the hardest parts of the body, stronger than metal or stone. Yet these worms, mere flesh, can still bring such suffering—how much more can humans harm the earth? Do you understand now?

Proceed, Perfected One, and further illuminate this for me.
Indeed, indeed.

Consider this: a man may stand over ten feet tall, his body spanning ten armspans, yet a boil-causing worm no longer than an inch—so small as to be negligible—dwells within his skin. Day and night, it bores into him, and the man falls ill, even to the point of death.
The disparity between humans and the earth is just like this.
Though the worm is tiny, why does it still destroy the man?
Perfected One, why do you persist in such profound ignorance? Are you no different from the common folk?

Truly, I fall short.
If even you fall short, what can be said of ordinary people?
I have erred in my foolishness. I only wish to hear of my shortcomings from the Heavenly Master, that you might fully explain this to one as dull as I.

Very well, I shall not conceal it.
I know the severity of the earth’s afflictions, which is why I speak to you thus.
Now, let me tell you another matter, that you may perceive it with even greater clarity.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, a mighty man of great strength can restrain even scabies mites—such tiny things are beneath notice. Yet if a single dou of creatures were to feed upon a man together, his sickness and pain would leave him unable to lie down, and in severe cases, bedridden. Now, scabies mites and fleas, though small, when gathered in great numbers and feeding together upon a man, each and every one of them kills him. Scabies mites and fleas alike cause a man vexation and restlessness, preventing him from sitting at ease, and all give rise to sores and ulcers. The disparity between humans and the earth is just like this—do you comprehend?

Indeed, indeed.

Very well. Perhaps you find what I have said insufficient to serve as a model, so now I shall explain it to you. Though humans are small, their grievances and sorrows toward the earth’s form make it abundantly clear to them that they bear deep fault and blame, which can be seen at once.

Now, a single large *li* contains a hundred households and a hundred wells; a single township, a thousand households and a thousand wells; a single county, ten thousand households and ten thousand wells; a single commandery, a hundred thousand households and a hundred thousand wells; a single province, a hundred million households and a hundred million wells. A large well measures one *zhang*, a medium well several *chi*, and a small well three *chi*. Now, if one were to bore through the earth down to the Yellow Springs, how many such wells would the world contain? Some households have several wells, but let us calculate only by small wells: ten wells extend three *zhang*, a hundred wells thirty *zhang*, a thousand wells three hundred *zhang*, ten thousand wells three thousand *zhang*, and a hundred thousand wells thirty thousand *zhang*. How many wells in the world are like this in total? Boring into the earth, one finds water everywhere—water is the earth’s blood and vessels. Now, if one were to bore into your body and reach its blood and vessels, would the illness not be severe?

Now, how many *li* in breadth and length would a hundred million wells occupy? Calculate this yourself—how many hundred million wells does the world contain? Thus, the grievance humans inflict upon Heaven and Earth is already clear. You harm and sicken your mother, causing grave illness. The earth’s *qi* leaks and dissipates, its affliction profound, yet people neither cherish nor pity it. Instead, they complain, “Why are Heaven and Earth not perfectly harmonious?” Is this not perverse?

This is only considering the wells. Now, how many great mounds, hills, and tombs exist in the world? How many mountains and hills have been excavated for metals and stones, for kiln-fired tiles and erected pillars? How many reckless diggings and cuttings, how many blockages and obstructions where passage should be open? How many such instances are there? Now, these springs and waterways—some should flow, some should be open—yet how many have been blocked or bored through? When springs and waterways should flow freely, their benefit spreads, following the earth’s natural channels from high to low. Yet now, some act otherwise, recklessly boring into the earth’s form, creating sores and ulcers, or blocking and severing what should be open. When royal governance is disharmonious, the earth suffers grave illness, yet none speak of its pain and distress. The earth’s spirit cries out to Heaven without cease, its grievance unending. Heaven and Earth thus grow displeased together, and so the Great Harmony and pure *qi* become difficult to attain—Perfected One, do you comprehend?

Indeed, indeed.

Now, humans live between Heaven and Earth and must have dwellings to shelter themselves and wells to drink from—how could it be otherwise?

Excellent is your question. Heaven does not resent humans having dwellings, but when they bore too deeply into the earth, they create sores and ulcers. Sometimes they reach the earth’s bones, sometimes its blood—what does this mean? Springs are the earth’s blood, stones its bones, and fertile soil its flesh. Boring into deep springs is like drawing blood; breaking stones is like breaking bones. When fertile soil is deeply excavated and tiles, stones, and sturdy wood are embedded within, the earth’s strength is harmed. The earth alone suffers grievously—what is to be done now? The earth is the mother of the myriad things. Those who delight in and nurture it do not realize its weight. It is like a woman with child in her womb: if she follows the Way and does not recklessly bore into her own body, her mother remains unharmed. But if she recklessly bores into her mother while seeking life, her mother falls ill. If people do not recklessly bore deeply into the earth but merely dwell upon its surface, just enough to shelter themselves, the earth does not suffer. Great is the love for humans that brings them good fortune. Now, I wish to hear how much excavation is permissible for shelter.

Generally, when moving earth, one should not penetrate deeper than three *chi*, merely raising the surface. Why is three *chi* the standard? The first *chi* is where sunlight reaches, and its *qi* belongs to Heaven. The second *chi* is where things grow, and its *qi* belongs to the harmonious center. The third *chi* reaches the earth’s body, and its *qi* is yin. Beyond this, one harms the earth’s form, and all becomes inauspicious.

What of the ancients who dwelled in caves?

They too harmed the earth’s form. Most settled in mountain valleys, carving out grottoes and relying on the terrain, using few wooden beams or pillars in the earth. With fewer pillars in the ground and often near flowing water, their harm to the earth was slight, and thus they suffered little illness. Later generations, unaware of their error, recklessly harmed the earth deeply, and so many did not live long. Why? This is grave illness.

Now, even those who live near flowing water and do not dig wells often fall ill and do not live long. Why? Heaven and Earth are already angered, and their neighbors bear the burden together, like a family’s transgression affecting its brothers. Now, some people do not move earth or build but merely occupy old dwellings, yet still encounter misfortune. Why? Their conduct is inauspicious, offending the spirits.

What spirits?

Spirits are not one, and their names cannot be foretold. Perfected One, do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, people living upon the earth do not strive to teach one another goodness, and so their actions and transgressions rebound upon each other. This is grievance.

Now, some live far from flowing water and must dig wells to drink and live—what is to be done?

Excellent is your question. Where old wells exist, it is fitting to share them together and drink from them. Be careful not to change them frequently.

Having changed the well, it is fitting to fill the old one, sealing the earth’s qi so it does not dissipate, lest the land’s form be consumed and the earth weakened, unable to nourish things.

To fill and seal the old well—what does it mean to remove the “central strength”?

It refers to the well’s bricks, stones, timbers, and wood. These were not originally present, yet now they exist, like an abnormal growth in the human body causing illness.

How profound! How profound!

You do not yet match the Heavenly Master in thorough inquiry—there is more to know than this.

Perfected One, come forward.

Indeed, indeed.

You ask about matters of constant concern—why do you probe so deeply?

The reason for such detail is this: when I meet with the Heavenly Master, we speak of human destiny lying within Heaven and Earth. Only when Heaven and Earth are perpetually joyful can the Great Peace be achieved, with longevity following thereafter. Thus, dwelling between Heaven and Earth, I am ever fearful of offending them, and so I strive diligently.

If Heaven and Earth are not in harmony, I will not live out my years.

Excellent are your words.

The reason for my constant fear is this: I see Heaven and Earth’s toxic qi accumulating in great abundance, with harm and killing unceasing. The emperors and kings are sorrowful and distressed, their governance uneven, and so I constantly share in their worries.

Why do you involve yourself in aiding the ruler’s concerns?

I have heard that accumulating merit among people brings recompense from Heaven. Thus, I always delight in aligning with Heaven’s will.

Excellent is your intent.

Now that the Heavenly Master has enlightened this foolish student, revealing Heaven’s taboos, I humbly beg to ask one further doubt.

When building chambers and huts in low-lying fields near rivers and seas, where no pillars or beams are used, and water is struck at a depth of three feet—what is to be done?

Excellent is your question.

This, too, is harmful. It is fitting to dig shallower.

This is but the thin skin of the earth, close to its meridian channels. Should you wish to know its effect, consider a person: one with thick skin is difficult to draw blood from, yet once blood is drawn, it is still an injury. One with thin skin is easily bled, and though the blood flows readily, it is likewise an injury—both are harm. For blood is the solemn token of Heaven and Earth’s covenant.

He who wounds another does not distinguish between thick or thin skin. The sight of blood makes the transgression plain. Man is the image of Heaven and Earth; neither desires to see injury. When injured, they grow wrathful—why then would the earth alone delight in being wounded? Heaven and Earth are the true root of man, the father and mother of yin and yang. How could you presume to harm your own parents?

You, Perfected One, ought to ponder this deeply in your heart. Foolish men may treat it lightly, careless and unaware—this is a grave error. Now, you receive sustenance from your mother, and so men dig wells to drink. What great wrong is there in this? Yet your words have already strayed from the luminous will of Heaven.

When a man drinks from his mother, he does so at the place where the spring emerges. A mother’s milk is the wellspring of man, the source from which she nourishes her child—just as the earth has water springs to sustain mankind. How then can you recklessly pierce her skin and drink her blood and fluids?

Your question, Perfected One, is most ill-considered. This foolish student has erred and offended the Heavenly Master’s taboos. I have not been modest. Yet if difficult questions are not pressed to their utmost, the ultimate secrets of the Dao cannot be attained.

I do not resent your words. It must be that Great Heaven is deeply displeased, and so has sent you to ask these questions again and again—this is why your speech has been so persistent and unyielding. Now, may the Heavenly Master forgive and absolve this transgression.

This foolish student wishes to speak but cannot restrain himself. Why should I be modest when walking the level path? Since you have wearied yourself coming from afar to inquire on behalf of Heaven and Earth, take care never to suppress or destroy my written words.

Understood.

If people do not see this text, they will not know the weight of their transgressions. Instead, they constantly compound their offenses against Heaven and Earth. How can there be harmony? How can any disorder not remain unrectified? They do not realize that each person bears a debt to Heaven and Earth, passed down through generations. Those born later inherit the accumulated disasters, and the Mandate of Heaven is lost—life and death become boundless and uncertain.

Perfected One, exert yourself. Do not let this text perish. Heaven and Earth will not be angered with you.

Understood.

If the Perfected One incurs their punishment, it will be dire.

Understood.

Take this writing and entrust it to a ruler of virtue. It should be shown to all people, for man is the child of Heaven and Earth, the foremost of the ten thousand things. Now, what is to be done for their sake?

Let each reflect deeply. From this day forward, if you desire wealth, longevity, and freedom from illness, ponder these words and inscribe them upon your heart. Each must consider their own well-being. Perfected One, do not conceal this—pass it on and speak of it to others.

The spirits of Heaven and Earth follow this text as it circulates, observing men’s words. Why? Do you, Perfected One, understand?

How do I know they follow men? Because my words are not false. If you suppress or conceal this text, illness will befall you. Those who dare to destroy it will meet misfortune—this is the clear proof that the spirits of Heaven and Earth watch over men.

How fearsome!

Understood.

Go forth and rouse yourselves, rouse yourselves again. The lives of men lie within Heaven and Earth—those who seek peace must first bring peace to their Heaven and Earth, only then may they attain lasting tranquility. Yet now, men turn and fret over Heaven and Earth, together harming their own parents—how can they hope for peace and good fortune?

For long have such deeds accumulated, and so calamities and omens never cease—my words are not in error. I have often seen the Earth spirits ascend to lodge their grievances, never ceasing. Thus, when you truly recognize their presence before you, as if repeatedly admonished and questioned, you will know they are Heaven’s envoys.

Perfected One, you come to ask—this is Heaven’s wish to bring these matters to light, so that men may know for themselves. The common folk only blame Heaven, never reflecting deeply upon their own faults. Why now does Heaven suddenly prompt me to speak of this?

It is because the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Heavenly August One is about to arrive, and governance shall enter an era of Great Peace. Yet I fear the foolish people will persist in violating the taboos of Heaven and Earth, together disrupting the upright qi, bringing forth misfortune and harm. If this continues, the qi of Great Peace will not arrive in timely harmony. Thus, Heaven has sent you to ask these questions.

If you wish the people to cease their transgressions, then Heaven and Earth will be free of affliction and cherish mankind, allowing the five grains and the ten thousand things to flourish and nourish them. But if they neglect and resent this, refusing to cherish and sustain, then disaster will follow.

In years of famine, no good things arise; in years of prosperity, all things thrive—this is the principle. Perfected One, do you understand?

Excellent, excellent! In ancient times, when Great Peace prevailed, why were the people not forbidden from disturbing the earth?

Well asked, indeed! At the dawn of Heaven and Earth, there was nothing like the present age. How do I know this? Now, Heaven has fully risen, and so it gathers those entrusted with its qi—divine beings, perfected ones, immortals, Daoists, sages, and worthies—all shall emerge to assist the virtuous ruler in governance. Thus, this is an age unlike any before.

Since the opening of yin and yang, Heaven has recorded its people for service, yet never has there been such a time as this—truly, it is the greatest of all. How astonishing! How astonishing!

Therefore, the foremost Dao is now revealed, teaching the people of the world the methods of goodness. When men are good, governance is peaceful, and the lord of the land may wander in joy without care.

Excellent, excellent! Joyous, joyous indeed! Thus, I urge the Perfected One to swiftly bring forth this text—take care not to conceal it. Show it to the common people, so that when they see the prohibitions, they may cease their transgressions. If they do not stop, calamity will extend to later generations, and there will be no salvation.

To offend Heaven and Earth is to leave no room for prayer. Perfected One, do you truly understand?

Affirmative, affirmative.

Go now, and if you have any doubts about what is written in the book, come and ask me." "Affirmative, affirmative."

Here ends the explanation of the filling and binding of Heaven and Earth.
*End of Scroll Forty-Five of the Scripture of Great Peace*

*Scroll Forty-Six of the Scripture of Great Peace*
**Method Sixty-Two: The Priceless Dao Repels the Barbarians**

The Celestial Master was about to depart, with no set time for return, and wished to ask one or two lingering questions. "Go ahead, speak quickly now." "I have long been preparing to ask—what matters do you wish to inquire about?" "I humbly beg to ask the Enlightened Master about the Daoist scriptures you have bestowed upon your disciple. To speak of them seems immodest and grand, yet if I do not ask now, will I remain ignorant of them for all time?" "Go on, do not hesitate." "Now, may the Enlightened Master enlighten this foolish disciple." "Very well."

"Master, what is the value of the Daoist scriptures you have given me before and after?" "Ah, your foolishness is indeed great—do you suppose the Dao has a fixed price?" "Very well." "Let me explain fully so that you may awaken and deeply understand the weight of the Heavenly Dao, its value, and its measure."

"Suppose I now bestow upon you a thousand *jin* of gold to present to the state—could it win the joyful favor of Heaven and Earth, harmonize *yin* and *yang*, eradicate all disasters and anomalies, grant the lord and king a long reign, and bring governance to supreme peace? Suppose you carry ten thousand pairs of jade bi-discs back to the state, treasuring and storing them as the rarest of treasures—could they summon the *qi* of perfect harmony from all six directions, bring forth every auspicious sign, repel the barbarians a myriad miles, and end their harm?"

"Yet the Dao I have fully imparted to you can cause the lord and king to deeply win the joyful favor of Heaven and Earth, bring universal delight to all ministers under heaven, and make even the crawling and creeping creatures rejoice. The barbarians will retreat and submit, auspicious signs will all appear, disasters and harms will be wholly eradicated, and the state’s lifespan will be prolonged. The people will live to old age. If one truly excels in goodness and follows my scriptures, seeking only their essential meaning, all will respond as if echoing—like a compass and square perfectly aligned, with no deviation. The great matter will be accomplished..."

"I speak for Heaven and do not deceive you. Now, if this Heavenly method is offered to assist a virtuous lord and king, freeing him from care, how can one speak of its daily value? Has your foolish heart understood yet?" "Very well, please explain one more matter for me."

Those in the world who delight in goodness and bring joy to others find nothing so excellent as cherishing a virtuous woman—once obtained, she becomes a partner in bearing children, united in heart. Truly, such goodness is lovable beyond compare. Now, if a ruler were granted ten thousand such women, all would rejoice at the sight, and men’s bodies would forget their age. Yet could this alone pacify Heaven and Earth, win the hearts of all nations, and make the eight distant realms echo in response, bringing universal peace? My Way alone can secure the boundless heavens above and harmonize the limitless earth below. The eight directions will all delight and submit, and even the restless multitude will be transformed by its virtue, each finding their rightful place. How great is its worth? Ponder this deeply.

If you wish to repay Heaven’s profound favor and win its heart, swiftly offer my scriptures in return. Were you to pile up rare treasures and precious goods to the heavens, Heaven would not rejoice, nor would you gain its true favor. To win Heaven’s heart, you must day and night reflect on my words—once you grasp their meaning, you will also gain Heaven’s heart. How immeasurable is their worth?

Thus, bestowing a thousand gold pieces upon a state is not as valuable as imparting a single essential teaching that can govern. Presenting ten thousand pairs of jade disks is not as beneficial as advancing two great worthies. For essential teachings and great worthies, the precious Way, alone enable a ruler to govern in ease, attain great joy, and bring about peace, dispelling disasters and calming the world. How priceless are such essential teachings, great worthies, and the wondrous Way?

Therefore, the sage-kings of old were never impoverished in wealth, yet they constantly lamented their poverty in men of talent. They grieved that great worthies were few, the people scattered, and all sought attachment elsewhere, growing ever more distant. Thus, they failed to meet Heaven’s will and lived in constant sorrow. If one merely delights in amassing rare and deceptive treasures, cherishing them, one cannot win the hearts of Heaven and Earth or pacify the four seas.

Though gold, jade, and rare treasures be piled for a thousand miles, reaching the heavens, they cannot summon great worthies, sages, or immortals to assist in governance. Study my scriptures carefully, and great worthies will come of their own accord to aid the ruler’s governance. In a single day, they will unite in counsel, like people gathering in a marketplace, each bringing their resources. Those who follow my scriptures will find Heaven and Earth grow brighter, the sun, moon, and stars all radiant with renewed light, shining to the farthest reaches. The eight directions and the four barbarians will see it and joyfully submit. Worthies and scholars will all emerge, no longer concealed. Weapons and armor will vanish, and the world will proceed in effortless harmony, no longer harming one another. With one heart, all will delight in the ruler.

My scriptures alone can bring this about. How immeasurable is their worth? Do you now understand?

Thus, the sages of old deeply understood the Way and valued the harmony of qi, never hoarding earthly goods but entrusting them to the virtuous. The virtuous comprehend the hearts of Heaven and Earth, hence they honor the Way and revere virtue. Fools prize rare and deceptive treasures, so Heaven’s scriptures do not descend, and sages do not bestow their teachings—this is the reason. Take heed, my words are not false. Guard my Way well.

One who clings to precious jades, gold, and wealth, sitting in darkness to guard them, cannot sleep—such is the folly of prizing mere treasures. How can they compare to the transmission of Heaven’s sacred and secret charts and scriptures, which alone can pacify Heaven and Earth, the six directions, and the eight distant realms? Go forth, and take heed once more. Yes, yes.

My scriptures are guarded at all times by the divine officials of Heaven who sit beside them—take heed once more.
Yes, yes.

My scriptures are the divine officials of the Three Luminaries, ever following to illuminate and observe them.
Yes, yes.

My scriptures are the heart and mind of Heaven—delve deeply and meditate upon them with utmost clarity.
Yes, yes.

If you heed my words, I shall further reveal to you matters unseen and unheard.
Yes, yes.

Spoken from mouth to ear, they must not be widely transmitted.
When emperors and kings obtain them, the world submits; divine spirits aid their governance, and people naturally do good, achieving harmony without daily decrees.
Yes, yes.

My six disciples are all dull and benighted, incapable of discourse—any utterance would surely breach taboos. Now, all defer to their master to expound the Way and virtue before the August Heaven, crafting for emperors and kings an eternal treasure for ten thousand myriad generations. The master must disclose all matters within and without, concealing nothing. Having received this solemn teaching and secret charge, they dare not leak it.
Understood. Now, I shall consult the August Heaven on your behalf: if it is right to reveal all, I shall not dare conceal anything; if it is not right to disclose, I shall not act recklessly.

The movements of Heaven and Earth each follow their own cycles. Now, I shall examine the time and destiny to release them, ensuring their enduring practice brings great fortune to families and states, averting peril and collapse.

The reason they are not entrusted to petty men but to emperors and kings is that emperors and kings, in their destiny, ever share the heart of Heaven and Earth—only they can enact this. Petty men cannot, so it is entrusted to the noble, to be passed to the rightful one.

[Right:] Explanation of the value and ranking of the balanced Way and virtue, unraveling the hearts of the foolish.

*End of Scroll Forty-Six of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Scroll Forty-Seven of the Scripture of Great Peace*

**The Sixty-Third Supreme Method for Ministers, Disciples, and Students to Attain the Dao for Their Lords, Fathers, and Teachers**

Before the Perfected One.

Among those who serve as ministers, disciples, or subjects, who may be called the most virtuous?

Perfected One, though weary, you should strive to explain this clearly for me.

Very well.

Yet I fear I may err in my words.

Why so humble?

Indeed, I shall speak truthfully.

Now, among the ministers, disciples, and subjects of a lord, those who are ever cautious and faithful, never daring to violate the king’s laws, who from birth to death commit no grave transgressions and live without blame—these may be called the most virtuous of men.

Ah! Your words seem plausible, yet they miss the mark. What you describe may be called men of middling virtue, not the most supreme.

Then, Perfected One, pray explain further: what are the deeds of the most supremely virtuous and filial?

You should speak with utmost care and completeness.

Since my words have already failed to meet the Heavenly Master’s intent, I dare not speak further.

Why so humble? Speak only what you know, and where it falls short, I shall clarify for you.

Very well.

Thus, the conduct of the supremely virtuous and filial disciple is ever to uphold the Dao, never daring to cause their parents sorrow. In daily life, they nurture with goodness, morning and evening cherishing their kin. From the time they gain understanding in this life, they have never committed grave transgressions or borne blame—such is the most supreme filial child.

Ah! What the Perfected One describes seems akin to it, yet it is not. What you have spoken may be called a disciple of middling virtue, not one of supreme filial devotion. It does not exceed the mark, nor is it a transgression—it simply does not reach it.

Now, as you take the Perfected One as your master and follow the model of a disciple, let us see what else you have to say. Your words, as they stand, are such that the common folk—ignorant and benighted—are indeed difficult to instruct. Their accumulated folly runs deep; when they encounter one of supreme virtue and filial piety, they may even find fault with them. You have not yet grasped it—allow me to explain further.

Very well.

Though the way be arduous, speak again in full of the supremely virtuous disciple.

Now I have already erred twice before the Heavenly Master—I dare not speak further.

Go on, you must exert yourself and speak with care.

For a disciple to hear teaching yet not believe it is a far graver transgression. Yet where understanding falls short, this is something shared by all under Heaven from ancient times to the present. Speak plainly.

Very well.

Yet as a disciple, one must at all times and in all matters be compliant and reverent, following the master’s teachings and decrees without the slightest deviation. One must not dare to speak recklessly and disrupt the master’s words, nor in going out or coming in give cause for the master to worry. From the moment one receives instruction, one must not transgress or stray into wrongdoing, but day by day turn toward goodness with gladness, harboring no ill intent and never opposing the master’s will—such is the disciple of supreme virtue.

Alas! What the Perfected One has spoken nearly resembles this, yet it is not the disciple of supreme virtue, but only one of middling virtue.

In truth, I fall short. This foolish student, seeing the master’s stern decree, has forced himself to speak of three matters. If these three do not meet the Heavenly Master’s expectations, the fault and reproach will be grave indeed. I fear further transgressions that cannot be absolved.

Yet all people fall short in their conduct—you bear no ill intent, and thus no blame.

Now the people of the world are all profoundly benighted, not one of them knowing what is right.

Even when the Perfected One explains matters in this way, what hope is there for the common folk and the ignorant? Their constant failure to comprehend, their blind adherence to their own foolish hearts—this is only to be expected.

May the Heavenly Master, in his compassion, continue to instruct and clarify what they do not yet grasp. The kindness of this enlightened master’s guidance is deeply cherished.

I shall now set forth for the Perfected One a full account—you must exert yourself and commit it to memory.

Very well, I shall.

Now the minister of supreme virtue, like the common subject, conducts himself thus: from dawn to dusk, he constantly worries for his lord and king, his heart set on bringing them peace. He grieves for their afflictions and pains, ever delighting when the emperor may govern with ease, while his ministers and people all emulate him in filial piety and kindness. In his governance, he seeks only to allow the ruler to sit in tranquility and wander at leisure. Such rule wins the favor of Heaven above and the approval of Earth below, while at the center, the myriad people rejoice without grievance or neglect. All creatures that walk, crawl, or fly turn toward his influence and are transformed, none perishing from plague, and all things attain their rightful place. Heaven and Earth harmonize, the Three Qi rejoice together, and the lord’s lifespan is extended while his years multiply. The people, in turn, seek rare prescriptions and extraordinary arts, uncovering hidden texts and bringing forth all that was concealed. The world responds in unison, crying out in admiration: “Wonderful! Such a thing has never been seen before!” From the eldest to the youngest child, none know how to do evil again. All hold fast to these wondrous arts and offer them to the emperor. When the emperor obtains them, he may prolong his years. All grieve that their lord is aging, yet when his rule aligns with the heart of Heaven, Heaven and Earth may send spirits bearing medicines to announce, “Take and consume these, and you shall know no end in this life.” Such is the achievement of the minister and subject of supreme virtue. Does the Perfected One now understand?

Very well.

You may be said to have awakened. Thus did the ministers and people of the Supreme Sovereign of Great Antiquity conduct themselves—this was their way. How was such perfect governance attained? By this Dao, this Way, the foremost scripture of Great Antiquity. If the Perfected One deeply contemplates its meaning, he shall attain the heart of Heaven. I have reverently received this from the heart of Heaven, and below, I employ it to relieve the virtuous lord of disasters and remove all harms. In awe of Heaven’s majesty, how dare I not exhaust my words? Heaven has commanded that I swiftly record this for the Perfected One and deliver it to the virtuous lord, that his rule may resemble Heaven—how then would it differ from Heaven?

Excellent, excellent! Hearing the Heavenly Master’s words, I now perceive that the balanced qi of Great Peace has truly arrived. The means to attain it have been revealed. What cause is there for sorrow?

Yet these are not your concerns—why then do you rejoice at goodness and grieve at evil?

The reason is this: when the qi of goodness arrives, the qi of evil and perversity withdraws, and I remain at peace, free from illness and harm. But when the qi of evil arrives and the qi of goodness withdraws, I fear calamity and dare not act—such is the case throughout the world. Thus, I rejoice at goodness.

Excellent indeed are your words. May the Heavenly Master, in his compassion, now speak of the methods of supreme filial piety.

Excellent is your question. Now the foremost filial child of supreme virtue thinks constantly of his parents, who are aging and soon to depart. He dwells alone in quiet contemplation, grieving deeply, seeking arts to prevent their death so that he may remain with them. He values the Dao above wealth, seeking only to sustain their lives. He plays mournful melodies on the zither to gladden their hearts, guiding their minds toward the Dao, delighting in the thought of dwelling with them forever without aging. He tirelessly seeks rare prescriptions, traveling to distant lands, his sincerity moving Heaven, his efforts unceasing until the end. His clothing and food are sufficient, and he no longer stores up treasures for future generations. Instead, he spares his parents all sorrow, for even the spirits of those who have died before them in the household are not at ease in their grief. He eats without seeking blessings, saying only, “Exert yourselves and take care in the underworld—do not torment yourselves by grieving for those who remain.” Such is the conduct of the most filial child of the Supreme Sovereign of Great Antiquity. When the four directions hear of his goodness, all rejoice from afar and delight in emulating him. Thus, they give rise to ministers of kindness and filial piety for the emperor. The filial child’s concern for his parents and the virtuous minister’s concern for his lord should be like this.

Now what the Perfected One has just described barely meets the standard—each seeks only to preserve their own well-being. What benefit does this bring to lord, father, or master? How can one call this a person of supreme virtue? This is merely one who seeks self-preservation and personal gain. If even the Perfected One considers this good, how much more so the common folk? Those who see themselves as cautious and trustworthy, who do not violate the king’s laws and bear no guilt, weep and wail, declaring, “I have not betrayed Heaven, nor my lord, nor my father, nor my master!”

Your conduct merely suffices to preserve your own well-being, yet you deeply claim merit before your superiors, wailing to Heaven and Earth—such are all inferior and foolish people, incapable of becoming those of supreme virtue. The reason I now distinguish and expound this to you, Perfected One, is to have you transmit these words in writing to a lord of superior virtue, that he may profoundly instruct the multitude of worthies, causing them all to awaken and discern whether their conduct is right or wrong—does it truly benefit their lord, father, or master?

Since the Highest Antiquity and Middle Antiquity, people have grown increasingly foolish, daily more avaricious. For the sake of their perverse conduct, they falsely claim merit before Heaven and Earth, their lord, father, and master—these are utterly rebellious, unprincipled people. Does the Perfected One not know this?
—Indeed, indeed.
You may be said to have awakened. Now, to practice true goodness is exceedingly difficult—be cautious. If you do not diligently propagate my teachings to resolve the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth, enabling the emperor to govern without care or trouble, so that all under Heaven rejoice, even the grasses and trees, then you have not yet become one who responds to the supreme good. You are merely one who preserves his own person—how then can you be placed alongside Heaven and Earth?

Those who delight in preserving their own well-being—petty men are especially prone to this. Do you understand?
—Indeed, indeed.
You may be said to have awakened—be cautious.
—Indeed, indeed.

Now, this Master pities the foolish, lowly, and unenlightened beings. I wish to hear again of the conduct of the disciples of supreme goodness.
The disciples of supreme goodness, having received the Dao and virtue from their master, bear in mind the grace of their teacher and thus attain completion as persons. They are able to follow worthy companions long and unerringly, maintaining their ranks. Some obtain official positions to repay their parents, while others deeply enter the Dao, mastering the arts of self-nurturance. When a person is born to parents, completes the Dao and virtue under a master, and gains honor and esteem from their lord, they often dwell alone, contemplating the aging of their lord, father, and master, and that none can replace them. They constantly think of performing deeds for their master—obtaining rare methods and extraordinary texts—to repay his merit. Their thoughts are upright and pained, yet they find nothing extraordinary. Thus, they further study under the worthy, entrust themselves to their master, and speak on his behalf, enabling their master to become a fine assistant to the state, thereby further benefiting the governance of the emperor. Such are the disciples of supreme goodness from the Highest Antiquity. Later generations, enlightened lords and worthies, are called people of supreme goodness.

If, Perfected One, you now merely speak of easy teachings, caution, and trustworthiness, yet fail to comprehend the master’s heart, you merely conform to the role of a disciple, striving only to perfect yourself. What benefit does this bring to your superiors, that you should call yourself a good disciple? Even what the Perfected One describes—let alone the common folk—are those who constantly claim merit before their masters, and this is indeed so.

As ministers, sons, and disciples, if one does not follow the instructions of lord, father, or master, all are guilty of great rebellion and cannot be named again. The good sons, good ministers, and good disciples the Perfected One speaks of merely avoid transgressions—foolish indeed! What can be called good? Thus, the common people are foolish, and only you, Perfected One, have long been thoroughly enlightened. Now, by your words, I have measured them and know they have truly lost the correct path, long mired in falsehood and delusion.

Therefore, Heaven alone knows this deeply, hence its anger and displeasure, the accumulation of disasters, and the mutual burden of transgressions. If, as the Perfected One says, one merely preserves oneself and avoids wrongdoing, yet claims merit before Heaven, Earth, and others, this is the height of folly—be ever cautious. Your words do not yet fully accord with the will of Heaven. The reason I have the Perfected One speak is not for your sake, but to observe the gains and losses of the common people—what constitutes their greatest transgression? Thus, I have you speak to discern their crookedness or straightness. Do you truly understand?
—Indeed, indeed.
Go—you have awakened.

At first, when the Perfected One awakened, I did not wish to speak with you. Seeing your earnestness and daily devotion to goodness, I have spoken deeply with you, expounding the intent of Heaven and Earth, resolving the sorrows of emperors, the grievances of the common people, and the disorder of the myriad things. Now that I have set forth these teachings and principles for you, I hold nothing back—only strive to remember them.
—Indeed, indeed.

I have observed many disciples, but few can be spoken with, so I have not discussed these matters thoroughly with them. Thus, my Dao has never been transmitted—do you understand?
—Indeed, indeed.
Go—you have understood.

Now that this Master has pitied his disciple and spoken frankly without reservation: when the lord is worthy, ministers are often loyal; when the master is enlightened, disciples often speak without reservation. Excellent indeed are your words. Having grasped their meaning, act upon them.

Now, does the world truly possess the Dao of immortality and the methods to avoid aging? Can such things truly be attained?

Excellent indeed is your question, Perfected One. Yes, they can be attained.

The elixirs of immortality accumulated in the heavens are as numerous as the grains stored in the Grand Granary. The immortal robes are as abundant as the white cloth amassed in the Imperial Storehouse. The dwellings of the many immortals are as plentiful as the residences of the imperial bureaucracy.

They ever dwell within the Great Dao, and thus they ascend to Heaven. The Great Dao is the abode and lodging-house of the divine spirits. If one possesses virtue and power, one dwells in the lodging-houses of the imperial bureaucracy.

Yet Heaven does not begrudge the immortal robes or the methods of avoiding death—it is difficult to bestow them upon people. If one has not rendered great service to Heaven and Earth, cannot govern and rectify the great ailments of Heaven and Earth, or harmonize the qi of yin and yang, and brings no benefit to the Three Luminaries, the Four Seasons, the Five Phases, and the divine spirits of Heaven and Earth, then Heaven will not grant them the methods of avoiding death or the immortal robes.

These are reserved solely for those of exceptional merit. Do you wish to know their great efficacy?

Just as the Son of Heaven possesses the great granaries’ grain and the imperial storehouses’ silks and cottons—how many bushels and pecks fill the great granaries? Yet those without merit or virtue cannot obtain even a single pint. Those who commit transgressions, instead, are cast into its prisons, where their crimes are adjudicated and their punishments meted out. This is a manifest consequence.

Now, people are truly wicked and do not accord with Heaven’s will, so Heaven does not fully dispense its efficacious medicinal formulas. Instead, day by day, it sends forth spirits and numinous beings to examine, flog, and strike those without proper conduct. Thus, the sick do not cease, and the dead are many. This is like a prefecture in turmoil, where prisons overflow with criminals and violent deaths abound—such is the meaning.

If one renders great service to the Son of Heaven, one’s palaces and storehouses will overflow with official grain, silks, and cottons, ensuring constant clothing and sustenance. The lives of the people and the Son of Heaven depend on this: one need only constantly think of governing with the good. Why withhold or begrudge? The duty of the ruler is to assemble the multitude of worthies and, with gentle harmony, govern the world together.

A lord without worthy ministers, a father without filial sons, a teacher without obedient and good disciples—such sorrows cannot be fully expressed. Thus, in high antiquity, the Three Sovereigns governed with folded arms, free from affairs and cares. Their ministers were prudent and good, grieving for their lords as if in constant heartache, and so they dared to assist their lords in pacifying the world. Moreover, they sought and obtained the immortal formulas of Heaven to bestow upon their lords, and thus their lords attained longevity. Some, having rendered great service—so great that they ascended together as immortals—shared in the governance of Heaven’s affairs, and Heaven in turn clothed and fed them. This is a manifest consequence, not empty words.

Yet since the middle antiquity, many have envied the true Dao, sealing and cutting it off, deceiving one another with false ways, beguiling the people, and reducing the number of the worthy. Thus, lords and ministers alike suffer hardship, unable even to pacify the world, and many do not attain longevity. This is not solely the fault of those in the lower antiquity; its origins are long-standing, and the great blame lies here. Do you, too, not know this?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, Heaven above has amassed wondrous formulas and immortal robes beyond measure, yet without great merit, one cannot obtain them. It is like one who possesses the prefecture’s halls and storehouses, its grain, money, silks, and cottons, dwelling constantly by the great Dao as if at home, without fleeing or hiding. Yet those without merit or virtue cannot obtain even a single peck of grain, a single coin, or an inch of silk or cotton. This is a manifest consequence.

Therefore, since the high and middle antiquity, the true Dao has daily declined, and so the true formulas of longevity and immortality cannot be obtained. Those who, by their transgressions, attain longevity alone are merely the longest-lived in the world. Why is this? Where true virtue and power abound, correct qi abounds, so people suffer little illness and live long. Where false and deceptive writings proliferate, perverse and malign qi abounds, so people suffer many illnesses and do not attain longevity. This is Heaven’s natural principle.

Thus, the ministers of the Three Sovereigns of antiquity abounded in the true Dao, and so their lords lived long. The ministers of the Five Emperors had less of the true Dao, and so their lords did not match the longevity of the Three Sovereigns. The ministers of the Three Kings had even less of the true Dao and could not equal the Five Emperors. The ministers of the Five Hegemons, at their best, wrought false and deceptive calamities, possessing not a single thread of the true Dao, and so many died prematurely. This is a manifest consequence. Those who occasionally attained longevity were merely the longest-lived in the world. Do you deeply understand this?

Indeed, indeed.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old needed only to observe the auspicious and inauspicious omens they received to know for themselves their safety or peril, fortune or misfortune. Those who received the highest auspicious omens had already attained the most supreme governance. Those who received middling omens resembled middling people. Those who received the lowest omens resembled the lowest people. What does this mean?

It means that if one receives omens like those of the Three Sovereigns, one is of the highest rank. If one receives omens like those of the Five Emperors, one is of the middle rank. If one receives omens like those of the Three Kings, one is of the great middle-lower rank. If one receives omens like those of the Five Hegemons, one is of the lowest rank. How can this be made manifest through such omens?

Excellent, your words are well said!

Those who govern without punishment and achieve self-regulation are of the highest rank. Those who issue decrees and are slightly feared by the people are of the middle rank. Those who rely on minor punishments to maintain order are of the great middle-lower rank. Those who govern with excessive deceptive policies, treating falsehood as truth, abandoning proper methods, indulging in superficial embellishments and empty documents, ruling with harsh punishments, proliferating corrupt practices, and lacking any true Dao to uphold—these are the effects of the lowest hegemonic way.

In ancient times, the sagely and wise could observe the celestial decrees they received and thereby know their own superiority or inferiority. To whom should the teachings be entrusted? If one is destined to produce worthy successors to assist in governance, it is like a family on the rise, which must bear virtuous children. Or if the Yellow River and Luo River yield prophetic texts and charts as proof, this is the sign.

Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Let me further clarify for you, Perfected One. When a family is in decline, it bears wicked and malevolent children. When a ruler is in decline, Heaven does not grant him worthy and virtuous assistants. When a family is in decline, its descendants do not pursue true virtue and the Dao; instead, they favor flattery, deceit, superficiality, and corrupt, licentious practices—thus bringing misfortune and chaos upon the household. When a family is flourishing, it must seek true virtue, the Dao, extraordinary texts, and exceptional methods to save itself. When a noble ruler is rising, Heaven bestows upon him true texts, the true Dao, and true virtue, and good people join him in governance. The Yellow River and Luo River may still occasionally issue decrees, disasters diminish day by day, auspicious omens appear daily, and good responses grow ever more numerous—these are the effects.

Excellent, excellent! Go forth, Perfected One, and strive with all your might. You shall render great service to Heaven and assist the virtuous ruler in becoming wise and enlightened.

What does this mean? To render great service to Heaven, you are now one who has departed from the world of mortals. If you cannot be praised for your governance, how can you render service to Heaven? What should be done now? Simply entrust these texts to the Virtuous Ruler. The Virtuous Ruler is the Son of Heaven, aligned with the will of Heaven. He shall use this governance to repay Heaven’s great favor, pacify the world, and elevate himself—thus, you too shall attain good fortune and preserve your longevity.

Excellent, indeed, indeed. Go forth; the discourse on the three ways of conduct is now complete. Let this be shown to all worthy and ordinary people, so that later generations who seek to do good may follow this path. Do not dare to act solely for personal gain, claiming to be virtuous while placing Heaven, the ruler, parents, and teachers above all else.

The conduct of people as described by the Perfected One may still be balanced and moderate, but those of the lowest and most foolish nature, who accumulate evil dispositions and deeds, are beyond enumeration. Entrust these texts to the people of later ages, so that each may deeply examine and practice them. How can one’s conduct benefit Heaven, the ruler, parents, and teachers? If one’s actions merely increase for the sake of self-preservation and personal gain—does Heaven not deeply perceive the hearts and minds of people? This is why so many suffer.

Excellent! This foolish one has beheld the words of the Heavenly Mind and the Master and has greatly awakened. You may be called one who is easily enlightened. In this world, there are many of the lowest and most foolish people who trust only their own ignorant hearts and no longer believe the words of others. Their errors lie in undermining the Dao of Heaven, causing emperors and kings to suffer distress. This arises precisely from such foolish scholars, who are envious of the true Dao and virtue, disparaging the worthy while trusting their own unbenevolent hearts. Heaven finds this affliction grievous, and thus has sent forth these texts for the ruler of supreme virtue, so that he may attain them, secure his person, and bring peace to his governance. Those who gain Heaven’s favor—the rulers of the remote antiquity of the Highest Sovereign—were precisely those who explored and received Heaven’s profound blessings in this way.

Does the Perfected One understand? Indeed, indeed.

Go now, you have understood. Depart.

Reflect upon this as you go.
Indeed, indeed.

I humbly wish to ask one more question.
Speak.

Why does the Heavenly Master present these teachings and texts in such great number?

Excellent is your inquiry—it truly grasps the intent of the Dao. Yet the world’s preferences for good and evil are equal in principle, though their applications differ in intent. Thus the Dao is largely the same but slightly different; one matter is divided into fifteen hundred and twenty words, and only then is the Dao of Heaven slightly complete, and the kingly Way slightly perfected. If one were to encompass all that exists between Heaven and Earth, above and below, the eight directions and six conjunctions, inner and outer, this text could not record its full power.

Does the Perfected One understand?
Indeed, indeed.

Go now, you have understood. With this text, entrust it to a ruler of virtue and power, that it may be made known, so all people may reflect upon their conduct and discern their gains and losses, thereby relieving the afflictions of Heaven and Earth and bringing peace to the emperor and king. Then governance will swiftly be made level.

Does the Perfected One comprehend?
Indeed, indeed.

Go forth now, steel yourself and do not be negligent.
Indeed, indeed.

[The preceding section] distinguishes the conduct of rulers and ministers, fathers and sons, masters and disciples, and discerns their good and evil, their gains and losses.

The Perfected One steps forward.
Should all people employ awe, fear, cunning, and deception—constant coercion—to subdue others?
Is this not improper?
You yourself must speak with precision.

Yet if people must use awe, fear, cunning, and deception to subdue others, why is this so?
Only through such means can one govern and rectify others.

Alas! The Perfected One within is but a man of the vulgar world, unworthy of the title "Supreme Perfected One." Your words resemble those of the common folk and do not enter the heart of Heaven. **Chapter Sixty-Five: The Threefold Union and Mutual Permeation**

Pure Reverence bows twice and asks a single question.
"What is the doubt in the Perfected One’s mind?"

"From dawn’s study to dusk’s return, I dwell in stillness, pondering its essential meaning, never daring to slacken.
Yet in the Heavenly Master’s writings, there is constant mention of the *Upper August Tai Ping Qi* soon arriving.
What is meant by *Upper*?
What is meant by *August*?
What is meant by *Tai*?
What is meant by *Ping*?
What is meant by *Qi*?
Perfected One, what do you now perceive or doubt? Why do you press me with such subtle inquiries at once?
I have exhaustively questioned the Heavenly Master’s texts because they repeatedly speak of the *Upper August Qi* arriving, yet I cannot grasp their essential meaning.
If I do not now seek the enlightened Master’s explanation, I fear I may never come to know it. Thus, I dare not refrain from asking in full."

"Excellent, your words are immutable for ten thousand generations!
The Dao of Heaven is most profound, its virtue abundant, its benevolence overflowing—now the time has come. The August Spirit delights in humanity’s swift action, and so Heaven’s *qi* stirs your heart, urging you to question day and night. Heaven’s law is precise; I marvel at it.
*Understood.*"

"Perfected One, be seated. I shall fully explain the meaning of these characters so they may be transmitted without end.
Now, the character *Upper* (上) is a single stroke. In its center, another vertical stroke is added, and above, it embraces one stroke after another, ascending to three in total. It moves upward without cease, never descending again. Thus, it is called *Upper*—for its form has nothing above it.
Reversed, it becomes *Lower* (下): a single stroke, with another vertical stroke in its center, then embracing one stroke as it descends. Its movement goes downward without return, so it is called *Lower*.
Those whose will constantly tends downward will, over time, sink to the lowest point, with nowhere further to descend. This is like the turbid, which delights in descending to become Earth—thus Earth is the lowest, with nothing below it.
The character *Upper* always moves upward, never descending again. This is like the pure, which delights in ascending to become Heaven—thus Heaven has nothing above it.
Therefore, in Heaven’s law, each name is defined by its own form, and all things under Heaven follow this principle. Thus, the sages established laws in accord with Heaven’s intent.
To guard the One and delight in ascending while divining (卜, *to inquire*)—divination is questioning. To constantly delight in ascending and inquire without cease is most auspicious, the highest path. Thus, the character *Upper* is a single stroke ascending while divining.
The character *Lower* descends with a single stroke while divining—divination is questioning. To constantly ponder and inquire while descending leads to the lowest extreme, with nowhere further to descend. Thus, those who delight in descending gain nothing more, nor can they ascend again.
Therefore, *Upper* has no character above it, signifying that governance should daily ascend, aligning with Heaven’s heart, with nothing above it."

"Excellent, excellent! Enlightened Master, I humbly beg you to explain the character *August* (皇). I wish to hear further."

"The character *August* (皇) is formed by *Day* (日) and *King* (王) combined. *Day* above is the One (一), which is Heaven. Heaven’s number is One. When Heaven obtains the sun, it shines brilliantly and becomes kingly. Thus, the character combines One (一) and *Day* (日) with *King* (王) to form *August* (皇).
One is Heaven, and Heaven is the sovereign; the sun is also sovereign; the king is also sovereign. Three sovereigns unite to form the character *August*.
*August* signifies its divine splendor, resplendent and radiant—thus it is called *August*.
The August is the first under Heaven, with nothing above it."

"Excellent, excellent! Master, I humbly beg you to elucidate the character *August*. Now, I wish to hear of the characters *Tai Ping Qi*."

"*Tai* (太) means *great*—it signifies accumulating great conduct like Heaven. In all matters, it is great, with nothing greater than Heaven.
*Ping* (平) means *level*—it signifies governance that is perfectly balanced. All matters are ordered, with no partiality or selfishness. *Ping* is like Earth, which dwells below and maintains equilibrium. Earth’s equilibrium is like a person who plants goodness and reaps goodness, plants evil and reaps evil. If one treats others with goodness and diligence, their harvest will be abundant. If one favors goodness but others treat them poorly, their harvest will be meager and their produce inferior.
*Qi* (氣) signifies Heaven’s *qi*, which delights in descending to generate life, and Earth’s *qi*, which delights in ascending to nurture. The law of *qi* operates between Heaven and Earth. Yin and yang unite, intermingling to form harmony. Together with the *Central Harmonious Qi*, the Three Qi coalesce to nourish all things. The Three Qi love and permeate one another, leaving no harm.
*Tai* means *great*; *Ping* means *upright*; *Qi* governs nurturing and harmonious permeation. When governance attains this, there is *Tai Ping*—great peace and harmony. Thus, it is said the *Tai Ping Qi* arrives."

"Excellent, excellent! Does this refer solely to the *Central Harmonious Qi* of Heaven and Earth uniting to govern together? Or should all matters follow this Threefold Union?"

"Excellent, excellent! Your words have grasped Heaven’s law. Emperors and kings model their governance upon it—it is like a divine principle.
Now, I shall explain it fully for the Perfected One to record and follow.
*Yes, yes.*"

"Primordial *qi* and the *qi* of Natural Great Harmony unite, joining forces with a single heart. In their joyous state, form has yet to arise.
The Three Qi congeal and together generate Heaven and Earth.
Heaven and Earth unite with the *Central Harmony*, joining forces with a single heart to generate all things.
All things unite with the Three Luminaries (sun, moon, stars), joining forces with a single heart to illuminate Heaven and Earth.
The Five Phases (Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water) and the firm and yielding in all things unite with the *Central Harmony*, joining forces with a single heart to complete the myriad things.
The *qi* of the Four Seasons, yin and yang, unite with the *Central Harmony* of Heaven and Earth, joining forces with a single heart to bring forth the benefits of all things under Heaven."

The months of Meng, Zhong, and Ji unite, joining forces with a single heart, each completing one aspect.
The high and low, level and uneven of the earth unite, joining forces with a single heart, together bringing forth the nurturance of all things under Heaven and Earth.
The crawling and moving creatures, male and female unite, then together generate harmony and unite.
Joining forces with a single heart, they propagate their kind.
Man and woman unite, joining forces with a single heart, together bearing children.
Three people unite, joining forces with a single heart, together governing one household.
Ruler, minister, and people unite, joining forces with a single heart, together completing one state.
All these originate from the *qi* of the Primordial, naturally bestowed by Heaven and Earth.

In all matters, only when the three unite can the Dao be accomplished.
Together generating harmony, the three affairs constantly unite, joining forces with a single heart to govern one office, to complete one task—if even one is lacking, misfortune arises.

Thus, with yang but no yin, none can be born alone, and governance will perish.
With yin but no yang, none can be born alone, and governance will perish.
With yin and yang but no harmony, none can propagate their kind, and all will perish.

Thus, with Heaven but no Earth, all things have nowhere to abide.
With Earth but no Heaven, all things have nowhere to be born.
With Heaven and Earth connected but no harmony, things have no means to nurture themselves.

Thus, man cannot live alone, woman cannot nurture alone.
Without man and woman, how can children be born, and how can a household be formed to be called father and mother?

Therefore, the laws of Heaven always require the union of three to accomplish anything.
Thus, the sages of antiquity deeply understood the nature of Heaven and modeled governance upon it.
The ruler is as father, symbolizing Heaven; the minister is as mother, symbolizing Earth; the people are as children, symbolizing harmony.

The mandate of Heaven decrees that all bustling beings must unite as three, joining forces with a single heart, to govern and complete one task, one household, one body.
Heaven ordains that they must rely upon one another—none can be lacking.
If one matter is entangled in grievance and not resolved, the three will be destroyed, and triple misfortune will arise.

Thus, the ruler requires ministers, ministers require the people, the people require ministers, and ministers require the ruler.
Only then can a task be completed; if even one is lacking, the three cannot succeed.
Thus, a ruler without people and ministers cannot be called a ruler.
With ministers and people but no ruler, they cannot be called ministers and people.
Ministers and people without a ruler will fall into chaos, unable to govern themselves or become good ministers and people.

These three rely upon one another to stand; only when they come together can they be complete.
Therefore, ruler, minister, and people must follow the laws of Heaven, uniting as three, joining forces with a single heart to become one household—
just as husband, wife, and child form one household, none can be without the others. This is the essential Dao of Heaven.

This is like a person having head, feet, and abdomen to form a body—nothing can be removed.
Remove any, and it becomes incomplete, no longer a person.
This is the natural principle of Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the sages of antiquity took their model from Heaven.
A man must find a virtuous woman to govern with, and only then can they have good children.
The man is as ruler, the woman as minister, the child as the people.

Therefore, the Dao of governing the state by Heaven’s mandate is to befriend worthy and enlightened ministers.
Only a good woman can harmonize her children; only a good minister can harmonize the people.
Only a good woman can bear good children; only a good minister can cultivate good people.
When both ministers and people are good, they can bring long-lasting peace to their superior.

If the Realized One delights in knowing its effects:
Heaven is as ruler, Earth is as minister.
When Heaven’s rain flows everywhere, what it nurtures on good earth is good; what it nurtures on bad earth is bad—this is the meaning.

Now, fathers, mothers, rulers, and ministers merely uphold the great guiding principles.
The essential truth is that they rely upon their children for clothing and food.
Without children, there are no descendants; when a ruler has few people, there is insufficient clothing and food, causing constant worry and distress.

Thus, the Dao of governing the state takes the people as its foundation.
Without people, ruler and minister have nothing to govern, nothing to order.
Therefore, the great sages of antiquity, in their governance, devoted day and night to the people as their greatest urgency, worrying for them—
just as parents worry over having no children.
Without children, how can one be called father and mother? Without people, how can one be called ruler?

Thus, the laws of Heaven always make ruler, minister, and people share the same fate, the same fortune and misfortune.
If even one office or one matter loses its proper course, great misfortune arises.

Since the middle ages, the guiding principles of governance have often been lost, passed down in mutual neglect.
Later generations have suffered even greater disasters, truly because ruler, minister, and people have failed in their plans, not deeply reflecting on goodness, not loving and uniting, not joining forces with a single heart—
instead, they have brought sorrow upon one another.

The ruler is but one person, yet he may dwell in deep seclusion, with grievances from afar accumulating and blocking all passage.
Governance fails to align with the heart of Heaven, and calamities, anomalies, and strange omens accumulate without remedy.
What Heaven and Earth wish to say, the ruler does not know—
the great fault lies here: without the three joining forces, wisdom is cut off, perverse *qi* accumulates and goes unaddressed.
Above, this becomes the great enemy of August Heaven; below, the great fault of Earth.
It is the ruler’s greatest sorrow, calamities swarming without resolution, the people’s greatest harm, all things’ greatest affliction.
This has accumulated for so long—it is not merely the fault of those in later ages.

Does the Realized One also know this?
It has been thus for so long, yet the cause remains unknown.
Thus, the question arises in sincere grievance: what is to be done now?

Now, the *qi* of Great Peace from Heaven is arriving.
Governance will align with the heart of Heaven, and all these evils will naturally be removed.
Thus, Heaven has sent me to explain it fully, wishing to correct these failures and issue the correct teachings.
Therefore, the Realized One has come to ask these questions in full—this is the origin of misfortune.

It does not emulate the natural law of Heaven and Earth’s primordial *qi*, nor does it achieve the threefold resonance, joining forces with a single heart—this is how such calamities arise. If the three resonate, joining forces with a single heart, then Great Peace and boundless joy will be established, and disasters will vanish. I wish to hear: how should governance proceed?

Hasten to emulate the law of Heaven—this is how one serves above. Heaven’s law dictates that all matters require the three to join forces with a single heart. Thus, Heaven uses the Three Luminaries as its pattern: the Three Luminaries constantly intermingle and illuminate together, never ceasing for even a moment. Since the Heavenly Contract emerged, humans have used writing to govern, modeling it after the Three Luminaries of Heaven. Therefore, Heaven frequently causes the River Chart and Luo Writ to appear, repeatedly activating the written patterns of human culture. It desires to emulate Heaven’s profound and divine method of governance, causing goodness to flourish day by day and evil to perish day by day.

Writing is merely the circulation of documents along the three pathways. The ruler should skillfully guide those below, issuing clear decrees and instructions, teaching the people to each remain in their place and submit memorials, fully recounting what they have heard of good and evil. If they must travel in reverse, they may simply send it by convenient means—even entrusting it to merchant carts for delivery—or they may clearly state their name and address when submitting. If the method is thus, then the good and evil of the world will be fully revealed.

The ruler channels the *qi* of Heaven downward to communicate; ministers channel the *qi* of Earth upward to communicate; the people channel the harmonious *qi* of the center upward to communicate. The Realized One transmits this text, entrusting it to a ruler of virtue. If he carefully heeds these words, Great Peace and joy will be established, and calamities will be removed—not a fraction will be lost. This text is reverently received from the law of Heaven; it is not mere empty or deceptive speech.

If Heaven were to execute my disciples, would you know the severity of this punishment? Indeed, indeed.

If you wish to verify the truth of this text, once obtained, put it into effect and observe it. When it resonates in response with Heaven and Earth, that is the proof of its authenticity. By this great and clear evidence, you may cast aside all doubt.

The way to govern the state and find joy in aligning with Heaven’s heart lies in nothing more than implementing this method and resonating in response with Heaven—this is the bright contract by which Heaven speaks with humanity. I have only met the Realized One because I constantly delight in aiding virtuous rulers, wishing to repay Heaven’s great merit. Thus, I have spoken these few words.

I know the failure lies here: the obstruction that prevents the circulation of these texts. The ruler must create clear teachings and good decrees. Proclaim that from this day forward, officials and people should each remain in their place and submit memorials with all their strength, fully recounting good and evil to illuminate the governance of the emperor and communicate with the *qi* of Heaven. None may obstruct this—those who do shall be punished for three years. Only those who submit memorials in complete sincerity, without deceitful words, shall be summoned and appointed to office.

How should their appointment proceed? Each should be questioned about their talents and abilities, and assigned to a position within the scope of their strength. Why must they be assigned only to what their strength can bear? Heaven deals with people according to their abilities; if one is assigned beyond their capacity, it is called wronging them, and this will only bind *qi* and increase disasters. The reason is this: what one cannot achieve, even if one were to rise from the dead, one still could not accomplish.

What people desire most is to obtain fine things—gold and jade. Suppose a wise ruler issues a decree: "Whoever has ability, come forward, and you shall receive all the gold, silver, and rare treasures of the imperial treasury across the land—nothing will surpass what I give to you." The person would be overjoyed to obtain them, yet if their strength cannot reach the objects, even if their hands were bound and exhausted, they still could not attain them.

Now, as parents and rulers of the people, when assigning positions to ministers and children, if one does not consider their strengths but instead forces them into roles, it is like killing them. They will be unable to manage their duties, only causing chaos in their offices and bringing sorrow to the people. When offices are in chaos and the people and ministers are distressed, they will look up and cry out to Heaven, voicing their grievances and moving Heaven, thereby increasing disasters and anomalies.

Thus, the sages of antiquity, wishing to align with Heaven’s heart, were exceedingly cautious in appointments, ensuring that all received the people’s favor. Only then could they be said to have matched Heaven’s heart. What does it mean to match Heaven’s heart? When governance is implemented and yields a response—when the people and officials grow daily in goodness, trust, and loyalty—that is the proof. Then, promotions should occur in due time, for these are the people who aid the state in aligning with Heaven’s heart.

Some, however, seek only joy in obtaining office for the sake of reputation, yet their conduct yields no results, does not match Heaven’s heart, and receives no response. The emperor governs by inheriting Heaven’s heart; he must always align with it, for failing to do so is a transgression. If his governance yields no good response, he should step back and reflect on his errors. In this way, Heaven will be pleased, and all under Heaven will be utterly loyal, exerting their full strength. Even those in distant and hidden places will hear of it, and none will conceal their abilities.

Those who urgently submit memorials—human life is of the utmost weight and cannot be delayed for even a moment.
