If people continue to cry out in grievance, disasters and anomalies will only accumulate. Resolve and report on these matters swiftly. Matters that can be endured should wait until autumn and winter. Why must they wait until autumn and winter? Because autumn is when things reach completion, and winter is when things are fully stored—Heaven’s *qi* is settled then.

Things ripen in the second month of autumn, the eighth month, when their fruits and kernels can be distinguished. Thus, one should follow the law of Heaven and Earth, beginning in the eighth month to examine and distinguish them. The ninth month is the culmination of Heaven’s *qi*, when all things approach death. Therefore, one should thoroughly examine them in the ninth month, observing the balance of good and evil. Ten is the end of numbers, so by the tenth month, things return to their beginning.

Heaven’s standard takes the eighth month as the tenth month, when all things reach completion. Earth’s standard takes the ninth month as the tenth month, when all things grow old. Humanity’s standard takes the *hai* month as the tenth month, when all things die. The three standards are complete, and things are ready to be reborn. Thus, *qian* resides in the northwest, and all things begin their kernels in the *hai* month. Heaven’s law distinguishes them in the eighth month, culminates them in the ninth, and solidifies their kernels in the tenth. Thus, the three standards of Heaven, Earth, and humanity all conclude, their kernels solidified in the *hai* month. Therefore, in the tenth month, the kernels are solidified and handed down for return.

This is because the eighth, ninth, and tenth months are the three months when the standards of Heaven, Earth, and humanity all reach their end and are ready to return to the beginning.

If the kernels are not solidified, their meaning is not attained—Heaven and Earth will not be pleased, disasters will not be dispelled, and harm will recur in the coming year. Thus, in the eighth month, they are distinguished and observed; in the ninth month, they are brought to completion; in the tenth month, their kernels are solidified and handed down for return. This compels officials and common people alike to reflect anew on their transgressions and dare not repeat them. In the coming year, officials and people will be more vigilant, and all things will be well. If they do not return to reflect on their faults with steadfast resolve, ministers and subjects below will fail in governance and remain unaware of their errors, their hearts unchanged. The Dao of Heaven is unyielding—evil is not easily transformed. Therefore, they must be handed down for return.

For the Perfected One who wishes to know its efficacy: when what is handed down for return this year is recorded in one copy and kept, and officials and people are also instructed to record one copy for themselves, the measure of good and evil is called the "Heavenly Bond." When the next year’s return is handed down, another copy is made to observe the measure of good and evil. When the following year’s return is handed down, yet another copy is made to observe the measure of good and evil. The records below are compared with those above, and if they correspond, it is called the "Heavenly Mandate Aligning with the Token." This compels officials and people to transform their hearts and act with virtue, gaining Heaven’s favor. If what is submitted above is mostly good, it indicates great transformation and great goodness. If they remain obstinate, unchanged, and unyielding, what is submitted will remain as it was. If evil persists without cease, what is submitted will grow worse. If officials and people greatly deceive and defy Heaven, what is submitted will be vastly more evil and severe. Thus, this is the mirror of Heaven’s all-penetrating illumination of the heart—it does not err by even a fraction, clearly revealing the conduct of officials and people.

Heaven and Earth are like echo and shadow, responding to human actions without fail. Perfected One, if you harbor good intentions, strive to complete them with care. Though you have come to inquire of this, if it were without purpose or benefit, Heaven would silently observe. Your words may speak, but how can they be proven? When a person speaks, if their words are detailed and virtuous, others respond with virtue, and the echo answers with virtue. If their words are ominous and inauspicious, others respond with evil, and the echo answers with evil. All things that correspond and harmonize are made so by Heaven. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Heaven is lofty, distant, and majestic—how could it descend to address mortals in every matter? Thus, its laws operate through natural resonance and harmony. Has your heart now opened? Indeed, indeed. I understand. I wish to ask the Heavenly Master for one more instruction. Practice the Dao.

In the middle antiquity, the August Emperor had no written records, yet the three realms communicated—how could order be maintained? Excellent is your question. The movement of Heaven made the people of that time upright and unadorned; they all embraced the Dao and believed with singular devotion. They communicated through simple words, each desiring utmost sincerity and seeking to align with Heaven’s will—none deceived another. Thus, ruler, minister, and people united in strength and purpose, communicating as one, and so they harmonized. If they had not been of one heart and one household, chaos would have ensued.

Now, under the weight of inherited burdens, written documents abound, and deception through texts flourishes. Even the worthy and learned are misled, collectively losing Heaven’s favor. Since Heaven has produced written records, mere words can no longer suffice. One must solidify the kernels and attain their truth—when the three realms communicate, Heaven’s *qi* will be balanced.

The laws of Heaven vary by the hundreds of millions, differing from age to age. Governance and methods are each distinct. Now, as the *qi* of Great Peace approaches, the fundamental texts must be solidified with correct and original characters to gain Heaven’s favor. If you cannot discern this, consider: since Heaven and Earth established affairs, their governance has taken countless forms. Those who practice their methods and receive Heaven’s response act rightly; those who do not receive Heaven’s response act wrongly. This is the great illumination of the Heavenly Bond’s verification and efficacy. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, and ask no more. Though I could recount for you all matters since Heaven and Earth established affairs—distinguishing each event and interpreting the world’s texts—the proliferation of writings would be too vast to record, and of no use to governance, offering no benefit to the king’s rule. Thus, I have only imparted the essential Dao in summary.

For when governance falls into disorder, it stems from the patterns of Heaven—this is the great affliction of Heaven and Earth, what the sages of old jointly despised. Therefore, when a virtuous ruler emerges through the Dao, he dares not create new writings but instead returns to the solid, seeks the root, and preserves the origin. Only then can the Dao of Heaven be ordered, and the state naturally find peace.

Though you, Perfected One, are fond of inquiry, do not seek further proliferation of texts. Depart and reflect upon this.

Indeed, indeed.

[Herein lies] the wrapping of primordial *qi*, the natural workings of Heaven and Earth, the near-matters of the three realms in communion—
united in strength, harmonized in purpose, the Heavenly Bond’s illumination, the royal way of Great Peace.

*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Forty-Eight, concludes.
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Forty-Nine: "The Urgent Study of Perfected Methods," Chapter Sixty-Six.

Perfected One, now the harmonious *qi* of goodness is about to arrive in full. Yet people wander without duties—how should they clarify their minds and rectify their intentions, so that they suddenly forget evil and daily grow fonder of goodness, never setting it aside? Thus may the Emperor sit with folded hands, nothing left to govern, while those of supreme goodness fill his court, and loyal, trustworthy, filial sons are all complete.

How is this to be achieved?

Perfected One, you possess a Heaven-born nature that delights in goodness and constantly worries over the Dao of Heaven. You should now fully expound it yourself.

Simply study with urgency—through the true Dao, true virtue, and true benevolence.

Why must one study the true Dao?

The Dao alone can guide and transform without limit, cherishing life beyond measure. Those who possess the true Dao bear the name of supreme goodness. Those without the Dao bear the most vile, withered, ominous, and transgressive name—death and ruin.

Perfected One, your words on truth are excellent; I have nothing to add.

Why must one study true virtue?

Those who possess true virtue can embrace and nurture the boundless. Those without virtue bear the name of the most feeble, impoverished, and petty. Excellent indeed are your words, Perfected One; I have nothing to add—truly, truly so.

Why must one study the Way of benevolence?

The benevolent can bestow loving-kindness without exclusion, delighting only in giving without end. Those who lack benevolence turn virtue into vice, hoarding and begrudging—bearing the name of the most greedy and base, their aspirations no different from beasts, with nothing to distinguish them.

Excellent are your words, Perfected One; I have nothing to add.

Now you have spoken of these three matters; I have nothing to add.

Should people study to do good, or not?

They must strive to study goodness.

Does goodness not have a name and form?

This disciple is unworthy; may the Master enlighten me.

Those who do good align with the heart of Heaven and do not oppose the will of others—this is called goodness. Goodness is utterly supreme, sharing the same name as the Dao. It is what Heaven loves, Earth nurtures, what emperors must urgently attend to, and what ministers and rulers must unite in purpose and strength to uphold.

Evil opposes the heart of Heaven, constantly harms the will of others, rebels against the Dao of Heaven, and disrupts the four seasons. It is detested by spirits, shunned by people, the greatest harm to parents, the source of sorrow for the noble, and bears the most ominous name in the world—utter ruin.

Thus, in human conduct, losing good fortune leads to misfortune, and departing from misfortune leads to good fortune. One moment of good, one moment of evil—such are the ways of the impure and careless. Do you understand, disciple?

Yes, yes.

In your view, Perfected One, how should people conduct themselves?

If people do not diligently study the Dao, they will have no way to know it and will be called those without the Dao. Those without the Dao are the most wicked and ominous of people.

If they do not diligently study virtue, they will have no way to know it. Those who lack virtue and delight in harm and injury bear the mark of ruin.

If people do not diligently study benevolence, they become inhumane. The inhumane walk the same path as beasts; their hearts differ from beasts only slightly more than from the dead.

If people do not study goodness day and night, losing goodness leads to evil. Evil is the realm of death and misfortune. Thus, if people do not diligently study good fortune, they fall into misfortune—for misfortune bears the most detested name in the world.

Excellent! You have deeply entered the true Dao and will not return to evil.

Perfected One, you have long concealed wisdom and feigned ignorance. Why?

I dared not act.

You are fortunate to have this ability. Fully express what you have said; I am greatly pleased.

Now that you have reached this point, have you ever seen my words and then abandoned them halfway?

I dare not.

When the Master commands me to speak, if my understanding falls short, I dare not express it fully.

Excellent, your words are always deeply humble.

Now fully commit to the gate of truth; may the Heavenly Master instruct what I have not yet grasped.

What you have just said is entirely correct.

Thus, the great sages of antiquity—the Three Sovereigns—studied the true Dao day and night. Those who did not study the true Dao were called people without the Dao. The conduct of those without the Dao is countless, a great and heavy resentment to Heaven. Those without the Dao are not desired by Heaven to be covered, nor by Earth to be borne. Spirits, gods, and ghosts do not wish to protect them; the world suffers because of them.

The noble, the worthy, and the gentlemen deeply detest those without the Dao.

Thus, in the time of the Upper Sovereign, people all studied purity and tranquility, deeply understanding the utmost essence of Heaven and Earth. Only after studying the true Dao did they gain the hearts of Heaven and Earth.

Those who do not diligently study virtue are called people without virtue. Those without virtue are not loved by Heaven, not favored by Earth, and not desired by others to be near. Their conduct constantly fails to embody virtue, bringing harm to rulers and disaster to gentlemen. Ghosts and spirits, following Heaven’s decree, will not long govern with them.

Thus, the ancient worthy sages and great scholars, upon seeing those without virtue, would not even speak with them.

If one does not diligently study benevolence day and night, they will neglect affairs and become inhumane. The inhumane speak against all things, wound the hearts of others, and do not align with the will of Heaven. They resemble beasts, so the ancient sages and worthies would not walk the same path as them.

If people do not serve a teacher and diligently study goodness, they become foolish and ignorant, not knowing how to do good. Instead, they indulge their unknowing hearts and lightly commit evil.

The evil, the foolish, and the benighted act against the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Even if they serve as gentlemen, they bring shame to their parents, sorrow to their clans, and act lawlessly. Ghosts and spirits, following the heart of Heaven, are displeased and bring threefold harm to their place—such are those the law must punish.

The ancients and sages regarded this as a great grievance, so they thoroughly examined and verified their learning, aligning it with the heart of Heaven. Their affairs were rooted in the Dao, virtue, benevolence, and goodness alone. Their conduct had to accord with the heart of Heaven and Earth, never relying on frivolous or ornate words. The reason for this was that to lose the celestial law was to invite misfortune, premature death, or even harm to later generations. The Dao of Heaven is never mistaken; it has its standards and measures.

Those who do not diligently study the greatly auspicious Dao but instead treat matters with carelessness and ease will surely fall into misfortune. Misfortune is detested by Heaven and Earth, by all people, and by the myriad things. It cannot endure long, for it is the root of great calamity, the gateway to disaster. Once one falls into it, death follows, and there is no return, no chance to repent or revert to the past. Though all under Heaven know this, the lesser scholars and the greatly foolish often mock the Dao, failing to guard it or early avoid harm. They pass down their folly, burdening one another, and each generation grows more benighted than the last. Thus, the true Dao becomes obstructed and impassable, leading people to treat it lightly and fail to fulfill their natural lifespans. The great fault and error arise from this.

Those who encounter my writings should ponder them deeply. Take care not to conceal them but instead entrust them to the wise, the gentle, and the discerning, so that they may awaken. The ancient Dao, therefore, follows the heart of Heaven and accords with the will of Earth. There existed in high antiquity the great true Dao and its laws, which constantly taught people to study the Dao, cultivate virtue, seek longevity, embrace goodness, practice caution, pursue auspiciousness, emulate the ancients, and strive for peace and immortality.

The reason for exhaustively expounding goodness is that the law of Heaven always opens the gate of the Dao, and the law of Earth always opens the door of virtue. The laws of the ancient sages and worthies always opened the path of benevolence. Thus, the ancients and sages, sharing the heart of Heaven and aligning with the will of Earth, jointly nurtured the twelve thousand things, perpetually transmitting them through the intent of the Dao, virtue, and benevolence. Where such transmission thrives, the myriad things flourish. But if transmitted with malicious or evil intent, all things daily decline and diminish.

Where the Dao, virtue, and benevolence reside, people multiply and incline toward goodness. Where they are absent, people dwindle, and governance grows impoverished and bitter. This is the unchanging law of Heaven and Earth. Those who possess the utmost Dao, luminous virtue, and a heart of benevolence and goodness ascend to correspond with the celestial stars and calendars, their conduct illuminated by spirits and deities.

Thus, the ancients and sages constantly reflected on doing boundless good, exhausting their efforts so as not to dare harbor evil thoughts or tread the path of misfortune. The benighted, however, have hearts that are blocked and ignorant, incapable of further delusion. They are led astray onto the evil path of decline and misfortune, unaware of their great deviation from the Dao of Heaven. They follow one another in wrongdoing, making it their custom, unable to retreat or return.

Therefore, I reverently received the celestial scriptures and teachings, complying with the heart of Heaven to open and expand the great path of high antiquity and Great Peace. This enables people to delight in goodness and no longer know the ways of evil. Yet the people of the world set their aspirations high, but their achievements often fall short, failing to match their original intentions.

Thus, the superior person, indignant at death and delighting in life, studies immortality and, through diligence, attains longevity. Such a person is the foremost of the determined. The middling person, also resolute, is grieved by the early deaths of their ancestors and, indignant, seeks the Dao to study longevity, striving to fulfill their natural lifespan. This is the foremost of the steadfast. Others, afflicted by frequent illness and unable to maintain even a modest state of well-being, study diligently to halt their suffering. If they can restore their former health, their illness was but a minor trial. If they study only when already gravely ill, seeking arts to save themselves, it is already too late—they are as good as dead.

Therefore, my writings teach people the celestial methods of longevity, urging them to exert themselves day and night. Only then can they attain even a modest state of well-being. If one of modest attainment studies the ways of ordinary people, they have already entered misfortune. The foolish do not understand that the original aspirations of ordinary people under Heaven are to think highly of those better than themselves, yet they cannot fulfill their own aspirations. Thus, to elevate them highly, reaching the pinnacle of immortality, is merely to preserve their natural lifespan.

The greatly worthy set their minds on ten and achieve all ten, perfectly aligning with my writings on the Dao. The middling worthy set their minds on ten but may falter or grow lax, achieving only five. The petty person resolves in the morning but forgets by evening. Therefore, those who elevate greatly delight in enabling the superior, middling, and inferior to each attain their heart’s aspirations.

Now, the people of the later ages are greatly foolish, far removed from the true Dao. If they study with the celestial standard of upright texts and methods, they merely avoid falling into deceit. If they study with texts of modest attainment, they are already greatly deceived. If they study with ornate words and fine speech, great falsehood and cunning arise.

Heaven regards the emperor as its child and detests those below deceiving those above. When people below are full of deceit and perversity, the virtuous and benevolent ruler above has no one to trust, and the common people have nowhere to entrust their lives. To teach diligently day and night with the true Dao is merely to attain a modest Dao. To study with the modest Dao is already to enter frivolity. Entering frivolity, ordinary people become greatly deluded and impoverished, falling onto the path of great misfortune. The emperor is distressed, and the people cannot be governed.

If the true person wishes to know the truth of this, consider a family with loving parents who daily teach their children to do good. Though they endure hardship, denying themselves clothing and food to care for their elders, the children may still stubbornly persist in evil. How much more so for ordinary people, who are taught with frivolous and ornate texts? If they do not believe my writings, let those who encounter them reflect on their own failings.

Since the middle antiquity, those who possessed the good Dao have taught one another to conceal and withhold it, refusing to transmit it to their disciples. Instead, they taught them with frivolous and false texts. Over time, this accumulation has led to the present great disorder in the Dao of Heaven.

The calamities and portents of Heaven and Earth do not arise in vain. Let the worthy and learned deeply reflect upon this—though I do not dwell among the common folk from dawn to dusk, I have already seen this clearly. The world suffers grievously, and thus I set forth these writings to admonish those who are bound to them; I do not speak idly. True persons ought to treat this with utmost gravity, for there are the bonds of Heaven. "Indeed, indeed, we dare not be careless." Whenever I hear the words of the Heavenly Master, I tremble with awe. "Your words are true, and Heaven will rejoice greatly, sparing you from harm." "Indeed, indeed."

Though ordinary people exert themselves day and night to study and cultivate true virtue, they may only attain mediocre virtue. Yet to study mediocre virtue is already to enter the path of false and deceptive virtue. To study false and deceptive virtue is to become as countless as the foolish, who, lacking true virtue, act wantonly—these are the very bandits of the noble person. Those who strive to learn and embody supreme benevolence may only achieve middling benevolence; to strive for middling benevolence is to act with mere mediocrity, devoid of true benevolence. To study without benevolence is to become a fool who turns to banditry, unaware of the countless lives they destroy. Acting recklessly, without principle, they incur the resentment of Heaven and the blame of Earth, becoming the greatest scourge of humanity.

Those who exert themselves day and night to study the Way of great fortune may only attain middling fortune; to study middling fortune is to attain but minor fortune; to study minor fortune is already to enter the path of misfortune. To study the path of misfortune is beyond salvation—they plunge into utter darkness, knowing nothing. They dismiss the words of the Heavenly Dao as false, deceiving the purely faithful with reckless lies. Their foolish hearts speak madness, offending the patterns of Heaven above and disrupting the order of Earth below, bringing harm and disaster to the people.

Therefore, when I teach the Dao through these writings, even ordinary people may study them diligently, aspiring to join the ranks of the true immortals. If they cannot attain the level of true immortals, they may still live in peace, sparing the virtuous ruler from worry. True persons ought to ponder my words deeply and not dismiss them as strange. "Indeed, indeed."

Now, as I speak on behalf of Heaven, I must fully expound the responsibility of *chengfu*—the karmic burden inherited since the opening of Heaven and Earth. Yet I cannot fully unfold the great methods of the supreme Dao and virtue, the arts of longevity, and the path of supreme goodness. People, lost in darkness, have long trusted their foolish and benighted hearts, turning to evil without restraint, unable even to comprehend the *chengfu*—the retribution and transgressions borne by Heaven and Earth. Do true persons understand my words? "Indeed, indeed."

The sagely worthies and lofty scholars, upon seeing written texts and studying them, must align perfectly with the essence of my writings, not deviating even by a hair’s breadth. The middling scholar, with half-comprehending intent, will grasp half of it; the lesser scholar, through diligent effort, can avoid losing the method—thus does Heaven broadly raise its people. Common folk who delight in both high and low, without losing the method at the center, all attain the true Dao. Each cherishes themselves, daring not to treat matters lightly, sparing themselves great sorrow.

The superior scholar, having attained my Dao and studying it without cease, may become a worthy minister to the state. Over time, grasping its essential meaning, they can transcend the world, no longer engaging in disputes or lawsuits, viewing matters with discernment. The middling scholar, studying my Dao, may become a virtuous minor official and fulfill their natural lifespan. The petty person, studying my Dao, may cultivate lasting prudence: fathers are kind, mothers loving, children filial; elder brothers virtuous, younger brothers obedient; husbands and wives consult as one, never harming each other. Even unto death, no resentment lingers. Their souls, dwelling below, endure long, no longer seen to act wrongly or be called wicked. None die prematurely or suffer violent ends.

In ancient times, when the primordial qi first gave birth to Heaven, people all delighted in studying to become immortals, yet still could not attain longevity—only ensuring they each feared death and avoided criminal laws. But the people of later ages, profoundly foolish, instead recite florid and insubstantial teachings, studying arts that do not prolong life. In life, they act recklessly, claiming as if they will never die, teaching each other to hold nothing dear, jointly pursuing inauspicious affairs, treating funerals with greater care than births.

Life belongs to Heaven; death belongs to Earth. To serve Earth by reversing Heaven’s order is a grave harm. I have observed this and know that their accumulated folly has endured so long that none remain wise. When inauspicious affairs arise, ghosts flourish, collectively hastening human deaths, preventing people from fulfilling their natural lifespans.

Those who strive to study the true Dao may only attain a false one; those who strive to study true virtue may only attain a false virtue. How much worse, then, for the people of later ages who teach each other with florid texts—how far they have strayed from the Dao! Impoverished and unable to restrain one another, they instead teach the crafting of memorials and legal statutes, debating cleverly over right and wrong.

To teach them to be benevolent is already to fear they will not be so—yet now they are taught to study the path of malevolence. Heaven provides laws for humanity, naming itself the Great Dao; Earth names itself virtue. The reason is this: Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things. In all matters, rulers and elders constantly guide with goodness, never daring to open the way to teach malevolence—how much less should humans do so?

Humans are the children of Heaven and ought to model their conduct after it. Yet now, having lost the method, people are difficult to govern. To instruct them in the Dao and virtue is to make them wise, self-respecting, self-cherishing, self-loving, and self-governing. Instead, they are opened to criminal laws, causing them to view death as fleeting, valuing brute strength and recklessness, passing down governance that entangles and oppresses them, leading to mutual harm and cycles of suffering. Thus, no one in the world loves another—the great fault lies here. Do true persons understand this? Be cautious. "Indeed, indeed."

The forceful teaching of benevolence still struggles to overcome its absence; in later ages, people instead instruct one another in written arts, yet this has only grown more superficial, and their mutual hatred and resentment remain unbroken. The forceful teaching of auspiciousness still struggles to overcome inauspiciousness; in later ages, people instead compel one another to study the implements of death and mourning, preparing for misfortune in advance. They die before their time, nearly extinguishing their households, yet remain unaware of their errors. When the moment comes, they cry out to Heaven and wail to Earth, calling themselves wronged, blaming the ruler’s unjust governance for cutting short their years, while their own conduct has brought this upon them. Fools do not guard against the root; once guilt is determined, they regret, but regret is futile. Though they scream until death, it cannot be undone.

Thus, I now forcefully teach the great immortal scriptures of the Dao, merely opening the steps to longevity. When one studies virtue, only then can they attain benevolence; when one studies benevolence, only then can they attain tranquility and preserve what they have, no longer daring to deceive or seize others’ possessions. When one studies tranquility, they have already lost the method. When one studies the method, they have already lost the way of mutual harm. When one studies mutual harm, they have already entered great conflict. Once in great conflict, the people, though innocent, are deceived, and the destitute become thieves and bandits.

Therefore, I uphold the Heavenly Dao’s method, opening the gate of great fortune and closing the path of malevolence. I open the steps to Heaven’s Great Peace, so that all may recite it, each exercising caution, leaving nothing to be governed. Thus, the turning of Heaven’s seasons proceeds, and the joyous ruler wanders without trouble. For this reason, my writings thoroughly examine the root of all matters; only then can their center be attained. Examining the center, one attains what lies below, but those who study like fools have already fallen into great chaos.

The reason why, in later ages, even emperors and kings with the virtue, benevolence, and wisdom of ten thousand people—though they strive to align with Heaven’s will—cannot end misfortune is that they bear the accumulated disasters and chaos of long-standing inherited burdens. Though they grieve and torment themselves, desiring joy, their governance breeds strange transformations: thieves and bandits of all kinds, barbarians invading the Central Kingdom—these are the failures of former kings, not the fault of one alone. One must deeply understand their root.

Thus, Heaven has sent forth my writings to absolve emperors and kings of the errors of inherited burdens. If true persons do not align my Dao with Heaven, they need only follow my texts without deviating by a hair’s breadth, and alignment will be established. My writings are greatly trustworthy; without diligent practice to untie the knots of grievance, how can the Heavenly Dao respond in silence?

If the foolish do not study, how can they become worthy? If the poor do not till, how can they reap? Study, and one becomes worthy day by day; till, and one reaps day by day. Practice my writings, and it will be the same. I assure you: without study, do not seek worthiness; without tilling, do not seek harvest. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

The true Dao is upright; great virtue flourishes with benevolence, and each attains their proper place. In governance and peace, nothing is lost. Do true persons understand? Those who wish to repay Heaven and Earth’s grace and attain longevity must strive to trust the Dao without slackening. Indeed, indeed.

Now, if the foolish wish to ask further, they dare not speak hastily. Proceed calmly.

How does the Heavenly Master know when a person utterly lacks virtue, benevolence, and humanity?

Excellent is your question. Observe their conduct and words. I wish to hear it.

Thus: when one sees a Daoist and reacts with anger, rejecting them, one knows them as a person utterly devoid of the Dao. When one sees virtue and reviles it, one knows them as a person utterly devoid of virtue. When one sees benevolence and rejects it, one knows them as a person utterly lacking in benevolence. When one sees goodness and caution and rejects them, one knows them as a person who is neither good nor cautious.

By nature, those of like minds love one another, while those of differing minds hate one another. Good people also suffer from the wicked, and the wicked also suffer from the good. Do true persons understand? Indeed, indeed.

In ancient times, sages and worthies, upon seeing someone, did not immediately speak with them. They simply observed carefully, noting their likes and dislikes, and thus knew them. Using this as a mirror for their conduct, they were never mistaken. Excellent!

Thus, the Dao shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as August Heaven; when the heavenly Dao abhors evil and delights in killing, to oppose Heaven is to incur profound enmity. The earth shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as virtue; when evil persons inflict harm, to oppose the earth is to invite great calamity. Benevolence shares the same bone-structure, laws, and bloodline as sages and worthies; thus, sages and worthies delight in bestowing benevolence and detest seizing by force, and to oppose the benevolent and sagely is to make them one’s mortal foe.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old deeply understood that these were the three norms upheld by the Three Powers. Thus, in establishing their laws, they dared not deviate from the true Dao, virtue, or benevolence. Heaven’s workings join forces with the four seasons: as Heaven moves qi, so too do the four seasons move qi, acting in unison with one heart. Thus, to go against the four seasons is to incur Heaven’s enmity. The earth joins hearts and forces with the Five Phases, together nurturing all things; when beings are harmed before their allotted time of death, this invites great calamity from the earth. Sages and worthies join hearts and forces with benevolence; thus, in their travels and dwellings, they ever honor the Dao and esteem virtue, relying on benevolence in their conduct. If one delights in seizing by force and lacks benevolence, this makes one an enemy of the sagely and worthy.

Fire is the heart, and the heart is sagely. Thus, fire ever dwells leaning upon wood. Wood is benevolent and possesses a heart; fire possesses light and can discern right and wrong. The heart is sagely and luminous. Therefore, the great sages and worthies of old ever dwelled leaning upon benevolence and clarity, returning to rulers of Dao, virtue, benevolence, and luminosity.

Thus, I earnestly admonish the true person, entrusting this book to rulers of Dao, virtue, benevolence, and luminosity. They must delight in and cherish my Dao, deeply comprehend its meaning, follow and emulate it, and become indistinguishable from the divine. I do not praise myself to the true person; only when practice yields response, perfectly aligning like compass and square, will later generations heed my words. Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, exert yourselves and strive, diligently study Dao, virtue, and benevolence. There is nothing else worth doing. Take out this book and do not allow it to be hidden away. Indeed, indeed.

Here ends the *Exposition on Illuminating the Hearts of the Worthy to Dispel the Darkness of the Ignorant and Resolve Doubts*, from the forty-ninth scroll of the *Scripture of Great Peace*.
Here begins the fiftieth scroll of the *Scripture of Great Peace*.

**The Sixty-Seventh Scripture: The Flying Luminance of Ancient Secrets for Dispelling the Deviant**

The Sixfold Perfected One, pure in essence, bows twice with reverence and respectfully inquires of the August Divine Person who seeks the True: I wish to make Heaven and Earth peaceful, yin and yang undisturbed, ever proceeding in harmony, so that calamities do not arise recklessly, and the king may daily wander in governance, composing the scripture of great joy. Though the questions posed above and below are many, how could they be heard repeatedly?

Excellent indeed! Profound are your questions, how penetrating and insightful! You have asked precisely at this crucial juncture—do you wish to advance toward the Perfect Dao and dispel the deviant texts?

Yes.

Now I shall explain all. You have accumulated goodness in Heaven; how could I dare conceal it? Today, out of deep regard for your virtue, I shall exhaust the intentions of the divine and luminous. If I do not speak and act, I fear I would contravene the will of Heaven. Since Heaven has indeed prompted you to seek and inquire, I shall distinguish and expound for you. Follow along and record it; take care not to omit anything.

If the emperor and kings exert themselves to employ this scripture, all calamities will be eradicated in a single day. The world will rejoice as one, all desiring to become scholars of Dao and virtue. Later generations will emulate their forebears, the old and young rising together, all coming to know and seek the verification of true texts. Superficial embellishments will vanish, and the heart will thoroughly harmonize with the divine and numinous. The ruler will have no single worry—why should he not daily wander in joy?

Thus, all matters under Heaven and Earth will find their proper place, the hundred spirits rejoicing in consequence. The king will deeply align with the will of Heaven, and the Perfect Dao will come to his aid. There will be daily auspiciousness, not a single inauspicious event. My words are true and steadfast, not erring even once in ten thousand instances. Yet I fear that though obtained, they may not be practiced, for the multitude of deviant influences may obstruct them.

Calamities and anomalies, superficial embellishments—these are the grave maladies of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang. If a grave malady is left untreated, how can it be resolved and cured? Since you have come to inquire about these matters, I speak for Heaven. Ponder carefully the words above and below in this scripture. Should you chance upon its profound intent, take care not to disorder it.

Yes, yes.

Once you return to a fitting place, day and night reflect upon it. Having received and recorded it, repeatedly elucidate and annotate it, hoping that it may endure for ten thousand generations without end.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, speech, writing, and texts have followed one another in succession. Matters of the same qi illuminate one another by kind. Seek their kind and gather them, and the Dao will daily become more manifest, never declining.

Thus, from ancient times to the present, the multitude of sages have together discoursed for Heaven, and the multitude of worthies have harmonized their words, jointly devising sagely plans. The emperor and kings are Heaven’s noble children. As children inheriting their father’s teachings, they ought to follow and enact them, thereby dispelling the worries of Heaven and Earth and receiving their protection.

Therefore, reflect upon and exert yourselves in these words.

My Dao—ah! When you perceive matters, whether awakened or not, Heaven and Earth, the divine and luminous, will require the seeking of countless, myriad, thousandfold, hundredfold, tenfold, and single matters, all of which must correspond before they may be deemed reliable. If they do not correspond, urgently seek again. Among their kindred and comparable instances, if even one does not correspond, that is the truth.

All matters should be thus. How can one ascertain their correspondence? Correspondence is when, upon inward reflection in the heart, there is outward resonance with the spirits and deities, near and far moving in accord. When divining matters and verifying them below, that which responds is true. That which does not correspond—all such explanations are false.

Take care not to speak recklessly, lest you leave no legacy for later generations. The reason is this: reckless speech and false words leave no legacy and cannot be employed for long, thus depriving people of posterity.

As the governance of the Dao daily declines, perverse and contrary words proliferate—these are truly not so. All such words disrupt the celestial patterns and terrestrial principles, failing to align with the hearts of sages. The spirits cannot be employed thus.

Therefore, one who speaks ought first to reflect inwardly upon human sentiments, and only then should the heart harmonize outwardly, thoroughly aligning with the spirits and deities. This is the means by which to grasp success and failure, the admonitions of celestial patterns.

Accumulate texts and arrange them by kind, assembling the multitude of worthies to compile them. Select from among them those that correspond tenfold, aligning with the hearts of people and the spirits, to form the text. Together, settle upon its meaning, and test it by verifying below. Only thus will it be unalterable for ten thousand generations.

Verification means that when divining matters, there is a response, and when enacting them, the response is realized. Only then can it be established as a canonical method of Heaven, the very means by which to regulate and stabilize yin and yang, the great art of pacifying the king.

This is how to transform misfortune into blessing, prolonging the lives of the people. Why is this so? When the celestial patterns and terrestrial principles are correct, yin and yang each find their proper place. When yin and yang each find their proper place, the spirits and deities rejoice greatly. When the spirits and deities rejoice, they protect the people. Thus, the emperor and kings enjoy long-lasting peace, and the people live long.

Can one not exert oneself diligently in this?

The Flying Luminance refers to the lesser of the Three Luminaries, all connected to the earth below and suspended above in the heavens. Their movements harmonize with the people, creatures, and all things of the earth—this is the proof of essential texts. When the written texts divining matters correspond a hundredfold, tenfold, and tenfold again, that is the truth. That which does not correspond and harmonize is false.

By this standard, measure and balance them. All deviant texts and writings will be entirely eradicated. Examine past events to verify present ones. Follow what Heaven permits, observe what Heaven may favor—do not disrupt the celestial patterns. Joining forces with Heaven, this may be called perpetual auspiciousness.

Heaven can only be followed, not opposed. Seize upon what may be advantageous and employ it, and the people will flourish. To oppose it is to cause the people to decline, losing the will and intent of Heaven.

---

**The Sixty-Eighth Scripture: Verifying Correspondences in Relocation and Movement**

All texts concerning relocation and movement are the celestial scriptures of Heaven’s course. When yin and yang intersect and unite, the celestial patterns are complete. The emperor, the people, and the myriad things all proceed according to their principles. Those who grasp their intent are auspicious; those who lose it are wholly inauspicious.

Matters have their reversals and sequences—one cannot but be cautious and deliberate in examining them. To ascertain their truth, test them with twenty-five instances of fivefold matters. Select twenty-five past events and twenty-five households of current affairs. Carefully record the year, day, month, and hour from which they originate, and to which of the five tones they belong. Divining auspiciousness and inauspiciousness, verify that which corresponds a hundredfold, tenfold, and tenfold again—that is the truth.

When this is examined and the principles of Heaven and Earth are securely established, the ruler acts without doubt. The people and ministers do not lose their proper roles, and the myriad things each attain their rightful place. If matters do not conform to what this text declares, they are the writings of chaos and deceit and must not be employed.

Measured by the standard of ascent, those who dare use texts that mislead others will leave no descendants in later generations. The reason is this: such texts harm the people and disrupt the proper divisions of Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth govern life, yet men invert their yin and yang, thus causing those who use such texts to be without posterity. In ancient times, before such writings existed, Heaven reversed their course. After the *Celestial Patterns* emerged, all understood the intent of the Dao of Heaven. Those who knowingly violated it met with early death and misfortune—this is the very proof.

When applied with harmonious resonance among kin, the Five Peaks and ten thousand *li* respond in kind. Through concentrated and meticulous contemplation, matters of goodness summon good responses, and matters of baseness summon base ones. Their quantity and rank, high or low, never err by even one part in ten thousand. Regularly tested with the twenty-five *qi* of fivefold cycles, they correspond to twenty-five households and twenty-five hills. When the text’s hundredfold and tenfold correspondences align, it is the *earthly prognostication*. When their *qi* combine, they are as kin to the land. Their people share the same likes and dislikes. Moreover, creatures of all kinds—birds, beasts, grasses, and trees—form categories of their own. This is the land of shared *qi*. By this clear distinction, the earth’s correspondences are verified. Where there are no aquatic *qi* among kin, their fish and turtles form their own kind. Using this as the basis for divination, and distinguishing their origins, the nature of all things and all affairs can be known. Those with identical images share identical forms; those with differing images have differing forms—right and wrong are determined precisely thus.

**Vermilion Radiance for Warding Off Evil, Method Sixty-Nine**
*Vermilion Radiance* refers to the celestial inscribed texts, which can rectify wrongs and ward off evil. When tenfold correspondences bring healing, it is because the celestial writings align with the true spirit-officials—this is the proof of their efficacy. When nineteen correspondences bring healing, it is because the earthly writings harmonize with the yin spirits. When eighteen correspondences bring healing, it is the harmony of human writings. Tested by this standard, all other texts are deceptive and must not be used. These are the writings that invite evil. Only those that align with the spirits are valid; those that fail to heal mislead people and cannot save lives.

Some texts, though authored by spirits or gods, bring healing in ways that cannot be known. Such a person’s fate and allotted years become the chief of evil, and others cannot use their writings. Should such texts proliferate through mass carving, are they not deceptive? They should be carved and then cast into uninhabited wilderness. These texts must be sought one by one and cannot be obtained hastily.

**Methods of Herbs and Trees, Method Seventy**
Herbs and trees possess virtue and the Dao, and those with official ranks can be commanded—these are called *herbal methods*, referring to the divine herbs and trees. Those that heal swiftly are the divine herbs of Heaven, though they grow upon the earth. Those that extend life are the immortal herbs of Heaven, though they grow upon the earth. Those that heal decisively are called *decisive healing methods*. Those that heal in a single day are called *one-day healing methods*, and their hundredfold and tenfold correspondences confirm their efficacy.

These herbs and trees possess spirit and can be commanded, for they are herbs and trees with official ranks. Those with tenfold correspondences that heal are the herbs of emperors; those with nineteen correspondences are the herbs of great ministers; those with eighteen correspondences are the herbs of the people. Those below this standard must not be used, for they are herbs that mislead. This is the art of saving life and death—it must not be examined carelessly.

When a method combines herbs and brings swift healing, record the herbs and call it a *decisive healing method*. If it heals in one day, call it a *one-day healing method*; if in two days, a *two-day method*; if in three days, a *three-day method*. The *one-day healing method* is administered by celestial spirits; the *two-day healing method* by earthly spirits; the *three-day healing method* by human ghosts. Those that do not conform to this are not celestial spirit methods but rely solely on the herbs’ natural properties, sometimes healing and sometimes not—these are called *waiting-for-death methods*. Be cautious, be exceedingly cautious. This is the art of saving lives and must not be treated lightly or without thorough examination.

**Methods of Living Creatures, Method Seventy-One**
Living creatures that act with essence—such as flying birds, walking beasts, and crawling things—can heal illnesses. Birds carry the divine medicines of Heaven within them, sent by Heaven to move in circular and square patterns. Those that heal with tenfold correspondences contain the celestial spirit methods within them; those that heal with nineteen correspondences contain the earthly essence methods; those that heal with eighteen correspondences contain the balanced human essence and divine medicines.

These three are the methods of Heaven, Earth, and the harmony of yin and yang, called the *healing envoys*. They are like a person of the Dao who is called an envoy—a divine person, a divine master. These are sent by the essences of Heaven, Earth, and humanity, and when their tenfold and hundredfold correspondences bring healing, they are the divine methods of emperors and supreme sovereigns. Those that heal with nineteen correspondences are the divine methods of kings and marquises; those that heal with eighteen correspondences are the divine methods of great ministers, commoners, and reclusive scholars of utmost virtue.

Each has its appointed emergence. Observed thus, not one in ten thousand errs. These three kinds act as divine medicines of Heaven, Earth, and humanity to heal illnesses. Heaven commands each to receive the mandate of their ancestors and embody their natural arts, which they cannot abandon. This is like the phoenix and qilin, which bear virtue upon their bodies; or like bees and scorpions, which bear poison upon theirs—this is what is meant.

One must deeply understand the essential intent of the Dao of Heaven to clarify the nature of the celestial Dao, which benefits the ruler’s governance and prevents people from being deluded. Without knowing these essential texts, to claim that all writings under Heaven can be used is mistaken.

Thus, those scoring seventeen or below are all deviant, failing to correspond with the three auspicious signs, and their harm runs deep. Therefore, those who err in one out of ten treatments do not align with the intent of Heaven; those who err in two out of ten do not align with the intent of Earth; those who err in three out of ten do not align with the intent of humanity. Those who err in six or seven out of ten or more bring about chaotic governance. Yin and yang grow discordant, and spirits engage in strife.

For this reason, the sage kings and divine rulers of antiquity, though dwelling in secluded chambers, deeply pondered the intent of Heaven’s heart to preserve themselves and attain long life. My writings, with their interconnected phrases above and below, are arranged as texts. When the wise and enlightened read them to complement one another, this rescues the lost and confused, allowing people to enjoy enduring fortune while avoiding misfortune. Each should reflect morning and evening on these essential meanings to preserve their well-being.

From ancient times to the present, when the common people sing children’s songs and poems, it is Heaven’s transformations that move them to speak. When divine texts emerge in their time, Heaven transmits their discourse to those of utmost virtue to remedy the world’s errors. The Way of Heaven detests killing and cherishes life; all creatures that creep and move possess awareness. None should be lightly killed or harmed without cause. If transformation can be achieved through means other than harm, one must first exhaust those methods before resorting to force.

Thus, the myriad things flourish, their lives bound to Heaven, their roots in Earth, and their proper use resting with humanity. Those who align with Heaven’s intent live long, while those who lose it perish. All things exist in constancy with Heaven and Earth, with humanity as their sovereign. Those who rule as sovereigns over humanity must be meticulous and thorough in their deliberations.

**Discarding Florid Ornamentation, Section Seventy-Two**
To grasp the essential meaning of all Daoist texts and scriptures, one must take each word as a complete unit. For instance, what is *jiazi*? When placed before a group, let one person explain its fundamental meaning, while the assembled wise collectively debate and expound upon it. Some may specialize in the intent of celestial patterns, expounding upward to thoroughly explore the Way of Heaven. Others may excel in geography, expounding downward to fully investigate the Way of Earth. Still others may focus on external matters, exploring the four directions to their limits. Some may sit and discourse, delving into the center. Others may trace the origins of affairs, excelling in the essence of the myriad things, thereby mastering them. Some may delve into the internal, others into the external. Once the roots, branches, foundations, blossoms, and leaves are all revealed, they are categorized and named by their likenesses.

The essential intent of all affairs, the writings of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, can thus be glimpsed in outline. With head and feet complete, upper and lower connected, and the natural order of things established, their meanings are harmonized, and each records their discourse. The worthy are gathered to form a unified explanation. Therefore, when the sage seeks the intent of Heaven’s heart to regulate and stabilize yin and yang, bringing peace to the ruler and tranquility to the world, all spirits rejoice in unison.

Thus, the radiant insights of the many wise are woven together to establish enduring laws that cannot be altered for ten thousand generations. The reason the intent of Heaven’s Way is lost today lies in this: the words of a single worthy, though penetrating one aspect, cannot illuminate all. They cannot traverse the six directions or thoroughly investigate the seven realms within and without, nor can they trace the essence of the myriad things. Hence, their explanations diverge, causing the original texts of Heaven’s writings to lose their foundation, leading to confusion and delusion—this is the crux of the matter.

For all matters one wishes to rectify, each has a root that can be exhaustively explored. Yin and yang do not reverse their order; all should proceed thus. Otherwise, it is called an isolated or singular opinion, failing to grasp the scriptures’ intent. Following the words of one person alone is termed a biased view. The nature of Heaven and Earth cannot be fully comprehended by anyone but the sage. Thus, when such a one speaks, internally they cannot fathom the heart of Heaven, and externally they cannot interpret celestial patterns or illuminate geography. Their divinations miss the mark, spirits do not heed them, and they lose the correct path, straying into delusion. This is what is meant by pursuing florid ornamentation, failing to grasp the root and essential intent. The fault lies here, causing the unadorned to lose their foundation.

When the Way of Heaven loses its rectitude, yin and yang internally generate illness, discord arises, and harmful qi proliferates. The ruler grows anxious and distressed, unable to restrain their heart, and calamitous qi arises in succession. The people do not live long, and this is the gravest misfortune. When the wise collectively lose the heart of Heaven and drift far from the sage’s teachings, they cannot attain proper order—this is called a chaotic Way.

The reason for this lies in the fact that all scriptures and records of the Daoist Way are interwoven, forming the discourse of Heaven and Earth. The head and origin of all affairs are the foundation of the spirits. Therefore, those who grasp the original intent prevent spirits from engaging in strife and harming people. Evil qi is sealed away, banditry ceases, and when bandits and thieves are suppressed, the barbarians retreat and submit. Wind and rain arrive in their proper seasons—this is the clear sign of Heaven’s joy. When Heaven is pleased, it cherishes its children. Thus, the ruler’s life is prolonged, and their blessings flow to the people, extending to the six domestic animals, birds, beasts, and even reaching the grasses and trees. Harmonious qi appears in full, evil qi dissipates, and the correct qi grows ever brighter—this is the natural method of yin and yang.

It is like the day’s affairs being conducted in daylight, while at night they are concealed; when petty men flee, the noble proceed. Reflect upon these words, for they benefit life, clarify yin and yang, and expound upon the spirits. If you doubt my writings, test the Way to discern its success or failure. Now, take a single character and place it before a group, letting the many wise debate and expound upon it. When their interpretations differ and their explanations vary, it becomes clear that the words of one person are not enlightened. How then can they regulate yin and yang and allow the ruler to wander carefree in joy?

Thus, those who grasp the root are few, while those who expound are many—there is nothing that cannot be exhausted. When those who grasp the root are many and those who expound are few, the Way becomes superficial and shallow. If this shallowness persists unchecked, chaos ensues. If chaos persists unchecked, yin and yang grow displeased, and evil qi arises.

Thus, the sage-kings must honor the root, and the noble person rectify the beginning—then nothing will fail to be ordered. If they do not honor and exalt the root, nor rectify the beginning, then all affairs lose their discipline, the myriad things fall into chaos, and order cannot be restored. Refine and clarify this, and delusion, the perverse Way, and heterodox writings will depart.

**Celestial Patterns and Secret Formulas, Scroll Seventy-Three**

Heaven and Earth possess constant laws, not erring by even a fraction. Distant and near all share the same images; qi of like kind respond to one another, not failing in even one of ten thousand cases. This is called *Celestial Patterns*, also named *Celestial Writings*. Countless billions, thousands of thousands, hundreds of hundreds, tens of tens—whether twelve days complete one cycle of the *zi* branch, or twelve years, sixty years, or one hundred twenty years, each is likewise a cycle of the *zi*. Some align after a hundred million *zi*, some after ten thousand, some after a thousand, some after a hundred, some after ten—all akin to the *jia-zi*. Though their qi differs, their affairs differ, their words differ, their songs and poems differ, though all are *jia-zi*, their qi has not yet completed its cycle, hence the difference. By their kind and image they are named; good and ill share the same qi, same words, same affairs—this constitutes one cycle.

Carefully examining and uniting these reveals how to understand the ancient and thereby know the present, and how to know the present and thereby revisit and clarify the ancient. This is how one knows the constant movement of Heaven, how to distinctly and thoroughly comprehend the principles of yin and yang. If the written words are mistaken or their sequence awry, they should be supplemented by one another; when the songs, sounds, and affairs all align, this is what is called the great cycle, the middle cycle, and the small cycle. Grasping their meaning, ordering their affairs, and thereby harmonizing yin and yang to bring peace to the ruler—this is how one emulates the constant laws of Heaven’s writings.

It is like spring, autumn, winter, and summer, which do not err. Yet those born later all rely on brief lifespans and have not witnessed even one full cycle—how can they know that within the great, middle, and small cycles there are three cycles? Do the ancient constant spiritual Ways still exist? Thus, they lose the correct path, glimpsing only fleeting moments, and lacking thorough understanding of the divine writings of past and present, they follow partial words and claim their own correctness. It is like a child born in spring who dies before autumn, never witnessing autumn’s affairs, or one born in summer who perishes before winter, never witnessing winter’s affairs. Those who speak only ever see what lies before their eyes, and though ten eloquent debaters may argue, they remain ignorant, inwardly unconvinced.

If celestial patterns fail to manifest, it is precisely because they are correct. Thus, affairs do not appear in vain; at times there are writings of order and chaos. The Way does not emerge in vain; the times and fate decree it. Therefore, the works of ancient poets all flow from Heaven’s qi, ensuring their words are not empty. Thus, the sage-kings of antiquity, perceiving the subtle and knowing the manifest, acted in accordance with their tasks, following the qi, and thereby attaining Heaven’s will—hence their long-lasting good fortune. To oppose it brings floods and droughts, qi in discord and conflict, accumulating disasters and unceasing anomalies, called calamities and portents. The many wise grow confused, unaware that it is merely opposing the qi and failing to follow the demands of the times—this cannot but be treated with the utmost caution.

Heaven’s purpose in leaving writings for later generations is that those born earlier know longevity, understand the natural, and enter the Way of emptiness and stillness—thus they know the cycles of Heaven’s Way, which resemble the constancy of spring, autumn, winter, and summer. Later generations, their qi long dissipated, their learning shallow, grow distant from the essential Way and its writings, forgetting the teachings of former and present times. Unless one is a divine sage, none can foresee the completion of a cycle. Therefore, Heaven repeatedly generates writings to be recorded and transmitted, so that past and present may mutually rely upon one another, desiring that they know and thereby secure themselves.

Encountering great peace, one may govern while resting at ease. Encountering moderate peace, one may strive to act. Encountering disorder, one may use the Way to aid and prepare oneself. It is like preparing for heat at the summer solstice and cold at the winter solstice—this is the meaning. Heaven’s Way moves in constant cycles, not favoring the ancients. Thus, following it brings prosperity and flourishing; opposing it brings peril and ruin.

When Heaven’s Way wages war, its mandate is harmed; the sun and moon lose their measure, and the constellations move in chaos. Knowing to follow the seasonal qi, the sun and moon keep their measure, and the constellations move in order—this is Heaven’s clear proof. Those who can apply this must exert themselves, daring not to conceal or hoard, and must take care not to harm or injure. Heaven’s secret writings are entrusted to the benevolent and worthy, to illuminate above and below and enable self-security.

**Moxibustion and Acupuncture Formulae, Chapter Seventy-Four**

Moxibustion and acupuncture serve to regulate and harmonize the three hundred and sixty meridians, the qi of yin and yang, thereby eliminating harm. The three hundred and sixty meridians correspond to the three hundred and sixty days of a year, with each meridian governing its day, moving in accord with the four seasons and five phases, circulating externally throughout the body and converging at the crown of the head, while internally connecting to the viscera. Their waxing and waning shift with the four seasons; when illness arises, they fail to correspond, their cycles and movements become irregular—knotting, injuring, flowing smoothly, or rebelling—thus requiring treatment.

Moxibustion is the essence of *Taiyang*, the clarity of impartial justice, used to discern deceit and eradicate harm. Acupuncture is the essence of *Shaoyin*, the radiance of *Tai Bai*, employed with righteousness to sever and subdue. When treatment is one hundred percent effective in a hundred cases, or ten out of ten, this aligns with the celestial meridian prophecies of the *Chen* texts, truly resonating with the meridians, and the spirits are thus commanded. When nine out of ten are cured, with one failure, this resonates with the yin meridians, and essence is commanded. When eight out of ten are cured, this is the way of human texts, guided by human intention. Below this standard, illness cannot be treated; instead, it may harm the spirit.

If the *Jia* meridian is afflicted yet the *Yi* is treated, this is called confusion, for the meridian is uniquely injured and severed. Thus, to discern whether the celestial way is spiritually efficacious or not, whether it corresponds or not, simply place a patient before you—this is the meridian’s root text, akin to the foundational text of the Daoist scriptures. Gather many worthy ones to discuss the illness: some may excel in the upper body, others in the lower; each of the three hundred and sixty meridians has its observable aspects. Record the methods of those whose treatments consistently succeed in ten out of ten cases—these are correct; all others are not. Compile the successful treatments into a scripture, and there will be no unresolved formulae in what is treated.

The celestial way governs the meridians, whether externally or internally, yet it cannot be fully known. Where treatment succeeds in ten out of ten cases, that is where the meridians converge. Though people vary in size, with differing measurements, their proportions remain the same, and one must rely on the divisions of *Dan* and *Pi* to achieve correspondence. Daoist texts, accumulated over time from diverse sources, are called "chaotic meridians." Treating yin when yang is disordered reverses the cure, bringing misfortune upon people, harming the innocent, and shortening lives.

The meridians resonate with heaven, earth, and the myriad things, rising with the qi and cycling back to their origin. Those who grasp their patterns may thereby cultivate their nature and discern the arrival of seasonal qi. If there is disharmony, they restore balance. In ancient times, sages and worthies sat in pure stillness, palpating their own meridians, observing the cycles and movements of their pulses to know the gains and losses of the four seasons and five phases, thereby understanding the waxing and waning of their own bodies. This is how they secured the state, nurtured life, and preserved their forms—how could one not be cautious?

Those who are deluded by indiscriminate moxibustion and acupuncture injure the proper meridians, harm the correct qi, and disrupt the four seasons and five phases, bringing forth calamities and anomalies. The great are greatly harmed, the small are slightly harmed, and all may be moved or unsettled—this is the natural course of things. Thus, the ancient sages and worthies held these practices in high regard. The sage emperors and kings observed the movements of the meridians to divine the auspices of the six directions—this is what is meant by "knowing the distant through the near, the external through the internal," and thus it is called the divine and essential way.

**Divine Incantations Formulae, Chapter Seventy-Five**

In the heavens, there are constant divine and sagely essential words, periodically bestowed upon people for use, dispatching spirit-officials to respond to the qi and come and go. The people who receive them call them "divine incantations." When incantations cure a hundred out of a hundred, or ten out of ten, they are the transmitted scriptural words of the celestial divine texts. Only those incantations that can summon the spirits’ trust, cure illnesses, and consistently succeed in ten out of ten cases are used—there is no direction in which they do not heal. Simply using words to cure illness is the divine prophecy of the heavens.

These are what good teachers and emperors should employ, compiled into scrolls and named the *Incantation Prophecy Scriptures*. They serve to summon the host of spirits, hence their tenfold efficacy. When nine out of ten are cured, the true spirits do not arrive, but lesser spirits do, and great ministers possess them. When eight out of ten are cured, human spirits arrive, and officials possess them. These are the words of the celestial spirits, originally meant to summon them. Their names and times occasionally leak down to earth, and Daoists who learn of them transmit them to one another, thus enabling the treatment of illness. Like sending a messenger with words, they cannot cure illness.

In matters of change, one cannot rely on others even for a moment. Heaven values human life, fearing that rare methods are difficult to perfect quickly, and that great physicians may lose the meridian scriptures, failing to comprehend matters of life and death. Thus, the essential way is placed in people’s mouths—this is the art of emergency relief. To obtain these essential words, simply place a patient before you as the root text of the incantation, and let each recite their secret oral formulae. If the illness is immediately cured, it is genuine; otherwise, it is entirely false, the response of deceptive and reckless words, and cannot be taken as a model.

Some incantations may cure when used alone, yet others fail to achieve the same effect—such words cannot be recorded. These are the leaders of ghosts and spirits, naturally employed by people, called "solitary words," not the true way of summoning spirits. Though people and heaven are distant, how can one discern whether the way is true or not? That which is true or false corresponds and harmonizes, fitting like tallying tokens—this is genuine; otherwise, it is not.

**Burial and Residence Formulae, Chapter Seventy-Six**

Burial is the original hillside dwelling of one’s ancestors, called the initial planting of roots. A residence is the earth to which the hun and po souls should return. If the land is auspicious, the souls return to nurture the descendants; if inauspicious, they return to harm them. When the qi of the five ancestors is exhausted, they are reborn as people.

**The Dao of Heaven and the Efficacy of Earth, Chapter Seventy-Six**

The Dao of Heaven follows the law by which qi circulates and returns to its origin. To discern the efficacy of earth, plant a small, humble seed in the soil; if later days bring flourishing growth and great goodness, it is a land of great vitality. If a fine seed is planted yet later days yield evil, it is a land of inversion. If daily fortunes wane and diminish, it is a land of depletion. Test this with twenty-five families’ burial mounds and hills: if ten, a hundred, or a thousand correspond in harmony, these are the texts of the *Treasured Writ of Earth’s Yin*. If nineteen correspond, it is the *Treasured Record of Earth’s Yin*. If eighteen correspond, it is the *Disordered Writ of Earth*—unfit for regular use. Anything below this is heretical script, harmful writings of the common folk. To verify their truth, record past events and compare them with later outcomes; only then will true and false be distinguished. Know that my writings are like Heaven’s *jia* and Earth’s *yi*, unalterable for ten thousand generations. The root matters of burial and residence, where human life is nurtured, must not be treated lightly. Once affairs are settled carelessly, heretical writings bring harm, causing disasters and misfortunes to arise frequently, bringing great suffering to the worthy and the people. Thus, whether noble or humble, those who wish their descendants to inherit in perpetuity must carefully examine the hills and mounds, clearly discern their principles, and divine future events. Take twenty-five burial mounds as the foundational text, compare them with past events, and record the outcomes to validate present and future affairs. True masters should study these writings closely, dispelling confusion and delusion—this is called the *Divination of Yin’s Concealment*, which discerns how ancestors benefit their descendants, transmitting blessings for ten thousand generations. Guard this well and do not conceal it.

**Discerning the True and False in Ancient Writings, Chapter Seventy-Seven**

All music serves to convey sound and transform the qi of the six directions and eight extremes. When its tones harmonize, responses come in accord with goodness; when they do not, responses arrive in conflict and opposition. Each sound has its own affiliation—east, west, south, north, *jia*, *yi*, *bing*, *ding*—and the twenty-five qi each have their own domain. At times, sounds converge to form coherent phrases, allowing one to perceive subtle words through listening, divining fortune and misfortune. When music aligns with the *Blowing-Hair Pitch-Pipe*, the tones of strings are known. The five notes—*gong*, *shang*, *jue*, *zhi*, and *yu*—distinguish the six directions’ distances and define the auspicious or inauspicious nature of names. How so? Only the refined can perceive the spirits’ responses to events. Thus, the sages of antiquity regulated music to move all things, harmonize yin and yang, and stabilize the four seasons and five phases. When yin and yang are balanced, the sounds are pleasing to hear; when they are disharmonious, discordant and chaotic, the music is harsh, and the strings must be tuned. The silk strings should be arranged in nine-by-nine sequences, with loud and soft sounds in harmony, so as not to harm the viscera and spirit. If untuned, the dance becomes disorderly, the music loses its proper tone, and it cannot be endured, injuring the viscera and spirit—thus, numinous beings and auspicious omens do not appear. Only those who are capable and skilled in sound can harmonize yin and yang’s transformations. How is this known? When the divine and numinous respond, auspicious omens gather—such is the person. Otherwise, all is chaotic noise, incapable of moving anything, and thus no response comes. Therefore, all matters depend on finding the right person. Without the right person, even the divine is as unreliable as reckless speech. With the right person, no matter is too difficult or easy—all can be accomplished. Without the right person, no matter is too great or small—none can be done. Thus, the sages of antiquity valued action and sought the worthy without concealment, as was the way of old. With the right person, order prevails; without them, chaos reigns.

Ancient writings are too numerous to record in full. Use one matter to analogize ten, ten to analogize a hundred, a hundred to analogize a thousand, a thousand to analogize ten thousand, ten thousand to analogize a hundred million, and a hundred million to analogize the boundless. Each matter has its own category and affiliation. Place the foundational text of each matter first, so that the knowledgeable may grasp its essence, and those skilled in application may expound upon it. Examine their correspondence and harmony—what aligns is true; what does not correspond or align is false. To discern whether the ancient sages’ writings on the Dao are authentic: this is like calling a person by their surname and given name—only then will they respond. Ghosts and spirits are the same. Without the correct name, there is no response; even if one wishes to harmonize, there is no means to reach them, and thus no response. Thus, the ancients called the study of names *Attending to Essence*. Essence means focusing intently on the matter’s image and suitability, then reflecting on its words. Thoroughly contemplating these writings and strategies completes all matters. Though the texts above and below are numerous, each has its proper application. Study them carefully, supplementing one with another, to fully grasp their meaning. Without deeply understanding their essential intent, words on the Dao are ineffective, and one cannot resolve the conflicts of yin and yang’s struggles.

My writings are for the benevolent and worthy, entrusted to those of virtue. Those of virtue who receive them treat them as treasures. If received but not read well, one may dismiss them as false Dao, unable to bring joy to the self or avert calamities. When the great Dao is revealed, does it not seem insipid? Yet its use is inexhaustible. Let the worthy reflect on this: can it not harmonize hardness and softness, exhaust the positions of yin and yang? Once all writings are settled in their proper places, is there still confusion? Evil is entirely dispelled, the Supreme Lord rejoices greatly, and the people are free from misfortune. Blessings extend even to the humble, and the teeming myriad things do not lose their qi. They return to the Great Beginning, Heaven and Earth take their places, heretical writings vanish, and the primordial qi is preserved. The One is the warp of the Dao; the Two, its weft. The Three brings chaos—it cannot be made clear. My Dao follows *jiazi* and *yichou*, the six *jia* succeeding one another, the five phases following in turn, the four seasons cycling back to their origin. Though the writings are many, each has its own record.

Just as in a person, where head and feet alternately serve one another, one word departs and another arises, the worthy take their turns to fill in, harmonizing yin and yang through speech, outer and inner aligning like compass and square—at first recitation, it seems flavorless, but with time, its depth unfolds. Persist in contemplation without ceasing, and verification will come: disasters depart from the body, spirits gather anew, people naturally become prudent and virtuous, free from malevolent offspring. This is called "the absence of punishment," the ultimate beauty of Dao-transformations.

Examine my writings to avert misfortune: treachery and calamity will cease of themselves, and the people will enjoy long life. Trace back to the origin, and you find no end or beginning. The texts where ten correspond with ten are the *Taiyang* writings. Those where nineteen correspond are the *Taiyin* writings. Eighteen correspondences form the *Zhonghe* writings. Seventeen correspondences make the *Poruined* writings. Sixteen correspondences mark the *Encountering Central* writings. Fifteen correspondences are the *Ignorant* writings—these may be called half-auspicious, half-inauspicious. Fourteen correspondences denote *Heretical* writings. Thirteen correspondences signify *Great Chaos* writings. Twelve correspondences are *Abandoned* writings. Eleven correspondences are *Alternating Central* writings.
