Now, Heaven, Earth, and humanity originally share the same primordial qi, divided into three forms, each with its own ancestral origin.

Thus, the Three August Ones are the ancestral heads; the Five Emperors are the rulers of their flourishing eras; the Three Kings are the rulers of their balanced eras; and the Five Hegemons are the qi of their final decline, perilous disorder, and punitive resurgence.

Therefore, by the time of the Five Hegemons—when only one part in four remains—the celestial pattern is nearly severed. Beyond this, the inferior becomes too weak to restrain the superior, the yielding cannot restrain the firm, the few cannot restrain the many, and the Dao falls into great chaos, unable to govern itself.

Thus, it must rise again from above. What does this mean?

Thus, the Nine August Ones all first sprouted in the North; the Five Emperors first emerged in the East; the Three Kings flourished in the South; and the Five Hegemons reached their consummation in decline in the West.

All things born of Heaven arise as yang qi, following primordial qi, merging with the Great Yin to germinate. At birth, they must emerge and grow, hence they flourish in the East. Once born, they must thrive, hence they reach their peak in the South. Having flourished, they must bear fruit, hence they wither and mature in the West.

The Dao of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang, completes its cycle.

Yet things cannot remain in fruition forever—they die, and nothing more. But the seeds of their roots must regenerate, so yin and yang together enter the Gate of Heaven, merging their qi in Qian, to begin anew from above. This is the natural nature of Heaven and Earth.

Excellent! Excellent!

Why then do Heaven, Earth, and humanity not share the same Three August Ones, Five Emperors, Three Kings, and Five Hegemons?

Excellent indeed—your question grasps its meaning.

Heaven, Earth, and humanity are divided into three domains, each dwelling apart.

The Way of the August Ones is like the father in a household; the Way of the Emperors is like the mother; the Way of the Kings is like the son; and the Way of the Hegemons is like the wife.

Now, these three domains dwell separately—how could they share the same father, mother, son, and wife? It is as if people were divided into three households—could they possibly share the same parents, children, and spouse?

Perfected One, do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Be cautious—do not recklessly challenge what you do not grasp. The Dao of Heaven has its own fixed and constant laws; one cannot forcibly oppose them, nor dare act with brute strength.

Indeed, indeed.

Though each time you ask, you transgress the taboos of the Heavenly Master, yet without asking, there is no way to know. I wish to beg one more word.

Proceed.

Now, there are forty-eight sections—how do these forty-eight sections operate?

Excellent and thorough—your question is most fitting.

Those who follow the will of Heaven in this practice will prevent calamities from arising. Those who lose the essential Dao of Heaven will find disasters unending. Thus, for myriad generations, they inherit and bear the consequences in succession.

A good ruler can cause misfortunes to subside on their own, dissolving their transgressions. But the most essential Way of self-cultivation, when reversed, allows perverse qi to spread throughout the world. Thus, residual disasters arise, becoming the adversities of inherited consequences.

What does this mean?

Now, listen carefully to my words.

Indeed, indeed.

The supreme ruler of Heaven is like the sun; the middling, like the moon; the lowest, like the stars.
The supreme ruler of Earth is like the Five Peaks; the middling, like level land; the lowest, like low-lying fields.
The supreme ruler of humanity is like the sovereign; the middling, like the ministers; the lowest, like the common people.

Where the Way is complete, its people and the myriad things are all free from illness and at peace, without thieves, deceivers, flatterers, or fraud.
Heaven and Earth know no disasters—this is called "supreme harmony," where the Way is complete.

Where three of four parts hold the Way, three parts of the people are peaceful, loyal, and trustworthy, while one part suffers injury or death, or becomes thieves and villains, together giving rise to perverse and strange transformations—greater or lesser in proportion to that one part.

Where two of four parts hold the Way, half the people and the myriad things fall ill and grow untrusting; half the people harbor deceitful hearts, and Heaven’s strange transformations occur in half.

Where only one of four parts holds the Way, three parts of the people are all afflicted, false and flattering, all become thieves, without any thought of mutual benefit—only one part remains good.

Heaven’s anomalies arise without cease, shifting from place to place, never leaving their appointed bounds. Why is this so?

Excellent—your words are most fitting.
Where the Way is complete, its virtue and power extend to all, and what virtue reaches, it governs. Thus, the myriad things are all good, universally receiving its virtue and power—hence, all is at peace.

Where three of four parts hold the Way, its virtue and power fail to reach one part—hence, one part is inauspicious.

Where two of four parts hold the Way, virtue and power do not extend to half—hence, half is inauspicious.

Where only one of four parts holds the Way, virtue is faint, barely reaching one part, failing the other three—hence, three parts are inauspicious.

Thus, the sage-kings of old, wishing to know their own excellence or deficiency, divined by this method—never erring by even one in ten thousand.

Why do those beyond virtue’s reach fall ill?
Where virtue and power do not extend, there is no governance, no leadership; the myriad things lack direction and descend into chaos, plagued by illness, treachery, and unending thievery.

The ancients governed by this divination, discerning the depth or shallowness of virtue, observing which qi it aligned with, thus profoundly knowing the gains and losses, the rise and decline of governance—clear as the sun and moon.

Excellent, excellent! How may these deficiencies be remedied?
Excellent—now that you, Perfected One, have grasped the Heavenly Canon, you should halt this flow of disasters and inherited burdens upon the myriad things.

How may these disasters be halted?
Only by the Celestial Master instructing the multitude of worthies, enabling them to attain the qi of the Supreme Sovereign.

Thus, each should thoroughly discuss the true Dao in its entirety, each reflecting on the first day to govern their own toil and illness—then their former harmony will be restored, and all will be made complete.

Excellent, excellent.
Proceed, Perfected One—observe the precepts.

Indeed, indeed. I humbly receive the forty-eight precepts with reverence.

How long or short is the practice of the Way?
Your question is most thorough.

I dare not be remiss—the Way of Heaven is most weighty, the master’s command most stern; thus, I venture to ask in detail.

Excellent—you know the proper conduct of a disciple, and may thereby comprehend the intent of the Heavenly Way.

Now, the Heavenly Way has three aspects, corresponding to the Greater Yang, the Greater Yin, and the Balanced Harmony.

The most excellent practice externally; the next, in the middle; the next, internally. The hegemons have no Way.

They merely borrow the path within the Three Kings—this Way is the shortest.

The Supreme Sovereign of Heaven, most excellent, practices most externally.
The Nine Sovereigns share one Way, with the less excellent ranked inwardly. The most excellent walk without moving; the next, move slightly; the next, move with some awareness.

The Fifteen Emperors share one middle Way.
The most excellent practice externally; the next, practice with awareness; the least excellent, practice with haste.

The Three Kings and nine men share one inner Way, riding as they practice. The next move with slight urgency; the least, gallop.

The Fifteen Hegemons borrow the innermost extreme path. The most excellent fly externally; the middling, fly swiftly; the least, like an arrow.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Excellent, excellent.

Perfected One, you have inquired of this matter before—why so detailed now? Since my birth, I have wondered why years alternate between long and short, why days grow thick and thin, advance and retreat. Had I not asked the Heavenly Master, I might never have known. I wish to hear the meaning.

Excellent, excellent are your words. The thickest are the days of Heaven; the next thickest, the days of Earth; the next, the days of humanity; and the thinnest, the days of the myriad things. Do you understand, Perfected One?

Indeed, indeed.

Go now, and ask no more of this. Such matters are your private concern, not because I would withhold explanation from you. The world’s gatherings hold no profit in this, nor does it benefit emperors and kings in bearing their inherited burdens, nor relieve the sorrows of the common people. Thus I do not distinguish the Way for you—not out of reluctance.

Indeed, indeed.

You have repeatedly transgressed the Heavenly Master’s taboos—this is a grave fault. It is not arrogance, but your joy in knowing the affairs of Heaven that brings you here with such private longing. For your sake, I will explain all fully.

Indeed, indeed. Go now.

Here follows the translation:

---

**Right: Method for Distinguishing the Conduct and Degrees of Excellence Among the Nine Sovereigns, Fifteen Emperors, Nine Kings, and Fifteen Hegemons.**
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Sixty-Six, Concluded.
#1 Originally written as "one hundred one," amended according to the Dunhuang manuscript *Catalogue of the Tai Ping Jing*.
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Sixty-Seven

**Six Crimes and Ten Governance Principles, One Hundred Three**

Perfected One, how many crimes do ordinary people commit?

Ordinary people commit no transgressions—what crimes could they have?

Ah, Perfected One, how benighted you are!

This foolish one does not comprehend. From birth, I have never heard that people incur crimes without violating the law.

Your words are correct and align with common understanding.

Yet you fail to see that ordinary people bear six great crimes, which cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations.

Perfected One, you study yet remain blind to these manifest crimes—does your learning not suffer from confusion?

This foolish one is suddenly awakened and does not suffer from confusion.

Yet you remain suddenly unaware. When common people die with grievances bound in their hearts, is this not truly dire?

They die in ignorance, only to awaken afterward.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, people have first been deluded and later enlightened—what fault lies in this?

I wish to hear of it.

Indeed, when people accumulate the Dao without limit yet refuse to teach others to awaken and seek life, their crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. The reason is this: they sever the Dao of Heaven’s generation and become enemies of Heaven.

When people accumulate virtue without limit yet refuse to earnestly teach others to guard virtue, nurture their nature, and act with care, their crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. The reason is this: they sever the Earth’s nurturing virtue and become enemies of Earth, greatly faulting humanity.

When people amass wealth by the millions yet refuse to relieve the destitute and aid the desperate, causing others to die of hunger and cold, their crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. The reason is this: these harmonious goods are the means by which Heaven and Earth enact benevolence, circulating and sustaining one another to prevent scarcity. Now, by hoarding and cutting off their flow, they prevent their universal distribution and become enemies of Heaven and Earth’s harmonious qi. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. Such wealth cannot be long retained and must circulate.

Heaven generates people, endowing them with knowledge to love good and hate evil. Yet, though blessed with understanding, they recognize Heaven’s Dao yet scorn it, refusing to study earnestly to save themselves. Though they may attain long life, inheriting the celestial mandate and their ancestors’ bodies, they instead treat themselves lightly, neglecting study, and regard death as sudden. Only at death do they lament their grievances—this crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations, leaving life in ignorance and becoming enemies of Heaven. The reason is this: Heaven itself strives to practice the Dao, thus it is ever auspicious; to lose the Dao is to invite misfortune and death. Though Heaven loves people and delights in goodness, imprinting the Dao upon their bodies, people refuse to practice it earnestly. They are called people without the Dao, and Heaven has no means to grant them the Dao and longevity. Instead, they sever Heaven’s Dao and become its enemies.

When people are born knowing virtue and goodness yet refuse to study earnestly to cultivate virtue, instead scorning virtue and nurturing evil, treating themselves lightly and acting wrongly, their crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. The reason is this: they act contrary to Earth. Earth delights in virtue and nurtures, yet these people neglect such matters, taking no joy in virtue. They love their ancestors’ bodies yet become enemies of Earth.

Heaven generates people, fortunately endowing each with strength and ability to clothe and feed themselves. Yet they refuse to exert themselves, instead suffering hunger and cold, betraying their ancestors’ bodies, and treating their own strength lightly. Though they could obtain clothing and food through effort, they constantly lament their poverty and hunger, relying solely on the wealthy, depending on them to survive—this crime cannot be absolved. Some incur punishment in their own bodies, while others pass it to future generations. The reason is this: Heaven and Earth generate all goods to nurture people, and each should gather according to their strength, taking enough to avoid scarcity. Instead, they idle and neglect their strength, treating themselves lightly. Or, in their demands, they act without harmony, forcibly taking others’ goods, becoming enemies of the harmonious mean. Their crime clearly merits death.

These are the six great crimes, which Heaven abhors. Their crimes cannot be absolved.

Perfected One, do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

I wish to ask, Heavenly Master, which of these crimes is the gravest?

Ah, how your words reveal your ignorance! Why do you ask?

These are crimes that extinguish entire families. How can you speak of their gravity?

This foolish one is deeply perplexed and does not grasp the essential meaning.

Now, let the Heavenly Master further elucidate, that I may fully awaken, deeply understand the intent, and never again transgress.

Indeed, Perfected One, your words are excellent. My discourse shall now be revealed, and you should follow closely and record it earnestly.

Indeed, indeed.

Go now. At present, August Heaven possesses the Dao and employs it to generate all things, the teeming multitude, all of whom depend on its mandate. Yet great Daoist masters, though they may silently comprehend it deeply, store it within their bellies and refuse to teach others earnestly. Teaching people the Dao is like giving fire to others. Few may come to take it, yet it does not diminish the source. Even if an infinite number come to take it, it does not diminish the source. Now, we are fortunate to share it, to teach the people of the world, to assist Heaven in generating beings, to assist Earth in nurturing forms, and to assist the Emperor in rectifying governance. Moreover, let each embrace the Dao, seeking life and hating death, enabling them to govern and assist others in governance. Let them no longer violate the law or act with wickedness and malice. With their hearts made good, they will assist Heaven, Earth, and the Emperor, nurturing the twelve thousand things, each delighting in long life. Let people harbor benevolent hearts and no longer lightly harm the myriad things. Then Heaven will be greatly pleased, Earth will be greatly joyful, and the Emperor will be greatly delighted, free from sorrow. Is not the merit thus accumulated vast indeed?

When one person teaches and transforms, it is as if enlightening a hundred foolish ones. When a hundred people all return, each teaching ten thousand, and those ten thousand all teach, they will have transformed a hundred million people. When a hundred million all teach, the teaching becomes boundless. This supreme goodness harmonizes with Heaven’s heart above and penetrates the infinite below, so that the people all delight in life and in doing good. If the Emperor wanders without duty, what harm does it bring to others that he does not strive to instruct and admonish them?

Now, people are fortunate to have received the admonitions of former masters, deeply embracing the supreme Dao and sealing it away, yet they do not teach and instruct others. This leaves people with nowhere to turn for refuge, causing them all to die unjustly with grievances unresolved—such is called severing the Dao of Heaven. Many lose the Dao and act recklessly, so that Heaven cannot grant them long life, nor Earth long nurturance. Indeed, people cannot be without the Dao. The petty man, lacking the Dao, often demeans himself, joining in rebellion, violating the patterns of Heaven and the principles of Earth, rising as bandits and thieves, harming one another, transgressing the king’s laws, and causing the noble man deep sorrow. The chaos becomes unmanageable, and the king worries day and night, grieving and distressed, causing Heaven and Earth to lose their proper order. Disasters and anomalies arise without end, leaving a burden for the Emperor. I have not yet spoken exhaustively—severing the Dao of Heaven is a grave and treasonous offense, its transgressions too numerous to record. Thus, I have merely outlined its essentials to show the Perfected One the gravity of right and wrong, and whether such a crime warrants death. Even in death, its excesses remain, flowing into future generations. How lamentable! Perfected One, be cautious indeed.

Only the Perfected One knows this truth, and thus may be said to have attained enduring fortune, far from harm. Indeed, indeed. I dare not depart from the admonitions. Yet you are already wise and enlightened, understanding the Mandate of Heaven. You will surely live and depart from death, no longer doubting.

Now, I humbly report the Mandate of Heaven’s Dao and wish to know the admonitions of Earth’s virtue. The great virtue of Earth lies in its steadfast compliance with Heaven’s Dao, its love for nurturing the myriad things, so that all beings, great and small, receive its grace and are raised to completion. Therefore, those of great virtue and great power should model their conduct after this. Fortunate to have received the merit and effort of former masters, they embrace and conceal the boundless virtue of the good Dao.

Virtue, when used to teach others, is like standing before a great river and drinking from it. If few come to learn virtue, it does not harm its source; if boundless numbers come to learn virtue, it still does not harm its source. Strive to teach and instruct, so that all ordinary people know to uphold greatness and embrace virtue, each cherishing and nurturing their own body. The good among them may assist Heaven in nurturing and growing things above, and assist Earth in rearing and maturing things below, all joining forces with a single heart, free of malice.

Among them, those of great wisdom and easily enlightened minds may be transformed and elevated to assist the ruler. Those of moderate virtue may serve as officials and teachers, while even the least knowledgeable may still become teachers among the common people. All people will delight in the transformation of virtue and do good. Such teaching benefits Heaven above and Earth below, forming the root of great transformation and assisting the Emperor in nurturing the people, preventing them from committing evil or wickedness. The noble man may govern with ease, free from worry, and his merit will be manifest and great. Heaven and Earth will cherish him, and he may be promoted in office.

Yet now, some possess vast virtue but instead feign ignorance and obstruct the path of the Dao, failing to assist Heaven in nurturing what is nascent, failing to assist Earth in maturing what is developing, and failing to assist the Emperor in harmonizing the people. They leave later generations ignorant and benighted, unable to distinguish black from white, persisting in death without change, becoming petty men who cannot move east or west. They recklessly demean themselves, following one another in wrongdoing, accumulating deceit and treachery. Above and below, they can no longer teach one another, stumbling in darkness and confusion, without restraint or taboo. They violate the patterns of Heaven above and the forms of Earth below, their conduct opposing the four seasons and disrupting the five phases. This causes the noble man great sorrow and incites harm among petty men, leading to banditry and theft, sometimes even self-destruction, bringing disgrace upon their parents and cutting off their lineage.

Now, I have merely outlined the essentials for the Perfected One, revealing the beginning so that the multitude may awaken and spur themselves on. Yet they refuse to teach the enduring virtue—this is called severing Earth’s nurturing Dao, and its transgressions are as grave as this. Such conduct is formless, and even in death, its excesses remain, flowing into future generations. Does the Perfected One understand? How lamentable! How lamentable!

The Perfected One understands early—this may yet be called gaining life. Be ever vigilant. Indeed, indeed.

I have reverently received the prohibitions of the Dao and virtue, and now wish to hear of the conduct of the benevolent.

Now, all things of value that Heaven and Earth produce are bestowed upon humanity, rootless and unattached—neither clinging to Heaven above nor to Earth below. These things arise from the harmony of the central qi, meant to circulate freely, floating and flowing to fulfill their office: aiding the destitute and relieving the urgent.

Those who hoard gold, silver, and precious goods—households of vast wealth, with tens of millions or more—let their stores rot and decay. Yet if the wise and discerning distribute them, bestowing upon the poor with joy, this is called benevolence alone. It aids Earth in nurturing forms and assists the Emperor in preserving the good and reverent among the people.

A household of tens of millions can sustain ten thousand families, giving of the old and receiving the new. Let there be no hasty desire for profit, and virtue will harmonize with Heaven and Earth, its fame spreading to distant lands. Thus, one may always obtain new goods while the decaying ones are removed.

Among them, the greatest worthies daily report their deeds to the Emperor. The lesser worthies raise them up in their villages. As for the most foolish—those who fail to repay kindness—there are scarcely twelve or thirteen in ten. How could this impoverish anyone?

When good deeds never cease, the great worthies and enlightened ones raise them up, their names resounding throughout the land. Travelers from the four seas fill the roads to follow their Way. When the enlightened king and sagely lord hear of them, seeing how they aid in nurturing the people, they rejoice greatly. Thus, they summon them, raising them to the highest ranks, and through this, they attain honor and nobility. Their legacy endures without end, becoming the greatest of benevolence—rare under Heaven. Above, they do not betray their ancestors; below, they do not betray their descendants. Heaven cherishes them, the hundred spirits benefit them, and the Emperor treats them as a radiant friend. Neighbors regard them as parents. Their merit is inscribed in Heaven and Earth, never to depart; their emoluments are fixed in office, never to diminish; their names are recorded among the people, never to fade.

How can one not practice benevolence?

Yet some chance upon fertile lands, obtaining the wealth of Heaven and Earth’s central harmony, amassing countless treasures—gold, silver, and precious goods in the tens of millions. Instead of sharing, they seal and hide them in dark chambers, letting all rot. When the destitute come seeking aid, they curse and refuse. Even when they grant something, they do not do so readily but demand repayment with interest—sometimes doubling, sometimes quintupling. They bestow upon the rich and cut off the poor, letting them starve and freeze to death, mocking them without reason.

They incur Heaven’s resentment, Earth’s blame, and become the greatest enemies of humanity. The hundred spirits despise them.

Why is this? These goods arise from the harmony of Heaven and Earth, meant to nourish all people. Such households merely encounter their gathering place—like rats in a granary, always sated alone. Yet the grain of the great storehouse was never meant for the rats alone. The wealth of the treasury was never meant for one person. Those in need should all draw from it.

Fools, lacking understanding, believe they will possess it forever, unaware that it is the accumulation of ten thousand corpses, all meant to find clothing and food therein. Their love turns to irrational anger and joy, refusing to exert themselves to aid the destitute and relieve the urgent. They let ten thousand households perish—unable to plant in spring or harvest in autumn. Their grievances rise in a clamor to Heaven, moving it to sorrow and Earth to tremble.

Those who do not aid the noble in relieving the destitute are the greatest of the unbenevolent between Heaven and Earth. Even when beseeched for offerings to the spirits, they refuse. The hundred spirits loathe them. They wish to cut off their lineage, and their villages curse them to die. When bandits hear of them, they gather forces to rush their gates, besieging their households until they are impoverished and near death. Yet still, they refuse to give, instead burying their wealth deep in the earth, hiding it from sight. They recklessly cut off the world’s resources, depriving the land of its use, and instead strengthen the underworld. Heaven abhors them; Earth ails from them, deeming them a great calamity.

The goods of central harmony dwindle day by day, and thus, they sit in want. The starving and freezing grow ever more numerous, becoming their greatest enemies.

Now, Heaven delights in the Dao, Earth delights in virtue, and central harmony delights in benevolence. All things are meant to reside between Heaven and Earth, circulating to provide for all. Yet when people lack, these goods are buried instead, sick and stifled, unable to emerge and be seen.

Heaven and Earth never desired wealth for themselves. Heaven delights in human life; Earth delights in human nurturance. Ignorant petty men obstruct the wealth of Heaven and Earth’s central harmony, preventing its circulation and sufficiency. They kill what Heaven has given life and harm what Earth has nurtured. They recklessly bury and hide this wealth, impoverishing the state, depleting its resources, and failing to save the lives of its people. They leave virtuous rulers to govern in emptiness.

Gold, silver, precious goods, and wealth are created through human labor, truly arduous. They should serve the state’s needs, yet they are cast aside without reason, removed from above and below. Earth does not delight in possessing them, deeming them a great affliction, a great burden.

Now, the unbenevolence of fools is so grave—should they not die for such sins?

Among them, there are those who, suddenly insatiable, contend in lawsuits, wronging themselves to seize the wealth of the weak and small, never knowing restraint.

I have merely shown the Perfected One the essentials, revealing the beginning. The transgressions of the greatly unbenevolent are too numerous to record, making wealth and resources difficult to manage. The Perfected One should ponder this deeply.

Thus, the three qi of Heaven, Earth, and central harmony despise them. Even in death, their sins remain, destined to flow into future generations. Perfected One, do you now awaken to this?

Indeed, indeed.

How lamentable! I do not wish to hear more.

If the Perfected One leaves behind such words, Heaven will surely take your life, that you may awaken and repent. Then, perhaps, you may yet live.

Be vigilant in your affairs.

Indeed, indeed.

I have reverently received the precepts of the Dao, virtue, and benevolence, and wish to hear why those with knowledge do not study the true Dao.

Excellent are your words.

When Heaven gives birth to humanity, it bestows upon them the fortune of wisdom, that they may study and attain long life. Heaven possesses the Dao and delights in sharing it with people; Earth possesses virtue and delights in bestowing it upon them; central harmony possesses wealth and delights in nurturing them. Thus, people naturally seek the true Dao. If the Perfected One persists without cease, it is as though consulting with the spirits, daily singing of goodness, and goodness will naturally return to them. By serving the multitude of the worthy, they will collectively instruct and guide, and the path will no longer be distant. This allows one to preserve their body, not betray the legacy of their ancestors, while others meet early deaths, and only they fulfill their natural lifespan. While others are called evil, they alone are deemed good. As a teacher to the multitude, their name spreads to distant lands, inwardly embracing the true Dao, virtue, and benevolence. They aid Heaven in generating life, assist Earth in nurturing forms, and support the emperor in transforming the people. The highest teachers can transform boundless numbers, ensuring even the foolish abide by the Dao and commit no wrongs. Middle teachers can transform ten thousand, and lesser teachers can transform hundreds or thousands, bringing benefit to the sovereign by making the petty-minded aware of prohibitions and preventing them from committing hidden evils. Such teachers gain office without betraying their ancestors or shaming their descendants. Given such learning, how can one not pursue it?

Thus, the sages of antiquity all regarded exhorting people to study as their greatest concern, aiding Heaven and Earth in generation and completion, and assisting the emperor in governing disorder. This is the highest praise for the good between Heaven and Earth. Yet some fools, though born with the desire for knowledge, refuse to diligently study the true Dao. Instead, they delight in superficial splendor, acting to deceive others—cheating their parents as children, their ruler as subjects, and their superiors as inferiors. This is called deceiving Heaven, and their sins cannot be erased. Others indulge in worldly affairs and strife, following one another in wrongdoing. When they see the followers of the Perfected One, they mock them, saying, "What is the use of study?" Thus, they remain in darkness, their ignorance profound. They crave dominance yet cannot achieve it, recklessly claiming that Heaven and Earth are without measure and the worthy are without knowledge. They act wantonly, offending the celestial patterns above and the terrestrial principles below, their comings and goings without restraint. At home, they neglect their parents, gathering with the foolish to become wicked sons. When they serve as officials, they return to execute their parents, unable to reflect, and flee to become bandits, harming and killing without cease. This is precisely what Heaven abhors, Earth blames, the emperor grieves over, the hundred spirits detest, and parents despair of. This is the greatest calamity harming others, severing the lineage of their ancestors.

If one does not diligently study the true Dao and acts thus, in the eyes of the Perfected One, should they not die? Even in death, their sins remain, flowing to their descendants, who will still be called the lineage of evil men, the heirs of bandits. Will their wickedness not flow to future generations? Now, I have merely shown the Perfected One the beginning; their evils are too numerous to record, and their wealth and resources are difficult to manage. Perfected One, do you now awaken to this?

Be vigilant, Perfected One.

Indeed, indeed. How lamentable!

You know lamentation; you have already turned from evil.

I have reverently heard these four matters and wish to hear what follows.

Now, when Heaven gives birth to humanity, it endows them fully before sending them forth, ever delighting in their pursuit of the Dao and virtue. The benevolent, fortunate in their knowledge, can study virtue. Heaven and Earth nurture the myriad things with virtue, delighting in people emulating them. Thus, the virtuous of the great antiquity endured humiliation, emulating Earth’s nurturing of all things. When people learn this, their hearts are ever joyful, no longer delighting in harm. They act with caution, daily doing good, no longer desiring evil. Like attracts like, and their stature grows ever higher and more distant. Through long accumulation, they become people of abundant virtue, to whom all respond, and the multitude turns toward them. Persisting in reverent goodness without cease, they become great teachers of virtue. Their virtue aids Heaven in nurturing the living, assists Earth in fostering growth, and delights in aiding the enlightened king in transforming the people, making them reverent and no longer knowing wickedness. In small virtue, they may transform hundreds or thousands; in great virtue, they may transform ten thousand or more. Thus, they turn ten thousand into teachers of virtue, their transformations boundless. Persisting in virtue, all people rejoice. Heaven and Earth love them, extending their years; ghosts and spirits favor them, collectively aiding and protecting them. Those with merit become the virtuous officials of the ruler, delighting not in harming others. They rejoice in goodness, and what they seek is ever attained. They dwell in constant joy, with none desiring to harm them. This originates from learning to follow goodness and cultivate virtue, thus reaching such heights. Their names resound in distant lands, their merits recorded in Heaven and Earth, not betraying their ancestors or shaming their descendants.

Yet some, though fortunate in knowledge and discerning good from evil, instead belittle themselves, not diligently studying to cultivate goodness and virtue. They follow the ignorant and benighted in evil, delighting in the use of force and martial prowess, their words ever harsh. Their speech is perverse, seeking to subdue others. They claim superiority, yet others surpass them; they boast of strength, yet others are mightier. Thus, all things under Heaven have their limits and can be controlled. When a great fire arises, it seems uncontrollable, yet water extinguishes it. When people do evil and rage, they seem uncontrollable, yet prison subdues them. When speech seems unrestrained, illness humbles them. Thus, Heaven and Earth govern humanity, each with its own measure. Yet people, though possessing knowledge, refuse to study diligently and instead belittle themselves in wrongdoing. Their dwellings become inauspicious, and none love them.

Heaven and Earth abhor them; the hundred spirits detest them; even emperors and kings are grieved and afflicted by them. Such men do not become good people but instead become bandits and thieves. Even in death, they remain malevolent spirits. Though they exert force and act tyrannically, none of their efforts endure after death.

The Dao and its principles are known to all, yet they lightly dismiss doing good—how lamentable! They forsake the legacy of their ancestors, burdening their descendants. Thus, they are branded as wicked and violent men. No one is willing to speak with them; passersby avoid sharing the same path. What fault is theirs? They merely inherit the sins of their parents, yet they are still called the children of bandits and thieves, and some even meet untimely deaths.

When the Perfected Ones come, people still take goodness lightly. They refuse to study under enlightened masters to cultivate virtue, instead following petty men—such transgressions are thus. Would not death itself be too lenient a punishment for their excess of sins?

How dreadful! There is no need for the Heavenly Master to expound further; my heart already aches with sorrow at the thought. People regard the failure to study as a trivial matter, unaware that it leads to such consequences. How foolish they are, no different from the vulgar masses. They do not reflect deeply, yet death alone cannot expiate their sins.

Perfected Ones, having rendered service to Heaven and Earth, must be vigilant.

"Yes, yes. One must not take this lightly."

I have merely outlined its essentials, revealing only the beginning—the evils of failing to study extend far beyond this.

When you receive my writings, reflect deeply upon them. "Yes, yes." If truly grasped, retreat to a quiet place and examine them thoroughly. "Indeed, so it is." To study without precision is no different from dreaming. "Yes, yes."

Having solemnly accepted my teachings, I wish to hear of the instruction that one with strength in life should follow. "Very well. Heaven and Earth together give life to all creatures, even the crawling ones, endowing each with strength. They draw qi from the four seasons and emulate the Five Phases. Strength, by its nature, moves and acts; one should follow its course to secure clothing and food.

Thus, those who consistently exert their strength, working day and night without respite, ceaselessly accumulating—whether great or small, whatever they obtain, they cherish. All things possess their own spirit and naturally incline toward those who love them; when people cherish them, they come to them. It is like the Eastern Sea, which loves water and lies lowest, so all the waters of the world gather there, making it the sea.

The noble person who exerts strength without ceasing becomes a leader in amassing wealth, and their household grows prosperous, lacking nothing. Their ancestors receive fine offerings, their descendants enjoy abundance, and the entire family benefits. By exerting strength without pause, the destitute from all directions come to receive its fruits, and their foundation grows ever greater. By giving without end, they earn great praise from the multitude, their name spreads far, and their merit is recorded in Heaven and Earth.

They should use their strength to aid the destitute and relieve the desperate, assisting Heaven and Earth in cherishing all things and aiding the ruler in nurturing the people. By ceaselessly rescuing the poor and needy, Heaven extends their lifespan, and all spirits come to partake of their offerings—no one in their household is not joyful. Through such virtue, they may attain high office, honoring their ancestors and not disappointing their descendants.

Yet some, though possessing strength, take it lightly and do not treat it as a matter of consequence. Though they could attain wealth, they instead engage in disputes and recklessly commit inauspicious acts. Seeing their strength overpower others, they persist in such behavior, becoming great evildoers. Their households grow impoverished, and they turn to banditry. Hunger and cold assail them, and they cannot restrain themselves from wickedness. Among them, the most unworthy perish from starvation and cold.

Those who wield strength to harm others, seeking what is not theirs and seizing what does not belong to them, repeatedly injuring others—such acts incur Heaven’s resentment, Earth’s blame, and the enmity of the noble. The Emperor grows sorrowful. If they persist without cease, all spirits despise them, and blessings no longer favor them. Heaven refuses to cover them, Earth refuses to bear them; calamities arise daily. They die by the roadside or languish in prison, their parents are disgraced, misfortune befalls their wives and children, and their six relations and neighbors all wish them dead. Yet their sins remain, flowing into future generations, leaving them as beggars’ descendants or thieves’ offspring—a great stain upon posterity.

Perfected One, their transgressions and punishments are thus. Would not death itself be too lenient for their excess of sins? When I hear the Heavenly Master speak of such matters, my heart trembles with shock and aches with sorrow, fearing I may never recover. Perfected One, if you understand this heartache, you will soon live rightly. But if you do not suddenly awaken fully, your death will come soon.

Be vigilant. My words must not be violated; those who violate them will perish—not by my hand, but by the consequences of their own actions. Do you understand? "Yes, yes."

I have expounded these six matters, yet they are but a fraction of the whole. You who have received my Dao should ponder deeply and plan far ahead. Do not carelessly take things lightly or fail to show compassion in doing good. In cultivating strength and learning, consider whether your actions are virtuous or wicked—for the latter will only bring you low.

Each must consider their own fate. Within these teachings lie six paths to death and six great virtues. Emulate the virtues, and you will surely attain goodness; take goodness lightly and act wickedly, and misfortune will come daily.

You must spur yourself on and reflect, for there is no joy in self-indulgence. Be cautious and ponder deeply. Meditate upon this, and the heart of the wise and enlightened will surely open.

Virtue, benevolence, and goodness are entrusted to those of moral character, while wickedness is left to those who do not reflect deeply—this is the established pattern. If all could emulate the principles in my writings to correct themselves, the world would have no more evil people.

This is the primordial Dao of the Highest Antiquity from the Heavenly Caverns, capable of transforming people. Once they know it, all become good and do not revert to wickedness. The superior person delights in life and may study the true Dao; the profoundly wise may cultivate its virtue; the benevolent may practice its kindness; the knowledgeable may develop its wisdom; the capable may refine their abilities; and the strong may harness their strength.

If one can fully apply these teachings, reflecting upon them thoroughly, they will distance themselves from misfortune. Heaven and Earth will cherish them, the six directions will nurture them, and the Emperor will have no further concerns—thus they may govern with ease. Perfected One, do you understand? "Great joy has come! I am overjoyed. You may indeed be called one who delights in goodness and understands it."

Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity taught without ceasing, for they saw the clear prohibitions of Heaven and considered their own fate. Therefore, the teachings of the sages and worthies filled the world. Have you alone not realized this? "Excellent! Excellent!"

Thus, the sages, worthies, and superior persons of antiquity all studied diligently, exerting themselves day and night without pause, for they too saw the clear commands of Heaven and Earth. They dared not take things lightly or act wrongly, nor did they dare to be careless in their studies. Thus, they enjoyed long-lasting fortune and no harm. These worthies and extraordinary individuals were originally no different, but through diligent study, they attained such heights.

The wicked among them all arose from a failure to study diligently, from taking things lightly and carelessly. My Dao is the gateway to fortune and misfortune—do you understand this? "Yes, yes."

Thus, I have addressed all, from the highest to the lowest. What does this mean?

Alas! Why do you still not awaken?

Seeing the Heavenly Master speak repeatedly, you remain confused and do not know yourself—what is awakening, and what is not awakening? Now, let me make you understand and act upon this.

Before the Perfected One, consider this: Heaven’s methods of governance transform people toward goodness, from the highest to the lowest—how many such methods are there? Though the methods are myriad and each bears a different intent, the Perfected One still upholds rectitude in this manner. The common people, however, are difficult to awaken, for their delusion has lasted long. If there is fault, it lies only with the Heavenly Master.

Yet in assisting the Emperor and kings in governance, there are, in general, ten methods:

First, governance by primordial *qi*;
second, governance by spontaneity;
third, governance by the Dao;
fourth, governance by virtue;
fifth, governance by benevolence;
sixth, governance by righteousness;
seventh, governance by ritual;
eighth, governance by culture;
ninth, governance by law;
tenth, governance by military force.

These ten are the completion—why? All things begin with primordial *qi* and end with the military. The military involves cutting and punishment, and thus it is the lowest. Therefore, things arise in the Great Mystery, mature in the Great Yang, and die in the White Tiger. Thus, primordial *qi* resides in the north, while the White Tiger dwells in the west—this is what is meant.

Thus, Heaven employs governance by primordial *qi*, using the winds to nurture all things. Earth employs governance by spontaneity, so that following goodness yields goodness, and following evil yields evil. Humanity, in turn, follows the harmony of Heaven and Earth, employing governance by the Dao, taking the active Dao as its guide, so that all affairs flow and circulate.

These three methods correspond to the omens of Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Beyond these three, virtue and benevolence serve as mere chapters and verses. Below benevolence, much harm is done, and intent becomes difficult to realize.

Thus, my Dao constantly delights in the original nature of Heaven’s precepts, while the intermediate nature of the yet-unformed Heaven is discarded. In the generation of all things, the root is the constant principle; they reach completion in the middle and descend into chaos at the end. Those who lose order and fall into chaos cannot be restored to principle. Therefore, one must begin with the highest origin.

Thus, Heaven constantly guards its root, Earth guards its single revolution in the middle, and humanity guards its three revolutions below—hence the reckoning of disorder in the Dao.

Perfected One, have you now clearly understood this? "Yes, yes."

Should you now harbor doubts? To follow a master is to speak without daring to doubt.

Perfected One, when Heaven aids the emperor and king, by what is this made manifest? When it benefits ministers and people, by what is this proven?

Master, I now dare not ask further—my many words have missed the mark, and my errors have multiplied, so I no longer presume to speak.

Go forth, then.

Yes, yes.

Now, when Heaven aids the emperor and king, I shall grant him wondrous scriptures, which may be employed to govern. Their application surpasses all bounds, harmonizing with yin and yang, and shall benefit lesser ministers. I shall grant him worthy officials to benefit the people, enabling them to bear virtuous children.

Perfected One, is this so? Is there yet more extraordinary discourse?

It is the utmost.

When Heaven desires to exalt a ruler of virtue, it is for the sake of bearing divine sages, that they may transmit the discourse of Heaven and Earth and comprehend their intent. Thus, Perfected One, you have come to study this.

It is fitting to entrust this to the most prudent and virtuous among the people, to awaken their hearts and prompt their reflection. Present it to a ruler of great virtue, that he may display it to the assembled worthies, ensuring all grasp its meaning and convey it to the common folk. When the common folk receive it, fifteen will follow as one, deliberating and governing together, rectifying all that is unjust—not for the sake of Heaven, Earth, or the ruler alone.

Yet the root of transgression lies in the long-lived among men. The long-lived, having gained authority, incur grave responsibility before the August Heaven and Earth—all borne by one person. When those who first attain the true Dao do not strive to transform and teach others; when those who first know virtue do not exert themselves to transform others; when the wealthy, amassing riches, refuse to practice benevolence with vigor; when men, though capable of learning, do not strive to seek the true Dao to attain longevity; when those capable of cultivating virtue do not strive to refine themselves; when those with strength do not labor diligently but instead invite hardship—these are the six great transgressions.

Heaven and humanity have long accumulated such faults. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, each generation has inherited and compounded the burdens of the past, and those born later suffer even more. When such transgressions amass, they coalesce into great harm, causing Heaven and Earth together to lose their rectitude. The emperor’s heart is long afflicted, and governance fails. Injustice persists, and Heaven grows deeply displeased.

Thus, I hasten to transmit the words of Heaven. From the most ancient times to the present, when Heaven and Earth suffer affliction, their qi stagnates and does not flow. Ordinary people cannot know this—only divine sages transmit these words. It is not I alone, Perfected One; do not find this strange.

Now that I am about to depart this world, I may no longer appear freely among the people. Therefore, I transmit this scripture to you, Perfected One. Having departed the mundane, you may no longer serve as a teacher among the people. Thus, I charge you to seek out the most discerning and enlightened among the people and entrust this to them. Now, hasten to deliver it to a ruler of virtue. Should you dare to delay or withhold it, you shall be held accountable—how grave this would be!

Today, Heaven seeks to alleviate suffering and bring peace to the emperor and king. Let the ruler of Dao and virtue make this plain to the assembled worthies, that they may transform the people. Let each reflect on their transgressions to dissolve the inherited burdens of their forebears. Let all people consider their own well-being and not grow negligent. Then Heaven shall rejoice greatly, and governance shall be established in harmony.

Should you still harbor doubts, questioning the sincerity of my words, know that my scriptures are but a test of truth. Why is this so? Ancient texts number in the millions, yet governance has never achieved true peace. Now, even the wise and enlightened may doubt, dismissing these words as untrue.

Without testing a warrior, how can one know his strength? Without applying a text, how can one know its divine power? I have received the words of Heaven to test you, Perfected One. From this point forward, when you receive any scripture, you must put it to the test—do not again indulge in empty or deceptive speech. Heaven deeply resents this; Earth profoundly suffers it, regarding it as a grave malady, a true grievance of indignation.

As a result, the myriad things do not flourish, disasters and premature deaths abound, and none complete their allotted years. The emperor is distressed, officials and people are in turmoil, and order is no longer restored. The great fault lies in these six transgressions:

Those who possess the Dao envy it and do not strive to teach the foolish; those who possess virtue envy it and do not strive to transform the foolish; those who hoard wealth envy it and do not practice generosity. Heaven births all people, intending them to offer their gifts to the world. Yet those with knowledge do not strive to learn the true Dao to their own fulfillment, and when taught, they mock it. Those with ability do not strive to practice generosity, and when taught, they revile it. Those with strength do not labor diligently to enrich themselves and practice benevolence but instead grow idle and lazy. When their parents teach them, they reject it.

Thus, I command you, Perfected One, to swiftly bring this text to light, that the assembled worthies may each deeply reflect on the people and consider the great transgressions. Perfected One, do you now clearly understand this charge?

Yes, yes.

Now that the divine person has expounded the laws of Heaven, why should it be confined to individuals alone? Should it not be disseminated among the people, ensuring proper order from above to below?

Excellent, excellent! Today, the qi of Great Peace is about to descend from the highest heavens. All matters must follow its course—thus, the order from above to below. Without this order, there is only rebellious qi, and governance cannot be harmonious. Most disorders arise from disobedience to this flow.

Perfected One, do you wish to add to this?

I dare not. Thus, the order must be from above to below—do not ask further.

Yes, yes. Go forth, and take care in all matters for your own sake. These six great transgressions exist, and the Dao of Heaven is most severe—do not act recklessly. Heaven, dwelling above, watches over humanity.

Yes, yes.

I humbly request to ask one more question: when a person has attained the essential Dao and essential virtue, where should they place them?

They should present them to their ruler.

Why must they be presented to the ruler?

The essential Dao exists to bring peace to the ruler; when employed in governance, it gains the favor of Heaven. The essential virtue exists to nurture the ruler; when employed in governance, it gains the favor of Earth. Those who truly understand this yet do not present it to their superiors commit an act of disrespect—such transgressions cannot be absolved.

How weighty this is! Observing your manner of speech and conduct, one would think you utterly devoid of understanding. As a child, you are unfilial; as a subject, you are disloyal and untrustworthy—your transgressions defy description.

You, Perfected One, now ask why these matters are so grave. Why has your learning not deepened day by day, but instead grown ever more shallow? Truly, this foolish student sees nothing.

You still claim to see nothing? Common folk conceal and obscure the essential Dao and virtue, causing their ruler to suffer in sorrow and ignorance. The fault lies in the obstruction of the true Dao and virtue, which remain uncommunicated.

Moreover, the essential Dao exists to align with Heaven, and the essential virtue exists to align with Earth. Fools sever these connections—Heaven detests them, Earth abhors them, and their transgressions cannot be absolved.

Fortunately, Perfected One, you alone have been privately granted longevity by Heaven, yet your learning remains incomplete, even transgressing Heaven’s prohibitions. Those who serve must take heed.

Yes, yes.

Here ends the scripture of Heaven’s teachings on harmonizing and enabling people to perpetually attain good fortune and distance misfortune.

*Thus concludes the sixty-seventh scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.*
*Here begins the sixty-eighth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.*

Admonition to the Six Disciples, One Hundred and Fourth Formula

As my departure draws near, I leave you, the Six Disciples, with this single admonition.

The Dao is all-pervading—without above or below, without exterior or interior. Guard its harmonious qi, and you shall be called a Divine Child. Seek it near, and you shall greatly attain; seek it afar, and you shall lose it.

Thus, the ancient kings who governed well began within the depths of their own being. Truly employing the Dao, they found governance effortless. Their movements never strayed from the measures and numbers, and the myriad things ordered themselves. Near at heart, their influence spread to fill the Four Seas. The ancients called this the Essential Dao.

Govern with joy, desiring no affairs. Take heed not to lose this, for it is the plumb line that rectifies the worthy.

Now I earnestly repeat this to enlighten you: though you six have asked me about the scriptures day after day, and though the Dao branches into different paths, it remains one in essence. Yet the tongue, capable of encompassing the Six Directions, completes the kingly Dao, explaining the myriad things, each with its distinct meaning. Thus, Heaven and Earth attain great peace, and the kingly ruler remains without affairs.

My writings reveal the divine mind, penetrating the Six Directions. The Eight Directions submit of their own accord, all harboring good hearts, devoid of malice. Their essential knot resides within. It is like the heart of the myriad things dwelling within, while their branches reside without. When the inner flourishes, the outer flourishes; when the inner declines, the outer declines.

Therefore, the ancient August Dao Emperors and Sages, wishing to rectify the all-pervading Six Distant Directions and Eight Sides, first rectified the inner. By rectifying the inner, the outer is rectified, resonating infinitely without fail. To rectify the outer in order to rectify the inner is to err ten thousandfold.

Thus, the great sages of old taught people to ponder deeply and plan far ahead, closing their nine apertures, resting their four agents, and returning to a state of primordial chaos. Like a ring without end, or a child in the womb without duties, only then can one grasp the principle.

My Dao takes this as its great essential, hence I repeatedly urge each to guard their root. When Heaven generates humans, it endows them with the true Dao through the tools of creation. Thus, the teacher opens and guides them; through learning, they may become all-knowing. If the gates of their senses remain unopened, though they receive the true Dao of Heaven, they shall know nothing. It is like a newborn placed in a chamber—without guidance and learning in affairs, nothing can be known.

The differences among people arise only from the varying customs of the Eight Directions, hence their knowledge and learning differ. If one person could learn, traveling throughout the inner and outer, they would know all.

As I prepare to depart for distant places, there may yet be those to whom I can transmit, but I cannot remain seated in constant ease, guarding all my disciples. You six must carefully study my writings from beginning to end, for they form a coherent structure. If you fail to grasp my intent, examine the ancient texts to clarify it.

The one who practices the Upper Dao is known as the Mysterious Perfected; the one who practices the Lower Dao is known as the Compliant Perfected; the one who practices the Eastern Dao is known as the Initial Perfected; the one who practices the Southern Dao is known as the Grand Perfected; the one who practices the Western Dao is known as the Lesser Perfected; the one who practices the Northern Dao is known as the Secluded Perfected.

The Dao is largely the same with minor differences, thus it can distinguish yin and yang without limit, transforming into the One Thousand Five Hundred and Twenty Characters. Though the harmony of the myriad things is somewhat complete, it has yet to exhaust the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, or penetrate the boundless without exterior or interior.

Therefore, examine its absence, grasp its essentials, and observe its beginning, so that it may serve as a model to be recorded. Records of the past and present, though their essentials may seem disordered, are the same. What the divine and sagely record is like overlapping compasses and matching squares—though separated by billions upon billions of years, it is as if they speak face to face.

Thus, it may serve as the eternal canon of Heaven and Earth, as the divine Dao of yin and yang. Do not wonder at the repetition in my writings. I repeat because I fear something may be lost.

Moreover, the Dao of Heaven is most strict. Having spoken, I dare not leave anything incomplete. Whether understood or not, an incomplete transmission is called a "stumbling Dao," a grave transgression. I truly pity this, hence the repetition.

It is like the sages of the high antiquity, middle antiquity, and low antiquity—though born in different eras, their words follow one another, repeating and expounding, mutually verifying and clarifying. Thus, the Dao of Heaven may be fully known. This is the meaning.

Go forth! I must hasten on my journey. Hold fast to the Heavenly Treasure with utmost care, and transmit it to the proper person.

*Here ends the Admonition to the Six Disciples.*
*Thus concludes the sixty-eighth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.*
*Here begins the sixty-ninth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.*

**Method One Hundred and Five: The Celestial Prognostications and the Cyclical Branches in Mutual Accordance**

The Perfected One bowed twice and said: "This foolish and lowly one, by the grace of the Heavenly Master, has been treated with the tenderness due a newborn child. Such boundless kindness and love have allowed me, in haste and confusion, to be granted audience even at dawn and dusk. The works of Heaven are vast beyond gratitude.

Now, I dare once more to inquire into the profound and essential, the secret Dao of Heaven—yet I hesitate to speak it all at once. Let the Way be made level. Since you, Master, have permitted this questioning from Heaven, the matter must be pursued to its end; it cannot be abandoned midway."

"Indeed, indeed."

"This humble one has observed that the teachings of the Heavenly Master are without limit or end. Thus, all disciples, awakened by Heaven, have come to know that the Heavenly Master’s wisdom penetrates deeply, comprehending the essence of Heaven and Earth, both inner and outer, in their yin and yang. Fearing that one day we may be parted from you, Master, with no one left to resolve our doubts, we dare—boldly and without restraint—to ask about the prognostication that can bring lasting peace to the state and family, allowing the lord of men to govern with hands folded in his sleeves, free from care. He would then need only to pluck the zither and lute, make music, and wander in ease, as secure as Heaven and Earth, never again facing peril. Can such a thing be heard?"

The various Perfected Ones—do you aspire to advance in understanding?

Profound and subtle indeed is your question, seeking the charts and prognostications that penetrate and unify Heaven and Earth, a single word of which cannot be altered for ten thousand generations. Does the Lord of Heaven, grieved by the many disasters and sorrows of the world, dispatch the Perfected Ones to resolve these doubts?

"Assent."

Then let me fully expound the great essentials of Heaven’s compass and square, the secret texts and oral instructions, so that they may be passed from mouth to mouth. The Perfected Ones shall follow and record them themselves.

"Indeed, indeed."

Now, the August Heaven takes the four seasons as its branches, while the fertile Earth takes the five phases as its body. The branches govern decline and flourishing; the body governs the compass and square. These nine spirits divide their domains, circulating throughout the world, ascending and descending without limit, their transformations difficult to perceive. They are the weighty treasures of Heaven and Earth, the gateways of all spirits. They possess an inherent constancy; one must not rashly transgress them. Those who follow them enjoy enduring fortune; those who disrupt them remain forever at odds with Heaven and Earth.

"Indeed, indeed."

We wish to hear their meaning—can they truly be perceived?

"Excellent indeed are the words of the Perfected Ones. Now I shall fully expound this for you—only compose yourselves, sit calmly, and ponder my words."

"Indeed, indeed."

The eternal celestial prognostication and pattern decree that the south is firmly established as the ruler. Thus it is said: the south is where the ruler resides; fire rules in the south; the Great Yang rules in the south; the flourishing summer of the four seasons rules in the south; the stove of the Five Domestic Altars rules in the south; the heart of the Five Viscera rules in the south. The ruler, according to the pattern, ought to wear red, for this is the phase of fire. Therefore, when the ruler encounters anomalies, they invariably correspond with yang—never with any other phase. Yang is most radiant in the sun, which governs all and stands as the eldest. Thus the celestial prognostication always takes the sun as the omen for the ruler’s prosperity or decline. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed. We have come to understand it."

The pattern for a human ruler is ever to seek kinship with the benevolent and to govern with those who possess a heart. Those with whom one may govern together must ever practice the Dao and cherish life. Even the young and weak, or those ministers and worthy ones who are still maturing, the ruler ought to nurture—not harm. Thus the east cherishes life, while the south cherishes nurturance. Those who lack benevolence and act with intent cannot long endure, and those whose dealings are unclear cannot serve as rulers. Thus the east, being wood, embodies benevolence and heart, while the south, being fire, embodies clarity. The celestial pattern decrees that emperors and kings who govern must ever do so through the Dao and virtue. Thus the east represents the Dao, for the Dao governs generation, while the south represents virtue, for virtue governs nurturance—hence the south governs nurturance. Those who govern ought to emulate Heaven by civilizing through culture. Thus the east represents culture, for the dragon emerges bearing it, while the south represents refinement—hence rectitude becomes the pattern of culture. Refinement is great clarity, so culture arises in the east and becomes luminous in the south. Thus the celestial pattern is red, and red is fire. Benevolence and rulership move upward, and the sun ought to stand high and bright, serving as the model for humanity. Thus when wood and fire move, they invariably ascend—this is the image of the ruler. Therefore, dwelling in the east, one relies on benevolence to ascend, and thus those who govern ought to reside in the south. The east is Lesser Yang, the ruler’s beginning; thus the sun rises in the east. The south is Greater Yang, the ruler’s radiant flourishing. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family and parents, while Greater Yang is the ruler’s person and position. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family, for wood is the parent of fire, and the ruler takes Lesser Yang as their family, while fire is called the child of wood. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this. Lesser Yin is the minister, and ministers bend and yield in righteousness, submitting to Greater Yang. Thus metal follows fire in bending and yielding. Among people, what is desirable is that ministers always yield in righteousness to assist the ruler in what is desirable—hence Lesser Yin is called the minister. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Greater Yin is the people, who flow and do not cease, just as water flows without knowing rest. The people are charged with the duty of sustaining the state and providing for the kings and lords. Thus water ought to follow in nurturing and fostering wood. The east is the ruler’s family. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Proceed, for you have already understood this. The celestial omens decree that Lesser Yang fears Lesser Yin. Thus ministers may seize control of the state and the offices of kings and lords. Greater Yang fears Greater Yin; therefore, when a state possesses the Dao and virtue and is ruled by the worthy and enlightened, the people follow. When a state lacks the Dao and virtue, the people rebel. Thus the great essentials of governing a state are these: many people mean wealth, while few people mean great poverty. Do all the Perfected Ones comprehend this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Now you have awakened to this. The celestial patterns and laws divide into six parts. The southeast and above belong to Heaven, thus all things in growth ascend, and crawling creatures and people all emerge and dwell without, belonging to Heaven. Therefore, Heaven’s color is outwardly azure, resembling wood, and inwardly red, resembling fire. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed. Now you have comprehended this."

"The celestial and terrestrial patterns and omens decree that the west and north below belong to Earth, thus when things reach autumn and winter, all fall and return to the soil. Crawling creatures and people, when autumn and winter arrive, all enter their burrows to dwell. Therefore, Earth’s color is outwardly yellow and white, resembling soil and metal, while inwardly it contains water, differing thus, resembling the northward movement. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"The celestial patterns and omens decree that the east and south, being noble in position, belong above to Heaven and govern as rulers, lords, teachers, and fathers. The west and north, being lowly in position, belong to Earth and serve as ministers, the inner palace, and the people. Thus, the *ji* stems from the inner palace of *jia*. *Jia* is Heaven, the fundamental position of kings. Thus, *jia* is the Heart Star; the Heart Star is fire and belongs to kings. Therefore, the east is also the precursor of kings. The Heart Star is fire and moves to belong to the south. It is like the sun rising in the east yet residing in the south. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, disciple. The celestial patterns and omens decree that *bing* is the chief of fire, the most radiant of all, and thus the position of the ruler. *Xin* belongs to *bing*; *xin* is the inner palace of *bing*. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, disciple. Now, *ji* is also called the Empress, and *xin* is also called the Empress—how can this be?"

"Excellent is your inquiry, disciple, for it grasps the meaning of the celestial omens. Now, *ji* is paired with *jia*, and *shen* is the father of *bing*; thus, *ji* is the palace of the Grand Empress. *Xin* is paired with *bing*, and *bing* is the son of *jia*; thus, *xin* is the palace of the Lesser Empress. *Bing* is the rightful son of *jia*, the ordained sovereign ruler. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, Perfected One. *Geng* belongs to *yi* and represents the feudal lords and kings of the state. *Ren* belongs to *ding* and represents the younger sisters of the emperor. *Gui* belongs to *wu* and represents the maternal family of the Grand Empress. Excellent, Perfected One, you have already understood this.

Now that the ten celestial stems have been explained, each with its proper affiliation, we wish to hear of the twelve earthly branches—how are they to be understood?"

"Excellent! The Dao of Heaven operates thus: though yin and yang move in succession, each has its own household in matters of governance. The Dao of Heaven is uniform, yet without households, all would simply follow one another to cessation. *Jia* takes *yin* as its household; *yi* takes *mao* as its household; *bing* takes *wu* as its household; *ding* takes *si* as its household; *wu* takes *chen* and *xu* as its household; *ji* takes *chou* and *wei* as its household; *geng* takes *shen* as its household; *xin* takes *you* as its household; *ren* takes *zi* as its household; *gui* takes *hai* as its household.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven operates in reverse to govern, while the Dao of Earth is still. Therefore, there are divided lands but no divided people—this is to have states and territories but no state in the absolute. Thus, Heaven and Earth do not shift: Heaven reverses its course day and night, circulating through one full cycle, and this is its constant way. Therefore, the twelve earthly branches each reside in their place and do not follow the ten celestial stems in their movement. Do you understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

To practice the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons and five phases complete one another in their cycles. Though their expressions differ as they revolve, they circulate through the hidden and obscure without end—only the great divine sages of antiquity knew this in every age.

To explain it all to you would exhaust resources and prove overly elaborate, only deepening confusion and leaving the lords of earthly virtue bewildered, uncertain of what to follow. Thus, I have ceased.

Not that I begrudge explaining it to you—rather, the explanations would be endless. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

You have gained some insight. The Virtuous Lord governs according to our celestial prognostication, and not one thing in ten thousand will go amiss.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven has its fixed boundaries. The east and south are assigned to the lord and king, symbolizing Heaven, hence the title "Son of Heaven." The west and north are assigned to the rear palace, subjects, and ministers, symbolizing Earth, hence Earth is called the "rear palace." Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

The celestial patterns of prognostication show that the east fears the west. Thus, since the opening of Heaven and Earth, when rulers have followed military methods, exalted the qi of Metal, and employed martial forces, the symbolic qi of the lord has been depleted. Fire is greatly weakened, and governance becomes inauspicious and chaotic.

If you, Perfected One, wish to know the truth of celestial prognostication, observe from high antiquity through middle antiquity to recent times: when rulers abandoned the Dao and virtue, exalted the qi of Metal, and employed military methods, their governance was entirely inauspicious, plagued by bandits, thieves, and omens of misfortune.

Therefore, the sages of high antiquity deeply understood the fixed patterns of Heaven and dared not govern by means of weapons, armor, or martial forces. If emperors and kings wish for long-lasting peace and good fortune, they should follow these celestial prognostics, swiftly restrain and abolish metal weapons and military preparations, and urgently promote the Dao and supreme virtue to emulate the patterns of Heaven, align with the will of August Heaven, and forever suppress all treacherous and inauspicious elements. The response will be immediate and unmistakable. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

The celestial prognostic patterns decree that though the Great Yang serves as the ruler, it paradoxically fears the Great Yin—the movement of Water. The purest and finest of waters is wine. Wine is the king of waters, its elder, the most excellent of all beverages, its qi aligned with the Kan position, governing theft and banditry by night. Thus, its name derives from "indulgent abandon," for as the king and elder of waters, when Water reigns, the Great Yang wanes.

Perfected One, if you wish to truly understand the veracity of celestial prognostics, observe this: from the highest antiquity through the middle ages, whenever rulers indulged in wine, none achieved great peace. Their governance turned to chaos, their officials engaged in constant strife, and bandits arose—this is the clear consequence. Therefore, when a virtuous sovereign governs in an era of Great Peace, the essence of Fire should shine brightly. One must not follow the Great Yin, allowing the power of Water to dominate and thereby suppress and harm the governance. Thus, wine must be prohibited.

Would you hear of the method of prohibition? Which wine should be banned? Simply the wine sold in markets. Now, Master, what have you seen or witnessed that compels you to ban only market wine? Indeed, the market corresponds to the movement of Water. Thus, people and goods from all four directions flow and gather there. The rivers and seas, too, are the kings and elders of waters, for all streams and wealth likewise flow and converge there. Water, being the movement of the Dark Warrior of the north, is inherently greedy, plundering others' wealth. The market, where goods from the five directions flow and gather for profit, gives rise to bandits, rogues, and treacherous elements—all governed by Kan, the Water trigram.

Heaven’s law operates through resonant correspondence by category. Thus, the market embodies the movement of Water. To indulge its wine is to amplify it further, once more crowning it as the king of waters. Market-dwellers, rejoicing in wine, also proclaim it king—this is a double reign of Water. The fault is sixfold: it suppresses the fiery qi of the Great Yang, causing the ruler’s governance to weaken and instead empowering treacherous ministers.

Have you, Perfected One, understood this? Now, seeing the Heavenly Master’s secret instructions, you are bewildered and do not comprehend—may I hear the great secret?

Excellent indeed are your words. Yet the various Perfected Ones have come from afar, inquiring of Heaven’s affairs, to resolve the harms of karmic inheritance for the virtuous lords, emperors, and kings. I shall withhold nothing.

Be seated in peace, and I shall distinguish and explain all for the Perfected Ones, expounding the essential meaning.

Very well.

The celestial prognostication’s secret instructions state: when gold and jade rise to prominence, affairs are governed by them. When the martial departments flourish greatly, the Wood qi is cut off at its root, and Earth gains sovereignty. When Earth is greatly exalted, it is the palace of the Grand Empress. Its qi belongs to the northwest, and when the Great Yin attains great sovereignty, it gives rise to treacherous ministers who act within the inner palace, losing their proper path and surging forth. When Earth rules, Metal becomes its minister, and together they surge upward in succession. The qi of *ji* and *xin* both attain sovereign flourishing, surging and rising greatly. According to Heaven’s standard laws, this breeds many treacheries in the inner palace—yet this is not the fault of the inner palace. Rather, it is called a failure in governance to align with celestial prognostication, a loss of the great departmental boundaries, causing disasters to return and overturn one another. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the cycles of celestial timing have not yet reached the point where the former masters could fully distinguish and explain the great departmental boundaries of Heaven. Thus, the emperor loses the governance of Heaven’s law, giving rise to these calamitous transformations.

Do you, Perfected One, deeply understand this?

Very well.
