Once they overpower another, grave punishment follows, and the authorities pursue them without cease. How then can you claim this is Heaven’s mandate? When a true king governs and subdues the people, would he ever be hunted and seized?

All people are born with the king as their lord and leader, as their destiny. Do you, Perfected One, not yet comprehend this?"

"I now fully understand."

"Excellent, excellent. Go forth, scholar, and refine your understanding. Do not recklessly raise difficult questions, for Heaven is not as men are."

"Yes, yes."

"You have erred, you have erred—do not act so. Be reverent and cautious, not like the common folk who speak whatever comes to mind."

"Yes, yes."

"When I, foolish as I am, speak, I often commit grave errors. Yet if I remain silent, I have no means to gain understanding. Now, if I have another question to ask, I dare not blurt it out at once."

"Speak freely."

"If each of the myriad things has its own lord and leader, do Heaven and Earth also have lords and leaders?"

"Ah! How profoundly subtle and far-reaching is your question. Now that you know your inquiry was not modest, you fear to ask the Heavenly Master directly, lest you remain forever ignorant.

Know then: Heaven takes the Central Ultimate, the highest of all, as its lord and leader. Earth takes Kunlun’s peak as its lord and leader. The sun takes the King Sun as its lord and leader. The moon takes the Great Moon as its lord and leader. The stars take the Central Ultimate Star as their lord and leader. The mountains take the Five Peaks as their lords and leaders, and the Five Peaks take Mount Tai, beneath the Central Ultimate, as their lord and leader. The hundred rivers take the Yangtze and the seas as their lords and leaders. Creatures with shells take the divine tortoise as their lord and leader. Those with scales take the dragon as their lord and leader. Winged creatures take the phoenix as their lord and leader. Beasts with fur take the qilin as their lord and leader. Naked creatures take humans as their lord and leader. And humans take the emperor as their lord and leader.

Such hierarchies in the world are too numerous to recount in full. I have merely outlined their essentials for you, Perfected One, to grasp their beginnings. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

You would do well to ponder deeply these principles, though they cannot all be committed to memory—such matters are not easily put to practical use.

"Yes, yes."

Now, consider the crawling creatures endowed with awareness: those whose nature lies within their own bodies, who accomplish their affairs without external prompting. Why should one recklessly kill or harm them? The concern is that it may provoke the wrath of their lord and leader.

In this era, as the qi of Great Peace arrives, one must join with a virtuous ruler to govern in harmony. To recklessly inflict harm disrupts the qi of Great Peace, throwing governance into chaos and confusion.

How could such petty beings possibly move Heaven to disorder its governance, causing such turmoil?

Alas, you remain as one benighted, still failing to grasp the greater truth. Every kind has its own lord and leader—just as the lowliest and most despised people in distant borderlands stand at the very bottom of the emperor’s domain, like ants or vile men, beyond all reckoning.

If, without cause, one were to murder or injure even a hundred or so of them, their families would cry out in grievance, petitioning the emperor. Upon hearing of it, the emperor would fly into a rage, issuing decrees to investigate and punish the offenders. Provinces, commanderies, and counties would be thrown into uproar, treating it as a grave matter. Many would be brought to ruin as a result—more than one.

Do you understand this?

How dreadful! How dreadful!

To act upon this, you shall know great awe—and thus attain long life.

Indeed, indeed.

Therefore, the sage-kings of antiquity, understanding that the celestial patterns and models were luminously clear, dared not recklessly employ punishments. Theirs was the utmost depth of thoughtful foresight.

Thus, their governance was ever balanced. Without expending force, they won the heart of Heaven—through their profound caution.

Yet when former kings made even slight errors, the consequences borne by later generations brought both gains and losses, making governance difficult to stabilize.

Do you understand this?

Indeed, indeed.

Now, as the qi of Great Peace arrives, Heaven cherishes the virtuous ruler. Thus, I set forth these admonitions in full, making it hard to transgress them.

Present my writings to the ruler of supreme virtue, that he may reflect upon his ill intentions.

Indeed, indeed.

*(Right: Compiled questions on the proper governance of things, each with its own lord and leader.)*

**Section One Hundred Thirty-Eight: The Secret of Yang’s Honor and Yin’s Humility**

I wish to ask: Why does Yang alone attain honor and esteem, while Yin is solely named lowly and base?

Excellent, your question! You nearly perceive the intent of the Dao and virtue.

Yang is called honored and esteemed because it guards its root, ever full and replete with substance.

Yin is called lowly and base because it is hollow and empty, lacking substance—thus it is despised and held in contempt.

Foolish beings, receiving meager and scant mandate from Heaven, are benighted and slow to awaken. I pray the Heavenly Master fully explain this meaning.

Why have you not fully grasped the intent of the Way of Heaven?

Even the Perfected remain unclear—how much more the common folk, sunk in darkness!

Now, the names Yin and Yang, male and female, arise from the primordial qi at its very inception—the gateway of Yin and Yang.

Where humans receive their mandate and life is their root.

Thus, the male receives his mandate full and overflowing, with surplus. Below and to his left and right, each still holds a kernel of substance.

Above, he is full and overflowing, ever bestowing. Below, Yin accumulates surplus, ever possessing substance.

The one above who bestows corresponds to the Great Yang and the movement of Heaven—nothing it cannot generate, nothing it cannot complete.

The one below who accumulates corresponds to the Great Yin, to Earth, with its patterns and veins, to the fields and paths.

The kernel on the left corresponds to humanity; the kernel on the right corresponds to the myriad things.

The kernel is the fruit’s core—thus, benevolence delights in giving, yet also possesses a kernel of substance.

Therefore, Yang is called honored and esteemed.

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

The Yin is woman, and why she is deemed lowly and base lies in the place where she receives her mandate: her gate is hollow and empty, without fullness or surplus, and moreover without kernel or substance—thus she is seen as lowly and base.

The fundamental names of Yin-Yang and male-female refer precisely to these two matters. As for the body’s upper and lower parts, though they bear no names in themselves, the fundamental name of Yin-Yang is distinguished by these two matters.

Consider the woman’s head, eyes, face, ears, and limbs—all are equal to the man’s. Her fondness for goodness may even surpass that of men, yet she is deemed lowly and base for this very reason. The man’s head, face, and limbs, his fondness for goodness not matching the woman’s, are yet called honored and esteemed precisely for this reason.

Excellent, excellent indeed. Thus you may be said to have awakened to this truth.

Therefore, the Dao of Heaven values the root and guards the origin. Thus the sage, observing the luminous patterns of Heaven, must return to the root and guard the primordial, rectifying characters and examining texts to resolve delusion.

Thus can Heaven and Earth be made enduringly secure, and the state know joy.

Therefore, to guard the root and possess substance, to delight in bestowing—this is the good person. The root being hollow and empty, without kernel or substance, ever insufficient yet fond of seeking—this is the evil person, the base person. This is the meaning.

Now I wish to ask one remaining doubt. Proceed with your words.

When a woman conceives and her womb bears fruit, yet the Heavenly Master says it is without substance—why is this?

Alas, your inner self is hollow and empty, somewhat resembling one who has lost the Dao. Yet Heaven sees your earnest and single-minded devotion, and so allows you to come and ask these matters.

Now, in a woman’s conception, the yin is fundamentally hollow and empty. Only when yang comes to bestow and transform does it take substance within yin. Yin, being lowly and submissive, fears yang and nourishes it obediently, not daring to cast it away.

Yang is Heaven, the ruler; yin is Earth, the minister. Thus, yin reveres and honors yang’s bestowal, nurturing it and not daring to abandon it.

If you wish to know its truth, compare it to a lord who entrusts a guest to a humble household. The household nourishes the guest and does not dare send him away, and so the guest grows robust and attains full stature—this is precisely the same principle.

The common saying that “yang generates and yin completes” means only that yin follows and nourishes, bringing yang’s substance to fruition. My writings often explain it in terms of nurturing—this is how it is.

I see that you, Perfected One, delight in knowing the kernel of the true Dao, the utmost essential meaning of Heaven. Therefore, I have spoken to you of its essentials.

Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Go on, you have awakened.

Now I wish to ask: only humans have male and female—can this distinguish the substance of yin and yang? Do all things between Heaven and Earth follow this pattern?

Alas, you remain as if deluded and uncomprehending. Excellent, Perfected One, your questioning is profound.

Now, the nature of Heaven and Earth applies to all things. Let me tell you one matter that penetrates from above to below.

You—if your words are not... go on, open both ears and listen, do not lose even a fraction.

Indeed, indeed.

Go on. When yang is outside, all things rise upward, conceiving and bearing fruit among the upper branches and leaves. At this time, Heaven’s yang qi is outside and has not yet returned to the roots below, so all things bear substance on the surface. Creeping creatures and the multitudes of people also gather outwardly.

When yang qi returns inward into the earth, all things above become empty and without substance, while those below conceive and bear fruit within the earth, nourishing roots and leaves. Creeping creatures and people also enter and gather inwardly.

This is the great and luminous proof by August Heaven of yang’s true substance.

Thus, those who hold to the Dao of yang possess substance, while those who guard the Dao of yin lack it.

Therefore, the sages of antiquity governed by emulating Heaven and never dared emulate Earth.

I wish to hear: what does it mean to emulate Heaven?

To emulate Heaven is to gather the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened scholars, the masters of Dao and arts, the sagely and wise—this is called emulating Heaven. To gather wealth and goods, petty men, the unworthy, and those ignorant of culture and refinement—this is called emulating Earth.

Excellent, excellent. I wish to hear: why do the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened scholars, and the masters of Dao and arts emulate Heaven?

Heaven is the benevolent, the worthy, the enlightened scholars, the masters of Dao and arts. Moreover, Heaven can ride the qi and fly—these six kinds of people, with their superior talents and unwavering devotion to the true Dao, may also attain the ability to ride the qi and fly. Thus, they belong to Heaven and emulate it.

Therefore, the sages of antiquity alone deeply understood the will of August Heaven and never dared stray from it.

I wish to hear: why does gathering wealth and goods, petty men, and the unworthy emulate Earth?

Now, wealth gathers below and forms mud, mud transforms into dung, and dung transforms into soil. Petty men, foolish and unworthy, are deaf and blind to the Dao and its arts. They enter inauspicious gates and are fated to dwell early beneath the earth. If they are not buried, in time they become deeply harmful to Heaven and Earth. Governing with them brings chaos to the patterns of Heaven and Earth, the Five Phases contend daily, the four seasons lose their order, the Three Luminaries dim, Heaven and Earth detest them, and the hundred spirits do not love them. They contribute nothing to proper governance and should meet an early end—this is the nature of wealth.

Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed. How terrifying! How terrifying!

Do you understand what is terrifying? This may be called the path to long preservation. Those who do not early grasp what is terrifying bring grave fault upon Heaven and Earth. The foolish and unworthy deeply fear this. If you understand and fear this celestial law, Heaven will preserve your life. If you do not revere and fear it, you share the same principle as the unworthy.

Fortune and misfortune are not originally Heaven’s transgressions—they are what people seek for themselves. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed. Go forth, and be ever vigilant. Indeed, indeed.

*(Here concludes the collection of essential distinctions between male and female, the root of honor and baseness, yin and yang, the kernel of the noble and the petty.)*

**One Hundred and Thirty-Ninth Secret of the Innumerable Secrets of the Realm**

I venture to ask one matter. Let the Way be made level. I wish to hear: how many states exist in the world?

Profound! Wondrous! This is what you ask. Now, the central region comprises eighty-one domains. Beyond it, encircling once more, the world holds ten thousand states. Extending further to the boundless void, the three regions together number twelve thousand states.

Why are there twelve thousand states? The celestial reckoning begins with one and ends with ten. Ten multiplied yields the Way of Heaven, which reaches five and then returns. Thus it arrives at ten thousand states. The two thousand additional states correspond to the alternating reckoning of yin and yang, akin to the completion of a count by tens. The reckoning of years and months is uniquely twelve, with an intercalary month added every five years. This reflects the cyclical arising of Heaven and Earth. Beyond the boundless void of Heaven, it accords with the combined reckoning of Heaven and Earth. Thus twelve months return and merge into one year, with intercalation inserted within.

These twelve months are the reckoning of the primordial qi in its obscure darkness, the alternating inception of yin and yang. It is like all things ending in death at *hai* (亥), while *qian* (乾) establishes its initial position at the Gate of Heaven, congealing its kernel. At *hai*, it conceives; at *ren* (壬), it takes form. The first nine at *zi* (子), the sun begins its return; the second nine at *chou* (丑), yin and yang revolve; the third nine at *yin* (寅), Heaven, Earth, and humanity—all things—turn from yin toward yang, gazing toward *yin*. Thus all things first spread their roots in the northeast and show their heads at *yin*. The greatest of things take wood as their chief. Thus *yin* is the inception of wood, and *jia* (甲) is the very beginning of wood. Therefore, all things appear at *jia-yin* and end in death at *gui-hai* (癸亥).

Thus wood receives its mandate and life from the primordial qi within the Great Yin’s water. Hence *jia-zi* (甲子) is taken as the initial beginning. The celestial reckoning of change multiplies by five in its cycles. Thus five thousand, added to the twelve earthly branches, arrives precisely at *gui-hai* (癸亥), the completion of the reckoning. Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

You have not yet grasped its meaning. Now, wandering in blindness, ponder it long and deeply—you will come to understand. Go, reflect upon it.

Why, Perfected One, do you persist in asking how many states exist in the world? This foolish student has received the Heavenly Master’s scriptures, which speak of repaying Heaven and Earth’s profound merit, healing the ailments of Heaven and Earth, and relieving the accumulated disasters and calamities that have befallen the world since the establishment of all affairs under Heaven and Earth for a virtuous and sagely emperor.

Now, the Heavenly Master’s writings on the unified Dao are entrusted to a single virtuous state. Yet even if the ruler of that state possessed the virtue of ten thousand men, how could he alone resolve the boundless interplay of yin and yang or dispel the disasters of Heaven and Earth? How could he traverse and govern both the inner and outer realms of Heaven and Earth, cutting off the deep and distant maladies of the limitless cosmos?

Ah, how excellent! Has Heaven sent you to ask this? Alas, how astonishing! Alas, how astonishing! I wished to remain silent, but now I fear that if I die without speaking, I will have failed to remove this burden from you. Perfected One, how did you come to ask such a question?

This foolish student, having received the Heavenly Master’s teachings and commands, returned to ponder their meaning in solitude. Where I found incomprehension, I asked. Yet you speak only of resolving the calamities of a single virtuous ruler’s state—why do you ask thus?

If the Heavenly Master’s writings merely resolve the disasters of one virtuous state, it would be called healing only that single land. How then could it heal the ailments of Heaven and Earth or repay the august Heaven’s profound merit?

Excellent indeed are your words—I have nothing to add. Perfected One, pray explain your meaning.

Now, the Heavenly Master speaks of the vast and empty cosmos containing twelve thousand states. If only one virtuous state receives the Dao, how could it resolve the disasters of all twelve thousand states and bring peace to Heaven and Earth as a whole?

Excellent are your words. Have you truly been sent by the Master to ask this?

"Very well. Now I shall explain in full for the Perfected One, that it may be made clear and all maladies of the world may be eradicated. I stand in awe of Heaven’s majesty and dare not conceal anything—record my words with diligence."

"Yes, yes."

"Observe: the celestial reckoning begins with one and ends with ten. One multiplied by ten is ten; ten multiplied by ten reaches one hundred; one hundred multiplied by ten reaches one thousand; one thousand multiplied by ten reaches ten thousand. One is the beginning of all numbers; ten is their end. One hundred represents the virtuous states and regions.

You need only take my writings and bestow them upon a single state of great virtue. Those who transmit my writings shall carry the original forth without exhaustion, circulating it to the hundred virtuous regions. When one state receives my writings, that state prospers, and its people all turn toward it. Its virtue then spreads to the four directions, and the hundred states all receive its transformative influence, becoming good. Thus, Heaven and Earth are both pacified, and disasters are eliminated. By bestowing it upon the hundred virtuous states, the ten thousand states will suffer no harm, and the ailments of Heaven and Earth will be wholly dispelled."

"Excellent, excellent! I wish to know why you do not instruct the foolish and ignorant as well."

"The reason they cannot be instructed in the same way is that states lacking virtue are those Heaven has doomed and forsaken—they cannot practice the true Dao. Thus, the teachings are directed only to the virtuous states. Now, when the virtueless states all turn toward the virtuous ones, they too will naturally be governed aright."

"Excellent, excellent! I wish to know why you take precisely these hundred virtuous states as the model."

"Excellent indeed is your question—you have grasped the meaning. The reckoning of Heaven, Earth, and humanity begins with one and ends with ten. Heaven’s numbers unfold upon the Earth and give rise to life; when the reckoning is complete, it emerges as one hundred. Only when Heaven, Earth, and humanity are all present, when the three unite in a single heart, is virtue achieved. If any one matter is discordant, virtue cannot be realized.

I wish to know why Heaven’s number begins precisely with one."

"One is the time when primordial qi is utterly pure. Primordial qi coalesces without division—like wind, it has no seams—thus it is called one. When one congeals, it forms Heaven, which encompasses the eight directions above and below, hence the number ten. There are also the five directions, each with its own yin and yang, thus the number ten. Below, it corresponds to Earth. When Earth’s reckoning aligns with ten, life is generated. Thus, humans mirror Heaven’s numbers, being born after ten months. One is precisely the time of harmonious and boundless bestowal. Those who have received this bestowal must in turn mirror Heaven’s reckoning, emerging after ten months—thus the number ends at ten. Therefore, one is multiplied by ten.

The Way of Earth is the mother. At the time of *yu*, it joins in harmony with humanity. When Heaven, Earth, and humanity are mutually attuned, virtue is achieved—hence the hundred virtuous states. Thus, Heaven governs generation, Earth governs nurturance, and humanity governs completion. If any one matter strays from rectitude, all three fall into error. Therefore, when Heaven acts wickedly, it brings calamity; when Earth acts wickedly, it brings calamity; when humanity acts wickedly, it brings calamity. When all three act wickedly together, Heaven, Earth, and humanity are destroyed, and the reckoning begins anew. When all three act with goodness, their virtue pervades the void in perfect unity—thus, when the three unite, virtue is achieved, corresponding to the hundred states."

"Excellent, excellent! This is the guiding principle of the ten thousand states, the realm where Heaven, Earth, and humanity unite in virtue. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

Thus, the Perfected One has now eradicated the afflictions of Heaven and Earth and removed the inherited burdens of the Virtuous Lord. Though you have diligently upheld my scriptures and transmitted them to the hundred virtuous states, all maladies of yin and yang have vanished, and the disasters of emperors and kings have all been eliminated.

Excellent, excellent! Foolish students in the past did not inquire with sufficient effort, and thus had no means to comprehend this. Your words are correct: those who study but do not inquire earnestly are no different from those who do not study at all. Therefore, the learning of the ancient sages and worthies involved questioning their teachers day and night without daring to slacken. Thus, they came to understand the Dao of Heaven.

Yes, yes. Truly, one must inquire with effort and dare not grow lax. In this way, you have already grasped the Dao.

I wish to ask: today, the customs of the world vary—if one were to teach and instruct them with a single Dao, would there be no doubt?

Alas! Your words on this matter reveal even greater foolishness and benighted ignorance. Why is this so? The so-called customs and rites of today are but false conduct, not their true nature. All people under Heaven receive the nature of Heaven and Earth, with the Five Phases as their inner treasuries and the four seasons as their qi. They harmonize with yin and yang to propagate their kind, all delighting in life and abhorring death, nourishing their bodies with food and drink, loving goodness and detesting evil—there is no difference among them. When there are those who do not understand the Perfected One’s scriptures and fail to comprehend, at the time of instruction, the Perfected One should employ their local language and customary teachings, adapting to their customs so that people may exert themselves to remember. In this way, all under Heaven will know how to apply it without doubt.

My Dao is like the sun and moon, circulating and illuminating all under Heaven, each speaking with radiant clarity, vast and luminous in its sufficiency. If you wish to further verify its truth, compare it to the myriad creatures that crawl and move, all sharing one Heaven and Earth, the Six Jia, the Five Phases, and the four seasons—these are more than sufficient. Thus, all are taught and shown through the standards of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang.

Do you understand?

Yes, yes.

Go forth, and if difficulties do not cease, then explanations will have no end. Now the great scriptures of the Dao, on the contrary, are difficult to grasp in meaning.

Yes, yes.

I wish to ask one more question and then stop. Speak.

Now, regarding these twelve thousand states, how should one regard them?

This is all within the reckoning, like intercalary months. If you wish to know its truth, compare it to counting: ten makes a complete cycle, and a year returns to twelve months before it ends, yet sometimes there is a thirteenth month inserted—this is what it means. If but a hundred states practice the Dao and virtue, then the ten thousand states will be free of disaster, and the ailments of Heaven and Earth will be entirely exhausted—this too is included in the reckoning.

Excellent, excellent! If you exert yourself to circulate my scriptures among the hundred states of virtue, allowing each to expound my writings according to their customs, then the twelve thousand states will all be at peace, the ailments of Heaven and Earth will be greatly dispelled, and your years will increase without limit. If you bring peace to a few, you will gain a few years; if to half, you will gain half a year’s extension; if to all, you will gain boundless years.

Since you, Perfected One, have such good intentions, Heaven has enabled you to ask fully—this is fitting, and you need not overburden yourself. The utmost limit of Heaven is numinous and luminous, without superior, yet it still practices the Dao with diligence, circling once each day to bring peace to all things. Thus, it alone attains constant fortune and long life. Earth likewise follows Heaven’s actions and nurtures all things. If Heaven were to cease its movement for a single day, the sun, moon, and stars would not shift, and there would be an imbalance of qi—Heaven would then be destroyed. Since Heaven does not dare cease its practice of the Dao, it attains long life—how much more should you?

Strive, each bending effort for your own sake, for you cannot do so for others. My ceaseless explanations are also for my own sake, not for yours. All within the six directions, all the myriad restless beings, each calculates for their own body and cannot do so for others.

Do you understand?

Yes, yes.

I have received the teachings of the Heavenly Master and had them recorded by the virtuous kingdoms, never daring to grow lax. In practice, you have already understood this.

All of you, strive, strive—once your tasks are complete, we shall follow one another.

Yes, yes.

As I prepare to depart, I wish to ask one matter.

What is it?

Now, the six of us return to our quiet dwellings, reflecting together upon the Heavenly Master’s words. At times, we seem to grasp them profoundly; at other times, confusion and distraction arise, yet we remain unwavering. We wish to present our doubts to the Heavenly Master for resolution.

I have pondered repeatedly whether to trouble the Heavenly Master, wishing to restrain myself from speaking. Yet I fear that if I part from you, I may pass the remainder of my years without ever again gaining such understanding. Thus, I overcome my shame and venture to ask once more.

Proceed.

Heaven has arranged for me to meet and speak with the six of you—do not decline.

Yes, yes.

Now, I wish to ask: among the kingdoms under Heaven, are there only twelve thousand?

Are there more?

Ah, how profound is your question! Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, there has never been such a reckoning. Yet these twelve thousand kingdoms are but one great division. What boundless limits could the rest possibly have?

Why are they so numerous?

Ah, your question this morning reveals the utmost depth of inquiry, yet now you turn back, lost in darkness—how foolish! Truly, you do not yet comprehend. Observing your disciples’ queries, I see that you have not yet fully grasped the Dao of Heaven. Just now, you seemed on the verge of understanding, yet inwardly, you remain distant.

The common people, lost in confusion and chaos, are naturally so. Compared to them, you are true persons—I do not fault you. Yet let me open your ears further and explain for the six of you.

Heaven extends upward and downward without limit, and its lateral expanse knows no bounds. Wherever it converges, it forms a division, a realm—how could it have any end?

I wish to hear: where does the uppermost limit of Heaven lie? What exists beyond it? And where does it find its ultimate cessation? Where does the lowermost limit of Earth lie? What exists beneath it? And where does it find its central cessation?

Where does the lateral expanse of Heaven and Earth end? Why does it turn back upon itself, reaching its limit?

These six directions—where do they find their ultimate bounds?

Thus, the Dao of Heaven is without end. In great use, it is precisely sufficient; in small use, it is precisely sufficient. In great use, there is surplus; in small use, there is surplus.

Do you true persons comprehend this?

Yes, yes.

Alas, how startling! Alas, how startling! Had you not pressed the question with such vigor, there would have been no way to attain this knowledge. Yet you may be said to have glimpsed a small awakening. Go now—do not pursue this inquiry to its end. I fear the Six Perfected Ones would be startled and undone. To force questions beyond one’s capacity is to invite great harm.

Yet those who would be teachers face many difficulties. Seeing your distress, I shall clarify further for you. Go, and listen with open ears. Be seated and attend. Very well.

You wish to delight in knowing its great efficacy. Consider this: a single household has father, mother, and child—just as the Dao of Heaven completes a household. The father is likened to Heaven, the mother to Earth, the child to the harmonious center. Their gathered possessions, all that the household contains, are like the myriad things—together, they form one family. The father is as the ruler, the mother as the minister, the child as the people. Wealth and goods circulate to nourish one another, sharing as the myriad things do. This one household shares one great concern.

A single district of ten thousand households likewise forms one family, sharing one great concern. Ten districts unite to form a commandery—one family, one great concern. Ten commanderies unite to form a great province—one family, one great concern. Ten provinces unite to form a great state—one great family, one great concern, and one great realm.

When the emperor’s virtue is abundant, his concern extends to twelve provinces; when vast, it reaches thirteen provinces. Together, they form one great family, sharing one great concern. Beyond these borders lie distant lands not subject to human rule. If those lands possess the Dao and virtue, their good people come to the human realm; if they lack virtue, they do not come. If their virtue is inferior, they come to harm others.

This is one division, one realm—the demarcation of Heaven and Earth. It ensures that the restless multitudes of the world each have their place and do not prey upon one another.

Thus, what is meant by the Great Ultimate, the Central Ultimate, and the Lesser Ultimate? The Great Ultimate governs what lies beyond all external bounds. The Central Ultimate governs the central region. The Lesser Ultimate ensures that each responds to its own realm and ceases there. They may seek one another through the Dao and virtue, but they must not greatly prey upon one another. Heaven resents this—hence, they are called one family, sharing one great concern.

Do you wish to know its truth? Consider a household of father, son, and wife: they worry only that their own family may not prosper and do not concern themselves with other households. A single district shares concern for its ruler—if he is good, they promote him to higher office, each striving to advance their local officials; if he is evil, they wish to remove him together. A district, a commandery, a province, a state—all follow this principle, sharing one great concern.

Now, it is recorded that twelve thousand states form one great division, sharing one great concern with the Perfected Ones. One realm—yet beyond it, realms like these twelve thousand states are beyond counting.

Thus, the works of the sages of old all recorded but one small division. Why did they not record the great realms? Heaven did not permit it to be spoken. The great transformation had not yet emerged; what was made differed, and could not follow the same pattern—thus, it was not recorded.

Now, the great transformation has emerged. The twelve thousand states have completed their cyclical revolutions, and so Heaven has sent the Perfected Ones to inquire into the scripture of the boundless and the governance of the all-penetrating. Thus, the text is entrusted to the one hundred states possessing virtue. One virtuous state transforms ninety-nine others. The twelve thousand states are counted together—like a year of twelve months, with the thirteenth month as an intercalary addition. This is what is meant.

Do you understand? Very well.

Go forth.

Very well. Guard the divine numina of Heaven’s Dao with reverence; do not recklessly destroy or disorder them.

Very well. Now that you have received the solemn mandate of the Heavenly Illuminated Master, though your awakening be slight and partial, you have come to know one great division. You wish to hear of one small realm—to be shown and told of this boundless land?

So be it. The Perfected One speaks to you with restrained words; record them carefully.

Now, if I were to command the Perfected One to amass wealth and resources—pillars reaching up to the sun and moon of Heaven, pillars reaching down to the earth, spanning ten thousand *li* in breadth and length—I fear that even with such boundless wealth and resources, one would still suffer from constant scarcity and hardship, and thus be unable to record the names and numbers of all these lands.

Do you understand?

Very well. This foolish student dares not press further on the Dao of Heaven. Having heard the words of the Heavenly Master, I am now as if bereft of *qi*, as if my soul has fled—I dare not ask again.

Yet you may be called one who comprehends affairs. If you wish to repay the profound merit of Heaven and Earth, and to receive the mandate of the boundless, simply traverse this one great division of the twelve thousand states, and your lifespan shall already be without limit.

As for the six directions above and below, which penetrate all extremes—Heaven does not task the Six Masters alone with their care. Those who bear this concern belong to another realm, not yours; nor will you be held accountable or punished for what lies beyond your charge. Their safety or peril, their good or ill, are governed by others.

The discourse on this division is now complete. Do not ask further.

Very well.

Go forth. Strive diligently, you Six Masters—let the Perfected One study to attain minor understanding, though the great intent of the Dao of Heaven remains yet unseen. Apply yourselves with unflagging focus.

Very well.

To study without precision is no different from madness; to be precise yet fail to grasp the truth is to be mute and deaf, pointing west while asking about the east. Thus do the masters of the world engage in ceaseless debate—why this clamor? Though clamor there may be, it profits nothing, for they remain as those who know not how to compare.

Like an infant still swaddled, unemerged from the womb, following its mother’s body in movement—how could it know the vastness and boundlessness of the Dao of Heaven? Therefore, lesser masters, in their stubborn anger, delight in reckless discourse, only to wound the Dao of Heaven and Earth. They lose the intent of the Dao, unable to bring peace to their lords and kings. The world is thrown into turmoil, all bearing the weight of their errors, their words diverging wildly. Disasters and calamities spread unchecked, beyond restraint or prevention.

Though texts may number in the billions upon billions, the world’s flowing misfortunes and harms never cease, ever repeating the same patterns—all born of forced interpretations, of failing to grasp the essentials of the Dao.

Does the Perfected One understand?
Very well.

Go on, I would fully explain it to you as your child, yet it would never end, straining resources and proving too burdensome—so I pause here briefly. If doubts remain, return to ask again.
Yes, yes.

*Here concludes the collection of disputations, transmissions of scriptural secrets, and the division of teachings among the states.*

**Reverently Serving the Spirits: Fifteen-Year Great Peace Secret, Scroll One Hundred Forty**

I humbly request to ask one matter.
Speak plainly.
Now that the heavens bestow Great Peace, can it be foreknown?
Yes, it can be known.
When the qi of the Five Thearchs’ spirits attains Great Peace, that year will be one of joyous harmony.
What does this mean?
I wish to hear it.
Thus: in spring, when the qi of the Green Thearch’s spirit is at peace; in summer, when the qi of the Red Thearch’s spirit is at peace; in the sixth month, when the qi of the Yellow Thearch’s spirit is at peace; in autumn, when the qi of the White Thearch’s spirit is at peace; in winter, when the qi of the Black Thearch’s spirit is at peace.
How is this made clear?
Great Peace means that not a single thing is harmed—this is the essence of the qi of Great Peace. In all matters, if not a single thing is injured or afflicted, all things find their proper place, and thus it is called *peace*. If one thing is harmed, it is immediately unpeaceful. If two things are harmed, it is immediately subject to punishment. If three things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to all things. If four things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to the four directions. If five things are harmed, it is immediately a harm to the five directions, and the world suffers great calamity. If six things are harmed, it is immediately an evil that pervades the six directions. If seven things are harmed, its baleful qi spreads unchecked. If eight things are harmed, it immediately causes the worthy and the unworthy to hold divergent plans and fail to unite their strength. If nine things are harmed, it immediately brings evil to its ultimate conclusion in yin and yang, causing things to churn in chaos. If ten things are harmed, it is a harm to the great net, and the celestial reckoning is exhausted, giving way to a new count.
Thus, the sages of antiquity simply observed clearly whether the qi of the Five Thearchs’ spirits was at peace or not, and thereby knew whether governance was successful or failing, whether peace had been achieved or not.
I wish to hear the meaning of the peace secret.
Thus: when all things in spring are born without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Green Thearch. When all things in summer grow without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Red Thearch. In the sixth month, when all things are nurtured without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Yellow Thearch. In autumn, when all things reach maturity and are harvested without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the White Thearch. In winter, when all things are stored without a single harm, it is the Great Peace of the Black Thearch.
When the Five Thearchs attain Great Peace for one year, the people rejoice and act with goodness and compliance. For two years, the earth above is filled with great joy. For three years, grace and favor reach their culmination in heaven. For four years, the winds and qi flow in harmony. For five years, the Nine Spirits do not war, and pernicious evils are subdued and destroyed. For six years, the Six Norms are fully established. For seven years, the Three Luminaries grow brighter. For eight years, grace reaches the eight directions. For nine years, yin and yang are both pleased. For ten years, the myriad things each find their proper place. This completes the lesser cycle of reckoning, and when things are thrice united, heaven, earth, and humanity are complete—thus, in thirty years, Great Peace is achieved.
Now, the qi of the Supreme Thearch emerges, and the true Dao arrives to govern, so in fifteen years, Great Peace is attained. If one does not vigorously practice the true Dao, how can Great Peace be idly achieved?
This fifteen-year attainment of Great Peace refers to the emperor and his ministers, great and small, who follow the true Dao, jointly dispelling falsehood and deceit—thus, in fifteen years, peace is achieved.
Does the Perfected One understand?
Therefore, to know whether peace is coming or not, simply observe whether the spirits of the Five Thearchs are at peace or not—this is sufficient for clarity, sufficient for self-knowledge.
Thus, all omens first appear among the celestial spirits. If the celestial spirits are not at peace, how can humanity alone claim peace?
Therefore, as the Five Thearchs take turns governing, each can bring about Great Peace. Those who lose the intent of the celestial spirits cannot bring peace to their governance.
Thus, one must carefully follow the four seasons, be prudent with the five phases, and not allow the Nine Spirits to war. Therefore, one must revere their conduct and serve their spirits.
Now, the first and supreme qi of peace is about to arrive, so I teach the Perfected One to revere the four seasons and five phases, causing the great and small to rise together and serve the affairs of the spirits.
In antiquity, they merely revered the four seasons and five phases, so Great Peace came slowly, in thirty years. Now, by also revering the spirits, it comes swiftly, in fifteen years.
Does the Perfected One understand?
Yes, yes.

Alas! Alas! Yet you have awakened.
I humbly ask: If a person’s conduct is loyal and upright with true substance, can this be known?
Excellent is your question.
In associating with them, if their words and deeds daily appear harsh and resentful, yet people long remember them, and what was once monthly good becomes monthly harsh, or what was monthly harsh becomes yearly good—if in youth their actions seem most wicked, yet in old age they become most virtuous—if all turn to their words, delight in their conduct, and cherish their Dao, this is one of utmost loyalty, trustworthiness, and supreme goodness, a person of true substance.
Excellent, excellent indeed.

I humbly ask further: Can one who is disloyal, untrustworthy, and deceitful in conduct also be known?
Yes, this too can be known.
In associating with them, observe their words and deeds: if daily and monthly they align with others’ hearts, appearing compliant and good, yet what was long remembered and employed becomes monthly more wicked, or what was monthly good becomes yearly wicked—if in youth they seem good, their words loyal and trustworthy, yet in old age what they do and recall becomes most wicked—this is pure deceit and flattery, the conduct of one who is disloyal and untrustworthy. As they grow old, their words and deeds are exposed, and they become most base. Calamity befalls their wife and children, and misfortune flows to later generations.
Excellent, excellent indeed.

**Method of Disasters from Matching Words but Not Deeds, One Hundred Forty-First**

Since the Highest Antiquity and Middle Ages, many have matched their words but not their deeds, thus inviting disasters, harms, illnesses, and accumulated misfortunes that cannot be dispelled—thereby bringing ruin upon themselves.

Therefore, I reverently received this Dao from Heaven, matching trustworthiness and sincerity, not empty words. Those who grasp and practice the Dao in my writings—though people of later ages may daily say, "This Dao is of no benefit," yet month by month it proves good; though they may monthly say it is of no benefit, yet year by year it proves good; though they may yearly say it is of no benefit, yet even in old age it remains constantly good, enduring without departure—later generations will take it as the learning of their age.

Those who do not practice swiftly know only the long, solitary suffering of their own time. Thus, I instruct and command the Perfected Ones to be ever diligent and earnest.

The Dao emerges for those of virtue and power: whether first or last, none are uniquely favored or closely bound to me—I receive them equally. Therefore, whoever obtains it and strives to practice it is that person; there is no distinction between one and another.

Do you understand?
Yes, yes.

Proceed: The Way of Heaven is impartial, returning to humanity; the power of Earth is unbiased, bestowed upon the careful. Among the people, there is no precedence or delay—only love for those of true trustworthiness.

Thus, the ancient emperors and kings had palaces and dwellings to employ those of virtue and power, not idle ministers without merit. Those of virtue and power are beloved by Heaven and Earth and can assist emperors and kings in pacifying the myriad things. Those without virtue and power are resented by Heaven and Earth, thieves of yin and yang.

How weighty is this?
Are you still so foolish?

Indeed, those without virtue and power—whose conduct is boundless—go against Heaven and Earth, thus becoming their adversaries; they disrupt yin and yang, thus becoming their thieves.

Do you understand?
Yes, yes.

Go forth, ask no more—good and evil are plain to see.
Yes, yes.

Go, for you are troubled; let me now distinguish and explain the conduct of the ancients.
People each day claim to be kind and well-versed in affairs, yet their actions betray them—monthly virtue turns to evil.
Month by month, each claims to have done good, to have betrayed no trust in Heaven, yet year after year they meet with disaster, misfortune, and untimely death.
In youth, all declare themselves virtuous, even surpassing their fathers and mothers in worth; yet as they age, not a single good deed remains—those once deemed worthy become the unworthy, poor and base, their days few, none knowing the true Dao.

Thus, in this later age, good and evil, worthy and unworthy, are revealed—why boast of virtue and understanding?
Observe the signs, and you shall know for yourself; you may discern truth from falsehood. Why argue further? The matter is already settled.

The Perfected One presents these written words to awaken them, lest they remain lost in eternal delusion, becoming Heaven and Earth’s greatest adversaries.

Go now; my words here are briefly concluded. If later you have doubts, return and we shall discuss them together.
Yes, yes.

*Here concludes the collected difficult questions on the "Tai Ping Decisions Regarding Sincere and Deceptive Conduct in Human Affairs."*
*Thus ends Scroll Ninety-Three of the Scripture of Great Peace.*
*Thus ends Scroll Ninety-Six of the Scripture of Great Peace.*

The One Hundred Fifty-First Decision on the Six Ultimates and Six Culminations of Filial Piety, Obedience, and Loyalty

Perfected One, you and I have long recorded my words and received the texts of the Heavenly Dao—could we have exhausted their vast divisions and boundaries? How many divisions does my Dao possess? What constitutes its ultimate? What constitutes its great culmination? Within these texts lies the Dao: the Six Ultimates and Six Culminations.

Foolish student, I now speak of this, yet you do not know what the Six Ultimates and Six Culminations are. Alas! Your foolishness remains unopened, and your learning, though earnest, has not yet attained true refinement. Thus, you do not comprehend the Dao’s utmost reach. You have failed your Heavenly Master, and this fault cannot be absolved.

Do not take offense. The Perfected One reproaches himself—how weighty is this matter!

Foolish student, I have heard: if a child is unfilial, they cannot exhaust their strength in nourishing their parents; if a disciple is disobedient, they cannot exhaust their strength in illuminating their master’s Dao; if a minister is disloyal, they cannot exhaust their strength in reverently serving their lord. Failing in these three practices brings an ineradicable sin. Heaven and Earth detest them, ghosts and spirits harm them, and all people despise them. Even in death, their guilt lingers beneath the earth, for they are known as the unruly child of the three unvirtuous practices. Each month’s end and new moon’s dawn, they stand before Heaven, where the spirits who govern the rectification of yin and yang—those who uphold the order of honor and humility—cause their hun and po to grieve until their annihilation is complete.

Thus, knowing your lack of refinement, you bear an unabsolved transgression against your master.

Excellent, excellent!

Whence did you receive these words?" "I received them from my former master." "Moreover, this foolish student once glimpsed the Celestial Master expounding them. Having received the Celestial Master’s teachings, I beheld the celestial patterns and saw that Heaven and Earth are the parents of the four seasons and five phases. If the four seasons and five phases do not exhaust their strength in supplying what Heaven and Earth desire to generate, they become unfilial children, and the year yields scant good things, becoming an inauspicious year. People, too, are children of Heaven and Earth; if they do not diligently nurture what Heaven and Earth produce, they are called unfilial children.

Thus, those who favor the use of punishments cause their states to be constantly disordered, imperiled, and ruined. The myriad things follow the four seasons and five phases in their decline and flourishing, growing and nurturing themselves—they are their disciples. If they cannot exhaust their strength in following the seasonal qi to grow, mature, and reach their end, they become disobedient disciples, and the year’s things are harmed. People, instead, blame the seasonal qi for disharmony, compounding the transgression of the seasons.

The people are the disciples of the sages and worthies. Now, foolish disciples recklessly steal and forcibly expound, causing sages and worthies to bear fault—this is called collectively disrupting and rebelling against the Dao of Heaven. Their sin is most grave and cannot be pardoned. Thus, this foolish student’s transgressions remain unabsolved.

Wind and rain are the loyal ministers of Heaven and Earth. Receiving Heaven’s mandate, they jointly circulate qi and distribute moisture. If they fail to harmonize and equalize, causing the world to be uneven, it is like a minister receiving the mandate of an emperor or king, turning against superiors and toward inferiors, using their intentions without balance. Many ministers together act disloyally and deceptively, collectively deceiving their superiors, causing the world to be turbulent with frequent disputes and the state’s governance to be imperiled and disordered.

These three matters—children being unfilial, disciples being disobedient, and ministers being disloyal—are sins that admit no pardon. Heaven detests them intensely, Earth loathes them deeply, regarding them as great affairs and grave calamities. Ghosts and spirits severely condemn them, thus they are the most vile and base conduct.

Alas! A perfected one long possessing wisdom yet feigning foolishness causes me to recklessly expound, speaking beyond what Heaven and Earth would allow. What I have said does not compare to what you have just uttered, which is profound and far-reaching. This foolish student’s thoughts have now reached this point, and I can say no more. Great humility—yet even this does not err. To be lowly yet not humble is also a grave transgression.

"Indeed, indeed, I dare not, I dare not."

Thus, this foolish student, as a disciple, cannot clarify the boundaries of the master’s Dao. Knowing my transgressions are grave, I expound upon the celestial patterns to reproach myself.

"Excellent are your words! I, too, have nothing to add. Now, comparing your words to mine, you have already understood yourself. The boundaries of the written teachings are indeed beyond my reach. Yet if you truly fall short, I will provide a detailed explanation for you, arranging them in order with distinct boundaries, so that they may never be forgotten for ten thousand generations.

Now, the perfected one speaks of the three disobedient and unrefined practices, saying that hun and po appear for judgment—this is most ingenious. From whom did you receive this oral teaching? It is like the Celestial Master recounting matters from the former master, who himself spoke of the admonitions of the perfected ones of high antiquity. This foolish student, upon hearing these words, also saw them in the Celestial Master’s written texts, thus confirming them again.

When this foolish student questioned the perfected ones of high antiquity, I was uncertain and had doubts. Yet the words of the perfected ones of high antiquity are correct—I have nothing to add. Now, I wish to ask the Celestial Master about this meaning.

Proceed, listen clearly.

Thus, at the end of the month and the end of the year, not only do the hun and po of those who were unfilial, disobedient, and disloyal in life appear for judgment, but so do the spirits of Heaven and Earth. Heaven takes fifteen days as a minor boundary, so the moon reaches its fifteenth day and then slightly recedes. A month is taken as a middle boundary, and a year as a great boundary.

All the spirits and essences between Heaven and Earth together assist Heaven in generating, nurturing, and maturing the twelve thousand things, thus all spirits and essences receive their emoluments. It is like many worthy ministers assisting the emperor or king in nurturing and maturing the common people and the myriad things, all receiving their emoluments.

Thus, following Heaven’s model, there is a minor reckoning every fifteen days, a middle reckoning every month, and a great reckoning every year. Those with great merit are promoted and elevated; those without merit are demoted and dismissed, completing the governance. Those who disrupt governance are the perverse and evil spirits.

The perverse and evil spirits act accordingly, so the hun and po of those who were unvirtuous in life appear together for judgment. The hun and po of good people refuse to serve them. Thus, the hun and po of those who were rebellious, unfilial, disobedient, and disloyal serve them, collectively disrupting Heaven’s patterns and defiling Heaven’s governance. Therefore, the evil spirits are seized and governed, and their guests are also seized and governed. It is like rebellious and evil ministers committing outrages, so that their guests also bear guilt—this is what is meant.

Excellent, excellent! This foolish student now understands."

Thus, while alive, as a child one must be filial, as a subject one must be loyal, and as a disciple one must be obedient. When filial piety, loyalty, and obedience never leave one’s person, then after death the hun, po, spirit, and essence will not be summoned for judgment.

Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

How astonishing! How astonishing! Now, only through the Celestial Master’s gracious compassion, revealing the celestial patterns in their fullness, do I dare not abandon the Way midway. I only wish to be shown the written decrees and the boundaries of the departments’ reach.

The general outline of your question I shall still answer. Were I not to speak, it would be called begrudging the study of the Dao’s work, halting its transmission, and thus incurring Heaven’s displeasure.

Very well. Let the Six Perfected Ones be seated at ease, and I shall distinguish them for you. Their departments number six in all, belonging to one great collection.

Those who guard the One follow their kind, and from ancient times to the present, those who guard the One share great commonality in their texts. The greatly worthy, upon seeing my writings, guard and practice them without ceasing. By refining them, they grasp their essential meaning—those who study in youth may become filial children, those who study in maturity may become loyal subjects, and those who study until old age, never ceasing or slackening, may all attain deliverance from the world.

There are yet further refinements: if one practices without cessation, one may even penetrate the six directions and eight limits. When all affairs are complete, what could be lacking? Above, one may then assist the virtuous Imperial Lords, together stabilizing Heaven and Earth. Their grace descends to reach even the grasses and trees. All things in the teeming multitude are thus brought to perfect order.

Heaven and Earth rejoice in this, and the Emperor’s reign is prolonged in ease. Only the sounds of zithers and lutes, singing and music, remain—no further sorrows endure.

Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

Those of middling virtue who maintain their practice, exerting effort in their conduct, reflecting upon its meaning day and night, may yet become filial children in youth and loyal ministers in maturity, aiding the state to achieve Great Peace. All under Heaven will submit, none failing to praise their goodness.

Externally cautious and internally sincere, each examines and corrects themselves, daring not betray Heaven and Earth, nor deceive their superiors. When many worthies join in concerted effort, enabling the ruler’s governance, their rule becomes akin to Heaven, their conduct mirroring the celestial Way. Their kindness and love extend downward even to grasses, trees, mosquitoes, and gnats—all things find their proper place.

Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

When the common people uphold and study these teachings, striving together in practice, mutually encouraging goodness and unity, they cannot restrain themselves. Fathers become kind, mothers loving; children filial, wives obedient; elder brothers virtuous, younger brothers respectful. Neighbors and villages all delight in doing good, no longer harboring malice, theft, or mutual harm.

When all people rejoice in loyalty, obedience, and filial piety, aspiring to emulate the middling and great worthies, the people no longer commit evil. Each household and individual disciplines and governs themselves, so that order may be maintained without punishments. When the high, the middling, and the low all practice this, Great Peace is established throughout the world without delay.

Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

Guard the One in Solitude, Know the Divine Precepts, One Hundred Fifty-Two

Thus, the Dao of guarding the One gathers those who have guarded the One from ancient times to the present, assembling them by kind. The supremely worthy, with clarity and effort, may transcend the world; the middling worthy, with effort, may become good ministers and virtuous officials to emperors and kings; even the petty, with effort, may remain free from joy and anger, so that the world bears no resentment or blame. This is the foremost and greatest boundary of my writings.

Fearing that the common people, long sunk in ignorance, remain deluded and do not trust my words, I therefore instruct them to compare and align with the writings of those who have guarded the One from ancient times to the present, grouping them by kind to mutually verify one another.

Excellent, excellent indeed. The foolish student humbly awakens.

Now, as for guarding the One: the great person who guards it finds it more than sufficient; the middling person who guards it finds it more than sufficient; even the petty person who guards it finds it more than sufficient. When all three kinds of people guard and practice it together, its goodness permeates the six directions and eight distant realms, its kindness and love equaling that of Heaven and Earth.

As for the most foolish, those who take no joy in guarding and practicing it are called the most wicked and violent people in the world. Heaven and Earth detest them, and ghosts and spirits no longer protect them.

When people persistently do not pursue profit, this is the method by which the celestial writings distinguish good and evil. Those who delight in reading and studying are known by Heaven as good people; those who show no desire to study are known by Heaven as wicked and violent—this is one and the same principle. Judging people by this, not one in ten thousand will be mistaken.

I compose these writings for the Virtuous Lord of the Highest Power, upholding Heaven above, Earth below, and the Virtuous Lord in between, without deceiving the Perfected Ones. Those who guard this and grasp its meaning have completed the Dao in full.

Let the Six Perfected Ones deeply ponder its meaning, for I cannot exhaustively record all its goodness.

The One is the very throat and heart of the Supreme Dao. The superior scholar delights in its virtue; the middling scholar echoes its knowledge; the inferior scholar detests and reviles it. Do you understand this? Indeed, indeed.

Thus, when the superior scholar attains it, great joy arises, and they cannot restrain themselves from acting; when the middling scholar attains it, they cannot cease, ever desiring to speak of it with delight; when the inferior scholar encounters it, it becomes their greatest taboo. Observing these three types of people through my writings, the distinction between good and evil in the world becomes clear. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

These writings are Heaven’s contract for rectifying the hearts of ordinary people, for eliminating the lingering disasters of inherited burdens from past generations, for resolving Heaven’s afflictions, and for lifting the inherited transgressions of the Virtuous Lord of the Highest Power. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed. Excellent, excellent! Go forth—you have awakened.

As for the two divisions of the boundary: those who read my writings on the Dao, aligning them with past and present and categorizing them by kind, grasp their essential meaning. The most worthy and enlightened rejoice in them unreservedly, unable to restrain themselves from doing good. They may even dare to enter thatched chambers, steadfastly guarding the teachings without fail, and will surely transcend the world and depart. Their aspirations merge completely with the divine spirits, no longer seeking praise in worldly affairs. Their goodness thoroughly governs Heaven and Earth, and their spirit aids Heaven and Earth, further assisting the Emperor in transforming evil. Their grace extends downward to the grasses and trees, and no being, however small, fails to receive the transforming influence of their virtue.

Thus, the wise and virtuous masters of antiquity who aided Emperors in achieving Great Peace were all such people. Their words and deeds were entirely in accord with goodness, loyalty, and trustworthiness, for they had received the teachings of virtuous masters of the Dao. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

As for those of middling worth who diligently read my writings, aligning them with the Daoist texts of past and present and categorizing them by kind, persistently studying without cease—the more worthy among them may ascend to become the Emperor’s good ministers and virtuous officials, aiding the Virtuous Lord in transforming evil. Their grace extends downward to the smallest grasses and trees, harmonizing yin and yang so that no more strife arises. The Emperor may wander at leisure without cares, while all ministers and subordinates teach and strive together, all in accord with goodness, loyalty, and trustworthiness. Governance is achieved without punishments, and their goodness cannot be fully recorded. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

When all the common people together study my writings and Daoist texts, their understanding flows freely from high to low, their strategies unite as one, and none remain who know how to commit evil. They examine and collate the Daoist texts of past and present, arranging them by category to illuminate one another, and take these as the learning of the age, passing them from father to son without end.

As the three ranks—great worthies, middling worthies, and lesser worthies—along with the common people all engage in this practice, the malign qi of Heaven and Earth is entirely dispelled, and no further suffering from karmic inheritance remains. Goodness then harmonizes yin and yang, the auspicious qi of Heaven and Earth emerges in full, and they roam through the imperial capital—this is the sign of the joy and delight of the August Heaven and Revered Earth.

Thus, those who study my writings should scrutinize them carefully, from the highest to the lowest, pondering their essential meaning, grasping their secrets, and becoming no different from the divine luminaries. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

As for the three divisions of the realm: when many attain the Dao, they see spirits and can command them. The most enlightened among the great worthies govern ten out of ten perfectly and may serve as the Emperor’s ministers, those who ward off evil and dispel wickedness. Some, after long practice, may enter the thatched chamber and transcend, no longer entangled in worldly affairs.

Only after guarding the One can one fully discern good and evil, faults and failings; only then can one guard the Dao. Only after entering the thatched chamber for refined cultivation can one guard the spirits—thus, this is the third rank. The worthy obtain and collate the divine texts of past and present to verify one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

The middling worthy, by guarding the One and entering the Dao, may also personally witness the divine governance of nine out of ten and serve as a great minister to kings and lords, together dispelling evil. After long practice, they too may hope to enter the thatched chamber. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

The lesser worthy, by guarding the One and entering the Dao through study, may also witness divine governance in eight out of ten cases and serve alongside the common people to dispel evil and remove harm. They too should collate and verify ancient and modern Daoist texts to confirm their own understanding—only then will the foolish gain clarity and fully believe in the Dao. If one merely reads a single scroll without conviction, they will not only disbelieve but may even speak against it, justifying their own doubts. Thus, evil will daily arise, bringing harm to others. If the great worthy, the middling worthy, the lesser worthy, and the common people all guard the divine Dao and practice it together, then the spirits of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons will all flourish, and evil will naturally vanish. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

In this way, the spirits of the world above and below, of the four directions, the six relations, and the six kinships will all rejoice and flourish, aiding people to bring fortune and dissolve evil harm. Above, they will remove disasters and illnesses for emperors and kings; in the middle, they will cure ailments for the worthy; below, they will dispel malevolent qi for the common people, preventing wicked ghosts and spirits from acting. Excellent, excellent!

There must be great secrets and precepts to see the spirits and divine affairs. To say one is accurate in ten out of ten cases is to align with the spirits of Heaven; to say nine out of ten is to align with the spirits of Earth; to say eight out of ten is to align with the spirits of humanity. Beyond this, such words are unreliable. Some may initially see spirits and be perfectly aligned, yet over time grow increasingly inaccurate—this is the Dao of spirits testing them, causing their inaccuracy. If they recognize this and renew themselves, earnestly correcting their faults and striving for purity without evil intentions, their conduct will daily improve. They may then meet the spirits’ expectations, achieving perfect accuracy or even surpassing it, or hitting one in ten with ever-increasing precision. Such are those who daily cultivate goodness and grasp the intent of the Dao. Thus, it is called progress. Using this to divine for oneself, one will not err in ten thousand cases.

Some may initially see spirits and divine inaccurately, yet later reverse course and achieve great accuracy—these are people who refine their understanding of the Dao’s intent and daily advance. Others may remain unchanged, neither progressing nor regressing—these are those whose dedication does not deepen. Those who daily decline are the indolent. Divining thus, one fails to grasp the Dao’s intent. Those who are tested and remain unaware, stubbornly persisting in evil, will be collectively deceived by the spirits. They will be led into depravity, bringing unpredictable fortune and misfortune, falling into heretical teachings, or suffering from lingering illnesses.

Thus, the great worthy, the middling worthy, the lesser worthy, and all common men and women who practice the Dao must use this to divine for themselves, never erring—for the divine Dao tests people. All matters under Heaven are subject to trial and failure. Heaven and Earth test people, so humans, in imitation of Heaven and Earth, also test one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

Do you wish to further know the great truth and evidence of the mutual resonance between the Dao of Heaven, the divine spirits, and the people? When their intentions align and their hearts are in accord, sincerity and trust prevail; when their intentions diverge, deception arises. Thus, in high antiquity, people’s sincerity and trust aligned, so superiors and inferiors did not deceive one another. In middle antiquity, half were misaligned, so half deceived one another. In later antiquity, none believed, so superiors and inferiors made deception their sole affair. Thus, in high antiquity, all undertakings succeeded; in middle antiquity, half succeeded; in later antiquity, none succeeded, leading to peril and ruin.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old constantly used this to divine whether they had attained resonance or not, ensuring no mistakes. With this, I admonish you, Perfected One. I see you constantly toil in hardship, so I deeply caution you—you are to serve as the eternal emissary of Heaven and Earth, resolving the flowing disasters of Heaven and Earth and removing harm for rulers. Your merit is immense and nearly unmatched. I fear you may grow indolent in your practice of the Dao, so I use these divine matters to warn you. If you serve as the emissary of Heaven and Earth and daily encounter fortune, it is because you have grasped the intent of Heaven and Earth. If you daily encounter misfortune, decline, and evil, it is because you have lost their intent.

In your interactions with the Dao and the spirits, if your days are fortunate and good, it is because you have grasped the Dao’s intent. If your days are misfortunate and declining, it is because you have lost the Dao’s intent. In your interactions with others, if your relationships daily grow deeper and kinder, it is because your intentions align. If they daily turn hostile and cold, it is because your intentions have diverged. Consider farming: those who harvest abundant, fine grain have applied careful attention and great effort. Those who harvest little, poor grain have been careless and exerted little effort. Even plants and trees respond to the diligence or negligence of human effort—how much more so the spirits of Heaven and Earth and humanity? Can you not be cautious?

Perfected One, this admonition may seem slight and insignificant, but if you deeply ponder it, you will find it profoundly weighty. This is precisely the gateway to safety or peril, fortune or misfortune. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

I, the foolish one, have awakened—how solemn the charge, how solemn the charge!

Now, the virtuous and enlightened, as paragons of supreme virtue and sovereigns, have collated and examined the writings of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, arranging them by category to mutually verify one another. Thus, the Dao/Way is rectified in a single day, no different from the sun and moon. They further gathered and assembled the great worthies, middling worthies, lesser worthies, and even the spoken testimonies of men and women among the people, again arranging them by category and cross-verifying them. The written texts then align perfectly, as if fitting a double compass to a square—without the slightest discrepancy.

The strategies of Heaven, Earth, and humanity converge as one. In this way, the sentiments of Heaven, Earth, and humanity are all encompassed, and the twelve thousand things follow likewise. Therefore, the sovereign of virtue must exert great effort in this endeavor, and calamities will depart in a single day. The world will govern itself, free of any remnant of perverse texts or corrupt words. Once all is purified and rectified, no vestige of perverse qi remains.

For perverse texts and corrupt words are the root of disasters. If you wish to further comprehend their clear and trustworthy effects, consider this: when someone records perverse texts against a ruler, or when someone slanders with corrupt speech, resentment and blame arise daily in abundance. People then turn to mutual resentment and slander, and the ruler, listening to these, strays from the correct path. His wisdom and clarity become obstructed, incurring the disapproval of Heaven and Earth, and his governance falters with inauspicious words.

Moreover, those below may use perverse texts and corrupt speech to deceive and confuse their superiors. Over time, when this is discovered above, ruler and ministers will likewise blame one another. Thus, perverse texts and corrupt words arrive daily, serving as the gateway to misfortune and evil. Therefore, one must vigorously collate and expunge them.

Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Thus, when a virtuous ruler fully employs correct speech, the calamities and perils of inherited burdens since the opening of Heaven and Earth are entirely dispelled, and no further disasters arise. Perfected One, do you wish to further comprehend its great truth?

Indeed, correct texts and correct speech serve as the fundamental root of the Dao, Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things. Therefore, the great sages and worthies of high antiquity, who acted in accordance with correct texts and correct speech, found Heaven and Earth aligned with their correctness, the Three Luminaries aligned with their correctness, the four seasons and Five Phases aligned with their correctness, the people and all things aligned with their correctness. Thus, correct texts and correct speech are the great and efficacious root of correctness for Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things.

Do you wish to further clarify and understand its truth? Consider this: when someone praises a ruler with correct texts and correct speech, the ruler gains great wisdom and great clarity. In all undertakings, nothing strays from correctness. Above and below thus attain the will of Heaven and Earth; the Three Luminaries do not deviate from their courses; the four seasons and Five Phases do not err. The people are all joyful, exclaiming, "Excellent!" The myriad things each find their proper place. Grace extends to the spirits and deities, and one’s fame spreads to distant lands. The host of spirits and auspicious omens emerge in delight. The worthy and learned of the world all gladly come to assist their ruler, and nothing remains concealed. Immortals and divine spirits then bestow upon him the methods of agelessness. Demonic influences are eradicated, and the people govern themselves. With correct texts and correct speech, no mutual resentment arises, and blame is entirely cut off.

All goodness emerges in the world, while all perversity and evil conceal themselves. The virtuous ruler need only sit with folded hands, and governance proceeds of itself—what worry of peril or ruin remains? This is the clear proof and efficacy of my correct texts and correct speech as the root of goodness. How could one not strive to uphold correctness? Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

How astonishing! Having heard the Heavenly Master’s words, I am now profoundly awakened. This foolish one now knows the world has already attained Great Peace. If the virtuous ruler heeds and applies them, his life will be prolonged. Excellent! You may truly be called one who understands affairs—a student who has thoroughly grasped the Way.

Joyful, oh joyful! The Heaven’s anxieties are resolved, and the Earth’s afflictions are removed. Perfected One, how do you know this? Indeed, all perversity and evil are now destined to be eradicated, and the great afflictions of Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things have been eliminated. Now that the correct texts and correct speech have been compiled and rectified, we know the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth are gone.

Excellent, excellent! You have indeed fully understood. If the emperor and kings diligently practice my texts, they will align with the profoundness of Heaven and Earth, and no further calamities will befall them. Excellent, excellent! These are the most essential words to convey to the Perfected One.

When a ruler of supreme virtue obtains my texts, Heaven’s patterns and images will govern his ministers—from divine transcendents above to the lowliest and most humble below, encompassing these nine ranks: divine immortals, perfected transcendents, Daoist sages, worthies, scholars, common folk, servants, and slaves. Among these nine, those who possess true faith, loyalty, and goodness, who delight in the authentic Dao and come to assist the virtuous ruler—all should be questioned regarding their abilities and appointed accordingly. Take care never to assign them roles unsuited to their capacities, nor to dismiss them unjustly.

Those who resist are called "obstructive people." With diligent and devoted hearts, Heaven is not human, yet it acts according to evidence and entrusts them with tasks, each questioned regarding their particular strengths—thus, nothing will remain ungoverned. The virtuous ruler should test them: those who daily produce good results should be promoted, with no oversight; those who prove ineffective should be swiftly dismissed. These are called "defilers of Heaven’s offices," preventing the arrival of correct *qi* and placing blame upon such wicked people.

The truly good, with hearts ever inclined to secretly assist and worry over all matters, are called "those who bring forth true goodness." The wicked, with perverse hearts, do not wish to secretly aid or benefit any affair—thus they bring forth wickedness. This is the natural standard and law of August Heaven. Therefore, they must be dismissed at once. If not dismissed, they will provoke Heaven’s wrath, causing the Earth to emit killing *qi*. Thus, they must be swiftly removed—this is a matter of great importance.

Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.
