The reason lies in *yin* being the domain of literary refinement, the abode of wood, where mountain forests and fierce beasts cannot be withstood. They ought only to maintain purity and cleanliness, for Heaven sends them to hunt—but they should not be seen too often, for many fear them, and thus they are called tigers. Those born in the year of *yin* have long destinies, and if three *yin* years converge in their birth, they may endure for a great span. *Shen*, however, stands in opposition, never to be lost, yet they fear the night and can only climb trees up and down, beset by many terrors. Their destiny lies in metal, and their actions harm and wound others. Thus their lifespans are short—this is readily known. If they neglect the spirits or grow remiss, if they indulge in perverse and oppressive fears without constancy, they will seldom encounter favorable times.

In the destinies of *mao* and *you*, each aligns with its respective month, and their months coincide. *Mao* governs the East, striking the Eastern Star in its charge, fostering abundant livelihoods and the sustenance of the people. Thus *mao* is called the East, and the true *mao* stands at the East’s center. In spring, it brings flourishing blossoms; in summer, it ripens fruit—nothing it does not bestow, none it does not bless with virtue. Therefore, the Eastern Star is named *Ren* (Benevolence), for it cannot bear to harm. Heaven cherishes human lifespans, and thus grants them long years. Yet the true *you* lies in the domain of metal, delighting in strife and battle, and cannot endure long. To act wickedly is natural—how could one hope for long life? Even if they encounter the prosperous phases of the monthly cyclical *qi*, their fate remains unchanged. Of six or seven evils, half their days are lost—this, too, is readily known.

For those born in the years of *si* and *hai*, each is assigned its month, and their names are likewise given. With double yin and no yang, their lifespans are naturally short. When the three yin phases converge, it is said that *si* and *hai* govern the opening and storing away. *Hai* rules the Northwest, *si* the Southeast—whatever they face or undertake, little aligns with propriety. Their livelihoods are difficult to advance, and their lifespans hard to prolong. Thus it is said that the ten celestial stems circulate in mutual correspondence, their names denoting merit, and their reckoning subject to Heaven’s calculations. By measuring their short and long spans, destiny is determined—how could one follow their own will in Heaven’s workings? Therefore, those of great virtue now oversee these patterns, their names recorded in the registers of the stellar lodges, their destinies held in the celestial bureaus. Within and without, above and below, in all eight directions, all follow these principles—how could one act as they please?

People, not grasping these calculations, instead ask what debt they owe to Heaven. By doing good, one may fulfill their allotted years; by doing evil, they forfeit length for brevity. If wickedness is not halted, calamity extends even to the unborn—what hope can there be? One reaps what one sows. If their destiny is meager and they do not exhaust their allotted span, their surplus is stored in Heaven to be bestowed upon the virtuous. They ought to warn their descendants to be cautious. If they repent and correct their ways, they may yet complete their years—each outcome is clear. Let them tally their deeds and not resent the celestial spirits.

Strive to do good, and your descendants shall enjoy long years; otherwise, the fault lies with you—blame not Heaven. If one first rectifies themselves but later wavers, they should reflect and restore balance. The noble and benevolent naturally cherish their years, as recorded in the *Life Bureau’s Verdicts*, Scroll One Hundred Eighty-Two.

Only the Most High’s virtuous ones conduct themselves thus: they foreknow the inner and outer workings of Heaven and Earth, moving in and out of yin and yang, guiding their principles, and awakening to the thoughts within—never forgetting the Dao. They act in accord with Heaven, daring not to doubt, and thus succeed, upholding Heaven’s great bestowals. Their thoughts dwell within, their actions bear no transgressions, subtly receiving the natural order. They repeatedly encounter warnings—past and future are known. If people bring harm upon themselves, they have no one to blame.

Since ancient times, few have been trustworthy. Those who claim trustworthiness seek only to deceive, heedless of the consequences. Thus Heaven and Earth grow dark with unceasing wrath, and even the wise and sagely, though they know, can only regret. Heaven instructs through its own ways, not through human words. Yet people turn away with malice, ignoring admonitions, seeking only their own satisfaction. Such people are more ignorant than beasts. For this reason, they ought to reproach themselves for their faults—from where does their recklessness arise? Day and night, they should reflect on their failings, relentlessly examining their transgressions—what cause have they to resent or blame? Yet they remain unrepentant, heedless of their faults, acting recklessly and inappropriately. They do not heed the great teachings but instead indulge themselves, shortening their own lives—what cause have they to resent or blame?

At times, they recall the transcendent ones of high antiquity who ascended and escaped the world—how did such thoughts arise? In all the writings they see, it is said: be loyal and filial, honor and serve your parents, live in harmony with your siblings, without inner or outer discord, in unity above and below, knowing Heaven’s prohibitions. Let the spirits govern the principles, openly acknowledging faults without ceasing, cultivating the self and reflecting inward—only then may one attain life. Lifespans have their appointed terms—how can one act as they please? The thought pains the heart, tears soak the garments, and there is no end to the sorrow. They cherish their years, fearing they may not live long. When they see those of long life and inquire of them, they are told: be loyal and filial, never losing the intent of Heaven and Earth; assist the four seasons in their generation, aid the Five Phases in their completion, and dare not destroy the things that ought to live.

Those who do good never encroach upon others, deceive, or betray; they are sincere and trustworthy, never daring to break their word. Their conduct wins the favor of the multitude, and they dare not fail their kin or bring harm to their village, always repaying what they owe in due time. They never lie drunk in the streets in broad daylight. The worthy and wise follow them, paying no heed to fools. They bear gratitude toward Heaven and Earth, never expecting repayment, only reproaching themselves. Yet when faults recur, they trace their origins to inherited burdens, reproaching themselves for years on end until moved to remorse.

Worldly folk commit many transgressions and debts, never finding release. They walk in sorrow and bitterness, not knowing where to turn. Whenever they see others at fault, they turn to blame themselves, unable to find peace. They seek out virtuous texts and precepts, hoping for good fortune, and when they encounter the sacred scriptures of Heaven’s great spirits, they ponder them again and again, their thoughts consumed without end. They bow their heads, strike their breasts, and weep aloud, their bodies unable to correct themselves, yet full of grievance. The weight of the prohibitions presses upon them, and they transgress, shortening their lives. Day and night, they repent.

Hoping for even a brief reprieve, they dare not commit further wrongs. Instead, they resolve to practice kindness and bestow alms, striving to grasp the principles. No harsh words pass their lips—only tears, their hearts filled with sorrow. The heavenly spirits hear and descend to ask: “Who is this person, so full of grief?” They observe one of great virtue, whose life is long and enduring. When asked, they say: “This one merely acts in accord with Heaven’s heart and Earth’s intent—thus they attain longevity.”

Returning to their quiet dwelling, they reflect as the virtuous of the Highest Dao have taught, examining themselves. When the spirits see their remorse and repentance, they ascend to report to the Way of Heaven: “There is one who weeps and laments without ceasing, fearing they will not live, and so reproaches themselves.” The great spirits hear and say: “The Heavenly Lord has often commanded the spirits: those who perform good deeds, are loyal and filial, and obedient—such words refer to this person alone.” They then report to the Heavenly Lord, who says: “I have heard that this person has reproached themselves for their faults for many years. Though once a worldly person, their unceasing self-reproach has made them one of the highest good.”

The great spirits frequently visit to observe their conduct, discerning whether their intentions are virtuous and if they seek advancement. Their destined years are then recorded in the Bureau of Longevity, where their deeds are reviewed to make up for any deficiencies. The great spirits say: “This person has reproached themselves for so long that their inherited burdens are dissolved. We request that their deficiencies be filled, and they be named a virtuous one of the Highest Dao, to repay those below who have fallen short.” The Heavenly Lord says: “The conduct of the virtuous of the Highest Dao must be as you have said.” The great spirits repeatedly command that they be protected and guided to ascend as spirits, ensuring their allotted years are not diminished.

The great spirits say: “This person was originally without a recorded name, but by decree, they have been placed in the Bureau of Longevity. We request that their deficiencies be filled in order, without skipping ranks.” The Heavenly Lord says: “When the day comes to fill the vacancies in order, their names shall be repeatedly submitted without missing the appointed time.” The great spirits assent.

Only the benevolent of the Highest Dao accumulate merit and deeds in Heaven. Heaven heeds and trusts them, sending them to assist the Eastern Star in arranging the creatures that ought to live, providing blossoms and fruits to nourish the people, ensuring warmth and fullness. Their bodies grow strong, nurturing one another in turn; yin and yang unite, and male and female take form. Old and young follow in succession, receiving their destined lifespans from Heaven’s decree. Among the twenty-eight constellations, they revolve and complete one another; the sun and moon illuminate and inspect without fail, taking turns to generate life—how could there be rest?

Yet people do not understand, believing each to be self-governing. Though names may imply autonomy, they are in fact mutually restrained. The reason is this: human lives have varying lengths, and the seasons of spring, autumn, winter, and summer bring constant cycles of life and death. Thus, they are made to govern one another, transferring and inquiring in turn. Lifespans increase or decrease, passing from one to another. Therefore, it is said that the four seasons, Five Phases, sun, moon, and stars all hold sway over life. The good are granted increase, while the wicked retreat on their own. The severity of transgressions is measured by unchanging laws—how can one escape if the laws are followed as they should be?

Heaven above and Earth below support one another like the outer and inner, with various spirits also working in concert. Thus, it is said that the Heavenly Lord commands the bureaus, each transferring their duties in turn, taking up their respective talismans without the slightest partiality. From above, they observe below—how could there be failure? Those of inherent nature, free from ill intent, may commit minor wrongs but repent of their deeds, and their faults are dissolved. Their records are regularly entered into the registers: the wicked are sent to the lower bureaus, while the good are reported as good, and the wicked as wicked. The spirits of fortune and misfortune each follow where they are assigned. If the wicked repent, their names are transferred to the registers of the good. If the good turn to evil, they are moved to the registers of the wicked—how could there be rest?

Among the living on Earth, even those still in the womb have their names and destinies recorded in the Register of the Undying. When their years are fulfilled and their conduct complete, those who are born are recorded, and those with guarantors are elevated. The reason is this: their lifespans are difficult to sustain, so their guarantors are held accountable for any transgressions. Thus, those who are neither loyal, filial, obedient, nor meritorious have no guarantors—they merely continue the merits of their ancestors, ensuring sacrifices are made. Yet if they persist in evil without cease, how can they expect to partake in future generations’ sustenance?

How could those who feed on filth ever hope to serve alongside the great spirits of Heaven for long? Even among the filth, there are those who respond to Heaven’s scriptures and are sent divine teachings. When the appointed time arrives, the Heavenly Lord commands the guardian spirits of the Great Heavenly Granary to sever their attachment to material forms. They are nourished by the qi of the Great Heavenly Granary, their bodies refined and their spirits lightened, moving between the profound and the obscure. Their names are then recorded, no longer in the ledgers—how could they seek life? How could people know of this?

If one is good and never loses Heaven’s heart, the great spirits stir their mind, making them delight in life, whether they follow the Dao or remain worldly. The reason is this: if one commits evil without a single good deed, merely coveting fine clothes and carriages, following their desires without restraint, their allotted lifespan will not be fulfilled—but Heaven and Earth will not deny their wishes either.

The wicked shall not long behold the sun, moon, and stars of Heaven, but must return to the eternal night—how could they remain? Such persons, unable to discipline themselves toward goodness, are known to Heaven for their enduring evil, and thus are made to consume only the food of form. They are buried beneath the earth, becoming servants to the earth spirits, never to be reborn. This is why the scriptures reveal it, that they may know.

Some undergo *shijie* (corpse liberation), their forms dividing: the bones and body separate. The corpse remains in one place, while the spirit becomes a wandering phantom, appearing to people as though dead. Yet those who understand may see them still alive—these are the *shijie* immortals. Over time, as their years and merits accumulate, they next ascend in broad daylight to Heaven. When their merits and years are complete, their radiance shines forth, aiding the celestial spirits in their all-pervading work. They return to dwell among the clouds, and within their appointed domains, all are *shijie* immortals who govern the affairs of humans and ghosts.

In the families of the Dao, those who depart may be enfeoffed as the most revered of spirits, known as *Dilingqi* (Earthly Numinous Spirits). They, too, may wear the purple, mugwort-green, and yellow. Their governance extends above and below, with each ascending to their proper station. If one’s evil is heard of, they may be demoted to consort with ghosts—do you not understand? Thus it is said: the paths of life and death diverge; how could they be compared?

Proceed, and when minor transgressions arise, still the mind and reflect. For those who later falter or fall short, this shall be explained. Only the actions of the Most High’s good persons manifest the affairs Heaven and Earth must carry out. Each has their charge, each their words, each their cultivation, each their spiritual attainment, each their merit, each their loyalty, each their governance, each their bestowal upon others, each their advancement in the Dao. Each gains the trust of Heaven and Earth, each does not lose the generative and transformative cycles of the four seasons and five phases.

Thus, those who respond to the goodness of the Most High are Heaven’s faithful and Earth’s safeguarded. All attain the harmonious heart-mind of Heaven and Earth, understanding the ebb and flow of human affairs, carrying out commands without daring to defy the will of the Great Sages. Below, they do not transgress the prohibitions of the myriad spirits. They constantly strive to perfect others, making them delight in goodness. They align with the hearts of Heaven and Earth, their inner and outer selves in accord, achieving success in their persons and attaining longevity. Their names are inscribed in the ledgers of the undying, and they serve alongside the great spirits in their appointed roles.

They discern right from wrong, their loyalty and sincerity directed to Heaven. They behold the sun, moon, and stars without losing the measure of the Dao, nor straying from their resolve. Constantly desiring to live, they contemplate serving Heaven’s transformation and understanding Earth’s principles. Their hearts rejoice, for they know the registers of fortune and misfortune, the affairs of survival and demise, and aspire to walk the same path as the natural order. Even slight greed or evil is seen, and the great spirits’ admonitions stir compassion for the unenlightened, illuminating their shortcomings so they may enter the records of long life. They witness the Celestial Lords bestowing life upon them, their names enduring in the ledgers of the undying.

They perform the affairs of Heaven above and comprehend Earth’s principles below. What they see and hear is vast: their eyes are bright, their ears keen, and they know the boundless past and future. Their writings and words are clear, and they grasp the essential and wondrous. Such is the aspiration of the Most High’s good persons. Only the great celestial spirits perceive and guide their wishes, as they yearn for the natural and inscribe their deeds in harmony with the generative *qi*, without end.

It is ever said: Heaven does not deny a person’s wishes, nor does Earth deny their peace. Thus, the natural order dares not bear even a hair’s weight of entanglement to trouble the spirits, so deeply do they cherish the written word. Day and night, they reflect on their failings, fearing they may fall short of the Most High Lord’s intent. What do they惜 or love that they would not exhaust their loyalty, sincerity, and filial piety? They must declare the grace they have received, the honor bestowed, without thought of repayment. Heaven’s heart holds them in profound love, yet they reproach themselves for their faults, offering little in forgiveness.

Only the great spirits may pardon and admonish them, not out of attachment but from compassion. They dare not distance themselves, constantly mindful of the unrepayed grace, their sins clinging to them. Fearful of being unable to explain or absolve, they can only grieve. Though pardoned and shown leniency, they are made to reflect on their failings.

The great spirits say: The Most High’s good persons reflect on their transgressions and reproach themselves; their words and writings ascend to be heard above. Their words extend far, yet they fear being misunderstood. Heaven’s faithfulness especially honors them, and they may attain boundless longevity. They should set their hearts afar, never forgetting the great gifts bestowed by Heaven’s generative power.

The Most High Lord praises them, saying: Life arises from the mandate of good life, unconcerned with wealth or sensuality. Seeing others live, they constantly desire to share in their longevity—when would they act recklessly or without heart, failing to repay such profound grace? They only regret that, since their years began, they have not seen the great measure of Heaven’s bounty. Only by receiving the grace of teachings and admonitions do they understand their allotted principles. They say: Knowing fate, they do not resent Heaven, nor dare they resent themselves and hinder life. How could their hearts harbor greed? They only fear their years may end before witnessing Heaven’s great dispensation of its ordered domains.

The Most High again admonishes the ignorant and benighted, granting them the wisdom to reflect—a great grace beyond words. They must concentrate their hearts and minds, ever mindful within, never forgetting their hunger and thirst, seeking the precepts and the living. Only by receiving pardon and leniency may they proceed.

The great spirits say: We originally advanced to the Celestial Lords from among the spirits, without the slightest fault, aiding Heaven and Earth with meritorious deeds. Our names are recorded in the Celestial Lords’ ledgers—when could we ever be forgotten? We humbly present our words of self-reproach, for we have long yearned for Heaven’s transformation. Are such persons recorded in the ledgers or not?

The Celestial Lord says: Those who reproach themselves act in accord with the natural order and are aided by the spirits. Let those who oversee the celestial registers examine them. If they have reproached themselves, the spirit in charge of the living ledgers is commanded to review the records, and their names are indeed found therein.

The Celestial Lord says: Those who conduct themselves well from birth, transgressing no prohibitions, achieve this through their own actions. The great spirits should further investigate, for there may be omissions in the records of those who have rendered service.

The great spirits say: Since the Great Beginning, those spirits whose merits have gained Heaven’s favor have advanced—yet there remain some vacancies.

If there are persons whose conduct merits it, their names should be duly recorded above.

The Celestial Lord says: The duties of your offices are many and onerous. Calculate their merits and offset their transgressions, ensuring they no longer violate what has been decreed.

The great spirits say: These most exalted persons naturally follow the correct path, and their faults and burdens are few.

The Celestial Lord says: Reconsider them. If any remain uncommended, hold their guarantors accountable to fill the vacancies.

The Celestial Lord says: Matters of this court must not be treated carelessly.

The great spirits say: As your decree states, before a hundred days have passed, the spirits of Heaven will vie to vouch for them, and we great spirits shall report our judgment.

The Celestial Lord says: Let each be assigned to their fitting role, sent to attend to their duties, and thus gain further esteem. Those who are trustworthy shall be appointed as Perfected.

The great spirits say: Let us dispatch envoys to summon them above, first transforming their appearance.

The spirit-envoys go forth, and their transformations shine with abundant radiance.

The great spirits say: Report back.

The Celestial Lord says: The person has already transformed into a spirit and now stands outside the gate, not yet having entered.

The Celestial Lord says: Let them proceed to the office of the overseer to pay their respects.

The great spirits say: We shall report as the great spirits have stated.

Yes, yes. Let the report be made as stated, and we shall observe their conduct accordingly.

The Celestial Lord says: It shall be as the great spirits have reported.

**Dialogue on the Longing of the Knowing to Meet the Great Spirits, One Hundred Eighty-Third**

Only those of supreme knowledge, the Knowing Ones of the Most High, foreknow the affairs of Heaven and understand what should be done and what should be upheld. Their actions arise naturally, and when primal qi converges upon them, they attain maturity—all becomes clear and known. They transform their hearts to accord with the natural, residing in what they do. Thus, the Knowing Ones comprehend both inner and outer, and in all their comings and goings, nothing fails to reach fulfillment. Nothing remains unachieved, and all transformations occur in due time. Revering the majesty of the spirits, they perfect their merit and name their virtue. Ever unwavering in loyalty and trust, never remiss, day and night they grieve and tremble, never departing from their inner resolve. Inclining and yearning, they long to achieve union and meet the great spirits. Through discourse and the exchange of words, they practice the Way they follow and advance what they know. Constantly contemplating success, they render grace to the spirits, prolonging life and increasing years. Thus, the Knowing Ones look inward to see outward—what is there they do not know? What is there they do not perceive? Their minds are clear and their thoughts distinct. They but crave the Way of long life, desiring to mount the carriage and serve as envoys for the great spirits. Wherever they arrive, they dare not speak falsely, responding in the moment as if already present, longing for their hearts to open. Receiving the words of the spirits as the spirits themselves do, knowing the spirits’ actions, they act with self-assurance and only then dare to speak, seeking merely to be granted life and audience. They dare not seek high office, only to be shown mercy. Though they witness matters of life and death, their hearts tremble with fear. Having received the great teachings, they must act to communicate them, bestowing grace and spreading kindness, benefiting those above and those below. Their names are inscribed in the ledgers, and they abide in the ranks of the undying. Their hearts rejoice and delight, exhausting their efforts in service to the Celestial Lord. Over the years, their merits accumulate, and they advance in speech.

Only by the great spirits’ intercession for their insufficiencies, knowing the weight of their words, do they thus crave advancement. Receiving their secret decrees, they roam the gates and chambers, daring not rest, desiring instruction and admonition to remedy their shortcomings. They wish to be examined and not contradict what is said, awaiting the commands and warnings of the great spirits’ words.

The Knowing Ones of the Most High perceive much, yet they cannot fully know the bounds of Heaven’s domains—what then should they be cautioned against? The spirits of Heaven all observe them. The words of the Knowing Ones of the Most High are but to know what is spoken, what is taught, and what is practiced—what cause for doubt is there?

The Celestial Lord says: Constantly command the spirits to advance the names of those who are loyal, filial, sincere, trustworthy, and meritorious. These Knowing Ones of the Most High, coveted by their allotted destinies, thus clarify their hearts.

Yet they fear that their written words are but their own speech—why would they withhold reverence for Heaven’s teachings and admonitions? They often say they suffer from having no scribe to respond, fearing that inner and outer may not correspond. If they wish to advance their knowledge and understanding, broadening inquiry and deepening comprehension, this too is what they should know.

Proceed, and heed the words of the great spirits. Heaven’s heavy admonitions must not be treated lightly, must not be disrespected, must not be held in awe too little—only then is it possible. The admonitions are many; one must grasp their essentials and further open one’s ears, eyes, and heart.

Yes, yes.

Thus, emerging from within, the great admonitions of Heaven decree that all who seek advancement and long life must advance what they know. To know and not speak is to listen in vain—this is to lack the heart for self-advancement. Those whose hearts hold knowledge must contemplate advancement. Those with aspirations must advance their aspirations. Those with sincerity must advance their sincerity. Those with filial piety must advance their filial piety. Only thus do they become the heart and core of Heaven—nothing must be left unadvanced.

The Celestial Lord foreknows human sentiments and permits no failure to advance or to expound the Way. To conceal knowledge and hide abilities—Heaven detests such persons, ensuring they do not appear in the ledgers of longevity. Is this not to know?

Not only do they not appear in the ledgers of longevity, but their essence is first lost, departing from their bodies, and their years perish. Can they not be cautious?

The Knowing Ones of the Most High act thus because the Celestial Lord knows what is known and what is not. They know themselves—what doubt remains? They need only carefully ponder the spirits’ words and not betray them.

The Knowing Ones of the Most High, though lowly and ignorant, press forward with questions beyond their reach, desiring to be granted what they do not know. How dare they conceal knowledge or hide abilities, causing the Celestial Lord and the spirits to hear of it and further forfeit their lives and lose their years, shortening their longevity? This is the root of calamity and misfortune, and even the destruction of their bodies would not suffice to repay it. How dare they advance thus?

Only may the great spirits illuminate and pardon their inadequacies.

The great spirits say: Those who seek life and abhor death naturally possess hearts and aspirations that cannot be otherwise. Yet they fear there may be times of confusion.

The one seeking life says: "I myself know not the precepts, yet by the great spirits’ gracious forbearance, I am taught thus. How dare I grow complacent and not advance what I know and what I can say? May only the great spirits record what has come before and not dismiss it."

The great spirits say: "What has come before is not easily matched. Only those who preserve trust and faith can align with the Celestial Lord’s will and thus hope for life. Take heed of this."

The seeker, truly coveting life, therefore exhausts his loyalty and sincerity, never daring to slacken or rest. He reflects on his faults and reproaches himself—how dare he waste day or night? The Celestial Lord, having heard his words, says: "This is the speech of one who possesses knowledge in the Most High." It is known that this person’s name appears in the ledgers, though with some deficiencies. The spirits charged with the living registers are commanded to examine the ledgers where this person’s name is recorded. Though his name is listed and he is naturally good and knowledgeable, he must fulfill his years and not lose track of the spirits governing his months and years.

"Yes, yes."

**Method for Accumulating Conduct to Repair the True Self, Scroll 184**

Only those of the Most High who possess intention each know their allotted portion. Each has their own Dao, their own conduct, their own offerings, their own advancement, their own declarations, their own words, their own destinations, and their own movements. If the heart is not stirred within, they constantly strive to fulfill loyalty, trust, and filial piety. Truly, they render service to Heaven, accumulating conduct over the years without ever slackening. Yet they do not forget gratitude or their allotted portion, ever mindful of their desire for life. Having received the protection of the host of spirits above, they dare not withhold even the smallest part. They constantly harbor a fearful heart, never at ease, seeking the precepts of the Most High to preserve their lives. How dare they forget the great bestowal of grace?

May the great spirits deign to glance upon their inadequacies. Their hearts ever long for the affairs of the Most High, and what they ought to practice—compass and square, plumb line and inked cord—naturally earns trust. Gazing toward the four quarters, they comprehend the four corners. What Heaven knows, they manifest before it comes to pass. Their hearts contemplate the great spirits’ memorials and communications, what they advance and what they declare. They dare not evaluate these with their own minds but constantly consult with the assembled spirits to determine what may be adopted or not, ever fearful of failing to win the hearts of the spirits.

They consider themselves fundamentally upright, without error. As if moved from the depths of their being, they constantly cherish the preservation of life that harms nothing. Previously, they coveted its radiance, reaching upward to the sound without essence or form, penetrating the Most High’s commands to advance. They dare not grow lax and thereby obstruct the great transformation.

May the spirits examine their desire for life and not depart from the great spirits’ left side. Upon seeing the precepts, their hearts open and their eyes brighten, desiring to abide by the scripture of longevity, to increase their years and lifespan. They strive to advance merit, personally engaging without daring to trust themselves or presume to judge right and wrong, contending over what is insufficient. They yearn for those above to be ever diligent, only beseeching compassionate illumination of the precepts.

When will their gratitude and devotion ever cease? Their hearts long day and night to meet, coveting knowledge of prohibitions and transgressions to stir their minds and thereby perceive their own inadequacies. These are not matters to be repaid with mere words; only by receiving examination may their thoughts pierce the heart’s diaphragm.

The great spirits say: "This is one of the Most High who possesses intention—his conduct is indeed fitting. Seeking to receive Heaven’s solemn precepts and prohibitions, he who possesses knowledge is fundamentally clear and discerning, distinguishing principle. What precepts does he not understand? Holding the heart to aim at the heart, there is no gap for selfishness. From above to below, all know their own master.

Now, those of the Most High who possess intention are close to Heaven and trusted by the celestial spirits. They need only hold fast to their hearts and minds, ever fearful of losing them. The rest is known to their own hearts. They must strive to transmit, widely inquire, and not lose what is said. Those who possess knowledge are mostly clear in their distinctions, only fearing that at times their actions may not match their words. Why suspect they would not openly explain? Such a person, possessing intention, naturally reflects on his faults and debts.

Simply contemplating what lies before and behind, longevity naturally emerges from within, aligning with the Celestial Lord’s heart. The remainder of the precepts for those who possess intention say: This seeker was originally a rustic, seeing those who lived long and aged gracefully, their vital essence and fluids flowing without loss, never witnessing their decline. Though many study, few attain it. Why? Because they do not hold their hearts with utmost care, lightly regarding what is said. Their strategies and records are not fitting, thus making attainment rare.

Now, this seeker, seeing the conduct of those who came before, further corrects and reforms his bearing, opening his heart to retain it. Desiring to raise his voice, he listens well, coveting longevity and cherishing his years. Thus, he dare not slacken or rest. May only the great spirits examine his inadequacies."

The great spirits say: "Those who possess intention shall be granted registration in the ledgers. We request the clerks of the registers to examine the ledgers for this person’s name and report to the Celestial Lord. The great spirits may not act on their own."

The seeker says: "May only the great spirits consider and discuss this. I dare not distance myself, lingering outside, but will personally prove my worth."

The great spirits say: "We request to report the names of those registered in the ledgers. Why suspect they would not correspond?"

The seeker says: "May only the great spirits report on my behalf. On the day of accomplishment, I will devote my life to proving my worth. What need is there to hope for repayment?"

The great spirits report to the Celestial Lord: "Those of the Most High who possess intention all hold their hearts firmly and closely, their aspirations ever coveting the heights and possessing faith. Command the spirits in charge to examine them. If such a person exists, advance and report to the great spirits. Command those in charge to examine whether this person’s name appears in the documents. This person’s name was recorded before his birth."

The great spirits report back: "This person’s name was recorded before his birth, solely by the grace of the Most High."

The Celestial Lord says: "Those recorded in the ledgers shall be seen to ascend. They must take responsibility for their debts and burdens. Command the great spirits to remove the tally of their debts and burdens, to transform their hearts, and to refine them into spirits. When their years are fulfilled, they shall advance."

The great spirits say: "This person’s years and calculations are complete, exceeding the term by a hundred days. Previously, there was no certainty, so for now, it is halted."

The Celestial Lord says: "Command the great spirits to ascend for now, assigning them to their posts in the interim. Where there are vacancies for the true, let them be filled by those who can exhaust their essence and devote their will, knowing how to eliminate and act concurrently."

The great spirits say: "We request to ascend as the Celestial Lord has commanded. Let their refined lifespans and calculations be recalculated. Those who are enlightened shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight."

The Celestial Lord says: "This is what those of sincere heart ought to do, that they may have something to govern."

The great spirits assent.

They request to command the proper officials to carry out the affairs according to the original text.

The great spirits say: "Report to the Ascension Bureau."

The petitioners report to the great spirits, saying: "Request to command the officials of the Bureau."

The officials having reported, they are assigned to interim posts, and where there are vacancies for the true, they are to be filled.

The Celestial Lord says: "As reported by the Bureau."

To the right: In heaven above, good deeds are to be concealed, while misfortune and calamity arise from their disclosure.

*End of Scroll One Hundred Eleven of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Scroll One Hundred Twelve of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Disaster of Coveting Wealth and Lust, and Admonitions Within the Womb, One Hundred Eighty-Five*

In ancient times, the formless divine persons sought the Dao of life. They aligned their aspirations with the qi of the Primordial, constantly yearning for the longevity of long life, ever mindful not to lose the intent of the Primordial qi. At dusk they settled their thoughts, at dawn they inquired after its well-being, clinging tenaciously to life, never forgetting. From time to time, they would look about, exhausting the utmost of their loyalty and sincerity, reverently following the wishes of the Primordial qi. Thus, they were enabled to ascend and move with clarity, their radiance illuminating the four directions, perceiving things unseen, and hearing sounds unheard, their comings and goings above and below all governed by principle. The host of spirits and refined qi would come of their own accord, attending to their countenance, fearful of displeasing them or losing their favor. All held reverent hearts, their garments and footwear transforming accordingly. They embraced and bestowed kindness, spreading virtue above and below, their fame flowing to the four directions, the six poles, and beyond the eight extremities, extending even to the ancient sages, each receiving the consequences of their good and evil, their generosity and meanness. Covered by boundless grace, they reverently followed the mandate, moving even the stars and constellations. With limitless resources and limitless virtue, they selected the steadfast and good to shield and conceal themselves. Their wishes fulfilled, their hearts at ease and joyful, they attained lives of immeasurable longevity. Serene and content, with little need for embellishment, they preserved themselves whole, never slackening. Others could not know them, nor could they hear of others—without rank or merit, how could they ascend to stand alongside the Primordial qi? Thus, they cherished, loved, and nurtured themselves, and in their abundant generosity, they bestowed without omission. How could they fail to receive blessings?

Yet they reflected: their comings and goings were within the harmony of heaven and earth, their illumination reaching the sun, moon, and stars. They drew clarity from the twenty-eight constellations ahead, carefully observing the cyclical signs governing the people, the patterns of good and ill fortune. But few understood. They considered themselves wise, yet in their actions and movements, they brought no benefit to heaven. Violating prohibitions, they invited calamity, even to the point of annihilating their families, severing their lineages, leaving their ancestors without worship. How could their lives remain whole? What could be done for such people? Failing to follow the ancient texts, they believed themselves free of offense against spirits and gods. Yet the three qi were not in harmony, and their fates varied in depth and shallowness. Unable to deeply contemplate misfortune, the gods of the three qi were sent to admonish them. Those who heeded the admonition prospered; those who did not sealed their own fate, descending below the earth, their misfortune flowing to their descendants. Heaven’s mandate was not obeyed; evil was practiced and good abandoned. How could they endure? What the August Emperor did not wish to see was their hastened demise. Yet people, unaware, blamed the azure heavens. When did heaven ever wrong them? They brought it upon themselves. Utterly lacking in foresight, their lives were like those of dogs and sheep—how could they long endure? Like birds in a net, they entangled themselves in its mesh, their greed consuming their bodies. Their peers followed blindly, heedless of their years. Only the wise emerged into the unharmed lands beyond the four borders—how did they alone escape? It was simply the natural course of their fate. Though dwelling among the unenlightened, their lives remained whole, for such was the decree of the times. Few repaid their blessings. Alas, what could be done? They asked, "What have we done to wrong heaven?"

Among the ancients, not one in ten thousand matched their aspirations. Coveting wealth and lust, they disregarded the perils, bringing disaster even within the womb, never beholding the sun, moon, or stars. What sorrow could compare? They left themselves incomplete, their fates bound to the earth. Wretched were these people, and there were many like them—even plants, trees, birds, and beasts fared no differently. They did not strive to correct themselves or rectify their intentions, uttering reckless and evil words. Above, the spirits recorded their deeds; below, there was no escape. Nothing was hidden from their overseers. Each must exert themselves to seek the admonitions of the divine spirits, the convergence of good and ill fortune—how could there be no reckoning?

Thus, the divine persons were commanded to establish prohibitions for the people, enabling them to perceive the taboos of life and death. Those upon whom yang qi bestows favor are recorded in the ledgers of true transcendents; those with transgressions are demoted. Those upon whom yin qi bestows favor are relegated to the ranks of the dead. Reflect deeply and consider carefully, lest you transgress the heavenly principles and the patterns of the earth. Understand human nature, the inner and outer, when to advance and when to retreat. Do not bring blame upon others, that each may extend their years and pass them on to their descendants.

After receiving the admonitions, be doubly cautious in speech. Evil committed below is disregarded above. The people of the vulgar world lack filial piety and loyalty, coveting what they desire, seizing and plundering what is not theirs. Their murderous intent never leaves their lips—how could they hope to live? Calamity and blame await them, sooner or later. Reverently follow the celestial patterns, for the divine spirits record all. Keep your distance from such things; do not test them. To test life is to gain life; to test death is to gain death. When death is certain, there is no doubt. Thus, I reiterate and repeat: do not associate with the ignorant, nor utter even slight deviations.

The Dao of long life lies near, in the three spirits. The three qi combine to form a person; if they fail to combine, they scatter and become earth, no different from tiles and stones, broken and unseen, unable to compare with the whole and complete. The spirits of the three fates reside near the heart. Why cling to or cherish what is flawed? To covet a broken form is to be displayed in the marketplace—when will it ever live again?

Parents grieve in sorrow, wives and children suffer affliction; distant kin rejoice in their misfortune, neighbors regret their belatedness—death flows on to later generations. Yet one who can rectify oneself and do good may thereby regain longevity. Sincerity reaches all things, and nature follows its course. Be vigilant within and without, between yin and yang, through the four seasons of growth and completion—do not violate them. Between heaven above and earth below, within the harmony of the center, all have their own masters. For those with understanding, this is the method by which the enlightened act. Those who aspire to life share the same wish as the Dao of Heaven; the wicked perish before their time—can one not be cautious?

The words of divine beings all receive celestial response; one cannot blame oneself. The term of extended life reaches upward to those who do good, allowing them to fulfill their natural span. The wicked descend into the Yellow Springs. Ponder this, ponder it well—do not recklessly transmit it. Those who are wicked, upon receiving this transmission, will suffer its calamities. Death and life place them in separate realms; none dare speak of it. If one acts wickedly, one must not blame others—there are always those who record such deeds, leaving no room for complaint.

Study the texts to grasp their meaning. Be reverent and cautious with sacred scriptures. Spirits and spectral agents all have their causes. If a destined household encounters this text, be careful not to harm oneself or deceive the virtuous. Heaven diminishes a person’s lifespan, bringing illness and disease—there is no need to seek help from physicians or tormented shamans. The registers are already set to sever it—what further doubt remains? Reflect deeply, contemplate, and consider—thus may one avoid calamity. Once misfortune strikes, there is no salvation.

The Perfected One holds this text to enlighten the ignorant, that they may reform and do good. Do not malign the words of the scripture. What has been said before is reiterated here. The reason is this: life and death alter destiny. Without speaking of its prohibitions, there is no way to preserve it. The natural order is self-evident—one must only know what is true. If the heart delights in these words, one should understand their meaning. Thus, holding to the One allows the body to fulfill its natural span. Holding to the One and reflecting on transgressions may yet extend one’s term.

The Dao of Heaven encompasses countless millions, yet few attain its truth. The *River Chart* and *Luo Scripture* have been abandoned by many. The reason is this: lacking faith in their texts, few achieve transcendence and instead become common folk. Now, therefore, through the masters of the Three Divine Beings, those whose hearts are moved may be inspired. Divine spirits attach to people, unwilling to let earthly qi summon them. Examine and ponder its meaning carefully—do not doubt this text. The masters of the divine beings, having received Heaven’s teachings, thus transmit it to those who comprehend the scriptures.

**Admonition of the Seventy-Two Kinds of Corpse Caution (186)**

Heaven has its four corners, earth has its four corners—thus the sun and moon pass and push one another. The stars have their degrees and measures, illuminating right and wrong. People have nobility and baseness; lifespans have length and brevity, each receiving their fate from the Six Jia. Birth comes early or late; emolument matches its due. Good and evil reside in separate places, not losing even a fraction. Common folk, not knowing this, claim there is no truth. Only when spirit and numen harmonize can one be called human. Only when the spirit and numen reside in the heart can one become a lord of men.

Timely responses are apportioned to their respective domains. Those who receive Heaven’s response are raised by celestial spirits. Those who receive Earth’s response are nurtured by earthly spirits. Those who receive the response of the Center are protected by human and spectral beings. Good responses follow good; good naturally elevates itself. Evil responses follow evil; evil naturally follows. All have their roots, circulating above and below. The waters of mountains and seas, each with their own boundaries, each desire those of good nature who do not oppose them as their household people. The spirits of the land likewise desire the virtuous. Each imposes its prohibitions, communicating upward to Heaven. Those who violate them bring ruin upon themselves.

In households of great wickedness, none—young or old—escape the hatred of spirits and gods. One can only rectify oneself; do not slander the divine. The Dao of Heaven, the Dao of Earth, and the Dao of Man—prohibitions do not favor the empty virtuous. Even the essence of spirit and qi can lend power to humans. The wicked do not escape their records; their deeds are promptly reported above. When transgressions accumulate, the Great Yin presides over the case, applying the law according to its weight. All are recorded in the ledgers of wrongdoing. People, unaware, assume there is no consequence

Those of exceptional ability who reverence and cherish the Dao, virtue, humaneness, and kindness align their power with Heaven and harmonize their intent with Earth. They benefit the central harmony, contemplating encounters with good spirits and gods, each holding to their faith—do not deceive the ignorant. Seeking long life and survival, one need not torment oneself with sorrow and poison. Contemplate and practice the affairs of Heaven above, and the spirits will elevate you, granting transcendence and enduring life, ever gazing upon the sun, moon, and stars. This is the great kindness of Heaven; one should avoid even minor misdeeds, for they too will be sent down. If evil persists unceasingly, households will be extinguished for generations—thus this admonition is reiterated. Those who commit no transgressions are spared, while offenders are deemed ill-fated youths. When one desires wrongdoing, explain and dispel their ignorance to avert misfortune. Often, one disregards others’ words only to regret it later—the speaker’s blessing is in the warning.

The stellar lodges observe humanity; one must not act wrongly. Each shall account for their deeds. The virtuous enjoy long life without doubt. Instruct and admonish the young so they may offer sustenance to their ancestors; otherwise, they erase their own names. Do not violate Heaven’s prohibitions, nor Earth’s punishments. Follow the four seasons in compliance, avoiding the taint of killing. The Five Phases bring completion—each must guard their place. Let no evil name arise. Do not slight superiors or inferiors, for all alternately govern one another, ensuring no sudden or violent ends, and thus attaining illustrious renown.

Reflect deeply in the heart, cautiously distancing the form. When essence and spirit disperse, malevolent ghosts startle the person. Contemplate self-preservation, never forgetting your name. Each has their joys—pursue the Dao and seek goodness to extend years and increase longevity, even attaining long life. Be cautious, be ever cautious—do not pervert justice in punishment. Though initially taxing, honor follows thereafter.

Masters may be good or evil; contemplate the root to perfect the branch. Disobedient disciples also forfeit their names and cannot attain transcendence. Violating the Earth’s punishments and spirits only compounds wickedness, barring rebirth. Be cautious, again be cautious.

Within the body, the radiance of spirit arises naturally. Inner and outer become one; movements and words follow propriety without losing sincerity. The Five Spirits reside within, knowing one’s shortfalls and longevity. Do not lightly transgress, for records are kept. Even minor faults are reported above to the Hall of Light. Form and spirit are bound and interrogated regarding one’s deeds. Grave offenses incur irrevocable consequences; lesser ones reduce one’s years. If the spirits do not exonerate, the person bears the penalty—there are laws and punishments. Not only living people act thus; spirits, ghosts, and entities do the same. The ancients, knowing this, dared not transgress. The reckoning of humans and spirits descends from Heaven and Earth. Without merit, one cannot expect reward.

The hearts of the worthy and sagely illuminate the scriptures. The scrolls contain warnings and prophecies—evil people act perversely. Those who covet life are protected by Heaven. Those who covet nurturance are aided by Earth. Those who covet humaneness are beloved by all. To exceed this and do evil is to invite destruction. Heaven knows their wickedness and dispatches malevolent spirits and spectral entities to await them, entering the body and flowing outward to the four limbs, head, face, abdomen, back, chest, flanks, and the Seven Governors. They ascend to report to the Hall of Light, manifesting in seventy-two forms—this is the corpse of death. When the Five Viscera are afflicted, their departure has its time. Be cautious in diet, avoid being assailed by wind and cold. Move in accord with virtue, and this is the span of a full life.

Heaven covets human life; Earth covets human longevity. Humans covet humaneness, but to act wickedly invites calamity beyond remedy. Thus, Heaven’s scriptures instruct and command the people not to violate the prohibitions. Heaven’s qi issues words through people—each should wash away impure conduct. Be cautious, do not forget, and joy will follow. Otherwise, there is no need to persist—[words indistinct] as spoken.

Write Not in Vain, Solely for Self-Admonition: One Hundred Eighty-Seventh

In ancient times, the words of divine sages never strayed from the guiding principles, for they held to standards and measures. The ignorant must each take heed—this warning cuts deep indeed. Whether punishment for transgressions is light or severe, all arises from human action, not mere emptiness; one invariably receives what is due. Heaven’s nature is spontaneous and cannot be deceived. Reflect deeply and without cease, and your conduct shall become that of the celestial spirits.

Transformation occurs in its time; do not lose the guiding principles. The qi of the four seasons must not be violated. When the spirit is present, negligence is no longer possible. Should one fail to report, Heaven will divine it, and the gods will act to prevent falsehoods from being concealed—only then may one live. Otherwise, punishment will be meted out: selling vegetables in the marketplace, unable to receive or take, one’s face marked by the moon as shameful, despised by others, scorned by the multitude. For grave transgressions, the penalty runs deep—forty years must pass before one may again ascend as a messenger of the gods. For middling offenses, thirty years; for lesser, ten. The domains they once governed are stripped away, each with its own appointed order. Yet if one can reform the heart and reproach oneself, one may once more endure long. Do not alter Heaven’s words and thereby invite blame upon yourself—can you not reflect deeply?

For those destined to become immortal adepts, weigh carefully the depth of your considerations. Blame rests with oneself; do not resent the words of the gods. In all your comings and goings, inner and outer, be vigilant against error or omission. Examine closely what you have received, for when entrusted by Heaven as its emissary, you may not act at will. You must promptly accept the mandate and may not delay, for reproach will come swiftly. For grave transgressions, the messenger is demoted, and the earth records what was received—name and document alike—with no delay permitted. Where a vacancy arises, one of lower rank fills it. The reason is this: even those whose hearts are wholly devoted to immortality may be demoted—how much more so the foolish adept?

From this point onward, take care to commit no further violations. Heaven holds humans accountable for their transgressions, and ghosts and spirits serve as its agents. Those who defy Heaven’s teachings will invariably encounter misfortune and blame, not through whipping or flogging, but through the natural course of their actions. Should you doubt this, you will be regarded with suspicion and may not remain long. Thus, the warning is repeated: be cautious indeed.

Do not imitate the ways of common folk, who with wine and meat seek to reconcile and appease. The Dao of immortality is most weighty, and thus it is spoken to humanity. Those whose fate is to endure are dispatched by the spirits, riding clouds and dragons, traversing all before coming to rest. When Heaven issues its commands, they must once more be carried out. Do not lose the rules and principles, nor neglect the records, for evidence is set in place, and one should not presume to act on one’s own. Heaven too rests, and each receives their due punishment—there is no cause for resentment. When reported by the spirits, do not transgress recklessly.

Between Heaven above and Earth below, the children of harmony must each respect themselves, lest they blame Heaven for misfortune or Earth for calamity, and thus be detained above or below. Even as with the people, when the words of decrees and commands lack sincerity, those below grow resentful and do not remain long. If the gods of Heaven contend over the Dao, how much more so the common folk? One ought to uphold and comply with Heaven’s laws, follow the harmony of Heaven, discard the root of recklessness, and cast off the garments of negligence. With merit, one may advance further. One may preside over those of the same rank, and when reporting, there is a fixed time. Act in accordance with the texts, without doubt. Each has their own report, and there is no mutual resentment when both are equal. Those who jointly recommend another will be punished and further debased. Though not immediately demoted, when dispatched by a great spirit, one may not act on personal inclination but must deliver the matter to the local earth deity, never to ascend again. Thus, when a vacancy arises, one’s person does not occupy it, for the ranks—high, middle, and low—are intermingled as one.

Heed these words carefully, lest the span of your life be forfeit and bound to the earth. The earth here is not the soil of the ground but possesses its own fierce spirits, who guard it as Heaven’s earthly emissaries. Should one fail to act as instructed, suffering will swiftly follow. Even immortals may err—how can mortals presume to act at will? Thus, the Controller of Fate is commanded to remain close to the heart and mind, never far from a person. Humans are the dwelling place of spirit and essence; fortune and misfortune lie within. Why seek to flee afar? To bring turmoil upon oneself is to hasten ruin, and when life is not yet spent but one’s allotted years are exhausted, distance is of no avail.

When Heaven convenes the spirits, the master knows life and death. Should the spirits themselves err or falter, they will suffer the consequences. Thus, human lives may not endure long, and so divine messengers are sent to display their writings. Those who receive the warnings and cease their evil may yet delay their report to Heaven for a brief time. In eating the various grains, take care never to burn mountains or break stones, nor to extend harm to grasses and trees, to break blossoms or injure branches, or to sell their fruits in markets and streets, cutting them with blades so that stem and root are utterly destroyed. Their mother will grow angry and report to their father, who will not spare the years of humans. Humans too require plants for their sustenance, but one should take only what is withered and fallen, not flourishing—this is to follow the natural order. Heaven and Earth give life as humans desire to live—why act with abandon and harm future generations? Those with understanding must not violate the prohibitions.

There are those who harm others, yet they rely on the completion of affairs without taking the young and tender. Those who provide food for others may extend their lives slightly, but their names are ultimately recorded. Do not raise weapons to rob, harm, or coerce lives. Heaven has decreed that such people may not live long. Evil begets evil, troubling the spirits and the qi of ghosts and spirits, each of whom may not rest. Is this not the fault of human transgression?

Those who previously committed evil will have their misfortune descend upon their descendants. Thus, children may be born on inauspicious days, or during pregnancy when thunder, lightning, the waxing and waning of the moon, the new moon, the dark of the moon, blood taboos, or opposing branches converge to join yin and yang—such children will not thrive and will surely meet with misfortune. The qi of the earth summons them, yet they blame the wolf in the granary. Evil is repaid with evil—what more can be hoped for? Those who do not change will bring about their own extinction, leaving no household. In death, they will not be equal to the multitude.

The officers, soldiers, and ranks of this company, when they reach desolate and unclean places, are scarcely covered with earth before foxes and dogs devour them. Their remains ungathered, cast aside by the roadside, both soul and spirit suffer without respite. Some cling to grasses and trees, consumed by the six livestock—when shall they be reborn? Punishment for evil and reward for good are known to all; why not reform oneself? Heaven repays merit and withholds from the virtueless. Ponder this, ponder it well. Rewards and punishments are clear.

One may die in solitary agony, yet the span of life for good and evil must ebb and flow. Examine this carefully, be cautious, and you may avoid blame. Thus, this solemn warning is given to prompt repentance. The convergence of fortune and misfortune lies worlds apart. Therefore, this text is set down to admonish and caution: do not blame Heaven or fault the earth, for good and evil must be distinguished.

The text records one’s allotted fortune, teaching that evil may turn to good, though the soul and spirit labor to exhaustion. Fools remain ignorant, so the words are repeated, reiterated, and passed on, lest later generations incur blame. By this, one may verify for oneself—what grievance remains? No resentment lingers, for each receives their due.

This text must be transmitted without cease. The wise may shorten their years, but fools will copy it themselves. Those who disregard its words bring only suffering upon themselves.

**The One Hundred and Eighteenth Admonition on the Bridge of Punishment for the Dead with Transgressions**

In the age of antiquity, divine sages foresaw the future and governed in harmony with Heaven. They were deployed across the four directions, above and below, and at the center, each with their appointed ranks and duties. High and low regarded one another, and order was achieved without coercion—all acted with goodness. Fearing any lapse, all shared a single heart.

Heaven’s messengers hastened to carry out their tasks, riding chariots of cloud and vapor, drawn by flying dragons. Divine immortals followed in ranks, each bearing ledgers. Without movement, they aligned themselves, fearing any disruption. Their actions followed rules, and they fulfilled their duties. In spring, they nurtured the qi of life; in summer, they fostered growth; in autumn, they oversaw the harvest, ensuring the people had offerings; in winter, they stored surplus grain, maintaining continuity without lapse.

The blessings of the spirits extended to all, bestowing glory. Even the crawling creatures and grasses and trees received their grace—was this not the benevolence of the above? Each received what was due. When they ate, there was always surplus, the new and old sustaining one another. How could one forget this? Having received the people’s aid, they ensured the spirits held no resentment.

Good people were repaid, each supporting the other in sufficiency. Heaven willed it so; hoarding was forbidden, lest people suffer hunger and cold. Thus, the wealthy were commanded to lend to the poor, exchanging the old for the new, enabling life and growth to be passed to descendants. The spirits protected and aided them—was this not the vast dissemination of benevolence?

Yet fools, lacking understanding, refused to repay or give thanks, assuming it their due. Their hearts grew unbalanced, and they seized others’ possessions to adorn themselves, lacking any thought of repayment or regard for hardship. They believed themselves capable of living out their full span. Thus, the text was written again.

Divine and perfected beings seek the good, those who transmit and apply the text’s teachings. Such people may extend their lives, increase their years, and harmonize with Heaven and Earth, transforming into spirits. They may ride forth, traversing above and below, the center, and the six directions—is this not good? Why not reflect deeply and keep it within? The dwelling of the spirit observes human actions. Knowing one’s due, one should serve and comply, turning from misfortune toward fortune. Even slight discord with Heaven’s will is unwise.

The myriad spirits and officers of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases record human lives. How can one fail to revere them, to contemplate repaying their grace? Those who refuse to do good acts against the celestial spirits. The celestial spirits cause wind and rain to fall unseasonably, altering the flow of qi. When it should be cold, it grows warm; when it should be warm, it turns cold. Planting and sowing occur at the wrong times, and farmers grow resentful, unwilling to tend the land for others. They scorn the grains, feeding them to dogs and swine, then abandon their fields for lands of virtue.

Where they sow, the harvest is meager; trees wither and shed their leaves. The people lack surplus grain, turning to predation and strife, competing for dominance alone. Forgetting truth, they later become the impoverished, reaping nothing, drifting as refugees. Before reaching the lands where grain is scorned, they starve by the roadside, dizzy and blinded, staggering wildly. After days without food, they die of hunger, unburied. No one in their household, great or small, escapes disaster, yet they curse Heaven for their misfortune.

Their land grows desolate, granaries empty of grain, meat scarce, and no coins stored. Year by year, the crisis deepens, leaving nothing to supply the court. Exemptions increase, granaries remain unfilled, and the Minister of Agriculture holds only empty documents. There is nothing to distribute, no salaries to pay, and the central lands lack resources. The people look to the state, yet no aid is given, and a time of great hardship arises.

All this is what Heaven abhors. The earth cannot long sustain such people—do the wicked not understand? Perfected beings must urgently transmit this text to lands of virtue, urging all to reflect and awaken. Only then may they live out their full span. The ignorant are no different from beasts; life cannot be forcibly prolonged. It is attained through one’s own conduct, with no cause to blame Heaven.

Ponder the text carefully, constantly cultivating filial piety, loyalty, trust, benevolence, and generosity. Acknowledge your faults, and you will have descendants. The text does not speak in vain. In lands without virtue, Heaven offers no protection. The celestial balance moves swiftly, and the sun and moon hasten, their light dimmed.

In lands of virtue, the celestial balance slows, and the sun and moon shine brightly—this is Heaven’s way. The celestial balance, the sun, moon, and stars all favor the good and bright. If they dim, it is the result of one’s own actions—what cause is there for blame? They are one with Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars.

Those who witness Heaven’s retribution see its clarity. When the five planets deviate from their courses, weapons and war rage, barbarians invade, and rebels rise. The state dispatches generals and armies; those with fate return, those without perish. This is the fault of the great.

Those who are unfilial as sons produce few loyal ministers in the state; their conduct impure, they invite mutual conflict, which ceases only at the year’s end.

Thus is revealed the *Scripture of the Utmost Cavern*, named *Great Peace*. Those who practice it receive its blessings; those who do not bring upon themselves the utmost suffering, their bodies bound without escape. Retribution is ever just, never unjust. Those who do not act as others do inflict harm upon them.

It is often said that none, whether noble or base, are not born of Heaven—only their recorded destinies differ. Cherish this, be mindful of it, and take heed: do not impose upon others what you ought not, nor encroach upon or oppress the innocent. Such deeds find no recompense in Heaven, no sustenance on Earth. Malevolent spirits follow, and one cannot long enjoy life or delight in existence.

Those who neglect themselves should not expect to live. Without a name in the register of long life, they forcibly enter the halls of the immortals, offering sacrifices to the gods and beseeching transcendence. Yet when the immortals consult the ledgers, they find no name for them—their prayers and offerings go unanswered. Wandering as beggars, they implore the gods anew, only to incur divine wrath. They are devoured by fierce beasts, their bones and flesh consumed, gnawed by foxes and jackals, never to return home. Even neighbors and kin claim they have attained immortality, yet no sign or response confirms it—how can they prove themselves? By this, it is clear: verification is difficult. Only when retribution is witnessed by all is ascension confirmed. Otherwise, they suffer punishment, their claims of partial success mere delusion. Such people are mad or base, yet they take their own words as truth. Together, they enter the realm of the dead, descending to the Yellow Springs, powerless to choose their fate.

Those of virtue who are destined for transcendence have their names recorded in life. When their years are fulfilled, they are received above, and escorts come for them. The young and ignorant, however, know not how to proceed. They squander their wealth, abandon their homes, and wander the wilds in vain. The Way naturally bestows rank upon people—it cannot be forcibly sought. If one inflicts suffering upon oneself, neglects to care for parents, or forsakes family to be seen as a worthy scholar, yet remains unfilial, disloyal, and untrustworthy, they may live out their years, but beneath the earth, they will know no joy or ease. With surplus wealth and property passed to descendants, one should provide for their needs without self-imposed hardship. Whether descendants are worthy or not, each lives their own life, free from mutual harm—this is good conduct.

Thus is this text recorded to enlighten the wise. Fools disregard it, indulging in reckless joy and anger, while the wise avoid punishment and evade misfortune. If three admonitions go unheeded, one should desist. Heaven aids the good and does not favor the wicked. Each must be vigilant, refraining from mutual blame. Let each act in their own best interest, for all possess understanding. None should transgress against Heaven, nor force what is not recorded in the ledgers—such efforts are futile. The reason is this: Heaven does not protect the rebellious and perverse.

Do not abandon your dwelling or the city walls. Bones join to form the paths, sinews govern the desire for life and fortify the walls, vessels direct movement as the skeletal network, and flesh within the skin serves as the vessels’ covering. The spirit within guards and oversees human good and evil—what need is there for distant concern? The Seven Governors stand watch at the gates of the spirit.

Those who seek the Way and attain life do not leave their dwellings. Through transformation, they unite with the spirit in virtue. What more does the Way require? Thus are good deeds inscribed in Heaven’s records. The ledgers of immortals differ from those of the mundane. At the time of ascension, the gods who oversee the registers and the guarantors arrive, for each knows their charge and the teachings they must uphold. There is an order to advancement, and each must proceed accordingly, not by their own will, but as the host of gods governs, ensuring all align with Heaven’s will.

Those who precede others in cultivation possess hearts of clarity and vision, free from partiality. Their conduct and birth remain unknown to others, for they existed before Heaven and Earth. Their transformations above and below never stray from the Way, though the gods do not fully manifest. They establish the framework, the cycles of years and months, each with attendants to left and right. The stars and constellations are distinguished, each with its charge, tasked with advancing the loyal and assigning divisions. When good is seen, it is advanced; when evil is seen, it is withdrawn. What doubt remains? Each acts by their own effort, never misled by the gods. Thus do they succeed and earn the title *Heavenly Lord*.

Those who govern Heaven’s affairs keep meticulous records, never straying from the measure. The gods who oversee the four directions and their divisions—each direction has its first, second, and third, rotating in sequence above and below—are called the *Great Year*. The *Great Yin* follows behind, overseeing the patterns of the Earth. The four seasons are established, governing all that is born and completed, dwelling in the wilds with their early and late grains and grasses. Those near do not live long, while those far endure, and the trees of sacred groves grow small of their own accord.

When dynasties change, punishment extends to descendants. The reason is this: those who do not dwell in peace, who abandon the old for the new, find their spirits unsettled. Each person has a life-tree planted in Heaven’s soil, its type determined by the season of their birth. Those born in spring’s third month have mulberry as their life-tree; those born in summer’s third month, jujube or plum; those born in autumn’s third month, catalpa or *Platycodon*; those born in winter’s third month, locust or cypress. These are the trees of the common people, each overseen by an official. As life nears its end, the tree withers halfway; when life ends, it withers and falls, and the official fells it. How then can the person live? To seek long life and avoid death, one must transform their heart and will, transplanting their tree near Heaven’s gate, where it is called *Long Life*. The divine officials oversee it, keeping it pure, radiant, and lustrous, born of Heaven’s domain, protected by the honored spirits.

If one can but preserve their name from ruin, Heaven’s constant mandate ensures generation upon generation of glory. Though they may not descend to protect, in time, they will naturally attain refinement. The reason is this: having long departed from the mundane, they engage in Heaven’s affairs and cannot falter. The gods examine them as a carpenter’s line and ink—how can they act of their own accord? Thus do they not descend, and one should not find this strange. When merit is due, it is recognized, for they are not like the common folk. Though others may see no benefit to their families, they are inwardly honored—is this not good?

Thus is this revealed to later generations, to awaken their hearts. Do not conceal this text, for concealment invites punishment. Do not associate with the deceitful or those whose hearts lack filial piety and loyalty. All should act in accord with the text’s words, lest they face reproach. Can one not be cautious?

This record is for the wise. The foolish disregard it, indulging in reckless anger and joy, while the wise avoid punishment and evade misfortune. If three admonitions go unheeded, one should desist. Heaven protects the good and does not favor the wicked. Each must be vigilant, refraining from mutual blame. Let each act in their own best interest, for all possess understanding. None should transgress against Heaven or force what is not recorded in the ledgers—such efforts are futile. The reason is this: Heaven does not protect the rebellious and perverse.

Let transmission be to those worthy of it, that they may safeguard and elevate it. Do not violate the sacred texts, nor test the divine words; heed the admonitions of the gods, for Heaven metes out retribution. Do not lightly transgress, lest calamity follow—minor offenses invite reprimand, while grave faults admit no salvation. Thus do the gods oversee one another, reporting transgressions above; those who act falsely shall face judgment. Matters must be interconnected, not kept private. The gods inspect and uphold one another, so why doubt the need for later remorse? To halt midway is to invite scrutiny; failure to confess the truth will lead to examination, and only then will the guilty be brought low. Thus, all actions are subject to review. Those who persist in wrongdoing shall remain unchanged—this is the meaning. Do not transgress lightly, nor harbor doubt. The laws of the gods are weighty; one must be cautious, deliberate, ponder, and reflect upon them. Is not the Way of long life and enduring vitality worthy of reverence?

Thus is this text revealed to fill the void, to establish good deeds, and to ensure unbroken succession. Those who do good shall see their years lengthen, with no cause for doubt. The natural Dao knows no end; only through awakening and mutual correction can one avoid even the slightest misstep, which invites suspicion. Heaven delights in music to gladden the gods, who in turn listen. The virtuous receive reward, while those whose tones and melodies falter face judgment. Each has their own master; none may lack origin or end. Those who fail to cultivate virtue consume from Heaven’s granaries and wear the robes of the Minister of Agriculture, yet their cold and warmth shift like garments. The yang is honored, the yin debased; coarse and fine, all things—gold, silver, brocade, pearls, jade—are to be evenly distributed, with no arbitrary bestowals. Only those with merit may receive Heaven’s clothing and sustenance. As stated before, this is reiterated to prevent resentment or suspicion, for Heaven holds the commands of the gods in great esteem.
