**The One Hundred and Ninety-Third Secret Transmission of the Nine Lords and the Supreme Sovereign**

Only the Supreme Sovereign possesses the law and order, illuminating and penetrating all, knowing all without exception, foreseeing events yet to unfold. Before the spirits speak, their intent is already known; before their forms appear, their actions are foreseen, leaving no room for deception. How could the words of the Supreme Sovereign fail to move all? Yet though people revere them, their hearts do not fully enact them—this is known, though their intent is not fully reflected.

The reason is this: the Supreme Sovereign is wholly divine, governing all that is born and transformed, all that lives and thrives. All is recorded in the divine registers, their ranks and stations clearly ordained—how could any fail to comply? Above the Nine August Ones stand the Nine Lords, who are the kin of the Supreme Sovereign. Each has their own domain, bestowing grace and favor, and all spirits follow their lead. The spirits honor their deeds, and none fail to comply. Lesser spirits, unable to grasp the intent of the Nine August Ones, how much less can worldly people?

With a sagacious mind and keen ears, one may perceive the patterns of fortune in their writings. The celestial registers, inscribed with radiant words, are etched on tablets of gold, their texts formed of silver. These records reside with the Heavenly Lord, with duplicates kept in the innermost chambers. Other documents and memorials are written on jade slips, their characters infused with spirit, their names shining with luminosity. With every utterance, illumination follows, revealing all that is known, never contradicting what is spoken.

When divine beings and perfected ones receive the Heavenly Lord’s decrees, they fully proclaim the affairs of spirits above and below, all knowing the matters of the mortal realm. The Heavenly Lord, aware of the spirits’ words, ensures they adhere to the rules of script and measure. The natural Dao—what does it not know? What does it not transform? Its movements and actions are free from partiality.

They partake of the celestial kitchens’ fare and wear garments of pure essence—what more could they seek? Such is the conduct of the Supreme Sovereign. Great and small spirits each have their roles, all revering and respecting one another, never acting with selfishness. They follow their desires, moving with purposeful intent, knowing what can be achieved, never allowing confusion to cloud their minds, guiding each person according to their deepest wishes.

They declare: "You have all received the immortal registers, and your lifespan shall know no end. Adorned with purple cords inscribed with gold and silver, you shall be enfeoffed as marquises with domains to govern, your intestines filled with silken brocades, gold, silver, pearls, and jade—whatever your heart desires shall be yours."

Yet this is not the path of immortals. They discern whether a person’s resolve is firm or faltering. Some are granted the semblance of beauties and jade maidens, crafted to test their composure and advantage. If their will wavers, the forms of great and small shift before them, their thoughts trailing after them, their minds fixed on posterity—this is the way of failure.

Some are placed in deep mountains and vast valleys, among beasts and tigers and wolves, or in deep waters, to test their hearts. Others encounter venomous creatures, compelling them to act. Some fear ascending high mountains, entering deep valleys, or venturing into deep waters—such is the path to failure.

These trials warn the unwary, for only those with unwavering resolve and single-minded focus can withstand delusion and remain steadfast. They traverse mountains and valleys, deep and vast, waters profound and wide, their hearts unafraid. Though they encounter beauty, their will does not covet it. Though the semblances of family, great and small, seek to restrain them, they do not heed their words, holding fast to the Dao. Advancing to meet the Supreme Sovereign, they fulfill their loyalty and filial devotion without regard for lesser concerns—this is the way to success.

Thus we admonish the multitude, extracting the essential teachings. Heaven trusts the virtuous, allowing the immortals to deliver them. If a person is inherently good, how could Heaven deceive them? Those who are deceived harbor doubts, forcibly demanding immortality, seeking ease without merit—how could they not be deceived?

Heaven cherishes life, favoring those of sincere intent and steadfast will, urging them to grasp the Three Illuminations. The Three Illuminations reside in the heart, governing the Hall of Light, channeling the radiance of the sun and moon. When the Three Illuminations attain the Dao, the heart’s resolve remains unshaken, and the records are inscribed—not to be forcibly sought.

Those who ascend to heaven in broad daylight possess true essence, their nature inherently good, their hearts inherently luminous. They move with caution, their will unwavering, unmoved by wealth or profit. Their garments are coarse, barely covering their forms—such is the conduct of those who ascend to heaven.

Heaven cherishes their goodness, sending benevolent spirits to guard and protect them, shielding them from harm. The celestial spirits love them, ensuring the completion of their merit. Such is the result of their own conduct. They do not covet worldly affairs or amass wealth, and thus their deeds are perfected.

The heavens recognize their utmost sincerity, recording their names in the celestial ledgers as true beings, each accompanied by a benevolent star. From the moment of their birth and the hour of their arrival, they refrain from evil, and the heavens further favor them, transforming their greed to aid the Heavenly Lord in governing the celestial documents, ensuring their clarity and unobstructed flow, their actions free from selfish concealment.

Their years of conduct are witnessed, their names inscribed in the honored registers of the living, aligning with the will of the Most High. They can articulate their merits and deeds, assisting where others fall short—such individuals are rightfully cherished and protected by the spirits. The heavens trust those who are filial, sincere, and whose conduct is without blemish or flaw. Thus, they are met with celestial escorts in broad daylight, their arrival and departure resplendent, visible to all people, their merit complete, inspiring others to witness goodness.

Among those who ascend in daylight, not one in a million attains this. Those who do are greatly trusted and safeguarded by the celestial deities. Others cannot compare to those who achieve liberation through *shijie*; even among millions, only one emerges. Though their merits vary in magnitude, they recommend and elevate one another, and such individuals are deeply cherished by the heavens.

Within, they gain the trust of the Most High, who recommends them as proven and faithful, each achieving their merit and renown—could this be anything but good? When the Heavenly Lord issues decrees, the spirits do not distort his words. The Heavenly Lord, having witnessed their faithfulness, knows what is yet to come, allowing not even a hair’s breadth of deceit. All are granted extended lifespans, even those who achieve minor liberation later. If their thoughts or words remain incomplete, they continue to contemplate the Dao.

**Admonition One Hundred Ninety-Four: The Unfilial Cannot Long Endure**
From ancient times to the present, the world has rarely met expectations. If one seeks only self-satisfaction, refusing loyal service to affairs...

Those who speak and teach delight in nothing extraordinary; when they see others doing good, they smile and speak—yet what benefit does this bring? Their words are careless and reckless, deceiving even father and son. They turn away in silence, then speak behind others’ backs, whether of good or ill, setting no standard to follow, offering no benefit to the world. The world is but dust and grime, where speech stirs on its own, and none respond to virtuous writings. Though their hearts claim goodness, their conduct does not match; lacking steadfastness, their words drift and sink, unworthy of trust. Such are the reckless—how can they endure long? They cannot be equated with those of good heart and resolve.

Those who seek life and dread death wish not to see such wicked men, yet fail to recognize their own nature, boasting of their strength and few who can surpass them. Instead, they lie in wait day and night to seize wealth without righteousness, avoiding toil to obtain it, believing they may long abide in harmony, speaking among others. Yet those beside them see through them and reproach their words. The spirits, hearing and observing their deeds and movements, know their hearts’ wickedness and that their goodness cannot last. They report to the heavenly gods: "Within the harmony of the Dao, there is one of reckless speech and careless words, whose goodness cannot endure. In but a moment, their evil words reappear, devoid of trust or proof. They only engage in flattery and deceit—what benefit do they bring to others?"

They are granted the grains to eat and silks and cloth to wear, changing garments with winter and summer, seeking food to please the palate and clothes to please the body. Though the market offers profitable gain, they refuse to seek it, yet claim to support aged parents. At dawn, they rise from bed, not knowing where they go. They peddle all they possess, shifting between host and guest, lounging in taverns with legs splayed, jesting and laughing, singing and dancing, making merry, boasting of their vigor. They whisper among themselves, spreading gossip and slander. When their wealth is exhausted and nothing remains to sustain them, they band together in wrongdoing, becoming wicked men beyond restraint. How could they find even half a day of goodness? Their actions bring no benefit to the household, only sorrow and poison to parents, siblings, wives, and children, who must ever bear this grief without relief.

Their plundering and theft know no end; though they see their hair turn white, they remain unaware that the spirits sent by Heaven stand at their side, enter their bodies, and hasten their deeds. They are made to meet misfortune, their years cut short, for their clamor of evil cannot be stilled. When their crimes reach the authorities, they are seized and lawfully punished, their lives not spared. Compared to death, how can they live again? Or they may be harmed by ghosts and spirits.

Parents ever think of them, seeing only their solitary tears and lonely vigil, with none to aid or support. In old age, they are cast aside, their food foul and meager, rarely tasting anything rich or fine. Their clothes and shoes are threadbare, with none to mend them. Such is the extremity of evil—years and months pass, days stretch empty and long, their faces grow hideous, bearing no semblance to human countenance.

As sons of this kind, they leave their parents in old age with no one to rely upon; even kin refuse to acknowledge them. This is the conduct of the wicked, whose offenses rise to the heavens. Their kin suffer for them, their names shrouded in disgrace. When such a son dies, no burial is seen, no shroud or coffin provided—he is simply interred. Foxes and jackals devour him, his bones cast upon the wilds. When shall he again know the comforts of clothing and food?

Thus are the deeds of good and evil made plain: men bring these fates upon themselves. Whom can they blame? How profoundly foolish are the people of the world, failing to weigh the vast gulf between life and death! While alive, they possess the breath of life, behold the radiance of heaven and earth, sun and moon, and stars. But in death, shall they again know the brightness of heaven? In the depths of darkness, when shall light return?

Fools do not ponder deeply, bringing calamity upon their descendants, disasters beyond remedy, misfortunes that flow to later generations. Whose fault is this? If men do not reform, they forfeit their years—should they not then emulate the conduct of the virtuous and the immortal? In every action and word, let there be discipline, bringing benefit to parents, ensuring their well-being, their food rich, their clothes fine, their faces aglow with vitality.

Such is the filial son’s conduct, his strength not that of the wicked. Ought he not alone repay his parents’ nurturing care? To be an unfilial son—when you have children, will they be filial? Good begets good, evil begets evil, as a mirror reflects a man. Do you not know your own nature?

Thus the records of good and evil share the same script, yet the span of life or its absence—how vast the difference! A living man’s years are numbered; when his allotted time is spent, he becomes a ghost, no longer subject to inquiry. The wicked die young, and in the underworld, they are seized and interrogated, held to account for their misdeeds. They endure suffering without respite, never knowing joy. As ghosts, when shall they find pardon?

Such is the extremity of evil: even as ghosts, they remain wicked, with nowhere to turn. Those without sustenance at home take to begging, chasing the fleeting breath of the fugitive, their days numbered. The underworld, too, desires good spirits, not the wicked. Thus, let each reflect upon goodness, not transgressing the proper measure—this alone suffices. Otherwise, what hope remains?

Men should share a common purpose, aligning their wishes with life. Does Heaven favor the unvirtuous? Why then do they persist in evil? The wicked cannot long endure beneath the gaze of heaven and earth, sun and moon, and stars. Thus are they hidden away in the underworld, denied the company of good spirits, bereft of joy or distinction.

Where the text repeats itself, it is to earnestly detest the wicked and deny them long life. The virtuous, favored by Heaven, beget descendants who are likewise good. Day by day, they encounter no taboos, their lives aligned with the moon’s phases and the radiance of sun, moon, and stars. For those born thus, what fear of not attaining long life? Such is the reward of virtuous conduct.

In the contemplation of good and evil, let each follow what brings peace. Heaven does not oppose men’s actions. Ponder again and again, reflect deeply—whether to advance or retreat, those who do not cling to life have no recourse. The words of this text are clear; doubt them not.

Let not suffering reach its extremity. Be mindful of life, never slackening, and heed these words with care. Though the discourse pauses briefly, let its lessons linger. If any point remains unclear, reconsider it.

**Admonition Against Transgressing Evil Precepts, One Hundred and Ninety-Five**

Of those endowed with sagely virtue, each has their say, each their discourse. Each distinguishes their abilities, ranks their merits, and fulfills what is fitting, so that trust may be placed in them, and Heaven’s words revered. Heaven loves mankind and bestows great merit, winning the heart of Heaven—this is the aspiration of sagely virtue.

All men wish to align with Heaven, to grasp its intent, without complaint. Thus, let each follow their resolve, avoiding baseless words, for this is to gain the people’s favor, ensuring their trust and shared understanding, adhering to what is proper.

To dwell in the world is no easy matter. In every action, one must heed what is said, never straying from the established bounds, nor blaming others while shirking self-reproach. Such is the conduct of inequity. Each harbors grievances, provoking Heaven’s wrath and displeasure, declaring that life and fate are inconstant.

Thus, there are those in the world of sagely and harmonious hearts who speak their intent, revealing the origins of transgressions, urging each to reform. For the span of a man’s life arises from within, not from others. Hence, it is said that the Controller of Fate resides near, within the heart, not far from man, overseeing right and wrong. At every fault, it withdraws, and how can there be no loss of time, no shortening of years?

Knowing the unvirtuous, it desires that they heed its warnings, finding peace. In moments of fault, let them reflect, lest they incur punishment and forfeit their years, harboring no resentment. Heaven is vastly forbearing and patient, not meting out punishment in a single day. Only when transgressions accumulate excessively does it dispatch the underworld’s officials to seize the soul, interrogate its deeds, and find them discordant with Heaven’s pattern. Deceit follows deceit, and the confession of faults brings unpardonable sin.

Thus, it again commands clear admonitions, explaining how evil conduct invites calamity, urging reform. If its words are ignored, how can one long remain among the living? Therefore, it distinguishes good and evil, ensuring no grievances arise. Heaven sets prohibitions to prevent transgression. Yet men deliberately violate them, defying the commands of Heaven’s spirits. How can they long endure among men?

Thus, the distinction between good and evil is made, so that none may complain. Heaven establishes prohibitions to prevent their breach. Yet men willfully transgress—let them be warned by the gods. Can they long remain among the living?

Acting thus—can this be the Way to keep men from death? Does the Central Heaven remain unaware? The conduct of common folk cannot be thus adopted. How can they long abide within the harmony of the Center, partaking of what is edible? Yet they turn against the protection of the good spirits, and their years end in exhaustion. When the time of the Central Heaven’s people arrives, this is the proof of goodness. If one does good day after day, why fear not living out one’s full span? Thus, it is known that men cannot strive to do good but harm themselves. How much worse are the evil, who believe they may long share the same fate? Unaware, the gods of Heaven hasten them downward into the earth. Once beneath the soil, when shall they be reborn? Below, they are drawn ever deeper, their corpses dissolving—such are those who receive no Heavenly blessing. Can they still be reckoned among the living?

Let each consider his own conduct and not add to the suffering of later lives—this is the mark of one who is moderately good. Otherwise, one becomes an evil person, unsupported by Heaven, unbearable to Earth. One must be cautious, avoid faults and debts, and thus be counted among men. One may then be a father or mother to one’s children and grandchildren, continuing the bestowal of kindness, and in turn gain added years, with vital essence flourishing, qi and strength robust—all the result of good conduct. Evil naturally declines; what room is there for doubt?

From this day forward, one must carefully weigh and discern, distinguishing good from evil, and reflect on which path to follow. Then one may abide in peace, for Heaven does not oppose what men do. Yet if one ponders and ponders again, acting contrary to what is right while seeking long life—can such conduct long be seen by the gods of Heaven, the sun, moon, and stars? Will they willingly shine upon it? Though protected by the gods of Heaven, one strives to endanger oneself—whose fault is this? Should this not be the conduct of one who is good and filial? Such a person attains rank and emolument, is fed by the Minister of Agriculture, and long governs the people, ensuring that superiors and inferiors serve one another—this is the noblest of men. Such is the result of goodness; evil cannot preserve the body. How great is the difference?

Observe this text and its admonitions. To disregard its words and act as one pleases—is this not to act against humanity? If one has evil and cannot reform, yet possesses filial piety, loyalty, sincerity, and trust, and expects Heaven’s reward; if one falls ill and seeks healing, but has committed too many evil deeds with no time for repentance—can one long be spared? Thus, this text is written to ensure that common folk do not complain when they receive punishment.

Let those who wish to live reflect: if one does not commit evil, one will not forfeit one’s years. Having received this text and its warnings, one should know how to avoid transgressions and not incur evil. If one can reform and do good, one may long behold Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars, and be equal to others—is this not goodness? Yet some disregard their lives, believing that death allows rebirth. As if one who does not know one’s own evil could deem it acceptable! They wish to be equal to others in speech, clothing, and food—can this last long?

Those who fear death dare not violate these admonitions, and this too is the result of their allotted fate. If a person is even slightly decent, one should straightforwardly fulfill one’s destined duty—what is there to hesitate over? Let each be cautious and strive, reflecting on the safety or peril of one’s actions. The admonitions in this text are self-evident.

The Heavenly text desires men to do good and does not wish to hear of their evil. Thus, the register of life is not complete—there is no great mystery in this. Reflect carefully and do not grow lax. Heaven has a register of the living, which may be coveted; Earth has a register of the dead, which is most detestable. Between life and death, there is no comparison—does one not understand this? Knowing evil, one must be cautious and examine oneself. One must not for a moment lose one’s years and lifespan—how lamentable this would be!

When speaking with others, let one’s words and voice win their hearts by doing good. Heaven favors this; let no evil words escape, lest one bring blame upon oneself. Since all share the same breath, one must choose words carefully before uttering them. Not even a single unkind word should be spoken, that one may prolong one’s life. Those who can ponder and practice the affairs of Heaven may obtain the essential words of the Heavenly gods. By heeding their admonitions and acting with reflection, one may alter one’s life register and be transferred to the bureau of long life.

One should cultivate oneself and rectify one’s conduct, never forgetting Heaven’s bestowals. One should set one’s heart on repaying this great kindness, making it easy to reform one’s aspirations. Heaven, in turn, will remember and ensure one does not encounter evil. One may trust the words of the Heavenly text and attain governance without strife.

The text’s words are not complete; one should select what is practicable and act accordingly, not forcing what one cannot do. Let each reflect on the good and evil of one’s own conduct. Heaven endows one’s nature—let there be no doubt. One should not deceive the good, nor should evil people obtain blessings. These words are clear—what room is there for doubt?

Those who become immortals do not commit evil; each cherishes their life—this is the proof of goodness. The text’s words are concise, reiterating the wishes of Daoists past and present. It speaks of the good and evil of the Way, urging reflection. If one does not heed it, the fault is one’s own. Those who complain should know that their complaint stems from their own lack of understanding, which leads to poverty and old age, and ultimately to self-blame.

The rest is left to one’s own will. If one desires to cherish life, one should not commit evil. Thus, one must reflect and know suffering and joy. Whose joy is it? Whose suffering? One must also reflect on this and not utter complaints or reckless words. Let one think carefully and think of doing good—this is why these earnest words are spoken.

Let one’s words be known and not transgress Heaven’s rules. By perfecting the natural Way, what cannot be accomplished? What cannot be transformed? All will welcome it—is this not the natural grace of Heaven?

Consider the foolish below who do not reflect on receiving Heaven’s great share, being born as humans, and believing they will long endure.

Yet one does not expect that there are divine spirits of shamans—one must cease and not offend them. The written admonitions are not few; they emerge again upon reflection. The texts bear duplicates, hence the repeated warnings. Regard those who do not heed the writings: let them reflect on doing good, for there is hope in living. Those who speak wicked and disobedient words are recorded without end. Be cautious and desist; desist and still reflect—reflect afterward on what is lacking, and if unsatisfied, expound further.

**Incantation One Hundred Ninety-Six**
Now, the people of the world each disobey filial piety, turning to rebellion and treachery, competing in disloyal and faithless deeds. They reverse the principle of requiting kindness, believing themselves to have become fully human and to endure long upon the earth. In all they say and teach, there is never the slightest good, only wicked words. Yet they constantly harbor ingratitude and refuse to bestow mercy, acting solely for their own satisfaction, never considering that suffering will follow their words. Such persons do not belong in this world; they ought not to have even a little trust. Stubbornly foolish, they believe they have won the hearts of others. Their spoken thoughts cannot be adopted, nor can they serve as models. Without fear or restraint, they commit transgressions and offenses, acting as they please, reckless of their lives, blind to long-term preservation. In their comings and goings, they do not repay their parents, nor do they attend to them morning and night, treating them as barbarians. Who are these people? From whom were they born? They slight their kin, neglecting food and drink, never understanding the Way. They are no better than the six livestock, with no fixed term for life or death. Their mouths crave fine flavors, their bodies fine clothing—does Heaven intend to let them live long? Their conduct cannot be followed. If they perish, will their deeds be of use? They provoke Heaven’s wrath, leaving no time for joy. Should Heaven cherish their lives and spare them from death? All they do is offensive and improper, yet they persist—this is self-seeking, as if they wish to avoid the sight of Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, stars, and all living beings.

Heaven’s admonitory texts clearly expound good and evil. If one does not believe these words, what recourse is there? Does one wish to live long and breathe freely? Are they not inferior even to the six livestock, birds, and beasts, which possess some understanding? Such extreme folly—how can one rely on the mysterious? They act frivolously, squandering all their wealth, engaging in reckless behavior that invites punishment, devoid of reason. From year to year, they neglect their households, wandering and playing, utterly unaware of restraint. Their thoughts never arise from proper measure, and so they cannot endure. These people owe their lives to their parents, yet their conduct lacks all righteousness. They show no loyalty or filial piety, no obedience, only rebellion. Should Heaven preserve them, allowing their eyes to blink and their breath to continue? Even in death, their transgressions remain, extending to their unborn children. Consider those who bring calamity: though they commit evil in life and die prematurely, they cut short the lives of those not yet born. Their hope of living as ghosts, then dying again, is insufficient to atone—is this not the result of their wickedness? How can they expect to live freely? If those born now resent their faults, why do they speak recklessly and act so arrogantly?

Why do the people of the world not reflect on themselves and reduce their transgressions? What benefit do accumulated faults bring to one’s body? They only shorten human life—should this not be considered? Why do they invite disaster upon themselves? This is plain to see. Those who dwell in the world, practicing filial piety and goodness, attain longevity, their descendants continuing in succession. They witness honorable offices and generous emoluments—is this not the result of doing good and being filial? Those who lack goodness and disregard future suffering are the most rebellious and wicked, beyond comparison, never ceasing. When your parents gave birth to you, did they wish to hear your goodness, or would they rather hear evil words, even in their old age? Siblings who resent one another never know joy. Each blames the other for their faults, yet they persist in their own ways, refusing to do good. Such conduct cannot last. It benefits neither Heaven nor Earth, neither people nor the four seasons, five phases, sun, moon, or stars. Such people are utterly wicked—what do they hope for? Should they not look up in reverence? Do they believe Heaven does not dispatch malevolent spirits to oversee their transgressions? They should not be surprised: in all they seek and do, there is nothing to rely upon. Day by day, they face decline, illness, and unending death—why would Heaven delight in killing them? The multitude says: “You have no understanding; in an instant, they are slain.” Or they may encounter the authorities, their wealth and property exhausted, their grievances and misfortunes continuing—is this not the result of their own conduct? Why blame Heaven and cry out in resentment?

The common people are thus: they wish to offend Heaven—what benefit is there in self-justification? Those who long evade sacrifices owe debts to the spirit officials, refusing to make amends. These debts should be resolved. Always in the third month of spring, on an auspicious day, perform the resolution. Three resolutions may reduce the written records, for spirit officials do not delight in heavily punishing people. Yet if documents persist, with superiors and inferiors shifting blame, how can the words of the common people—who cease when impoverished and do not complete their deeds—be heeded?

In life, all consume tangible things; in death, they should consume qi, yet they do not. Ancestors say that bearing children is for the time after death. Once they attain the consumption of qi, they join their peers and no longer consume one another. If children are born thus, how can you expect your descendants to care for you long? Your life will also end, like those who have gone before. When hunger strikes, what will you gain? In the heavenly offices, great filial piety is required. Sacrifices must be performed clearly—how can there be doubt? For three years after death, before burial, one must offer prayers and thanksgiving. One cannot say, “There are unburied dead on earth, yet no sacrifices are made.” Not eating increases transgressions and faults, harming descendants. This is plain to see—sacrifices must be performed.

Those who were wealthy in life indulged in extravagance, slaughtering cattle, sheep, pigs, and the six livestock for sacrifices. The officials gradually grew distant, and later, they faced reproach, heedless of poverty.

Wealth and property cannot be swiftly acquired, yet conduct remains unworthy—refusing to return what is due, sacrifices cease for long. How can reproach be swiftly resolved? One ought to frequently acknowledge debts and transgressions; only then may goodness follow, and descendants surely live long. Heaven delights in those who confess their faults first. For impoverished households that, knowing the taste of grain, gather to kowtow and strike their breasts in repentance, lifting their faces to thank Heaven—Heaven pities their hardship, and the sacrificial officials lend them means, allowing modest offerings. This is what Heaven grants; though one may possess only modest wealth, one must perform sacrifices without doubt. To fail in this is to meet one’s ancestors at the assembly of spirits, where the sacrificial officials reproach the neglect. Ghosts are sent to guard the home, and illness afflicts the living without end. The ancestors, bound and confined, cannot be consulted through divination; when the proper day arrives, one must act. Heaven’s granted respite expires—failure is not without consequence. One must thank Heaven and Earth, summon the bodily form into the earth, while the hun-soul is examined in the celestial prison, where transgressions are weighed in turn, and death follows in succession. The fault is too grave, thus this text is sent down so that all may know to accept Heaven’s punishment without resentment. Let them warn one another, that none may transgress again. Ancient records exist, yet offenders never cease. For those whose coffins remain unburied, sacrifices must not be neglected. Now this text is extended once more, for those of sincere heart to read and comprehend its meaning. Doubt not its words—still one may be inscribed in the register of the living. To doubt and fail to act is to fix the day of death. Reflect upon this; do not blame Heaven or fault the Earth.

Proceed, and let this text rest briefly in your thoughts. Thereafter, ponder its words, understand what must be done, and return to the Dao.

**Heaven’s Faithful Retribution: Divine Formula One Hundred Ninety-Seven**

Only those who advance in goodness and seek life, who delight in repaying Heaven’s will, may extend their years from the present. Those who witness Heaven’s workings above say: “I too shall follow what Heaven transforms and accomplishes.” When they see the scriptures of long life, their forms and countenances change, their essence and spirit flourish, their radiance increases daily, without cease. Such are those of sincere and virtuous intent, who never forget Heaven’s grace. Those who repay kindness—when would they ever resent? Even in moments of rest, their hearts reproach themselves, grateful to have been born human and to rely upon Heaven’s completion. They come to know Heaven’s prohibitions, shunning harm and pursuing goodness, never opposing the divine. Seeing goodness, they follow it, never failing to reproach themselves and repent, turning toward rectitude. They ponder its meaning, never daring to grow complacent or doubtful. In their resolve to do good, they awaken to Heaven’s will, understanding it fully—no doubt remains. Reproaching themselves and repenting, days accumulate; having received blessings and protection, they uphold Heaven’s transformation, spared from peril. Knowing they receive Heaven’s recompense, how could they forget even for a moment? They fear the divine may reproach their words, thus they remain disquieted, never at ease. Driven by the desire to advance, they strive to fulfill Heaven’s will, fearing any lapse. Thus they purify their hearts and reform their conduct, moving the powers above, yearning for ascension and coveting life. Truly, they dread the term of short life, fearing prolonged absence from Heaven and Earth. They exhaust their strength and devote their loyalty, pondering their sincerity. Having heard the words of the divine many times yet never seen their forms, their hearts cannot rest, ever reverent and fearful, anxious day and night, never daring to grow complacent. For this reason, they dare not abandon goodness for evil deeds.

All people receive food and drink, inhaling Heaven’s primordial qi, allowing them to breathe. Knowing human sentiment, they understand they receive Heaven’s grace and must repay it—when would there be doubt? Heaven engenders the essence of humanity; Earth nurtures their form, allowing them to grow and mature. Seeing Heaven’s admonitions and reading its words, they tremble without fear, how could they speak in defiance? Their hearts ever quake—when would they know peace? Only the great divine, in timely mercy, repeatedly grants leniency, though they know they cannot repay such great kindness in full. Only the great divine, in boundless compassion, allows them to remain long within the qi of life, extending the years of their allotted span. They dare not forget the measure of great grace, nor the fullness of its bestowal, never daring to slacken even for a moment, nor betray its favor. Only the great divine completes them, allowing them to see the celestial spirits and converse with them, longing to hear further admonitions. They hold Heaven’s words in reverence, and only when they receive its response do they dare trust. The great divine responds to the words of the virtuous: the Heavenly Lord ever cherishes those of sincere and good heart, advancing them when they prove useful to Heaven.

From now on, those of sincere and virtuous heart may present themselves and report to the Heavenly Lord, who will heed and employ their offerings without doubt. Surely it shall be as previously stated—this is what the Heavenly Lord dares to affirm. As the years and months draw near, strive to trust Heaven’s words. Heaven too trusts those of sincere and virtuous heart, who no longer dwell among the common. Their names are recorded in the celestial register, among those who ascend to Heaven in broad daylight—this covenant is not deceitful. The Heavenly Lord desires to advance the good, those of sincere heart who do not defy His words—such are the ones. The great spirits, from afar, witness their conduct. Though their households may lack for a time, as previously stated, they need not worry. Let them constantly reflect that they shall stand before the spirits of Heaven above—this is the result of goodness, and they must not grow weary.

Those of sincere and virtuous heart say: “In life, I am no ascendant being, yet I resolve to repay the great divine, seeking advancement and coveting life. I exhaust all I know—how dare I hope for ascension in broad daylight?” When selected, they are deemed worthy, yet in life, they dare not presume. They fear being reproached by the great divine, yet by grace, they are fortunate to receive favor, their allotted measure of grace fulfilled. They regret only that they have not yet repaid it in full, and pray the great divine may grant them respite to recover. Hearing the great divine’s words, they compare their former intentions with their present resolve, advancing them to the Heavenly Lord, who declares: “This is one of sincere and virtuous intent.” The Heavenly Lord desires to draw near them, allowing no doubt.

The bestowal of grace does not lie with the great divine—why then speak of repayment? Rather, one ought to clarify what one knows, ensuring that there is indeed a sign of reciprocation, and simply offer sincere gratitude with a pained heart. Thus shall the gods protect them, allowing no malevolent spirits to interfere. Be ever cautious in speech, making goodness the foremost topic, and inscribe words with trust as their bond, so as not to betray those of sincere and virtuous intent. Day and night, Heaven itself commands the divine generals to guard them, leaving no room for doubt. As for writings that command or obstruct, let them first be borne by those who inherit past burdens, and do not take them as cause for worry.

Those of sincere and virtuous resolve say: “By nature, I am humble and lowly, long mired in the mundane world. I fear I cannot extricate myself from its midst, yet I yearn for the favor and kindness of the great divine, moved by their warmth and sincerity to recognize my own worth. Only when the great divine reports to the Heavenly Lord am I placed among the ranks of the undying—how then dare I hope for ascension in broad daylight?” The great divine replies: “The Heavenly Lord trusts those of sincere intent who advance in virtue. His decree admits no double promise, no room for doubt—this is the will of the Heavenly Lord himself. Though you may worry over your family’s insufficiency, with hunger and cold pressing upon you, Heaven’s kitchen is ever at hand. Simply look upward to accomplish the task, and the gods will themselves instruct your children—cast aside such concerns. After receiving your allotted measure, how could you ever forget the words of the great divine? Your only fear is that you may fail. You dare not neglect the great divine’s pillow and mat, keeping them ever in your heart and breast, never slackening.”

Such are the words of the great divine. The Heavenly Lord, who knows all, deems that goodness naturally attains goodness, and sincerity naturally wins the Heavenly Lord’s favor. When the matter was previously presented to the Heavenly Lord, he commanded the great divine: “As I have already stated, the day this person is to ascend must not be missed. Let no delay occur. The tally is already set within their heart, and the gods, seeing clearly, speak in confirmation. Transformation will come on the appointed day—only remain steadfast in thought day and night.” The disciple replies: “After receiving such a decree, how dare I slacken? Will I truly be made whole?” The great divine says: “You must inscribe the tally, and it will be seen for yourself. Have no fear of failing to attain heavenly longevity. It is not only the great divine who speaks thus—all the gods affirm that this is a person of sincere heart, and all the gods are concerned for them. Simply look upward to accomplish the task.”

The disciple says: “Such a weighty matter—if it comes to pass as wished, I shall only humble myself in reverence.” The great divine replies: “This is also the wish of such a person. One ought to respond with a sincere heart. The Heavenly Lord values their family, ensuring they do not fall into grave transgression. The burdens they bear shall be resolved—do not trust the words of spirit-mediums or diviners, for their divinations can neither add nor subtract. Those who seek to deliver and enliven others must rely on the true gods. Even if lesser spirits are negligent, the higher powers will resolve it—do not act recklessly in ways that are improper. This is known to those of sincere heart who walk the Dao.”

Each must consider their own path, trust in Heaven’s words, for Heaven does not deceive those of sincere intent who advance in virtue. Though you may know kindness and constantly reflect upon it, never forgetting for a moment, beware: when malevolent spirits descend from below, those without resolve, who fail to guard themselves and indulge in reckless thoughts, will be cast down, unsettled, and their endeavors may come to naught. This scripture does not trust the wicked, nor do the wicked trust this scripture. Only when efficacy is demonstrated and reciprocation is received can it be truly known. Now, you must have faith in the writings of those who advance in virtue, for the gods themselves desire to see the sign of reciprocation. Those who lack sincere intent to advance in virtue will find nothing. The words of this scripture are already clear—when the sign is seen and verified, it will not be long.

How is this made evident? For those who delight in life, Heaven causes them to rejoice—this is Heaven’s sign of reciprocation. Such a person will surely transform into a divine being, ascending in broad daylight without doubt. Day by day, they grow lighter, their food intake diminishes, and their essence and radiance become ever more refined. Day by day, they draw nearer to the gods—this is the sign, the clearest of proofs. Have no doubt.”

The disciple says: “Having received your admonition and decree, I shall follow your words, reflecting upon and bearing them in mind, never slackening or forgetting.” Though I was once ignorant, after our meeting, I have grown ever closer, as if no different. The great divine says: “Excellent, excellent. You shall indeed be favored to succeed. Your name is fitting, and you shall complete the work—this is the constant admonition of the gods. Though the scripture’s words are many, they are weighty for the sake of the Way of life. Do not be alarmed, for the words will soon come to an end. Each has more to say to those of sincere intent and reflection.”

“Yes, yes. I dare not forget.”

**Decree on Advancing the Method, One Hundred and Ninety-Eighth**

Reflect upon the people of great sincerity and trust from ancient times to the present, each demonstrating efficacy and accumulating merit before Heaven, thus daring to step forward. In their actions and retreats, they have never committed even the slightest transgression. They constantly harbor compassion and benevolence, bestowing kindness and favor to benefit the multitude. They do not lose even the smallest trust, nor do they fail to revere Heaven and Earth, following the guidance of the four seasons and the five phases, aiding in the generation and completion of all things. They dare not harbor any intention of failure that would endanger themselves and bring instability. Thus, they examine their own transgressions and burdens, fearing they may not be resolved, and that the multitude of gods will record them, reporting them to the Most High.

For this reason, they dare to rest in peace. From ancient times to the present, goodness and evil flow in succession—when has there ever been an end? Therefore, they remain composed and tranquil, never slackening or forgetting Heaven’s works. Those who seek virtue reflect within their own hearts. When they see others with good hearts, they rejoice; when they see others with evil hearts, they are alarmed. They imagine the heavenly gods knowing all, each advancing in their own way. They further reflect: “Originally, I was born in the mundane world, yet my heart constantly yearns for the great transformation, coveting the Way of life and departing from the realm of death. I cherish the essence and radiance, desiring them to remain within me, so that I may love myself and my heart may be at peace. Otherwise, I fear I will not be among those who are constantly seen.”

Only the gods of Heaven, in their timely mercy, instruct them in advancement and retreat, aligning with Heaven’s will. They must not commit even the slightest transgression, lest it be heard by the Lord of the Most High.

Thus, through the gods they seek broad inquiry, and only by not opposing them do they avoid suspicion. Having received a single portion of destiny, they dare not forget it even for a moment. They only reflect upon their words, contemplating the heavenly admonitions to perfect themselves and avoid peril. This is the day of the gods’ favor and grace, and they dare not rest, nor fail to reflect upon repaying this profound kindness.

Before the gods have reported to the Heavenly Lord, they learn of the dispatch and the attending gods who bear the decree. When these individuals speak or act, how can their intentions be fully questioned? The gods inquire of them, then report back: “The people of harmony and equilibrium, who cultivate goodness and accumulate merit over time, covet long life. They humbly declare their constant vigilance, fearing faults or debts, never slackening in their devotion. The gods recount their merits and effects.”

The gods then confer among themselves: “This person of merit and virtue, who reflects within the state of harmony, seeks to repay Heaven’s great kindness. Having long accumulated good deeds, they wish to declare their merits through the gods, yet harbor doubts and dare not advance to report to the Heavenly Lord. They have long entrusted themselves to the gods’ trust, having rendered service to Heaven. Those with merit should be advanced.” Yet the gods observe their conduct over time and wonder why they have not reported it.

The gods, filled with apprehension, say: “Originally, we did not know this person’s arrival, and fear they may not be entirely sincere.” They deliberate on their intentions, unaware whether the Heavenly Lord has heard of them. The gods, lacking resolve, see a meritorious person yet fail to report them to the messengers of the Way. They dispatch spirits to examine their accumulated deeds, finding great merit. The gods, thus without excuse, have no merits of their own, yet share an external mindset, assuming the Heavenly Lord remains unaware.

The gods offer their explanations, asking: “What use is there in this? Is it merely for gain? Can we each be at ease?” They thank the gods, acknowledging their duties, removing their crowns in apology: “We minor spirits, in our official roles, have fully devoted our loyal hearts, yet are questioned for our inexcusable faults, awaiting death at the gate.”

The Heavenly Lord issues a decree: “Wait outside.” He commands the gods to prostrate themselves, standing in peril as they attend. The decree instructs: “The Heavenly Lord does not wish to harm the gods, nor yet bears to inflict injury. They are to be exiled to the land of harmony and equilibrium, in the capital of Luoyang for ten years, selling medicine to cure the sick without accepting excessive payment. After the exile, those of higher rank shall serve in the Hearing Bureau for one year, and only upon merit shall they be restored.”

Thus, the gods, seeing the Heavenly Lord pardon their capital offense and impose only a light exile, truly recognize their transgressions. Humbled and broken, they had not hoped to live, nor borne any intent of harm. They again offer their service to the Heavenly Lord, saying: “We inform the clerks of the Bureau and descend without delay, dispatching spirits to observe and report.”

The Bureau reports and dispatches them as the Heavenly Lord commands. The Heavenly Lord instructs the clerks to inform the great gods, reviewing their documents and ordering one god to inspect them. The clerks transmit the documents to the great gods and their subordinates, each fulfilling their duties. When they see those who covet advancement through merit and goodness, they are to present them, reporting all matters clearly.

The Heavenly Lord instructs the great gods: “Swiftly observe this person and question the dispatched spirits to see if their accounts align.” The great gods reply: “We were sent to observe this person, reviewing their days and merits, and report back. As instructed, we observed the meritorious in harmony and reported as the spirits declared.”

The Heavenly Lord says: “Such a person of merit, yet those under the gods’ charge failed to report them to the Heavenly Lord in a timely manner—was this not negligence? Having received a light exile in the land of harmony, let this serve as a warning henceforth. Those who fail to report merit shall be punished upon the Heavenly Lord’s hearing, bearing their own exile. Each must attend to their duties. Dispatch spirits to guide and transform them, that they may become gods and augment their essence and radiance. Review the registers, and for those not yet recorded, inscribe their names.”

The great gods receive the decree and return to the Bureau, examining the registers for the names. They report to the Bureau: “The documents list this person. We request to consult the Heavenly Lord’s internal registers to verify alignment.” The Heavenly Lord produces the documents and reviews them, finding them consistent with the external records. He then instructs the great gods: “Verify whether their term is complete and report back for careful review.”

The Heavenly Lord asks the great gods: “Did you not fully observe them, yet now request another review?” The great gods apologize for their duties, and the Heavenly Lord says: “Hasten the review and return swiftly.” The great gods then verify that the person’s term is complete. Their failure to report, being inexcusable, incurs guilt, and they await execution.

The Heavenly Lord says: “For now, restore their rank and duties, but do not slacken.” He summons the person to ascend, cautioning them not to neglect their minor duties, knowing how to accumulate merit. “Yes, yes,” they reply, requesting to follow the Heavenly Lord’s decree. “So be it.”

The great gods then appoint the person to a minor post, observing their conduct. As the days and months are yet few, they request further verification of their sincerity. If their merits are great and their trustworthiness genuine, any deficiencies shall be filled by their appointment.

The Heavenly Lord says: “Heed what the great gods have reported and do not slacken.” The great gods reply: “Yes, yes. We request to dispatch spirits to observe and report.” The Heavenly Lord approves.

*Text incomplete: Section 199, "Without Written Decree, the Mandate is Not Fully Concluded"*

Only in Heaven do the sagely and enlightened possess offices and duties, each exhausting their loyalty and conduct, never failing their superiors. Each exerts their strength, and in their actions, never lose intent. They foreknow the Heavenly Lord’s decrees, ever inclining their ears to listen, desiring to grasp his will. They constantly review the documents of the Storage Bureau, distinguishing what must be known. When the Lord summons, there is no fixed time, and they dare not act privately. Only in official matters do they proceed, first reporting their intentions before daring to depart.

Wherever their circuit extends, wherever their reach encompasses, upon receiving the decree they proceed to inspect, never daring to linger even for a moment.
