*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 117*
**Heaven’s Joy in Obtaining Good People: Text Entrusted to the Fire Lord, Secret 207**

Now, the Perfected One has accumulated goodness and is wise, understanding all matters.

At this time, the Supreme Heavenly Sovereign’s qi of equanimity has fully arrived, and there is an urgent matter in the heavens—do you, little one, know of it?

This humble student is foolish and dull, unable to comprehend. I rely entirely upon the Heavenly Master.

Very well. All Perfected Ones, be seated, and I shall fully explain it to you.

Now, the heavens rejoice in obtaining good people, who can regulate wind and rain and bring forth all the myriad things. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, those who do good have been few, and even fewer have aligned with Heaven’s will. Heaven has long regarded this as a source of sorrow, for now, among the people of the earth, there are none who meet Heaven’s requirements.

Why does the heavens not simply create people itself, rather than selecting them from the earth below?

The generation of all things by Heaven and Earth arises from the union of two as one. Now, the heavens above unite with the earth below. The birth of all yang must occur within yin, and thus people are taken from this earth. Moreover, humans contain the qi of both yin and yang, and their procreation must occur in the soil and springs, so they all take after the earth from which they are born. Thus, the customs of the five directions differ, and the world, though small, is not uniform. Therefore, among the twelve thousand states, even the people within a single region do not resemble one another.

Do you understand this?

"Yes, yes. Those born among humans who are perpetually good are entrusted to their fathers, and thus good people are ultimately entrusted to Heaven. The essence of the myriad things—those that are good ascend to unite with Heaven and become the Three Luminaries. Those of middling quality are entrusted to humans, enabling them to serve, follow the rhythms of yin and yang, and govern the myriad things. Those of lower quality are entrusted to the earth, causing them to walk and labor. Do you, Perfected One, understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, excellent! Therefore, when Heaven above now desires to harmonize wind and rain, nurture the myriad things, and rejoice in obtaining good people, I have been sent down to select and seek them. With this text, I entrust it to you, Perfected One, to convey to the diligent people, bidding them pass it to the sovereign of fire essence and virtue, so that it may be shown to all under Heaven, that they may together ponder these words of mine. Thus, I entrust it to you, Perfected One—take care never to sever this transmission. Should you fail in this, you will incur affliction. Be ever vigilant in this matter."

"Yes, yes."

Now, the foolish among the living suppose: Does Heaven above, being boundless and upright, unite solely with this earth below?

"Excellent is your inquiry! Though Heaven moves above without bound, it too possesses yin and yang, and the two unite as one. Does the earth below also possess such union?"

Indeed, though the earth moves below without bound, it too possesses yin and yang, and the two unite as one. Thus, one yin and one yang, above and below without end, extending laterally without limit—this is the nature of the Great Dao, the constant law of Heaven. All things take one yin and one yang as their vital axis. This is the art of the Supreme Numinous, operating naturally. The governance of the boundless turns in cycles, returning to its origin, without end or cessation.

I wish to distinguish and set forth the Dao for you, Perfected One, in clear order, that you may fully comprehend it. Thus, I briefly raise its beginning for you, reveal its great principles, and leave you to reflect upon its threads, that the worthy and sagely upon the earth may themselves refine it. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"I wish to hear your teachings."
"Very well. Commit my words carefully to memory within my teachings, and you shall ascend and rest."
"Yes, yes."

**Heaven’s Reproach: Four Who Shame the Dao’s Precepts (Section 208)**
What great abhorrence exists in the heavens above? It is called *Heaven’s Reproach*.

Perfected One, you have studied and practiced for so long—do you not deeply understand this already?
Now, this foolish one knows nothing of such matters. I wish to hear of them.

Indeed, from ancient times to the present, all who cultivate the Dao take the August Heaven as their model. The most excellent appellation—crowning the unsurpassed, encompassing the boundless, inwardly without interior, outwardly without gap, entering without aperture—serves as the teacher of all affairs under heaven. It is the origin of life, the elder of all matters, the enduring attainment of sages and worthies past and present. It is how emperors and kings secure the heart of Heaven, becoming the parents who bring peace to the people, the source from which all transformations arise.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
"Yes, yes."

The Dao is Heaven itself—pure and luminous, unwilling to be defiled or shamed. Yet now, those who study and practice the Dao all engage in four ruinous deeds, jointly defiling the numinous Dao of August Heaven, throwing into chaos the principles of Earth, and rendering themselves unfit to lead transformation, to serve as models, or to be parents. Together, they destroy Heaven’s precious vessels. Heaven names them all as *greatly rebellious sons*.

You dwell upon the earth—if you do not conform to the models of the Dao, how could Heaven, in its tranquility, conform to your models instead? Do you wish to know the truth of this? It is as if a petty man among the common folk does not conform to the models of the Dao. Would he, standing before the emperor, then conform to those models? If one remains below and fails to conform to the Dao’s models, yet Heaven were to cherish him and take him as its model—would this not mean that those in the heavens above and before the emperor would instead be ruled by those who hoard wickedness? Thus, Heaven above deeply perceives their deviation from the Dao, not out of deliberate malice in reproaching them.

Now, as the Primordial Qi of the Cavernous Upper August arrives, it will no longer tolerate these four kinds of people. These four cause both Heaven above and Earth below to despise those who practice the Dao, instead branding them as *evil sons*. This is why the human Dao daily declines and fades, resting in decay without revival. Today, all under heaven commit evil—this is precisely the ruin wrought by these four.

Heaven above greatly abhors and reproaches them, and thus seeks to select seven others instead.
Do you understand, Perfected One?

This foolish one’s nature is dull and slow—I still do not comprehend. What does this mean? I wish to hear of it.
If you do not immediately grasp this, what hope is there for the common people?

"Very well. Open your ears and listen closely. I shall set forth in detail for you the origins of the Dao’s great flaws and diseases, so that later learners may clearly recognize their deviations from the Dao.

The first is *lack of filial piety*.
The second is *failure to preserve one’s true nature*, leaving no posterity of their kind.
The third is *eating feces and drinking urine*.
The fourth is *acting as beggars*.

These four kinds of people jointly defile the true Dao of Heaven, utterly unfit to inspire transformation or to serve as models for Heaven above and Earth below through the ages. Even if they were to attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, when Heaven examines them, they would be found wholly wicked. Today, they cannot regulate the winds and rains, bring forth the myriad things, or serve as teachers and elders. How lamentable! How lamentable!

This humble one is deaf and blind—I have never known my offenses against Heaven. Now, only the August Heaven and luminous teachers can grant me further clarity. I beg you to explain in detail and distinguish them clearly, that I may gain understanding and enlightenment."

"Very well. Listen carefully, and I shall fully expound their meaning for you, Perfected One, so that it may serve as a model for all ages to come. Let later learners, earnest and good, who practice the Dao no longer transgress Heaven’s prohibitions, enabling them to attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, where Heaven will rejoice in them. It is like when the Earthly Thearch and kings find good people to govern with them—they too rejoice.

Thus, what Heaven above advances, Earth below likewise does. Is this not excellent?"
"Yes, yes. I have received your instruction."

The Dao is the teacher of August Heaven, the most precious treasure of Heaven. Those who practice it must conduct themselves as if formed by Heaven itself. The Dao ought to be practiced with utmost reverence, for Heaven cherishes and employs those who do so. Yet now, some who have erred and attained the Dao ascend to Heaven, only to be received with inquiry—only to reveal conduct lacking in reverence and filial piety. The Dao is the foremost transformer, and Heaven serves as the model for humanity. How could it reverse its role to shelter and nurture the irreverent and unfilial of the world? If a child harbors such evil conduct, how could Heaven deem it fitting to grant this person longevity and share its work? Would Heaven instead take such a rebellious child as its master? Even on Earth, such a person would not be employed—how could Heaven employ them? Thus, no one who is unfilial and practices the Dao has ever ascended to Heaven. Though they may depart, they are all deceived by malevolent spirits and treacherous ghosts. They will dwell in death upon barren lands, in desolate wilds, their forms punished. Heaven’s response to humanity is as swift as an echo—how could evil conduct yield good reward? Such cases are rare in past and present. Though many on Earth have practiced the Dao, few have been deemed worthy. Now, in Heaven, there are few good people, none with whom to share its work—their conduct is entirely wicked. Why does Heaven not immediately destroy them, instead consigning them to barren lands, to uninhabited wilds where breath ceases? It does not immediately annihilate them because between Heaven and Earth, qi gathers in abundance, fostering harmony—this is called the balanced harmony of the center. It is like human harmony, which encompasses all without exception. Thus, Heaven temporarily tolerates them, for Heaven governs with clarity and brightness, like standing before an imperial sovereign—it cannot harbor the wicked. Therefore, Heaven does not employ such people in its governance, nor does Earth. Heaven does not employ the irreverent and unfilial, just as a sagely king does not employ the irreverent and unfilial. If even a sagely king refuses to govern with them, how could Heaven alone do so? The ancient sages and worthies did not govern with such people because they deeply observed Heaven’s laws and modeled their conduct upon them. To govern with the foolish would incur Heaven’s great resentment. How do we know this? When a ruler governs with such people, Heaven manifests many disasters and omens, and the barbarians frequently invade—this is clear proof of Heaven’s hatred. Is this not as unchanging as the compass and square, as binding as a contract? Now, if even humanity detests and despises such people, how could Heaven itself employ them? What humanity hates, Heaven also hates; what humanity cherishes, Heaven also cherishes. Thus, the ancient worthies and sages deeply understood Heaven’s will and always modeled their conduct upon it, not daring to deviate even slightly. Therefore, they alone enjoyed Heaven’s favor and gained its heart. If one does not align with Heaven’s heart, one does not gain it—and great misfortune follows. If human conduct is already thus, how much more so for those who would become Heaven’s chosen officers? Heaven’s chosen officers must work alongside Heaven, governing the boundless arts. They must join forces for eternity, harmonize their qi with one heart—how could a Perfected One be remiss in this? Be vigilant! My words embody the pure will of Heaven—do not transgress them. Those who transgress will die. □□! Excellent, excellent!

The foolish student’s heart holds but a single good understanding in this. You, too, should refine even this single good understanding—common people do not grasp it, lost in their dark and muddled confusion. Heaven detests this, and so has sent me down to proclaim the great teaching, fully revealing Heaven’s laws. From this point onward, let all learners take heed and be vigilant.

Now Heaven values and esteems the transmission of life in succession, so the four seasons receive Heaven’s Daoist instruction, passing life onward to generate and complete, without end. Thus do all things flourish and endure. Therefore, Heaven is named the Father of Generation, Earth the Mother of Nurturance. Following the qi of the Six Jia, Twelve Branches, and Eight Trigrams as their guiding principles, they take turns generating and employing one another. Thus, the Dao of Heaven remains eternally present, never destroyed or ruined—this is the constant work of its transformative power.

Now, those who study the Dao must be pure and take Heaven as their model. Yet many, though outwardly pure, leave no posterity, jointly extinguishing Heaven’s lineage. The steadfast among them still uphold Heaven’s nature, but their qi is insufficient. The unsteadfast force the matter, obstructing and blocking the Dao of yin and yang. Scattering their seed across the four wilds, some even abandon and kill, leaving their wives and children destitute—these are all people who greatly destroy and lose the Dao. They are unworthy of emulation, beings of great misfortune in every fraction, unfit to serve as teachers or models for others. How could they possibly align with the laws of the Heavenly Master?

The August Heaven is the elder of all affairs, the parent of humanity, the model from which all sages under Heaven take their pattern. Why would one act recklessly, losing the Dao and behaving without posterity, to serve alongside such a one? If Heaven were to govern jointly with such a person, Heaven would be named a master who shelters evil, promoting inauspicious arts—how could this be called sagely, how could one serve as a teacher above others? Therefore, Heaven does not tolerate or cease to stop them.

The ancient sages and great worthies knew well to avoid such transgressions, refusing to govern alongside those without posterity, for in doing so, they would fail to gain Heaven’s heart. Thus, the sages and worthies—whom Heaven causes to be esteemed and to have posterity—jointly detest those without posterity. The sages deeply understood Heaven’s will and always modeled themselves upon it, not deviating even slightly. How much more so for Heaven itself?

Now, for a long time, there have been no good people above in Heaven, so I have been sent down to proclaim these great words, to instruct and admonish those who come later, that the foolish may all come to know. If those above in Heaven employ such people, would Heaven above not instead become a host for those without posterity? Acting in this way, would one ascend to Heaven? Would Heaven above love those without posterity and not favor life? Thus, all such people die in barren lands, lifeless soils, and desolate wilds where no one dwells, each sent to return to their own kind. You do not favor life, opposing Heaven, so you are cast into places where nothing grows. You delight in desolation, so you are cast into wilds where no one lives.

Common people, blind and unseeing, claim they have already transcended the world—this is not true. I dare not deceive the Perfected One. I have personally descended after journeying above in Heaven. Whether one sees or not is like showing the sun to the blind—telling them they are being deceived, they cover their mouths and laugh. Fools are just like this. Perfected One, be vigilant! What Heaven above detests, those above also detest. Excellent, excellent!

The foolish student has never before witnessed such matters of Heaven above—only now has he truly awakened to this. You must strive to perform good deeds. My writings heal the illnesses of Heaven and Earth, relieve the sorrows and sufferings of emperors and kings. When your merit is complete and you ascend to Heaven, you will see for yourself—the efficacy of my words will be greatly proven. Indeed, indeed. I dare not delay, nor dare I be remiss. You must be vigilant and not grow lax. If you truly falter and grow lax, your great mandate will be severed. The foolish student deeply fears Heaven’s majesty and sincerely receives and practices this. Excellent, excellent! You have grasped Heaven’s will.

Now Heaven is pure and bright, the Dao is clear and untainted. Heaven and the Dao dwell highest of all, serving as models for humanity. The pure and bright favor purity and brightness, so the Three Luminaries ascend and reside in Heaven, each following its kind, uniting as if forming a single body. Heaven’s form is like a bright mirror, like a person with two eyes that illuminate all, unwilling to see defilement or disgrace. Before a sagely king, one must always desire purity and brightness, unwilling to see defilement or disgrace. If one defiles and disgraces, one incurs the transgression of destruction and death. Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Oh, how grave! Oh, how grave!

Thus, the human head and mouth resemble Heaven, unwilling to delight in seeing defilement or disgrace, always desiring freshness and brightness, desiring good things. Therefore, when people in the world indulge in filth, disgrace, and evil, feeding such things to others, Heaven sends down thunder and lightning to capture and seize them. Perfected One, do you recognize this as perverse and wicked? Indeed, indeed. This foolish one deeply fears it.

From the great central high antiquity to now, people claim to be good, utterly distinct from common folk. Yet those who study the Dao often instruct one another to eat feces and drink urine, calling themselves plain and good people—Heaven and the Dao deeply detest this. In Heaven, such are named the great rebellious children, whose human forms Heaven does not wish to see. These are the marks of great evil, the descent of dog and swine spirits.

The Dao gives birth to Heaven, and Heaven possesses the Dao, which serves as the teacher and elder for all affairs. The true Dao is that by which goodness flourishes and evil is eliminated. Thus, when ancient sage-kings and emperors were about to rise, they all received the Dao as their teacher, entering to receive its strategies and wisdom, transforming their people. The teacher was honored, and it was said that they could know Heaven’s will and emulate Heaven in their conduct.

In Heaven, those who follow the good Dao are also revered and esteemed, for it is said they can harmonize with the winds and qi, follow the four seasons, uphold the five phases, regulate wind and rain, assist the sun, moon, and stars in shining brightly, and cause the myriad things to flourish. Now, how can those who eat feces and drink urine serve as teachers?

Today, even earthly teachers fall short, named rebellious children—how could they possibly become teachers in Heaven? Such petty people are profoundly foolish, deeply mired in defiling and disgracing the Dao of Heaven.

Perfected One, having received this ultimate text, ponder its meaning: what the earth below uniformly detests, Heaven above also detests; what Heaven above detests, the earth below likewise does. Thus, when people below detest eating feces and drinking urine, Heaven above also detests it, and so sends down thunder and lightning to strike them dead.

These words are merely to enlighten those on earth, for Heaven’s detestation is far more severe. If even those on earth abhor this, how much more so in Heaven? Heaven is pure, bright, and fresh—how could it instead gather and shelter those who eat feces and drink urine?

Even if one errs by chance and momentarily attains the Dao, they will not ascend to Heaven. All will perish in the lands of the five wastes, where qi is cut off and fortune fails, to follow their conduct, to manifest their transgressions, each returning to what they sought—no deception here.

Perfected One, if your years have reached their virtuous end, be warned and cautious, setting an example for those to come. When the equable qi of the Supreme August One descends, such evil conduct will find no refuge—death for transgression is clear indeed.

Oh, how grave! Oh, how grave! Perfected One, do you understand? If you do and yet allow it, you share in the guilt. If you know and still persist, the sin cannot be absolved. Indeed, indeed. I dare not, I dare not.

Now the nature of the Supreme August Heaven is ever to bestow and grant—thus it presides over giving, over bestowing, over engendering, over nurturing. It governs emergence, not reception; it governs triumph, not submission. To submit is to act in rebellion. Therefore, the Dao of Heaven cannot be coerced by force, for coercion and duress bring about the ruin of humankind.

Heaven presides over goodness, over clarity and luminosity; it takes no delight in witnessing stagnation, defilement, or disgrace. Now the gift of Heaven and the Dao is called the "Peerless Appellation." Thus, emperors and kings model their conduct upon Heaven, styling themselves "Peerless Sovereigns." They dare not lose even a fraction of Heaven’s way—adherence brings fortune, while deviation brings great misfortune.

Now, those who study the Dao to attain longevity must purely emulate Heaven. Heaven delights in life; therefore, those who seek longevity must purely guard Heaven’s primordial life-generating qi, and their conduct must follow the intent of the Dao of Heaven. As for Earth, it presides over disgrace and destruction, over concealment—one must not follow Earth’s intent.

The Dao is the root of the great transformation, the teacher and elder of the great transformation. Thus, nothing under Heaven comes into being without emulating it. Yet now, petty and foolish men who seek the Dao bring no benefit to the people; instead, they collectively defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven. Their rebellion is extreme and without form. In Heaven above, they are named "rebellious sons," men of great misfortune—Heaven does not wish to see them.

What does this mean? The foolish generate knotted, closed-off hearts, and thus have not yet attained it.

Excellent indeed is your question! Heaven has prompted your words—open wide your ears and listen attentively.

Does not Heaven and the Dao favor bestowal, favor life, and favor praise? Why then do they not divine with hexagrams, dispense medicines, and bring benefit to the people, allowing spirits to govern humanity so that illness may surely cease? These three kinds of men may all be called masters, yet they do not profit the Dao of Heaven, nor dare they defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven.

The Dao of Heaven does not deceive; it ever demands utmost sincerity. If one deceives with the pretense of not deceiving, in time, day by day, misfortune and decline will follow. The Dao of Heaven does not delight in defilement and disgrace, nor does it desire to benefit others. Heaven is supreme above all, and the Dao is yet more exalted—it is the teacher and model of the Heavenly Sovereign, loftier even than Heaven. Thus, Heaven and the Dao preside over cultivation and rectitude, ever leading in all affairs. Thereby they harmonize yin and yang, regulate wind and rain, rectify day and night, and array the ranks. Between Heaven and Earth, none fail to receive grace and destiny, each attaining its proper place.

Yet now, petty and foolish men who pursue the Dao instead engage in deceit, arrogance, delusion, and madness. Together they confuse and disrupt the Dao of Heaven, ruin the primal transformations of Heaven, and turn to begging for others’ possessions, bringing no benefit to the people. They defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven. Though they claim to benefit the common folk, they cannot serve as models for teachers. Instead, they lead later generations to teach one another the Dao, causing people to become deluded, arrogant, deceitful, and defiled, resorting to begging. Thus, their conduct is named the Dao of the deluded, arrogant beggar. They cause all people to revile Heaven together, to despise the true Dao, and to sever the great transformation. Heaven deeply abhors them; the Dao deeply detests them. Heaven above does not wish to see their form.

Now, the Supreme Sovereign of Heaven has sent forth the great rectifying qi. The sun, moon, and stars are arrayed in order, all reverently illuminating the Dao and Heaven. They regulate wind and rain, harmonize yin and yang, and cause the myriad things to each attain their proper place. Yet those who previously chanced upon the Dao and ascended to Heaven found no office there. Heaven questioned them and found them full of transgressions, unfit to serve together. You all dwell upon the earth and are still called deluded, arrogant beggars—how could you be fit to serve as teachers to emperors and kings, let alone as teachers in Heaven above?

Heaven abhors them; the great Dao declines and falls into ruin. The fault lies with the people of later ages who, in learning from one another, lost the proper standards. Heaven is afflicted by this, deeply grieved. The Dao of Heaven is obstructed, and thus it has sent me down to discuss with the Perfected One and distinguish the gains and losses of the Dao. It delights in the awakening of all under Heaven, that they may together know the intent of Heaven above, reform their conduct, transform their hearts, and no longer transgress Heaven’s prohibitions. Then those who study will succeed. If they persist in their former ways, Heaven will not raise them up.

They shall surely return to die in the land of the five disgraceful things, their lives consigned to the five defiled soils, cut off in the desolate wilds of delusion and madness. Above, there are no Three Luminaries; below, no fertile earth. Why is this? I wish to hear: how grave is their transgression? It is not that they are punished without cause. The Dao of Heaven serves as the law, and each follows its kind—this is the deprivation from below.

Why then are they not immediately killed, but instead brought to this? If they were to be instantly destroyed, they would claim to seek long life and profess utmost faith. If they were to be killed outright, they would weep to Heaven and wail to Earth, calling themselves deeply wronged, yet unaware of the source of their transgressions. Thus, Heaven examines and tests them, later casting them into the land of the five disgraceful and deluded things, that they may come to know themselves.

Do you wish to know the truth of this? It is like a wise king examining a person’s transgressions and holding them accountable—not immediately killing them, but rather, according to the severity of their crime, sending them to prison. Great crimes go to great prisons, small crimes to small prisons, where they are governed until the person submits, comes to know their fault, and dies without resentment or complaint. If their words are not thoroughly examined, they may protest their innocence, die with grievance in their hearts, and harbor resentment. Thus, the hegemons of the Five Dynasties had many subjects and ministers who died with grievance in their hearts.

Do you now understand that the administration of punishment in Heaven above is like this? Perfected One, do you comprehend? How admirable! How admirable! To know awe and reverence is the gateway to life; not to know awe and reverence is the root of death. Heed my words well—my words are the soldiers of the rectified Heaven. Do not defy or slight them, for defiance brings harm. Minor defiance brings minor harm; great defiance brings annihilation.

I caution you, Perfected One: the people of later ages accumulate folly, trusting their ignorant hearts, and say, “It is not so,” thereby bringing ruin upon themselves. I personally traverse the realm above Heaven and know its affairs below—ten thousand times, not one is lost. I dare not deceive you. Though I do not fear the Perfected One, I fear the majesty of Heaven. Thus, my words are trustworthy. That I repeat and emphasize them is to guard against those who might stubbornly err. Therefore, I reiterate to make my words more abundant and refined.

The affairs of Heaven above are truly distant and difficult to know, so the scriptures are frequently sent down to align with the earth. Good upon the earth is good in Heaven above; evil upon the earth is evil in Heaven above. Thus, when people do good upon the earth, Heaven above responds with goodness; when people do evil upon the earth, Heaven above responds with evil—this is the ascent of their qi. The five qi are interconnected, above and below as one; the six jia are linked, above and below as one. The twelve branches unite above and below, and none, whether near or far, fail to communicate. If below is good, above is bright; if below is evil, above is inauspicious.

Thus, the Five Phases arise below, and the Five Stars shine above. This is how Heaven enlightens the people under Heaven—all Three Luminaries are likewise. Heaven above and the earth below are connected through the Three Luminaries. When the Three Luminaries shine below, so too in Heaven above; when Heaven above is bright, so too upon the earth. The two respond to one another, harmonizing to form the warp and woof. What is greatly good in Heaven above is likewise upon the earth.

Just as Heaven possesses the six jia and twelve branches, so too does the earth; just as the earth possesses the six jia and twelve branches, so too does Heaven. Thus, above and below ever correspond, not erring by even a hair’s breadth. O Perfected One, be vigilant in this. Though My words may seem distant, guard against concealing them; show them to learners, but transmit them only after fasting and purification. Be vigilant.

Follow the text as law; do not recite it in darkness.

“Yes, yes. I humbly ask: since the Middle Antiquity of the Most High, among those who taught the Dao, many abandoned their homes and forsook their kin, cast aside wives and children, and feigned madness—begging, eating filth, drinking urine. Later learners, following their example, passed these practices down as teachings, each with its own master and method, yet none were empty or careless.”

“Excellent is your challenging question, for it exposes their perverse intent. Does Heaven despise them, that you ask this? How cunning their words—why do you raise this? Long have I wondered at this, yet none dared ask directly, ever holding it in silent distress. Excellent indeed! Has Heaven truly appointed you to raise this matter?”

“Very well. Open your ears, and I shall distinguish and explain it for you. When the Supreme Heaven first revealed the true Dao, it was not like this. All practiced filial devotion to their parents, maintained descendants with wives and children, kept proper appearance, and were not mad—nor did they eat filth or drink urine. All their actions accorded with the Dao and moved within its laws. The highest adepts became teachers and assistants to emperors and kings, transmitting and nurturing their kind without harm.

At that time—like the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors—they acted by the true Dao, striving to benefit and never to harm or injure. Thus, they practiced the true Dao openly, without concealment. But when the Three Kings brought chaos and the Five Hegemons arose, rulers and ministers, the people, all deceived and slighted one another. Hence, they feigned madness, fearing discovery, begging, eating filth, drinking urine—these are the deeds and words of the desperate and destitute.

The Dao, too, has its cycles of decline and flourishing, like the Three Sovereigns, Five Emperors, Three Kings, and Five Hegemons. In later ages, the way of hegemony prevailed: begging, abandoning kin, forsaking wives and children, eating filth, drinking urine—this is the decline of the Dao, the rise of hegemony. Thus, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors often attained the Dao and ascended to Heaven, some through corpse liberation, others by departing in bodily form. The Three Kings lived out their years, but the Five Hegemons gained no true Dao, all dying in battle upon the wilds. Those who now cling to this hegemonic way in the later age likewise perish upon the wilds—this is what it means.

I do not deceive you, Perfected One: this, too, is a hegemonic Dao, no different from the hegemons and kings. How could they ascend to Heaven? Excellent, excellent! The foolish heart of this student is now truly enlightened. I never imagined the Dao could have a hegemonic aspect. Only through the Heavenly Master’s explanation have I come to know this. Truly, truly… how profound! You may be said to have opened my eyes.

I ask: what should learners of today do? Now, the great cycle of the Heavenly Dao is complete and fully prepared. From this time onward, it differs from the past. If one seeks to practice the hegemonic methods of Middle Antiquity, the true Dao will not come. O Perfected One, be warned and vigilant. If you desire long life and joyful existence, study My texts. Lose even a hair’s breadth, and your life will not be whole—how can you fail to guard it?

The primordial Dao of the Origin-Yuan has arisen; the fire-light practices it. The hegemonic Dao is ended. Though Heaven is vast, it has its own divisions and principles, revealing texts to all people that they may discuss them together. What belongs to the high should be assigned to the high, what belongs to the middle to the middle, what belongs to the low to the low, and what belongs to all—high, middle, and low—should be shared by all. Why do you not see their sincerity and trustworthiness… as if speaking with Heaven?

Excellent, excellent! The qi of the times is now balanced.”

"How does the Perfected One know this? By seeing that Heaven has personally sent the Heavenly Master to speak, one knows the qi of Heaven is now balanced. Excellent, excellent! You have grasped its meaning. I humbly request to ask one or two more things—dare not speak further.

In practicing the Dao from now on, where should one seek it? Seek it always in a quiet chamber, without abandoning parents or leaving wife and children. Proceed gradually, ceasing only when seclusion is complete. If one’s inner self is not virtuous yet seeks seclusion, it will bring no benefit—rather, one may die prematurely.

Each must examine their own truth. Act without betraying Heaven. Though one may deceive others, one cannot deceive Heaven. Do not worry that others may act wrongly. Let each govern themselves by this principle. Those who dare not practice the Dao are wicked people, those who seek to deceive and feign. By this measure, not one in ten thousand will err.

If disciples learn thus, deceit and cunning will vanish, and the good and evil among people will be revealed. This is called *The August Heaven’s Selection of the Worthy*, a text by which the highest may attain transcendence, the middle may serve as counsel to emperors and kings, and even the ignorant and foolish may follow its precepts as diligent commoners.

Perfected One, take heed of this." "Yes, yes."

"May I inquire how one who suffers from *pi-lou* may attain the Dao and depart? If the Dao is achieved, one departs—nothing more. If the Dao remains unachieved, one must daily serve one’s parents, protect one’s wife and children, and practice with gradual purity. Each morning, one will come to understand one’s own intent.

The worthy together uphold this teaching."

"Yes, yes."

*[Right] The Celestial Selection of the Worthy—On the Flourishing of the Dao and the Severing of Falsehood—enables those who abandon hegemony to extend their lives, ease their minds, dissolve cunning, and uphold filial duty to parents while protecting wives and children.*

**The One Hundred Seventeenth Scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace concludes.**

**The One Hundred Eighteenth Scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace**
**Chapter Two Hundred Nine: The Prohibition Against Burning Mountains and Forests**

I humbly ask the Supreme Master of the Celestial Cavern-Heaven: though this unworthy and foolish student is unworthy of your compassion, you have deigned to reveal the affairs of Heaven—truly, this is beyond what I dared hope. Since you have already granted this, opening the path that allows me to know the matters of Heaven, I wish to inquire: what does Heaven above delight in, and what does it forbid? I seek only its prohibitions. Day and night, I contemplate their meaning, never daring to transgress them, that I may instruct future generations.

Excellent indeed is your question—you have grasped its essential intent. Perfected One, be seated at ease, and I shall expound it for you. This may be transmitted for ten thousand generations, never to fade.

"Yes, yes."
I receive your command with profound gratitude. There is no need for thanks.

You inquire on behalf of Heaven and Earth, while I speak on behalf of Heaven—this is no private matter of yours, but a shared public duty. Why then should thanks be necessary? Yet to withhold gratitude would seem to treat the Dao as trivial and the task as easy, burdening the master; while to offer thanks might touch upon taboos, appearing immodest. I merely fear that excessive words and ornate phrasing would obscure the meaning, which is why I limit myself to the Perfected One’s discourse.

Words are the handle of the Dao, the origin of all scripture. Do not be disheartened, for I shall now distinguish these matters for you.

"Yes, yes."

Now, in the heavens above, the Supreme Sovereign’s Primordial Qi of Equilibrium flourishes in full vigor. The yang sun shines brightly, perverse qi halts and recedes, while upright qi advances. Decay dissipates, and the Dao and virtue align with yang.

Heaven urgently prohibits setting fire to the mountain forests and thickets of trees. Why is this? I wish to hear of it.

Indeed, mountains are great yang, the web of the upper earth, their sovereign. The myriad rooted things—trees are their chief, their ruler, their yang. Fire, too, is the sovereign and chief of the Five Phases, their yang. Three sovereigns, three yangs, when they meet, they mutually diminish one another.

Thus, Heaven’s decree urgently forbids burning mountain forests and thickets. If trees are not burned, they remain within yin. Yin is called "mother," and thus leans downward. This is why Heaven causes the branches of *zi*, *chou*, and *yin* to first sprout and flourish abundantly. When they flourish, fire reigns; when fire reigns, the sun grows ever brighter. When *bing* and *ding* flourish, *si* and *wu* rejoice. Why is this? I wish to hear of it.

This is Heaven’s pattern, its nature. When the mother is abundant and reigns, her child assists. When the child assists, it receives qi for a long duration, extending life. Thus, Heaven prohibits this.

When yang flourishes, yin’s treachery daily recedes; when yang wanes, yin’s treachery daily rises. Thus, the cunning and deceitful always emerge in the depths of night—this is the great proof of treachery arising when yang wanes. Therefore, Heaven desires to eliminate treachery and so prohibits this. Such is the natural method and law.

In the heavens above, it is thus; on earth below, it is also thus.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed.

I ask: when the Three Yangs align, why does misfortune and decline follow?

Excellent indeed, your question—you have grasped its essence. Now, the Three Yangs correspond to the yang of Heaven, the yang of Earth, and the yang of Man. All three are entirely yang, without a trace of yin; all three are rulers, without a single minister; all three are male, without a single female. This is the path to annihilation, the Way without posterity. It dares not transmit its kind, nor can it mutually generate and complete—hence, it is inauspicious. This is what is meant by having Heaven but no Earth, having the sun but no moon, having above but no below, having exterior but no interior. In Heaven, this is called the *Record of Established Ruin*, and thus it is detested and prohibited.

Excellent indeed. Though foolish, I have ventured to ask this, and I am deeply wary of it. You who know wariness—this is the root of life. Those who do not know wariness—this is the gate of misfortune.

Indeed, indeed.

**Method of Burning the Lower Field’s Weeds, Two Hundred Ten**

I ask: regarding the weeds of the lower field, may they be burned?

Heaven does not prohibit burning them. They ought to be burned.

But why ought they be burned? I wish to hear of it.

Now, weeds are the yin of wood and correspond to *yi*. Wood corresponds to *jia*. *Jia* is yang and of the same kind as wood, hence they correspond. *Yi* is yin and of the same kind as weeds, hence it corresponds to *yi*. *Yi* fears metal, and metal injures wood; when wood is injured, yang declines, and when yang declines, false treachery arises—thus, they ought to be burned.

Moreover, Heaven says: *yi* is yin, weeds are yin, and the lower field is the yin of earth. When the Three Yin align, they instead jointly generate treachery. Thus, the Dark Warrior dwells in the northern pole of yin, and when yin reaches its extreme, yang is born anew. Fire is yang, and when yin obtains yang, it follows auspiciously, generating good affairs. Therefore, Heaven instructs: burn the weeds of the lower field to please yin and invigorate yang—thus, burn them. This is also the way of Heaven.

*Jia* is the wood of Heaven. *Yi* is the weeds of Heaven. What then are *yin* and *mao*?

Now, *yin* is also yang and the wood of Earth. *Mao* is yin and the weeds of Earth. These four all move eastward. Yet yang is called wood, and yin is called weeds—this is the natural law, the classic of Heaven. I dare not deceive the Perfected One.

You inquire of Heaven’s affairs to resolve doubts, and I expound Heaven’s affairs. Together, we share this duty, jointly ordering yin and yang, removing the ailments of Heaven and Earth, ensuring the Emperor knows no sorrow, and enabling the twelve thousand things to each find their place. None will fail to emerge joyfully, and there will be no grievances or entanglements.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed.

Peradventure, the Perfected One may be said to have grasped the Dao.
—Not at all, not at all.
Yet in learning and inquiring of the Dao, what offering should there be?
—Indeed, indeed. I strike my breast and heart, never to depart from it.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed. In learning and inquiry, you have attained its method.

**Heavenly Spirits Examine Transgressions and Adjudicate the Threefold Concord: Scroll Two Hundred Eleven**

Now, the harmonious and equable qi of Heaven descends in goodness, yet I ever fear that the people may, through misfortune, violate the seasonal ordinances and harm it. Today, all the spirits of Heaven jointly record those who delight in killing and wounding, the sons who hunt, shoot, fish, and trap, those who defy the Dao of Heaven and do no good, those who habitually take life and inflict harm. Heaven deeply reproves them; Earth deeply abhors them; the host of spirits deeply condemns them.

I now fear that petty men, accumulating folly, can no longer be restrained, and together they pollute and disrupt the pure, equable qi of the Cavernous Emperor. Thus, Heaven’s great urgency compels the deployment of all spirits to record their deeds, following their actions day by day, noting even the slightest transgressions for examination.

Three years, including intercalary months, constitute one intermediate reckoning; five years, one great reckoning. Those with grave transgressions shall be held accountable; those with minor faults shall have their years diminished and their allotted spans curtailed. Every three generations, a great reckoning is conducted; every five generations, annihilation follows. Therefore, today Heaven gathers the documents of the Three Dao, and all spirits jointly record transgressions, severing the propensity for killing, wounding, and penal punishment—while fostering joy, the same holds true upon Earth.

Fortunate is the Perfected One who cultivates goodness, ever desiring to render virtue unto August Heaven and pity the Emperor’s sorrows and afflictions when the seasonal qi are discordant. The true fault lies with those who delight in killing and wounding, hunting, shooting, fishing, and trapping, who together promote penal punishment and habitually harbor intentions contrary to Heaven and Earth. Thus, long-standing disorder and disharmony persist, and Emperors past and present have incurred sorrow and affliction—this is a grievous transgression.

Fortunate is the Perfected One who ever seeks to render merit unto Heaven and grace unto the Emperor. Today, Heaven accumulates its virulent toxins. The host of spirits instructs me in these words, and thus I now entrust this document to the Perfected One, to return it to the virtuous ruler and display it throughout the world. Let each person who receives this text deeply reflect, pondering their faults and heeding its words.

Today, the harmonious and equable qi of Heaven descends in full, yet it does not favor those who harbor malice and treachery. Knowing that Heaven holds these words, how dare I not transmit them below? To remain silent would be to become complicit in malice and treachery, bringing harm upon myself—I dare not transgress. Therefore, I report these matters. All Perfected Ones, take heed.

If the Perfected One does not speak, harm shall befall you. If you display this to the common people and they, in their folly, violate it, harm shall befall them, and Heaven shall no longer hold the Perfected One accountable.

From this day forward, Heaven shall mobilize the host of spirits to conduct examinations and govern the people. In Heaven, the Three Dao gather and circulate documents to record transgressions; the spirits, too, circulate documents of the Three Dao to record transgressions; thus, people likewise circulate documents of the Three Dao to record transgressions. Therefore, people take their pattern from Heaven, Heaven takes its pattern from people, and Heaven, Earth, and humanity each have their affairs. They emulate the numinous spirits and likewise model their affairs upon their methods.

Thus, the spirits and qi of ghosts admonish humanity, and admonition is ever present. Heaven, Earth, and humanity act in unison. Therefore, spirits respond to Heaven’s qi and act; refined beings respond to Earth’s qi and arise; ghosts respond to human governance and contend. These three are the agents of harmony and disharmony in Heaven and Earth, moving in accord with the spirit-qi, responding to the seasons in their comings and goings, traversing the Cavernous without interruption, their movements and abodes difficult to discern.

Thus, today the Dao of Heaven transmits governance, differing from ancient times. To divine the present by the past often misses the mark; to divine the past by the present no longer accords. Therefore, ancient texts have declined and are difficult to employ; their use seldom hits the mark. Yet there are places where true and authentic texts are gathered.

Thus, Heaven speaks of "adjudication and examination." Former and latter, threefold concord: the median goodness is taken to clarify affairs and align intentions. Only then is the Dao of Heaven rectified, the kingly Dao complete, all evil and wickedness expelled, the Emperor greatly joyful, and affairs at peace. People, through their own caution, attain Heaven’s intent.

Perfected One, do you grasp the gravity of these matters?
—Indeed, indeed.
Excellent. You have comprehended its meaning.

The right [section] concerns Heaven’s prohibition of fire to foster life, the cessation of punishments that wound and kill, and the halting of hunting and archery that violate the seasonal qi—all recorded here for posterity, knowing that at the Vermilion Beginning, the talismans were received and the texts renewed.

*Thus concludes the one hundred eighteenth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Begins the one hundred nineteenth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*

**Three as One Household: The Yang Fire, the Number Five, and the Secret Second Hundred Twelve**

The lowest of the foolish, born with a single wish, now asks: Today, the Dao of Heaven is complete, encompassing all without exception. What does Heaven observe, and why does it suddenly desire all life to flourish while urgently enforcing punishments?

Excellent, your challenging question has grasped its essence. I have always deeply cherished your words, for they constantly rouse my intent and cause the Dao to flourish. If even you cannot pose such a difficult question, who else could? Thus, the Dao of Heaven has long been severed, blocked, and cut off, causing Heaven great distress and suffering. I have long been despondent, wishing to speak but having no one to address. Therefore, the Dao of Heaven has lost its proper order for ages—year after year, until now.

Heaven’s course has brought forth a sage to speak, yet none have fully dispelled its afflictions. Thus, it has caused the Perfected One to come before me, and only now do I have the chance to fully expound for Heaven. Your questions alone deeply align with Heaven’s intent. Sit calmly, and I shall thoroughly expound the Dao for you. I wish not to speak, but I fear Heaven’s majesty. Therefore, when you ask, I am compelled to speak without concealment.

Perfected One, do you also understand this?
—Indeed, indeed.
Ah, you have comprehended it well.

Now, the reason Heaven above strives to foster and nurture all life while urgently preventing harm and injury lies in the Dao’s constant regulation of the three qi. The first favors generation and is called yang; the second favors completion and is called harmony; the third favors destruction and is called yin. Thus, Heaven presides over generation, humanity presides over nurturing and completion, and what is completed is called destruction—destruction that conceals. Heaven, Earth, and humanity share this work together, their tasks mutually dependent. Without yang, nothing is born; without harmony, nothing is completed; without yin, nothing is destroyed. These three are interdependent as one household, jointly bringing forth the twelve thousand things. Yet the Dao of Heaven encompasses beginning, end, and middle.

Now, since the Dao of Heaven first arose, it has completed a great cycle and returned, presently aligning with humanity and yang. Yang favors generation and abhors destruction; what is generated requires joy to unite hearts in mutual growth. Yet if destructive qi intrudes, it causes injury and prevents generation and completion. If you wish to know its truth, consider the child in the womb—even slight harm will cause injury and death, and once dead, it cannot be revived. Each loss is one person abandoned, and if such injuries continue unchecked, the line is severed, leaving no posterity, and the household perishes without succession. Thus, the urgency is greatest when punishments and killings occur. The Dao of Heaven is not always like this.

Now, the urgency has grown even greater, and I shall make it clear for the Perfected One to discern, so that people of later ages may fully awaken to the Dao of Heaven. I do not wish for destruction and injury to prevail, which is why I speak so plainly to the Perfected One. Common people follow me only in idle literary pursuits, crafting clever words. Therefore, I shall further present the celestial proofs of punishment and Heaven’s evidence.

Now, the first year of the sexagenary cycle is the celestial norm, when the sun returns to its origin at the winter solstice. The second year is the terrestrial norm, when things spread their roots. The third year is the human norm, when at dawn people rise, open their doors, and attend to their duties. These three together mark the beginnings of Heaven, Earth, and humanity—the root of all things. The initial generation belongs to yang, which is the primordial qi of Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Thus, *Qian*, *Kan*, *Gen*, and *Zhen* reside on the northeast face, with harmony at the center between *Kan* and *Gen*, where yin and yang unite to generate at the center.

Therefore, all who conceive reside in the middle of the abdomen, slightly below the center of harmony. When yang unites, it first generates and sends forth its form and qi, casting them to other regions—this is where the three qi of Heaven, Earth, and humanity first arise, where things renew above and below. There must be no punishments or killings, for qi resides within. When the qi of virtue and yang are established, the myriad things attain their proper generation; if inauspicious qi intrudes, it causes injury. Thus, punishments are cast out.

Now, the Dao of Heaven has completed a great cycle and renewed, with pure yang governing above and below. Therefore, punishments must be urgently abolished. Heaven is called spirit, and yang is also called spirit; thus, Heaven now sends spirits to govern humanity. Perfected One, do you wish to know whether my writings align with Heaven? From now on, those who violate my writings and favor punishments and killings will be examined by Heaven above. People will also urgently condemn them, and spirits will examine them. Heaven above and Earth below, though in different realms, will conspire together; ghosts and spirits, though not of the same household as humanity, will also conspire. This is the arrival of Heaven’s balanced qi.

The initial qi of Heaven renews above, the initial qi of Earth renews below, and the initial qi of humanity renews at the center. These three qi now begin together, unwilling to encounter the qi of punishment, evil, or misfortune, and desiring only to meet joyful qi. Therefore, from now on, Heaven and Earth will joyfully abolish punishments. Perfected One, do you understand? —Indeed, indeed.

The foolish and benighted among the living suppose that Heaven swiftly punishes those who do evil by forbidding injury and killing. They do not realize that this concerns the generative qi of Heaven, Earth, and humanity— the very root and origin of renewal. Hearing the Celestial Master expound this, I am deeply awed and humbled. To feel such awe and humility is to awaken, to grasp the intent of the Dao of Heaven. Excellent! You who understand these matters, take heed of this text and be careful never to sever it, lest you harm yourself. —Indeed, indeed. —I dare not, I dare not. Go forth and hold it in reverence.

All who study and inquire do so for their own sake, striving to align with the Dao of Heaven. —Indeed, indeed. Proclaim these celestial prohibitions; do not conceal them. —Indeed, indeed.

May I ask why the Dao of Heaven now establishes this great cycle as the primordial beginning, and why the celestial reckoning precisely corrects the texts at this time? Excellent is your challenging question—it perfectly accords with the mind of Heaven. Now is the ascendance of the Five Yangs, the inception of the Five Fires. The supreme Fire ascends to become Heaven, manifesting as the radiance of the sun and moon. Fire is red, sharing Heaven’s color; Heaven is red, and Fire is red—red is the mark of the numinous. Heaven and the numinous endure eternally, attaining the origin of all things. Thus, the eleventh month is the celestial standard, and so too in the heavens above. Its qi is red, for red is the sun’s returning inception. The initial nine qi belong to *jiazi*, the chief and foremost of the Six *Jia*s. *Jia* is essence, the heart of all matters; thus *jia* emerges first from *zi*, ascending to become the Heart Star. The spirit of Fire is the human heart. The heart of humanity is sacred and numinous, most revered and truly good. Thus, the sacred heart of the numinous can create and initiate all things, serving as their primordial origin. The law of the sacred begins with the heart, and nothing remains unexplained. Therefore, the most flourishing of the red is Heaven, the sun, and the heart—Heaven, the sun, and the heart ever shine, illuminating all without exception. Henceforth, those who practice this Dao will utterly eradicate all that is wicked and perverse.

The birth of Yang occurs within the depths of darkness. Thus, Yang qi arises in the north, emerges in the east, flourishes in the south, and wanes in the west—such is the law of Heaven. Excellent! May I ask why the birth of Yang now occurs precisely within the depths of darkness? All that is born returns to its origin; only when Yin and Yang unite can generation occur. Thus, all that is born reverts to its initial beginning. When Heaven and Earth were undivided at their first arising, there was neither above nor below, neither sun nor moon nor the Three Luminaries. All was profoundly dark, without division or pattern. Though without division, within it inherently existed above and below, left and right, exterior and interior, Yin and Yang, all mutually sustaining yet undifferentiated. When Yin and Yang first sustained one another to generate life, their emanation was boundless, still undivided. Only after birth did head and limbs become distinct. How do we know that the inception of Yin and Yang, the beginning of generation, was thus? Therefore, when humanity now undergoes transformation to generate life, they all withdraw to secluded, dark places—Heaven ensures they do not forget their origin. The initial reception of Heaven and Earth’s law is humanity’s primal state; thus, Heaven ensures they do not forget.

Excellent, excellent! Hearing the August Celestial Master’s words, I now understand the principles of division. You may be said to have been easily enlightened. May I ask why Yang and Fire are uniquely paired? The qi of each phase has its own pairing; Fire is not alone. Metal and Fire are most closely paired, as the chief of the Red Emperor. Does not the *Celestial Strategy* state it thus? *Bingwu* and *dingsi* are the ancestral beginning. "Beginning" means first, foremost. Thus, the text speaks of the ancestral beginning. The inception of all things arises from the red heart. The heart penetrates and illuminates, knowing all matters. Yang arises within Yin, also penetrating and illuminating. Water is dark without but bright within, penetrating and illuminating, for it contains Yang essence. Thus, Yang begins in the north, while Yin begins in the south. In the eleventh month, the earth below is warm; in the fifth month, the earth below is cold.

Now, why do Yin and Yang begin not in the heavens above but precisely within the earth? Excellent is your challenging question. The earth is the mother; the father’s essence is bestowed upon the mother, hence within Yin. Its emanation of Yang essence originates equally from Heaven. Yang is the transforming inception of qi, subtle and difficult to perceive. It enters Yin to take form, becoming visible and manifest; thus, its record lies within Yin, not within Yang. Now, when rain and snow fall, they follow the same transformative Dao—visible and perceptible. Why then say that Yang’s subtle emanation is imperceptible?

Excellent is your question! It is difficult to grasp its intent. I wish to explain it clearly for you, Perfected One, but fear that the great form of the Dao of Heaven would become manifest. Yet I fear you would harbor resentment. To be a teacher, to stand above others, is difficult. Please sit calmly, and I shall explain subtly.

When Heaven’s rain and snow are about to form, they are but breath and qi. Only when Yin and Yang unite can their emanation become perceptible. At that moment, Heaven’s qi descends, Earth’s qi ascends, and their emanations converge. Thus, rain and snow take form and become visible. May I ask: now, when clouds rise from crumbling mountains, all is visible. Why then say it is imperceptible? I wished not to ask, but my heart was heavy with distress. Now I must ask fully. As your disciple, I am not modest, yet if I do not ask, I cannot attain understanding. Thus, I must ask without hesitation.

Very well. I shall explain subtly, though it cannot be fully exhausted.

Yet when clouds and rain shatter mountains, this is the rage of excessive Yin, which cannot restrain itself from harming the transformations of Yang—a dire omen, not a virtuous change. It wounds the Way of transformation, a failure of Yin, an injury to Yin.

Perfected One, do not press further in questioning. The Way of Heaven cannot be exhaustively examined or fully spoken. Ponder its meaning yourself.

Very well, very well. I shall depart.

**The Dao’s Blessing on Three Kinds of People, Secret Teachings 213**

The Perfected One bowed twice and respectfully inquired of the Heavenly Master about the Dao:

When the Qi of Great Peace arrives, who is fit for the Dao? Who is unfit for the Dao?

Excellent, your question is apt. The Dao and humankind are like wind and rain: those who act upon it prosper; those who do not, desist. Those who delight in acting are its people; those who do not delight in acting are not its people. Those who act without strain, who are easily opened and penetrated—these are its people. Those who remain closed and impenetrable, who labor all day without success—these are not its people. To act is auspicious; not to act is inauspicious—such is its people. Those who do not act remain naturally auspicious and free from suffering, yet once they act, they suffer instead—these are not its people.

Moreover, in nurturing oneself, one must examine carefully. The Dao is the tally of the upright. Illness, demonic forces, and malevolent spirits are the pathways of wickedness, thieves who murder good people. When some see others about to enter the true Dao, they grow resentful, quarrel with them, and though they act for the true Dao, they bring misfortune instead of goodness, finding false peace among the mediocre. One must be vigilant and refine oneself: attaining the Dao brings good fortune; losing it brings misfortune. The mandate of life and death cannot be taken lightly or treated carelessly.

Excellent, excellent! Your foolish disciple now understands.

Since the Perfected One has asked about these doubts, I shall now impart the essential words of Heaven. The reason my Dao endures and nurtures is that there are those who delight in the Dao, delight in virtue, and delight in benevolence, who disregard worldly affairs and cherish life alone. The Dao rightly endures in nurturing and guarding these two kinds of people. Those who fall below this standard—my Dao does not endure in nurturing them.

Why is this? The human Dao covers all without exception—why then does it uniquely favor these three kinds of people and not others?

Excellent indeed, your challenging question grasps the meaning. When the Great Dao emerges, all people receive its grace, even grasses and trees—none fail to be transformed for the good, all attain their proper place, and each fulfills its natural lifespan. Those without Dao, virtue, or benevolence cannot be nurtured for long.

Why? Simply because they do not delight in Dao, virtue, or benevolence. Why then can only those who delight in Dao, virtue, and benevolence be nurtured for long?

I wish to hear the meaning.

Ah, you are perceptive! Your question cuts to the ultimate secret. Listen carefully, and I shall distinguish its meaning for you.

Very well.

Those who delight in Dao, virtue, and benevolence—these three kinds of people each possess the mandate of the Three Powers. Those who delight in the Dao belong to the mandate of Heaven; those who delight in virtue and nurturing belong to the mandate of Earth; those who delight in benevolence belong to the mandate of humanity. These three kinds of people correspond to the harmony of Yin and Yang, and all have their names recorded in the registers. Thus, the myriad spirits of Heaven declare: “Our scriptures can nurture them.” Those who do not act thus have no record in the registers, and so our scriptures cannot nurture them for long.

Now that the Qi of Great Peace has arrived, there is no favoritism, and so it does not nurture the wicked for long—unlike the past, during times of internal disorder, when it could encompass and nurture evil people.

I wish to hear the full explanation.

When the Qi of wickedness and evil arises, it can nurture evil people for long but cannot nurture good people for long, for their harm is great and the good are few. It is like the arrival of bitter cold, when the Qi of heat declines. Now that the upright Qi has arrived, it cannot nurture evil people for long—like the arrival of Yang Qi, when Yin Qi dissipates.

When the Great Yang’s crimson Qi ascends, it is the flourishing essence of fire. The ruler of fire shines above as the sun. The sun illuminates and examines the wicked, so they cannot act wrongly—thus, evil people are not tolerated.

Moreover, the Dao governs life, virtue governs nurturing, and benevolence governs the mind’s use of love. Spring brings life, summer brings nurturing, and humanity uses the mind to govern and nurture all things. Thus, the Great Yang’s work of giving life, nurturing, and growth is the most laborious—this is what it means.

Excellent, excellent! Your foolish disciple has heard your decree again.

Be seated calmly, and I shall further expound for you.
Very well, very well.

First, in the study of the Dao: those of great attainment reside in Heaven, those of middling attainment reside among the divine spirits, and those of small attainment reside among men.

Second, in the study of virtue: those of great attainment reside in Heaven, those of middling attainment reside among the divine spirits, and those of small attainment reside among men.

Third, in the study of benevolence: those of great attainment reside in Heaven, those of middling attainment reside among the divine spirits, and those of small attainment reside among men.

Fourth, in the study of office: those of great attainment reside in Heaven, those of middling attainment reside among the divine spirits, and those of small attainment reside among men.

Fifth, in the love of amassing wealth and property: those who amass much reside in Heaven, those who amass a middling amount reside among the divine spirits, and those who amass little reside among men.

Thus, in these five matters—whether of great, middling, or small attainment—all depend on one’s effort. Surrender your fate to Heaven, return your virtue to Earth, and render your benevolence to men. Uphold these three principles.

Cultivate the self with a worthy heart and good intentions; ponder and reflect upon them, and the self may be perfected. Accumulate and gather them, and the spirits will naturally arise. Guard and nurture them, and the Dao will naturally be achieved. Delight in and cherish them, and the self will naturally flourish.

The Way of Heaven is neither partial nor distant; it bestows itself upon the good.

Thus, Heaven exerts itself to enact the Dao, completing one cycle each day. This daily cycle follows the pattern by which all things are born, modeling themselves upon the Six Jia, the Five Phases, and the Four Seasons. If even one qi fails to arrive, a thing will be incomplete, and its birth will be insufficient and unbalanced.

For one who would be a ruler, a superior, or a parent, such imbalance is a grave transgression.

Therefore, Heaven completes one cycle each day, personally overseeing its enactment. It does so because, for instance, if you were Water, and the qi of Water were incomplete, the qi of the Five Phases and the Four Seasons would be insufficient. Thus, Heaven enacts and oversees the cycle:

When Jia aligns above, there is the Phase of Wood and the qi of spring.
When Bing aligns above, there is the Phase of Fire and the qi of summer.
When Wu aligns above, there is the Phase of Earth and the qi of the four seasons’ center.
When Geng aligns above, there is the Phase of Metal and the qi of autumn.
When Ren aligns above, there is the Phase of Water and the qi of winter.

When the Five Bodies are complete and the Four Qi are established, then all things may be born. When the transformations of Heaven and Earth are evenly bestowed, and the noble and the humble, the great and the small, are as one, there will be no contention or litigation—thus may one be a ruler or a parent.

Those who cultivate the Dao, virtue, and benevolence must model themselves upon this to align with the will of Heaven. They must not treat themselves lightly or act recklessly.

The Way of Heaven is thus established as a model—how much more so for man?

Therefore, the superior person models Heaven and embodies the Dao; the middling person models Earth and embodies virtue; the inferior person models man and embodies benevolence. Those who fall below this are no longer counted among men and share the impermanent fate of birds, beasts, grasses, and trees.

True person, having received my written teachings, you must deeply ponder their essential meaning. If you follow them without fail, you will harmonize with Heaven and partake in its work. Those who act contrary to my teachings are the enemies of Heaven and Earth, and I shall not tolerate them. What my written teachings revile is precisely what is correct.

True person, be vigilant. Transmit this to the superior person, return it to the authorities, and show it to the common people. From this day forward, Heaven differs from ancient times.

Excellent, excellent!

The above distinguishes the proper and improper applications of the *Taiping* writings' esoteric principles.

Thus concludes Scroll One Hundred Nineteen of the *Scriptures of Great Peace*.

chunks.original_text: 太平经 经名：太平经。 据《复汉书襄楷传》称：东汉顺帝时琅琊郡人宫崇诣阙，献其师于吉於曲阳泉水上所得神书，号曰《太平清领书》。 此神书即《太平经》，系汉代原始道教重要经典。 南北朝至唐代流传的《太平经》，凡一百七十卷，分作甲乙丙丁戊己庚辛壬癸十部。 今残存五十七卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太平部。 太平经卷之三十五 分别贫富法第四十一 真人前，子连时来学道，实已毕足未邪？ 今天师不复为其说也，以为已足，复见天师言，乃知其有不足也。 今意极讫，不知所当复问，唯天师更开示其所不及也。 行，真人来。 天下何者称富足，何者称贫也？ 然，多所有者为富，少所有者为贫。 然，子言是也，又实非也。 何谓也？ 今若多邪伪佞盗贼，岂可以为富邪？ 今若凡人多也，君王少，岂可称贫邪？ 愚暗生见天师有教，不敢不言，不及有过。 子尚自言不及，俗人安知贫富之处哉？ 今唯天师令，弟子之无知，比若婴儿之无知也，须父母教授之，乃后有知也。 善哉，子之言也太谦，亦不失之也。 诺，真人自精，为子具言之。 富之为言者，乃毕备足也。 天以凡物悉生出为富足。 故上皇气出，万二千物具生出，名为富足。 中皇物小减，不能备足万二千物，故为小贫。 下皇物复小於中皇，为大贫。 无瑞应，善物不生，为极下贫。 子欲知其大效，实比若田家，无有奇物珍宝，为贫家也。 万物不能备足，为下极贫家，此天地之贫也。 万二千物俱出，地养之不中伤，为地富； 不而善养，令小伤，为地小贫； 大伤，为地大贫； 善物畏见伤於地形而不生，至为下极贫； 无珍宝物，万物半伤，为大因贫也； 悉伤为虚空贫家。 此以天为父，以地为母，此父母贫极，则子愁贫矣。 与王治相应。 是故古者圣王治，能致万二千物，为上富君也。 善物不足三分之二，为中富之君也。 不足三分之一，为下富之君也。 无有珍奇善物，为下贫君也。 万物半伤，为衰家也。 悉伤为下贫人。 古者圣贤乃深居幽室，而自思道德，所及贫富，何须问之，坐自知之矣。 善哉善哉。 今唯天师幸哀帝王久愁苦，不得行意，以何能致此贫富乎？ 善哉善哉，子之难问也，已入微言要矣。 然所行得失致之也。 力行真道者，乃天生神助其化。 故沃神善物备足也。 行德者，地之阳养林出，辅助其治，故半富也。 行仁者，中和仁神出助其治，故小富也。 行文者，隐欺之阶也，故欺神出助之，故其治小乱也。 行武者，得盗贼神出助之，故其治逆於天心，而伤害善人也。 道者乃天所案行也。 天者最神，故真神出助其化也。 地者养，故德神出助其化也。 人者仁，故仁神出助其化也。 文者主相文欺，失其本根，故欺神出助之也，上下相文，其事乱也。 武者以刑杀伤服人，盗贼亦以刑杀伤服人。 夫以怒喜猛威服人者，盗贼也。 故盗贼多出，其治凶也。 盗贼多以财物为害，故其治失於财货也。 故古者上君以道服人，大得天心，其治若神，而不愁者，以真道服人也。 中君以德服人，下君以仁服人，乱君以文服人，凶败之君将以刑杀伤服人。 是以古者上君，以道德仁治服人也，不以文刑杀伤服人也。 所以然者，乃鄙用之也。 上君子乃与天地相似，故天乃好生不伤也，故称君称父也。

**The Scripture of Great Peace**

**Scripture Title:** *The Scripture of Great Peace*. According to the *Book of Later Han: Biography of Xiang Kai*, during the reign of Emperor Shun of the Eastern Han, Gong Chong of Langye presented at court a divine book obtained by his master, Yu Ji, at Quyang’s Spring of the Curved Waters. This book was titled *The Scripture of Great Peace and Pure Governance*. The divine book is none other than *The Scripture of Great Peace*, a foundational scripture of early Daoism in the Han dynasty. From the Northern and Southern Dynasties to the Tang, the transmitted version of *The Scripture of Great Peace* comprised one hundred and seventy scrolls, divided into ten sections: Jia, Yi, Bing, Ding, Wu, Ji, Geng, Xin, Ren, and Gui. Today, only fifty-seven scrolls remain. The base text is from *The Orthodox Daoist Canon*, Great Peace Section.

**Scroll Thirty-Five of The Scripture of Great Peace: The Method for Distinguishing Wealth and Poverty (Forty-First)**

The Perfected One approached. You have come repeatedly to study the Dao—have you truly mastered it, or is there still more?

Now, the Heavenly Master no longer expounds for you, assuming you have already attained sufficiency. Yet upon hearing the Heavenly Master’s words again, you realize there is still more to learn.

My thoughts are now exhausted, and I know not what further questions to ask. I only beseech the Heavenly Master to enlighten me on what I have yet to grasp.

Come, Perfected One.

What is called wealth and what is called poverty in the world?

Indeed, those who possess much are wealthy, and those who possess little are poor.

Yet while your words are correct, they are also not entirely so.

How so?

If one possesses much that is false, deceptive, flattering, or stolen, can this truly be called wealth? If the common people are many and the ruler few, can this be called poverty?

Foolish and ignorant as I am, I dare not refrain from speaking upon seeing the Heavenly Master’s teachings, though I fear my words may fall short or err.

You yourself admit your inadequacy—how then could the vulgar know the true nature of wealth and poverty?

Now, by the Heavenly Master’s command, your disciple, in ignorance, is like an infant who must be taught by father and mother before gaining understanding.

Excellent! Your words are most humble, yet not without merit.

Very well. Perfected One, attend closely, for I shall explain fully.

Wealth signifies complete and perfect sufficiency. Heaven deems all things fully produced as wealth and sufficiency.

Thus, in the era of the Supreme Sovereign, the qi emerged, and the twelve thousand things were all brought forth—this is called wealth and sufficiency. In the era of the Middle Sovereign, things were slightly diminished, unable to fully produce the twelve thousand things, hence it was called minor poverty. In the era of the Lower Sovereign, things were further diminished from the Middle Sovereign, hence it was called great poverty. Without auspicious responses and the arising of good things, it is called extreme poverty.

Would you know its great effect? Compare it to a farming household: lacking rare treasures or precious goods, it is a poor household. Unable to produce the ten thousand things in full, it is an extremely poor household—this is the poverty of Heaven and Earth.

When the twelve thousand things all emerge and the earth nourishes them without harm, it is the wealth of the earth. If it fails to nourish them well, causing minor harm, it is the earth’s minor poverty. If great harm is done, it is the earth’s great poverty. If good things fear harm from the earth’s form and do not arise, it is the earth’s extreme poverty. Lacking treasures and precious goods, with half the ten thousand things harmed, it is the great cause of poverty. If all are harmed, it is an empty and destitute household.

This is to take Heaven as father and Earth as mother. If these parents are extremely poor, then their children will grieve in poverty. This corresponds to the governance of kings.

Thus, the sagely kings of antiquity were able to bring forth the twelve thousand things—these were the supremely wealthy rulers. If good things were lacking by two-thirds, they were rulers of middling wealth. If lacking by one-third, they were rulers of lesser wealth. Without rare and excellent things, they were rulers of extreme poverty. With half the ten thousand things harmed, they were a declining house. If all were harmed, they were the most impoverished of people.

The sagely and worthy of old dwelled deep in seclusion, reflecting on the Dao and virtue. What need had they to inquire about wealth and poverty? They knew it all while seated.

Excellent, excellent!

Now, the Heavenly Master, in compassion for the long-suffering emperors and kings who cannot realize their aspirations, by what means can they attain this wealth or poverty?

Excellent, excellent! Your question is most profound, delving into subtle and essential matters.

Indeed, it is the success or failure of one’s conduct that brings these about.

Those who exert themselves in the true Dao receive the aid of Heaven’s spirits in their transformation. Thus, fertile spirits and good things are fully provided. Those who practice virtue receive the nourishment of Earth’s yang, forests, and springs to assist their governance, hence they are half-wealthy. Those who practice benevolence receive the aid of the harmonious and benevolent spirits, hence they are slightly wealthy. Those who practice civil arts open the path to deception, hence deceitful spirits aid them, and their governance is slightly disordered. Those who practice martial arts receive the aid of thieving spirits, hence their governance runs counter to Heaven’s will and harms the good.

The Dao is what Heaven follows in its conduct. Heaven is most numinous, hence true spirits emerge to aid its transformation. Earth is nourishing, hence virtuous spirits emerge to aid its transformation. Humanity is benevolent, hence benevolent spirits emerge to aid its transformation. Civil arts govern through literary deception, losing their root, hence deceitful spirits emerge to aid them. When superiors and inferiors engage in literary embellishment, their affairs become disordered.

Martial arts subdue people through punishment, killing, and harm, just as thieves subdue people through punishment, killing, and harm. Those who subdue people through anger, joy, ferocity, and might are thieves. Thus, when thieves abound, governance is inauspicious. Thieves often harm through wealth and goods, hence such governance loses its grasp on material resources.

Thus, the supreme rulers of old subdued people through the Dao, greatly winning Heaven’s favor. Their governance was like that of spirits, and they knew no sorrow, for they subdued people through the true Dao. Middling rulers subdued people through virtue, lesser rulers through benevolence, disordered rulers through civil arts, and doomed rulers through punishment, killing, and harm.

Therefore, the supreme rulers of old subdued people through the Dao, virtue, and benevolence, not through civil arts, punishment, killing, or harm. The reason for this is that such methods are base and vulgar. The noble ruler resembles Heaven and Earth, hence Heaven loves life and does no harm—thus is he called ruler and father.

chunks.original_text: 地以好养凡物，故称良臣称母也。 人者当用心仁，而爱育似於天地，故称仁也。 此三者善也，故得共治万物，为其师长也。 夫欺刑者不可以治，日致凶矣，不能为帝王致太平也，故当断之也。 今真人以吾书付有道德之君，力行之令效，立与天相应而致太平，可名为富家不疑也，可无使帝王愁苦，反名为贫家也。 今民间时相谓为富家，何等也？ 是者但俗人妄语耳，富之为言者，乃悉备足也。 一事不具，辄为不具足也。 故古者圣贤不责备於一人者，言其不能备之也，故不具责之也。 今八十一域国，物各少不备足也，不能常足也，故从他国取之也。 今一家有何等富哉？ 真人其好随俗人妄言邪？ 不敢不敢。 子既学慎言，无妄谈也。 夫妄谈乃乱天地之正文，不可为人法，慎之。 唯唯。 今天师既加恩爱，乃怜帝王在位，用心愁苦，不得天意，为其每具开说，可以致上皇太平之路。 愚生受书众多，大眩童蒙，不知当复问何等哉。 唯天明师，悉具陈列其诫。 善哉善哉。
