The Earth nurtures all things with care, hence it is called the good minister and mother. People ought to employ a heart of benevolence, loving and fostering as Heaven and Earth do, thus are they called *ren*. These three are good, and so together they govern the myriad things, serving as their teachers and elders.

Those who rely on deceit and punishment cannot govern; daily they bring about misfortune, and cannot bring emperors and kings to Great Peace. Thus, such methods must be severed.

Now, the Perfected One entrusts this scripture to a ruler of virtue and power, that through diligent practice its effects may manifest, aligning with Heaven to achieve Great Peace. This may rightly be called a "house of abundance" without doubt, sparing emperors and kings from sorrow and distress, and avoiding the name of a "house of poverty."

Nowadays, people commonly speak of a "house of abundance"—what does this mean? Such talk is but the reckless chatter of the vulgar. "Abundance" signifies complete sufficiency. If even one thing is lacking, it is not truly sufficient.

Thus, the sages and worthies of old did not demand perfection from any single person, for they knew none could be fully equipped, and so did not impose such expectations. Now, among the eighty-one domains and states, each lacks some things and cannot always be self-sufficient, hence they take from other lands.

What true abundance can a single household possess? Perfected One, do you truly wish to follow the vulgar in their reckless speech? I dare not, I dare not. You have studied the importance of cautious speech—do not indulge in idle talk. Idle talk disrupts the proper pattern of Heaven and Earth and cannot serve as a model for people. Be cautious.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, the Heavenly Master, in kindness and compassion, pities the emperor on his throne, whose heart is burdened with sorrow and distress, failing to align with Heaven’s intent. Thus, he fully expounds the way to open the path to the Great Peace of the Supreme Sovereign.

This humble student has received many scriptures, yet remains greatly bewildered, like an unlearned child. I know not what further questions to ask. May the Illustrious Heavenly Master fully set forth all the admonitions.

Excellent, excellent!

chunks.original_text: 然天法阳数一，阴数二，故阳者奇，阴者偶，是故君少而臣多。 阳者尊，阴者卑，故二阴当共事一阳。 故天数一而地数二也，故当二女共事一男也，何必二人共养一人乎？ 尊者之傍不可空，为一人行，一人当立坐其傍，给侍其不足。 故一者乃象天也，二者乃象地也，人者乃是天地之子，故当象其父母。 今天下失道以来，多贱女子而反贼杀之，令使女子少於男，故使阴气绝，不与天地法相应。 天道法，孤阳无双致枯，令天不时雨。 女者应地，独见贱，天下共贱其真母，共贼害杀地气，令使地气绝也不生，地大怒不悦，灾害益多，使王治不得平。 何也？ 夫男者乃天之精神也，女者乃地之精神也。 物以类相感动，王治不平，本非独王者之过也。 乃凡人失道轻事，共为非，其得过非一也，乃万端，故使治难平，乖错也。 天地之性，万二千物，人命最重，此贼杀女，深乱王者之治，大咎在此也。 今天师为王者开辟太平之阶路，太平之真经出，为王者但当游而无事，今是伤女为其致大灾，当奈何之乎？ 善哉，子之问也，得天心矣。 然天下所以贱恶女者，本恶过在其行。 何谓也？ 愿闻之，试得记於竹帛，万万世不敢去也。 善哉，子今能记之，天下无复杀女者也。 唯唯。 愿记之以除帝王之灾，吾所乐也，以救冤女之命。 善哉，子已得益天算矣。 何谓也？ 然活人名为自活，杀人名为自杀，天爱子可为，已得增算於天，司命易子籍矣。 不敢也，不敢也。 无可复让，此乃天自然之法也。 然天下所以杀女者，凡人少小之时，父母自愁苦，绝其衣食共养之。 非独人也，跂行亦皆然。 至於老长巨细，各当随其力而求衣食，故万物尚皆去其父母，而自衣食也。 贤者得乐，不肖得苦。 又子者年少，力日强有余。 父母者日衰老，力日少不足也。 夫子何男何女，智贤力有余者，尚乃当还报复其父母功恩，而供养之也。 故父母不当随衣食之也。 是者名为弱养强，不足筋力养有余也，名为逆政。 少者还愁苦老者，无益其父母，父母故多杀之也。 今但为乏衣食而杀伤之，孰若养活之者，而使各自衣食乎？ 真人，是诚冤绝地统，民之愚甚剧也。 今小生闻是，心大悲而恐，知冤者诚多，当奈何哉？ 然夫好学而不得衣食之者，其学必懈而道止也，而得衣食焉，则贤者学而不止也。 当使各有所利，不当使其还反相愁穷也。 何谓也？ 、夫女者无官，女之就夫，比若男子之就官也，当得衣食焉。 女之就夫家，乃当相与并力，同心治生，乃共传天地统，到死尚复骨肉同处，当相与并力，而因得衣食之。 令使贤且乐，令使不肖者且苦。 比若土地，良土其物善，天亦付归之，薄土其物恶，天亦付归之，不夺其材力所生长也。 天地尚不夺汝功，何况人乎哉？ 如是则凡人无复杀其女者也。 善哉善哉，一大深害除矣，帝王太平已至矣。 真人何以知之乎？ 然夫父母与子，极天下之厚也，不得困愁焉，不宜杀之也。 母乃杀其子，是应寇贼之气，大逆甚无道也。 故其乱帝王治最深。 夫女今得生，不见贼杀伤，故大乐到矣。 然，子说是也。 可谓知之矣。

Thus, the Dao of Heaven follows the yang number as one, and the yin number as two—hence yang is odd, yin is even. Therefore, the ruler is few while ministers are many. Yang is noble, yin is base; thus, two yin must together serve one yang. The number of Heaven is one, the number of Earth is two; therefore, two women should serve one man—why must two share the burden of supporting one?

The side of the noble must not be left vacant. When one acts, another should stand by to attend to what is lacking. Thus, one symbolizes Heaven, two symbolizes Earth, and humanity is the child of Heaven and Earth—therefore, it must emulate its parents.

Since the world lost the Dao, it has scorned and wantonly slaughtered girls, causing women to be fewer than men. Thus, yin qi is severed, no longer aligning with the pattern of Heaven and Earth. The Dao of Heaven decrees that a solitary yang cannot thrive alone, causing Heaven to withhold timely rain. Women correspond to Earth, yet they are universally despised. The world collectively scorns its true mother, murdering and harming Earth’s qi, severing its vitality so that it ceases to produce. Earth grows enraged and displeased, multiplying disasters, preventing the king’s governance from achieving peace.

Why is this so? Men embody the spirit of Heaven, women the spirit of Earth. Things of the same kind influence one another—if governance is not at peace, the fault does not lie with the king alone. Rather, the common people, having lost the Dao, treat matters lightly and commit wrongs together. Their transgressions are not singular but manifold, making governance difficult to stabilize and leading to disorder.

The nature of Heaven and Earth encompasses twelve thousand things, yet human life is the most precious. This slaughter of girls deeply disrupts the king’s governance—here lies the greatest calamity.

Now, the Heavenly Master opens the path to Great Peace for the king. The true scripture of Great Peace has emerged, allowing the king to wander without care. Yet this harm to girls brings great disaster—what is to be done?

Excellent is your question! You have grasped the heart of Heaven.

The reason the world despises and reviles women lies in their conduct—where does this fault originate?

I wish to hear it, to record it on bamboo and silk, so that for ten thousand generations it may never be abandoned.

Excellent! If you now record this, the world will no longer kill girls.

Indeed, indeed.

I wish to record it to eliminate the king’s disasters—this brings me joy, to save the lives of wronged girls.

Excellent! You have gained the favor of Heaven’s reckoning.

What do you mean?

To save a life is to save oneself; to kill a life is to kill oneself. Heaven cherishes its children—by acting thus, you lengthen your allotted span in Heaven, and the Controller of Destinies alters your register.

I dare not, I dare not.

There is no further refusal—this is the natural law of Heaven.

The reason the world kills girls is that when people are young, parents fret and struggle, denying them clothing and food while raising them. This is not unique to humans—even creatures that crawl do the same. When they grow old, large or small, each must seek clothing and food according to their strength. Thus, all things eventually leave their parents to provide for themselves. The worthy find joy, the unworthy find suffering.

Moreover, children are young, their strength daily increasing and abundant. Parents grow old, their strength daily waning and insufficient. Whether son or daughter, the wise and strong should repay their parents’ kindness and nurture them. Thus, parents should not be responsible for their children’s clothing and food.

This is called the weak supporting the strong, the insufficient sustaining the abundant—it is a perverse governance. The young burden the old, offering no benefit to their parents, so parents often kill them. If they kill them for lack of clothing and food, how is that better than letting them live and provide for themselves?

Master, this truly severs Earth’s lineage—how profoundly foolish the people are!

Now, hearing this, my heart grieves and trembles with fear. I know the wronged are many—what is to be done?

Those who study but lack clothing and food will slacken in their learning, and the Dao will halt. But if they obtain clothing and food, the worthy will study without ceasing. Each should have their own benefit, not be made to return and burden one another.

What do you mean?

Women have no official positions. A woman joining her husband is like a man taking office—she should obtain clothing and food. When a woman joins her husband’s household, they should unite their strength, work together to sustain life, and jointly transmit the lineage of Heaven and Earth. Until death, their bones and flesh remain together, and they should combine their efforts to secure clothing and food. Thus, the worthy will be joyful, the unworthy will suffer.

It is like the land: fertile soil yields good crops, and Heaven bestows its favor upon it. Poor soil yields bad crops, and Heaven bestows its favor accordingly, never seizing what grows by its own strength. If Heaven does not seize your labor, how much less should people?

Thus, no one will kill their daughters.

Excellent, excellent! A great and deep harm is removed—Great Peace for the emperor is at hand!

Master, how do you know this?

Parents and children share the deepest bond in the world—they must not be distressed or impoverished, nor should they be killed. A mother who kills her child aligns with the qi of bandits and rebels—this is the height of rebellion and the absence of the Dao. Thus, it most deeply disrupts the king’s governance.

If girls are allowed to live and not murdered or harmed, great joy will arrive.

Indeed, your words are correct. You may be said to understand.

Now, if every household in the world kills one girl, how many households are there in the world? Some families even kill ten or more girls. Some injure them before they are born, cutting them down in the womb. Their grievance and resentment rise to Heaven—how can this be without reason?

Thus, I earnestly and repeatedly affirm this truth.

When each person relies on their own labor for clothing and food, women will have no divided hearts, their minds will be single, and their work will no longer be hesitant or doubtful. But if they toil without reward, their spirits will remain discordant—this is the natural principle of Heaven’s nature.

Master, guard this well. Do not discard this text, but entrust it to a benevolent and worthy ruler, that one great grievance and disaster may be removed. Heed my words and show them to all people, so that none will willingly cast away their daughters. Then, one man will have two women, and this will accord with the laws of Heaven and Earth.

For Heaven’s laws decree: the yang number is odd, the yin number is even. Since the Great Middle Antiquity, people have lost the intent of the Dao of Heaven, wantonly killing girls, causing men to outnumber women and leaving them insufficient. This greatly violates the Dao of Heaven, perpetuating a cycle of mutual burden as common custom. Later generations will suffer the world’s worst calamities—how grievous and devoid of the Dao!

Men inherit the Heavenly lineage, women the Earthly lineage. Now, by severing the Earthly lineage and preventing its transmission, many will be cut off without descendants. How grave their sin!

All things should mutually generate and transmit their kind, yet now the Earthly lineage is broken, and humanity’s kind is extinguished. Thus, Heaven will eventually sever their posterity.

Moreover, all people are born bearing Heaven’s qi in full: the head is round like Heaven, the feet square like Earth; the four limbs correspond to the four seasons; the five viscera to the five phases; the ears, eyes, mouth, and nose to the seven luminaries and three lights. These correspondences are beyond enumeration—only the sage fully understands them.

All people possess both yin and yang. When the sun and moon are full, the womb opens, and they emerge to gaze upon Heaven and Earth, to grow, and to transmit their ancestors’ lineage, assisting Heaven in generating beings and Earth in nurturing forms. Now, Heaven and Earth’s spirits trust this family, and the spiritual lineage of Heaven and Earth comes to dwell within this person. Yet people harm them, and Heaven greatly blames them. Since people do not restrain one another, Heaven has sent forth this text to show to later generations.

If, after this matter has been revealed, one still persists in the old ways, this is willful violation of Heaven’s law. Their sin will be doubled, and their lineage will be extinguished without doubt.

Master, guard this well. Exert yourself, exert yourself!

Yes, yes.

Now that you have revealed this matter, if you flee and hide this text, you will bear the punishment on behalf of others.

Go forth, and each of you consider your own fate.

**Method of One Man and Two Women, Forty-Second**

The Perfected One approaches.
Now, the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, and the king’s governance nears perfect harmony. Should people uphold chastity or not? How ought one uphold it?
Chastity means moderating desires and refraining from reckless conduct.
Alas! The Perfected One’s words reveal the errors of common folk since the purest antiquity. Their teachers, consumed by inner jealousy, instead instruct the people in recklessness.
The Perfected One asks: What do you mean?
A chaste man does not emit, and a chaste woman does not transform. When yin and yang do not unite, their line is cut off, leaving no descendants. Two people together sever the lineage of Heaven and Earth, coveting a hollow, false reputation while forfeiting posterity and losing the true kernel. This is the greatest harm under Heaven.
Had your parents not transmitted life to you, how would you exist? Yet you sever it—this is what Heaven and Earth jointly detest, a person who defies principle and commits great treason. The consequence is that Heaven and Earth become estranged: Heaven refuses to send rain, and Earth refuses to bring forth life. Why? When Heaven does not rain, it is because the chaste do not emit. When Earth does not generate the myriad things, it is because the chaste do not transform. If Heaven does not rain and Earth produces nothing, this is the gravest misfortune under Heaven. How can this be called good?
Consider the Perfected One’s words: they defy the teachings of Heaven and Earth, reverse the Dao of Heaven, and take no joy in aiding Heaven and Earth’s generation and transformation—instead, they seek to sever it. Do your spoken words not weigh upon the August Heaven and Revered Earth? Even the strong may falter, and those with faults may err. Having heard the Celestial Master’s discourse, do you not recognize the gravity of your transgression?
I speak to you: no matter should contravene the Dao of Heaven. To follow the words of common folk and defy the will of Heaven—this is why yin and yang are so often estranged, for it stems from disharmony between men and women. Men and women are the root of yin and yang. If governance loses its root, how can it be auspicious?
Now, Celestial Master, what should be done?
As the qi of Great Peace from the Supreme Heaven above draws near, one must purely follow Heaven’s law. Thus, let one man take two women, to emulate yin and yang: yang is odd in number, yin is even. This is the arrival of the qi of Great Harmony.
If there are too many women, yin qi flourishes; if too many men, yang qi lacks balance and method, also inviting misfortune. Why? The number of people must correspond with Heaven and Earth. If they do not correspond, their strength falls short, and calamity ensues.
The imperial harem corresponds to the land—what does this signify? What the Perfected One has spoken aligns with my words. Women are the spirits of the land, while the king is the spirit of Heaven. The ruler fears that the land may not receive the spirit of yang, causing the king’s qi to fail to harmonize. If the land does not transform and generate, each province must offer one woman to circulate its qi. Delighting in their transformation and generation, the ruler fears that his grace may not extend fully, that his governance may not be complete, and thus takes them in accordance with the land. When grace is universally bestowed, Heaven’s qi flows freely, timely rain falls, and Earth brings forth the myriad things.
When the qi of Great Peace arrives, one must not esteem the chaste. Excessive inner solitude is a profound transgression, causing the king’s governance to lose harmony. Even common people must not exceed proper measure—hence the method of one man and two women.
Excellent, excellent!

Herein lies the method of aligning with Heaven and Earth’s law, harmonizing yin and yang, ensuring men and women bear no grievances, bringing timely rain, enabling Earth to transform and generate, and achieving peaceful royal governance.

**Method of Promoting Good and Suppressing Evil, Forty-Third**

The Perfected One approaches.
Now, as the qi of Great Peace descends, we wish to ensure that the cautious and good daily flourish, while the evil daily recede. Yet there are those who injure and kill, and bandits arise. How should governance address this?
What do you mean? I refer to the immediate resolution of known outbreaks.
If the sovereign, seated in doubt, wishes to greatly promote the good and swiftly suppress the evil, and bandits arise, how should they be promptly apprehended? How ought governance proceed?
Perfected One, you should take careful note. Today, the Celestial Master commands me—how dare I not speak? Yet if my words do not accord with the Celestial Master’s law, why be modest in speaking?
Since ancient times, great sages have not demanded perfection from any single person. If your words today miss the mark, why be modest?
Yes, yes.
One must only reward the good and punish the evil, making the distinctions clear and unequivocal. Then the good will daily flourish, and the evil will daily recede.
Your words are correct. But do the rewards and punishments lack specific designations?
I dare not speak further without diligent effort and a single word of instruction.
Now, may the Celestial Master fully elucidate it.
Very well. You must remember this, and I shall explain it to you in detail.
When the magistrate arrives at the site of an outbreak, he must summon all the people of the district. Former high ministers and officials shall sit facing east; those learned in the classics and the Dao shall sit facing north; the filial and fraternal shall sit facing west; diligent farmers and cautious youths shall sit in the southeast corner, facing northwest; wicked youths shall sit in the southwest corner, facing northeast; and the sovereign shall sit facing south.
Why must they sit precisely thus?
Each follows their kind—this is the Dao of Heaven, guiding people to establish goodness. How are bandits easily apprehended?
Former high ministers and officials are placed in the position of loyalty, for these people, though no longer in office, delight in aiding with righteousness. Those learned in the classics and the Dao are placed in the position of clarity, to illuminate their teachings and assist in scrutinizing evil. The filial and fraternal are placed in their native villages, for the utmost filial piety resides in the heart—thus they return to their hometowns. The filial and fraternal are to remain constantly reverent, as if attending court. Things are born in the east, delighting in daily progress. Diligent farmers and cautious youths are placed in the southeast corner, the direction of growth and nurturance, to delight in cultivating the myriad things without negligence.

If, after this matter has been revealed, one still persists in the old ways, this is willful violation of Heaven’s law. Their sin will be doubled, and their lineage will be extinguished without doubt.

Master, guard this well. Exert yourself, exert yourself!

Yes, yes.

Now that you have revealed this matter, if you flee and hide this text, you will bear the punishment on behalf of others.

I dare not, I dare not.

Go forth, and each of you consider your own fate.

The reason for revealing it first is to delight in the daily flourishing of those who do good and the daily cessation of those who do evil. Now, as the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, I fear that people’s wickedness may disrupt its governance. Thus, I first awaken them.

In governance, one ought to emulate Heaven. Heaven does not conceal people’s faults. The sages of the Great Antiquity did not do so either. To be called obscure and benighted, to have governance that reverses course and invites misfortune, failing to align with the will of Heaven and Earth—this is why I reveal it first.

Excellent, excellent! Why must the lord remain inside behind closed doors while making the speaker stand outside? When a person is about to hear confidential words, their heart must not be aware beforehand. If faces draw too close, bystanders will know, and the speaker may come to harm. For a lord or leader to receive wisdom and insight, only to bring harm upon the speaker, is called injuring the loyal and trustworthy. Thereafter, no worthy minister or stalwart aide will dare speak again. With wisdom and insight cut off, governance will fall into chaos and peril.

Moreover, the lord is yang and dwells in the yin. The minister is yin and stands in the yang. When yin and yang are in harmony, people delight in what is said, and every proposal is met with full trust. This is the natural law of Heaven. Does the Perfected One not know this?

**Forty-Fourth Chapter: Guarding the Three Realities**

The Perfected One stepped forward.

chunks.original_text: 然天下人本生受命之时，与天地分身，抱元气於自然，不饮不食，嘘吸阴阳气而活，不知饥渴，久久离神道远，小小失其指意，后生者不得复知，真道空虚，日流就伪，更生饥渴，不饥不食便死，是一大急也。 天地怜哀之，共为生可饮食，既饮既食，天统阴阳当见传，不得中断天地之统也。 传之当象天地，一阴一阳，故天使其自有一男一女，色相好，然后能生也。 何乃正使一阴一阳，夫阳极者能生阴，阴极者能生阳，此两者相传，比若寒尽反热，热尽反寒，自然之术也。 故能长相生也，世世不绝天神统也。 如男女不相得，便绝无后世。 天下无人，何有夫妇父子、君臣师弟子乎？ 以何相生而相治哉？ 天地之间无牝牡，以何相传？ 寂然便空，二大急也。 故阴阳者，传天地统，使无穷极也。 君臣者，治其乱，圣人师弟子主通天教，助帝王化天下。 故此饮食与男女相须，二者大急。 天道有寒热，不自障隐，半伤杀人。 故天为生万物，可以衣之，不衣，但穴处隐同活耳，愁半伤不尽灭死也，此名为半急也。 所谓天道大急者，乃谓绝灭死亡也，急无过此也。 夫人不衣，固不能饮食合阴阳，不为其善。 衣则生贤，无衣则生不肖也。 故衣者，有以御害而已。 故古者圣贤不效玄黄也。 饮食阴阳不可绝，绝之天下无人，不可治也。 守此三者，足以竟其天年，传其天统，终者复始，无有穷已。 故古者圣人以此为治也，其余不急，召凶祸物者，悉已去矣。 何谓也？ 此三者应天行。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet when people first receive life and destiny at birth, they partake of Heaven and Earth, embracing primordial qi in its natural state. They neither drink nor eat, but live by inhaling and exhaling the qi of yin and yang, unaware of hunger or thirst. Over time, they drift far from the spirit Dao, gradually losing its guiding intent. Later generations no longer understand this truth, and the authentic Dao lies empty. Day by day, they drift toward falsity, until hunger and thirst arise—now, without eating and drinking, they perish. This is the first great urgency.

Heaven and Earth, in their compassion, provide sustenance for life. Once people begin to eat and drink, the transmission of yin and yang under Heaven’s mandate must not be severed. This transmission should mirror Heaven and Earth, one yin and one yang. Thus, Heaven ordains that each person have one man and one woman, their forms harmonious, so that they may give birth. Why must it be one yin and one yang? When yang reaches its extreme, it generates yin; when yin reaches its extreme, it generates yang. These two alternate in transmission, like cold reaching its limit and turning to heat, heat reaching its limit and turning to cold—such is the natural art. Thus, they perpetuate life endlessly, preserving the celestial lineage through the ages. If men and women do not unite, their posterity will be cut off. If the world has no people, how can there be husbands and wives, fathers and children, rulers and ministers, masters and disciples? By what means would they be born and govern one another? Without male and female between Heaven and Earth, how would transmission continue? All would fall silent and empty—this is the second great urgency.

Therefore, yin and yang transmit the mandate of Heaven and Earth, ensuring boundless continuity. Rulers and ministers govern disorder; sages and their disciples propagate the celestial teachings, aiding the emperor in transforming the world. Thus, sustenance and the union of men and women are the two great urgencies.

The Dao of Heaven has cold and heat, which, if not shielded against, cause half the harm that kills people. Thus, Heaven generates the myriad things so they may be clothed. Without clothing, one might survive in caves or hidden places, but half the suffering would remain, not wholly eradicating death—this is the minor urgency.

What is called the great urgency of the Heavenly Dao refers to annihilation and death; nothing is more urgent than this. Without clothing, people cannot properly eat, drink, or unite in yin and yang, nor cultivate goodness. With clothing, the worthy are born; without it, the unworthy arise. Thus, clothing serves only to ward off harm. Therefore, the sages of antiquity did not adorn themselves in dark and bright hues.

Sustenance and the union of yin and yang must not be severed; if severed, the world would have no people and could not be governed. Upholding these three—sustenance, union, and clothing—is sufficient to fulfill one’s Heaven-appointed years, transmit the celestial mandate, and ensure that endings give way to new beginnings without end. Thus, the sages of old governed by these principles, discarding all else that was not urgent and invited misfortune. What does this mean? These three accord with the movements of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 男者天也，女者地也，衣者依也。 天地父母所以依养人形身也。 过此三者，其余奇伪之物，不必须之而活，传类相生也，反多以致伪奸，使治不平，皇气不得至，天道乖错，为君子重忧。 六情所好，人人嬉之，而不自禁止，意转乐之，因以致祸。 君子失其政令，小人盗劫刺，皆由此不急之物为召之也。 天下贫困愁苦，灾变连起，下极欺其上，皆以此为大害。 所从来者久，亦非独今下古后世之人过也。 传相承负，失其本真实，悉就浮华，因还自愁自害，不得竟其天年也。 后生多事纷纷，但以其为不急之事，以致凶事，故常趋走不得止也。 上古所以无为而治，得道意、得天心意者，以其守本，不失三急。 中古小多事者，以其小多端也。 下古大多忧者，以其大多端而生邪伪，更以相高上而相愁也，因生邪奸出其中也。 内失其真实，离其本根，转而相害，使人眩乱，君子虽愁，心欲乐正之。 所为亿万端，不可胜理，以乱其治。 真人深思此意。 善哉善哉。

Man is Heaven, woman is Earth, and clothing is dependence. Heaven and Earth, father and mother, are what the human form and body depend upon for nurture. Beyond these three, all other strange and deceptive things are not essential for life or the transmission of kind through generation. Instead, they multiply and give rise to deceit and treachery, causing governance to falter, the imperial qi to fail in its descent, the Dao of Heaven to go awry, and becoming a grave concern for the noble person.

The six emotions delight in what people indulge in, yet they do not restrain themselves; their minds grow ever more enamored, thereby inviting disaster. The noble person loses control of governance and decrees, while petty people resort to theft, plunder, and violence—all summoned by these non-essential things. The world falls into poverty, distress, and suffering; calamities arise in succession. Those below reach the extreme of deceiving those above, all stemming from this great harm.

This has endured for a long time, and the fault does not lie solely with the people of today, past ages, or future generations. Transmitted and inherited through generations, they have lost their original truth and authenticity, all turning to superficial splendor. Thus, they bring sorrow and harm upon themselves, unable to fulfill their Heaven-appointed years.

Later generations engage in ever more affairs, busily pursuing what is not urgent, thereby inviting misfortune. Hence, they are constantly in restless motion, unable to cease. In high antiquity, governance was achieved through non-action, attaining the intent of the Dao and the will of Heaven, for they upheld the fundamentals and did not lose sight of the three urgent matters. In middle antiquity, affairs multiplied slightly, for they pursued many minor paths. In later antiquity, great worries abounded, for they pursued many paths and gave rise to deceit and falsehood, each striving to outdo the other in distress. From this, treachery and villainy emerged.

Having lost their inner authenticity and departed from their root, they turn to harming one another, causing people to be dazzled and confused. Though the noble person grieves and desires to rectify this with joy, the countless affairs they undertake cannot be properly ordered, throwing governance into chaos.

The Perfected One deeply contemplates this intent.

**Chapter Forty-Five: The Three Urgent Matters and the Laws of Fortune and Misfortune**
The Perfected One stepped forward.

"Among the crawling creatures, how many matters are of great urgency, how many of minor urgency, and how many are not urgent at all?"

"Indeed," came the reply. "Each has its own urgencies—thousands of strands, ten thousand paths—all designated as some form of urgency. Crawling creatures each have their own aspirations, yet they cannot be named."

The Perfected One sighed, "You have grown weary and dim. Why do you persist in feigning ignorance? How utterly burdensome this is!"

"It is not that I fall short."

"If you yourself admit to falling short, how can you speak of the common people losing their way? Is this not the very essence of falling short?"

"Only the Heavenly Master, in your compassion, might dispel this ignorance and darkness."

"Very well. All crawling creatures receive the governance of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang, and are born alike. They share two great urgencies and one minor urgency. What are these?"

"When crawling creatures first receive the governance of yin and yang, they all breathe in unison, inhaling the qi of the natural world, yet they do not yet know food or drink. Over time, they drift far from their root, the great Dao wanes, and Heaven’s qi can no longer constantly follow and protect them. Thus, hunger and thirst arise, and Heaven provides food and drink. They, too, transmit the governance of yin and yang, hence the existence of male and female, generation after generation perpetuating life without end. To sever their food and drink, to disrupt the transmission of yin and yang—this would leave the world devoid of crawling creatures. These are the two great urgencies.

The minor urgency is this: creatures with fur, feathers, or scales may live, yet even bare-skinned creatures survive. Those with fur or feathers are ever gentle and beloved, shielding them from cold and heat. Those with scales ever ward off harm. These are not essential for life, hence their urgency is minor. All other movements are but sources of calamity. Those who do not uphold these three fundamentals, who act recklessly without cause, will surely meet death. This is the natural law suspended between Heaven and Earth.

The Perfected One ought to ponder this intent. Those who uphold these three ways will harmonize with the central harmony of Heaven and Earth. Those who lose these three and pursue many paths will all suffer misfortune and harm."

"Excellent indeed, excellent indeed."

The Heavenly Master having expounded thus, a question was humbly posed: "Now, what of the rooted plants and drooping branches that neither eat nor drink nor clothe themselves? How is this to be understood?"

"Alas! Your learning does not advance day by day but instead recedes into ignorance. Why is this? They, too, have two great urgencies and one minor urgency. What are these? Listen closely."

**Chapter Forty-Six: In Serving the Dead, One Must Not Exceed the Laws of the Living**

The Perfected One stepped forward.
"Yes, yes."

A filial child serves their parents—when the parents pass, should they then serve them as they did in life?
"No, they should serve them *beyond* how they did in life."
"Why is that?"
"Through their parents, a person is born and grows to greatness. Seeing their parents die, with no hope of return, the heart cannot forget them even for a moment. In life, they saw each other daily, received teachings and commands, and could repay kindness in return. But in death, they can no longer behold one another, and sorrowful longing fills their thoughts—thus, they should serve them *beyond* how they did in life."

The Perfected One spoke truly, yet this is already a great departure from the true Dao of Heaven, drifting ever farther away. If even the Perfected One’s discourse remains thus, how much more do the benighted common folk err, clearly violating Heaven’s laws.
"What do you mean?"
"Master of Heaven."
"Indeed: a person in life resembles Heaven and belongs to Heaven; a person in death resembles Earth and belongs to Earth. Heaven is the father; Earth is the mother. One must not serve the mother beyond the father. The living are yang; the dead are yin. One must not serve yin beyond yang. Yang is the ruler; yin is the subject. One must not serve the subject beyond the ruler. To serve yin in excess of yang is to invite *rebellious qi*; a small excess brings minor rebellion, a great excess brings great rebellion—this is called *rebellious qi*, called *rebellious governance*. Its harm allows yin to overpower yang, the lower to deceive the higher, and ghostly and malevolent entities to flourish, jointly usurping the human Dao, moving about in broad daylight without regard for others. Now, illnesses cannot be eradicated, and roaming ghosts do not cease. The great fault lies here—do you understand? Do you truly understand?"

"I, foolish and unlearned, have committed such transgressions without realizing it. Now, hearing the Master of Heaven’s words, I am suddenly awakened with deep remorse. Master, I humbly beg your forgiveness and will diligently take heed. You have revealed what I did not comprehend—yet this transgression seems minor; why does it lead to such grave consequences?"
"To serve yin beyond yang, to serve the lower beyond the higher—this is the greatest of transgressions. How can you call it minor when it reaches such extremes?"

The Perfected One was again at a loss.
"Moreover, the living are yang; ghosts and spirits are yin. The living belong to day; the dead belong to night. Do you wish to understand the profound consequences of this? When day grows long, night becomes short; when night grows long, day becomes short. When yang flourishes, it overpowers yin, and yin dares not appear recklessly—thus, ghosts and spirits remain hidden. When yin flourishes, it overpowers yang, and yang retreats—thus, ghosts and spirits appear in daylight. The living accompany the sun; malevolent ghosts and entities accompany the stars. The sun is yang; the stars are yin. Therefore, when the sun appears, the stars flee; when the stars appear, the sun sets. When yin prevails, ghosts and entities jointly cause profound harm, beyond description—this is called *flourishing yin* and *weakening yang*. It disrupts governance and harms the living. This transgression is most severe—ponder it deeply."
"Yes, yes."

Thus, the Dao of Heaven establishes its laws: the office of yin must always be weaker than yang. Just as a subject must be weaker than their ruler, so a subject serves their ruler with obedience; a child must be weaker than their parents, so a child serves their parents with filial piety. If they grow strong and unyielding, the harm becomes profound and severe. Therefore, though a filial child’s love cannot forget their parents, they must not serve them beyond how they did in life.
"Perfected One, do you now understand?"
"Yes, yes."

Beware, beware. In all matters, one must not indulge recklessly or act wantonly.
"Yes, yes."
If you serve the dead more lavishly than the living, you transgress against Heaven—how can this be? It is to disrespect yang and instead honor yin, called "turning upward to face downward," hence the transgression against Heaven.
"Foolish one, I bear great fault. May the Heavenly Master forgive me."
Not so. Simply reflect carefully: all actions must accord with the law.
"Yes, yes."
The Heavenly Master has instructed me; I wish to fully understand why one must not exceed the standards of the living.
In burial rites, clothing, and funerary provisions, nothing should surpass what was done in life. All such excess is perverse governance, and even the dead incur punishment for it. To send off the dead without adhering to their original state—when the underworld’s ledgers examine the discrepancies, the false and deceptive conduct is exposed, and thus punishment follows.
Moreover, excessive reverence in mourning rites—when inauspicious affairs grow too grand—invites misfortune. Ghosts and corpses flourish, spreading disease and harming people, giving rise to omens and strange transformations. How can this be made clear?
"Excellent question.
In high antiquity, the sages conducted funerals with utmost sincerity alone, never daring to make them extravagant. Death and mourning are the most inauspicious affairs under Heaven. To amplify inauspiciousness is to invite harm. Thus, sincerity alone sufficed, and though food and drink mirrored the living, nothing was lacking. In those times, people enjoyed good fortune, free from illness, and all fulfilled their natural lifespans.
In middle antiquity, funerary rites slightly deviated from the law. People could not maintain pure sincerity, losing the true intent and instead drifting into minor displays of reverence. They pursued ostentation to appease the living, their devotion to the dead only half-hearted. The dead’s ghosts came to partake, but with slight deviations from truth in the rites, the offerings summoned malevolence. Unseen spirits and entities arrived to share the feast, lingering to afflict people, so minor illnesses became common.
In later antiquity, people inherited and compounded the errors of middle antiquity, exacerbating them greatly. They no longer acted with sincerity toward their kin, instead seeking to overwhelm the living with grandeur. Imitating the ostentatious practices of the past, they fabricated falsehoods, failing to move Heaven or ensure the dead’s ghosts would regularly partake. Instead, they expanded sacrifices beyond measure, violating the law. Yin flourished and harmed the weakening yang, and unknown spirits and entities gathered to feast, then rampaged unchecked, killing people without end. When one person was slain, the perpetrators saw only the spectacle, not the guilt—why would they not persist?
Thus, malevolent qi daily increased, turning to attack its host. Once accustomed to feeding, it followed the living relentlessly. With yin strong and yang weak, the living were oppressed. Subjects deceived their rulers, children deceived their fathers, governance became unjust, and the people remained unaware. Hence, malevolence grew daily more severe, no longer restrained.
Therefore, the sages of antiquity dared not serve the dead beyond how they served the living—this was a clear prohibition.
"Perfected One, do you now understand?"
"How profound! How profound! Had the Heavenly Master not revealed this, my foolish heart would never have known it.
Perfected One, you and I share a mind. Surely Heaven has sent you to preside over these inquiries. You must not take this lightly, which is why I have told you everything.
The reason is this: now, the qi of good governance is about to arrive. All affairs must follow its course; even a single reversal will prevent its coming.
What does this mean? The Dao of Heaven should flourish yang, but to weaken yin is to follow the proper order. To instead amplify yin and suppress yang is to act perversely. To revere inauspicious affairs is to invite inauspicious qi, causing governance to falter and lose its rightful place—this is no minor transgression.
Perfected One, do not conceal this text. Let it circulate so all people may recognize their gains and losses.
When governance is disordered, the fault does not lie solely with Heaven, Earth, or the ruler. The blame rests with the common people, each bearing their own transgressions, mutually inheriting and compounding them, all seated in their failure to uphold truth.
By departing from truth and turning to falsehood, they stray from the root without realizing it.
What does this mean? The living are the root; the dead are the false.
Why call it false? In truth, one does not see the deceased’s desires, yet the living fabricate them, vainly depicting forms and appearances beyond what existed in life. They cling to emptiness, not to substantive matters.

"Excellent! You may be said to have grasped the intent of the Dao.

Foolish as I am, I have received your grace and now comprehend deeply. Yet I have no end of questions—only that the Celestial Master might admonish and caution me again.

Now, one who can profoundly nurture the self is able to nurture others; one who can profoundly cherish the self is able to cherish others. If one neglects one’s own body and cannot even nurture oneself, how can one generously nurture others? Then examine the writings of those in middle antiquity who followed the Way and won the Heart of Heaven. Then consider the texts of those in later antiquity who pondered and practiced, won the Will of Heaven, and preserved themselves for long.

You should examine all these, from beginning to end, and you will find they align perfectly with my words, like a compass and square in perfect accord. Only then will you, though now enlightened, come to trust my writings fully.

Nowadays, the sickly and the young grow ever more reckless, contending over fate. The most foolish even claim Heaven is without knowledge, that the Dao of Heaven yields no effect. Yet even the earth does not deceive: plant millet, and you reap millet; plant wheat, and you reap wheat. The more effort one invests, the finer the harvest—how much more so with Heaven!

Now, Heaven has accumulated resentment, and the ignorant, lacking understanding, teach one another to treat matters lightly, growing ever more foolish with each generation. Thus, calamities, anomalies, and strange omens arise without end.

Heaven and the sovereign share a bond as deep as that of father and son, yet the foolish, seeing this, fail to admonish their ruler in due time. Instead, they conceal and obstruct, severing the path to Heaven. Heaven’s indignation only grows, and the burden of *chengfu* deepens, worsening beyond remedy.

Though an emperor may possess the virtue of ten thousand men, he may still suffer harm without cause. Thus, those who do good remain unrecognized, as if their efforts were of no benefit. This is why the foolish claim Heaven is without knowledge—yet is there not reason for it?

Now, hearing the Celestial Master’s words, my heart is enlightened as if reborn.

Excellent, excellent!

Though I, your disciple, have often troubled you, risking transgression to ask these matters—beginning with what seemed like errors—now that I have grasped your meaning, I rejoice without regret.

For without inquiry, there is no path to understanding. Your words have captured this intent.

Excellent! The writings are complete in every part—head, feet, belly, back, surface, and core—so examine them alongside the worthy, and ask no more."

"Yes, yes."

**Section Forty-Eight: Five Matters Explaining the Method of *Chengyuan***

The benighted disciple bows and speaks:

"A great sage, upon hearing a master’s words from one side, understands the teachings of all four sides. A lesser sage, upon hearing a master’s words on one matter, grasps the teachings of all four. Thus, instruction is easy.

But for those of us who are dull, benighted, and slow, even when matters are explained repeatedly, doubts linger in the heart. Thus, I dare to ask the Celestial Master in full.

You have resolved the enmity of *chengfu* for High Heaven, lifted the calamities of *chengfu* for the Earth, eased the burdens of *chengfu* for emperors, absolved the transgressions of *chengfu* for the common people, and relieved the obligations of *chengfu* for the twelve thousand beings.

Yet I, your foolish disciple, ask these things on behalf of Heaven. I dare not but risk transgression to speak fully—may I hear the meaning in its entirety?"

"Speak plainly.

Do emperors and the people bear *chengfu*? Do all matters likewise carry *chengfu* of their own?"

"Excellent! You ask on behalf of Heaven—truly thorough and careful.

Whenever we meet, you say you ask these questions for Heaven’s sake, so I dare not be remiss.

Excellent! You possess a diligent and upright intent—you may be entrusted with matters.

Now, do you wish me to explain everything in full?"

"I would not shrink from the difficulty."

"Yet I fear the vastness of the text may overwhelm your capacity. To fully expound the *chengfu* of the world would require millions of words—far too many to bear.

"Yes, yes."

"Now, when Heaven and Earth give life to all things, and one harms them without virtue, the world falls into chaos: households grow poor and wanting, the old and weak suffer hunger and cold, the government reaps no harvest, and granaries stand empty. If a master teaches ten disciples, and the master’s words are false and insincere, the ten disciples will act accordingly, each teaching ten more—now a hundred spread falsehoods. When ten thousand voices speak from all sides, the world is filled with deception.

Moreover, when many transmit words, their cumulative weight makes reversal impossible, and falsehood becomes the norm. This begins with one person’s misstatement, yet it leads all people astray, distorting the true texts of Heaven, altering customs, and corrupting the world—a great malady that cannot be curbed. Later generations grow ever worse.

This is the calamity of *chengfu*—clearly not the fault of later people. Yet later generations, unaware of its distant origins, blame their contemporaries, deepening mutual grievances. The stagnant *qi* remains unresolved, worsening day by day.

The people of the marketplace spread the word, and ten thousand households came to know it. Old and young, great and small, all walked about speaking of it, until the whole world heard. Thus the world was deceived, and later generations only amplified it, those more distant suffering even worse. This began with one man’s words—yet the burden of *chengfu* for empty falsehoods falls upon him, so how can later people be at fault? Yet they turn and blame their contemporaries.

This is the third matter—listen again for further clarity.

On South Mountain stands a great tree, its branches and canopy spreading hundreds of paces across the earth, though its trunk is but one. Above, its branches, leaves, and fruit are beyond measure; below, its roots do not firmly grasp the earth. When great winds and rains assail it, its countless branches, leaves, and fruit all wither and die—this is the great *chengfu* transgression of the ten thousand things, grasses and trees alike. The fault lies in the root, not the branches, yet they blame the branches—is this not a grievous wrong? Now the branches bear no fault, yet they suffer calamity and perish without cause. Such is the burden of *chengfu*—how can later generations be blamed?

This is the fourth matter—now attend once more with clarity.

On South Mountain lurks a poisonous *qi*. The mountain fails to contain it, and when the spring southern wind arises, the *qi* rides with it, obscuring sun and moon. The world bears its blame, and the dead pile up in great numbers. This began with the mountain’s release of *qi*—why then do the people of the world bear the burden of *chengfu*, falling ill and dying? Yet contemporaries say, “You are wicked, so Heaven slays you,” blaming the people—is this not a grievous wrong? These people bear no fault, yet they suffer this disaster through *chengfu*. Their souls cry out in injustice, and the living further blame them, their *qi* knotting in grievance until it stirs Heaven. The fault lies in the mountain’s evil *qi*, carried by the wind—such is the burden of *chengfu*.

This is the fifth matter—now, Perfected One, sit solemnly and heed my words with care.

The Dao was originally upright, never deceptive or false. Yet people rely on their ancestors, rulers, teachers, and fathers, whose teachings deviated slightly from the upright Way. They lost the upright words of self-nurturance, and later generations imitated them, worsening day by day. Over time, these teachings spread, and none grasped the truth. The world turned wholly to falsehood, unable to restrain itself, and thus ten thousand disasters arose, too many to record. This has accumulated over a long, long time. The foolish, knowing nothing, blame their rulers and contemporaries—are they not doubly wronged? The world is wholly lost, unable to recognize itself. Though the emperor alone may possess the virtue of ten thousand people, what can he do alone? Yet people act as they do—is there any remedy?

If one’s food is exhausted and they seek more, yet the sick cannot eat and thus perish—is there any remedy? If yin and yang unite in perfect harmony, with descendants to offer sacrifices and pray for blessings, yet one remains childless—is there any remedy? If one lives in utmost joy and goodness, strong and robust, yet turns out base and wicked—is there any remedy? These are all the great effects of *chengfu*. Yet they blame their contemporaries, so their governance cannot be settled. People have long transmitted falsehoods—how can they suddenly correct themselves? Thus grievances persist, growing ever more entrenched, and Heaven takes pity. Therefore, the Supreme Sovereign’s Dao descends in accord with the primordial *qi*. Do not wonder at this.

What is the beginning? To ponder and guard the One—why? The One is the beginning of numbers, the Way of life, the origin of primordial *qi*, the guiding principle of Heaven. Thus one must guard and contemplate the One, ascending and descending from above.

Whenever things or affairs grow too great and fail to return to their root, they become deeply confused and cannot be resolved. Thus they must return to their root. Therefore, the sages of old, before undertaking any great endeavor, would gaze up at the celestial patterns and look down at the earth’s principles, clearly demonstrating the luminous effects of returning to the root.

Perfected One, do you understand? Yes, yes.

Now, Master, you seem troubled. I have already laid out the beginnings of *chengfu*—all matters in the world follow this pattern of *chengfu*. Do you understand? Yes, yes.

Today, the Celestial Master has fully explained its origins, and this foolish student’s heart-knots are undone. Go now, and I will tell you one great essential truth.

Those in high antiquity who attained the Dao and brought order to their governance simply mastered self-nurturance and guarded their root. **Fifty-Second Section: Explication of the Master’s Cipher Text**

The Perfected One bowed twice with reverence and said, "Yes, yes. I humbly request the resolution of one lingering doubt.

What does *ping yan* mean?"

The cipher text you previously bestowed upon this dull and unenlightened student consists of ninety characters. I have retired to a secluded chamber, dwelling in solitude for days and nights, pondering with utmost diligence. Though my nature is dull and my mind slow, I have meditated ceaselessly, exhausting my spirit and depleting my heart, yet still fail to grasp its meaning. Now, I beseech the Heavenly Master to take pity on this unenlightened student and provide a full explication, that it may be transmitted through ten thousand generations, its threads unbroken and never forgotten.

"Excellent, your difficult question! You may indeed be called a celestial being."

"Very well. Perfected One, listen closely, and I shall fully resolve its essential meaning."

The Master said: "My text reads: *Eleven characters to clarify the stopping point.*"

*Master* refers to the divine teacher of August Heaven. *Said* means discourse. I ascend to address Heaven, personally sent down to expound before emperors and the myriad people, resolving the karmic retributions of *chengfu* across a hundred million generations.

*I* is the self. *Self* is the divine emissary urgently dispatched by Heaven. Today, the calamities of *chengfu* flow in four directions, their roots established at the beginning. Later rulers all follow in their wake, losing governance, unable to sever or halt them. Instead, they harm one another, inflicting profound suffering. Heaven regards this as a grave concern.

*Characters* refers to the celestial script I now array, the accumulated symbols of Heaven’s text. *Ten* signifies that the text aligns with the celestial perfected, its sincerity and truth resonating perfectly—tenfold, without error, not a single deception. Those who obtain it and reflect deeply will realize that their ancestors all bore *chengfu*. Reciting it without cease, the calamities of *chengfu*, great and small, will all be dispelled.

*One* is the essential Way, the correct path that begins with guarding the One. Guarding the One without pause, one’s clarity grows daily, and profound delusion dissolves. *Clarify* is the stopping point; *stopping* is sufficiency. Sufficiency gives rise to action. Those who practice this Way will only grow ever brighter, never again sinking into ignorance and darkness.

*Eleven* is the scholar. *Clarify to the stopping point* is the red. When the red *qi* attains this, it will flourish anew, and the king’s great illumination will return. *Stopping* is the sufficiency of the myriad things. When the myriad things first sprout, they extend their roots to draw sustenance from their origin. Practicing this Way restores the primordial *qi*, aligning with the heart of Heaven and Earth—this is the highest and most excellent, thus called the Way of the Supreme Sovereign.

*Bing-wu and ding-si* are the ancestral beginning. *Bing-wu* and *ding-si* are fire, the red. *Bing-wu* is pure yang; *ding-si* is pure yin. Yin and yang harmonize all things. This means the *qi* of yin and yang will reunite and flourish across the world. *For* means to benefit the emperor by eliminating misfortune and calamity. *Ancestor* is the first, embodying the virtue of the Three Sovereigns. *Beginning* is the return to the original source. Thus, practicing this Way will restore the era of the Supreme Sovereign.

*Four mouths govern affairs and order the myriad things.* *Four with mouths* means speech. Those who daily recite this text will obtain the true celestial script, grasping its profound intent. Their will shall align with Heaven’s heart, enabling the myriad things to each find their proper place without further disorder—hence, *ordering the myriad things.*

*With a cap and horn, govern the right—this is reciting the text.* Reciting this scripture without cease will rectify all affairs in a single stroke. Above, it will delight Heaven’s intent, bringing constant joy without lingering resentment.

*The hidden dragon, unused, hums as its marker.* The *hidden dragon* is the return of Heaven’s *qi* to the first nine, the *jia-zi* year, the winter solstice—the day when Heaven and Earth truly begin. The *dragon* is the lesser yang of the east, the spirit of wood. Thus, the Dao of Heaven emerges through wood to activate the fire phase. When things are about to flourish, they must first open their gates. Perfected One, when the appointed time arrives, present this text in a place of luminous clarity. *Open* means to expand, to unblock, to reach. Opening the south will harmonize and invigorate the yang *qi*, dissolving the calamitous convergence of *chengfu.*

*Hidden* means concealed. The Dao has already passed, returning to concealment. *Not* means caution, not yet. Those who first encounter the text do not yet know how to practice it. *Use* means governance, affairs. Today, Heaven intends this text to eliminate disasters. When it emerges in a *xuan-jia* year, the ruler of that time may not yet deeply fathom its meaning or be able to apply it—hence, *unused* means seeing the celestial signs but not daring to immediately implement them. Those who trust and apply it will see affairs established, effects manifest, and responses echoing—this is its clear proof, aligning with Heaven, thus the resonance.

*Kan as the marker* is called *yan* by the child. *Jia* is Heaven, the guiding principle, yang. *Kan* is the child, water, yin, the marker. Thus, Heaven and Earth are ever united, their guiding principles and markers emerging at the outset of *xuan-jia-zi*. This may serve as the guiding principle for a virtuous ruler—hence, *hums as its marker.*

This is the celestial script of the Supreme Sovereign, revealed below as the true scripture for a virtuous ruler, to sever the perverse with the measuring line, with *xuan-jia* as its subtle beginning. All things that live take *jia* as their head and *zi* as their root—thus, it is presented in sequence beginning with *jia-zi.*

*Those who behold it will enjoy long life.* *People* refers specifically to the emperor, the one of supreme virtue who readily perceives and practices the scripture of the Way. According to the auspicious signs, they will not doubt the Dao of Heaven. Deeply grasping its meaning, they will attain longevity. *Longevity* is fulfilling one’s Heaven-appointed years. *Long* means without end. *Enduring* means enduring existence. *Dwelling between Heaven and Earth, alive and no more.* *Dwelling* means abiding. *Abiding between Heaven and Earth, alive and no more* means studying the true Dao. Fleeting, ornamental texts cannot sustain life for long."

*Governing* means rectification. To govern by the true Dao is the method of sustaining life—thus, immortality may be awaited.

*Those who skillfully heal illness must not deceive or endanger.*
All people, being foolish, fail to consider their own well-being. Instead, they recklessly deceive themselves with false and spurious texts, inviting grievous wrong. In turn, they incur Heaven’s severe censure and bear the heavy responsibility of *cheng-fu*. Therefore, Heaven compels them to abandon superficial and ornate writings, to each uphold what is true and real, and to exert their utmost in practice. Thus, every person may benefit themselves, and none will dare again to deceive or endanger.

*Rejoice in the marketplace of Everlasting Peace.*
*Rejoice* means there is no greater joy than the advent of the Supreme Peace of the Celestial August One. *Ah!* is an exclamation of awe at the unmatched excellence of its virtue. *Everlasting* means those who practice this Dao will see their virtue flourish without end. *Peace* means they will no longer face peril or ruin. Those who attain and practice this Dao will see all the censures of Heaven and Earth from *cheng-fu* dissolve, achieving Everlasting Peace—vast and boundless, free from all care.

*Marketplace* refers to the place beneath the banner where people gather and assemble. Those who practice this scripture speak of the great flourishing of the nation and its people, as if they were thronging in a bustling city.

*Enabling people to attain the longevity of the Queen Mother of the West.*
*Enabling people* refers to empowering the emperor who embodies celestial virtue and delights in enacting correct teachings. *As* means compliance. One who greatly complies with and practices this scripture aligns with the Dao of Heaven, bringing supreme fortune and no misfortune.

*West* signifies that every person shelters the true Dao within their heart. *King* refers to the emperor who, by following and enacting the Dao of Heaven, achieves great flourishing and kingship—his governance unparalleled in excellence. *Mother* is the proof of venerable longevity, the elder of the spirits.

*Comparable to the four seasons returning to their beginning.*
*Comparable* means likened to the four seasons, which transmit and engender one another in an unbroken cycle, no longer inflicting harm. Such governance knows no punishment.

*Ninety-character talismans are transmitted to the fangshi.*
*Nine* signifies thoroughness and completion. Those who practice this will see their virtue thoroughly harmonize with the hearts of Heaven, Earth, yin, yang, and the myriad things. *Ten* means tenfold resonance, free from contrived teachings.

*Characters* refer to the celestial patterns above and below, circulating and pervading the Dao to perfection. *Transmitted* means trustworthiness. Thus, written tokens of commission are made to convey it faithfully.

chunks.translated_text:
**Striving in the Good Dharma, Fifty-Second [Chapter]**

Perfected One, consider this:

How many predicaments do the people of the world face?

What does this mean?

When all is level and unchanging, how many constraints press upon a person? Though their predicaments are many, are they not nameless?

They cannot be named.

You do not yet understand.

The people of the world face four predicaments.

What are they?

First: when you are born of your father and mother, in your youth you cannot leave their care—this is the first predicament.

Second: as you grow and mature, a woman desires marriage, a man desires a wife; unable to master their passions, they become bound by love and cannot part—this is the second predicament.

Third: once bound in love, they bear children. As husband and wife age, their appearance becomes unlovely, yet their young children are dear; they must now be cared for—this is the third predicament.

Fourth: when their children grow and no longer need support, they themselves have aged and can no longer move freely—this is the fourth predicament.

After these four predicaments, if one meets an enlightened teacher and reflects deeply upon guarding the Dao, those of exceptional talent and celestial mandate may attain liberation. Others may gain longevity, and still others may enjoy fleeting happiness in life. Yet when their hun and po dwell beneath the earth, they will relive those pleasures.

What does this mean?

In the underworld, the newly deceased are questioned about all they did and experienced in life. Based on these deeds, their names are recorded in the ledgers, and they are held accountable accordingly.

Thus, one must prepare in advance—safety and peril are determined by one’s own actions.

Perfected One, be vigilant.

Do you heed this warning?

Indeed, indeed.

The Heavenly Master then instructed with words unseen.

Why this instruction? Seeing your constant good intentions, I feared the Perfected One might grow weary, and so I have made this clear.

Indeed, indeed.

Perfected One, what do you now aspire to in your studies?

chunks.original_text: 以年穷尽为期。 善哉，子志可谓得道意矣。 然凡人行，皆以寿尽为期，顾有善恶尽耳。 何谓也？ 愿闻之。 然守善学，游乐而尽者，为乐游鬼法，复不见愁苦，其自愁苦而尽者，为愁苦鬼恶而尽者，为恶鬼也。 此皆露见之事，凡人可知也。 而人不肯为善，乐其魂神，其过诚重。 何谓也？ 人生乃受天地正气，四时五行来合为人，此先人之统体也。 此身体或居天地四时五行，先人之身常乐善无忧，反复传生后世不肖，反久苦天地四时五行之身，令使更自冤死，尚愁其魂魄，是故愚士不深计，不足久居也。 故令欲使其疾死亡，於其死不复恨之也。 精神但自冤怜，无故得愁恚於此下士。 是故古者大贤圣，深计远虑知如此，故学而不止也。 其为人君者，乐思太平，得天之心，其功倍也。 魂神得常游乐，与天善气合。 其不能平其治者，治不合天心，不得天意，为无功於天上。 已到终，其魂神独见责於地下，与恶气合处。 是故太古上圣之君乃知此，故努力也。 愚人不深计，故生亦有谪於天，死亦有谪於地，可骇哉。 弟子愚暗，不欲闻也。 善哉，子既来学，不欲闻此，即且努力为善矣。 唯唯。 天师处地，使得知天命，受教勅深厚，以何得免於此哉？ 善乎，子但急传吾书道，使天下人得行之，俱思其身，定精念合於大道，且自知过失所从来也，即承负之责除矣。 天地大喜年，复得反上古而倍矣。 善哉善哉。 行辞小竟，真人努力勉之，异日复来。 唯唯。 得书详思上下，学而不精，名为惚恍，求事不得无形象，思念不致，精神无从得往。 善哉善哉。 右天师诫人生时不努力卒死尚为魂神得承负之谪。 分解本末法第五十三 真人前。

Setting life’s end as the limit—how excellent! Your aspiration may be said to have grasped the intent of the Dao.

Yet for ordinary people, all conduct is bounded by the span of life, differing only in whether their goodness or evil reaches its end. What does this mean? I wish to hear it.

Those who maintain goodness and learning, who pass their days in joy and ease, become joyful wandering ghosts, spared from sorrow and suffering. Those who exhaust themselves in sorrow, or whose lives end in wickedness, become wretched ghosts. These are plainly visible matters, knowable to all.

Yet people refuse to do good and delight their hun and shen—truly a grave transgression. What does this mean?

Human life is formed by receiving the pure qi of Heaven and Earth, the convergence of the four seasons and five phases, the inherited body of one’s ancestors. This body, dwelling within Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and five phases, should ever delight in goodness and know no sorrow. Instead, unworthy descendants repeatedly transmit suffering to the body of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and five phases, causing it to endure prolonged hardship and even die in grievance. They further afflict their own hun and po, so that foolish scholars, failing to consider deeply, cannot long endure.

Thus, some wish to hasten their death, and upon dying, feel no regret. Their spirits merely pity themselves, needlessly incurring sorrow and resentment in this lower realm.

Therefore, the great sages of antiquity, with deep calculation and far-reaching foresight, understood this and never ceased their learning. Those among them who became rulers delighted in pursuing Great Peace, aligning with the heart of Heaven, and their merit doubled. Their hun and shen constantly wandered in joy, uniting with Heaven’s virtuous qi.

Those who failed to bring order to their governance acted against Heaven’s heart, forfeiting Heaven’s favor and earning no merit in the celestial realm. When their lives ended, their hun and shen faced solitary reproach in the underworld, dwelling among malign qi.

Thus, the supreme sages of high antiquity understood this and exerted themselves accordingly. Foolish people, lacking deep reflection, incur punishment from Heaven in life and from Earth in death—how terrifying!

Your disciple is dull and ignorant; I do not wish to hear this.

Excellent! Since you have come to study, if you do not wish to hear this, then strive earnestly to do good.

Indeed, indeed.

The Heavenly Master, dwelling in this realm, enables you to know Heaven’s mandate and receive profound instruction. How may one escape this fate?

Excellent! Simply hasten to transmit my writings on the Dao, so that all under Heaven may practice them. Let each reflect on their own body, concentrate their essence, and align their thoughts with the Great Dao. Then they will recognize the origins of their transgressions, and the burden of inherited responsibility will be lifted. Heaven and Earth will rejoice for a great span of years, and the ancient age will be restored and doubled.

Excellent, excellent!

This minor discourse now concludes. Perfected One, exert yourself and persevere. Return another day.

Indeed, indeed.

Study the text carefully, pondering its entirety. If your learning lacks precision, it is called "huhuang" (vague and indistinct). Seeking affairs without form or image, thoughts that do not reach their mark, the spirit has no means to proceed.

Excellent, excellent!

chunks.original_text: 子既来学，当广知道意，少者可案行耶？ 多者可案行耶？ 然备足众多者，可案行也。 噫，子内未广知道要意也。 今天一也，反行地二，其意何也？ 今地二也，反行人三，何也？ 愚生愿闻其相行意。 然夫地为天使，人为地使。 故天悦喜，则使今年地上万物大善； 天不喜悦，地虽欲养也，使其物恶。 地善，则居地上者，人民好善，此其相使明效也。 故治乱者，由太多端不得天之心，当还反其本根。 夫人言太多而不见是者，当还反其本要也，乃其言事可立也。 故一言而成者，其本文也。 再转言而止者，乃成章句也。 故三言而止，反成解难也，将远真故有解难也。 四言而止，反成文辞也。 五言而止，反成伪也。 六言而止，反成欺也。 七言而止，反成破也。 八言而止，反成离散远道，远复远也。 九言而止，反成大乱也。 十言而止，反成灭毁也。 故经至十而改，更相传而败毁也。 夫凡事毁者当反本，故反守一以为元初。 是故天数起於一，十而终也，是天道自然之性也。 是故古者圣人问事，初一卜占者，其吉凶是也，守其本也，乃天神下告之也。 再卜占者，地神出告之也。 三卜占者，人神出告之也。 过此而下者，皆欺人，不可占，故卦数则不中也。 人辞文多，则不珍。 善哉善哉。
chunks.translated_text:
Since you have come to study, you ought to broadly comprehend the intent of the Dao/Way—can the few be followed in practice? Can the many be followed in practice? Yet only when all are fully prepared and numerous may they be followed. Alas, you have not yet broadly grasped the essential intent of the Dao/Way.

Now, Heaven is One, yet it acts contrary to Earth’s Two—what is the meaning of this? Earth is Two, yet it acts contrary to Humanity’s Three—what is the meaning of this? Foolish student, I wish to hear of their mutual interaction.

Thus, Earth serves as Heaven’s agent, and Humanity serves as Earth’s agent. When Heaven rejoices, it causes the myriad things upon Earth in this year to flourish greatly; when Heaven does not rejoice, though Earth may wish to nurture, it causes those things to turn foul. When Earth is good, those dwelling upon it—its people—are inclined toward goodness. This is the clear effect of their mutual agency.

Therefore, order and chaos arise when the many ends fail to align with Heaven’s heart; one must return and revert to the root. When a person’s words are too numerous yet fail to reveal truth, one must return and revert to the essential root—only then may affairs be established through speech.

Thus, a single word that achieves its end is the root text. Two turns of phrase that conclude form a passage. Three words that conclude instead create explanations of difficulties, for distance from the truth gives rise to the need for explanation. Four words that conclude instead form literary expression. Five words that conclude instead produce falsehood. Six words that conclude instead produce deception. Seven words that conclude instead produce destruction. Eight words that conclude instead produce separation and estrangement from the Dao/Way, growing ever more distant. Nine words that conclude instead produce great chaos. Ten words that conclude instead produce annihilation and ruin.

Therefore, when scriptures reach ten, they must be revised, for transmission without change leads to corruption. When all things are ruined, one must return to the root—thus reverting to the One as the primordial beginning. Hence, Heaven’s numbers begin with One and conclude at Ten; this is the natural nature of the Heavenly Dao/Way.

Thus, in ancient times, when the sages inquired of affairs, the first divination revealed fortune or misfortune—this was to guard the root, for the Heavenly spirits descended to inform them. The second divination was when the Earthly spirits emerged to inform them. The third divination was when the Human spirits emerged to inform them. Beyond this, all is deception of others, and divination cannot be trusted, for the hexagrams’ numbers will not be accurate.

When human speech and writing are excessive, they lose their value.

Excellent, excellent!

Now, as the Heavenly Master ever pities those who fall short, he once more wishes to entreat a single word.

*Proceeding evenly.*

Why does the number of divinations stop at three and conclude?

Excellent! You grasp deeply and inquire after this method of affairs. Indeed, Heaven’s numbers begin with the primordial One of Heaven. Descending, it joins with Earth to become Two, and with yin and yang complete, all things are born together. The myriad beings first sprout in the north, where the primordial qi arises at *zi*. Turning to the northeast, roots spread at *jiao*; turning to the east, life emerges and reaches forth; turning to the southeast, branches and leaves fully grow; turning to the south, they flourish in abundance; turning to the southwest, they incline toward fullness; turning to the west, they ripen; turning to the northwest, they come to an end. When things end, they must return to the beginning—thus at *hai*, two persons embrace the One, forming the Three Sovereigns’ origin.

Therefore, *hai* is the kernel, the first coagulation of the seed—hence water begins to congeal in the tenth month. *Ren* means "to bear," for once borne, it must burgeon, growing ever greater—thus *zi* means "to burgeon." When Three achieves the harmonious qi of yin and yang, all is complete, and it returns to the initial arising—hence reverting to the root, it is named *jiazi*.

The Dao/Way of Heaven in generating things must circulate and fully possess all. Only when one beholds the qi of Heaven and Earth’s four luminaries and five phases does completion come. If one qi is insufficient, then insufficiency immediately follows. Thus, it is rooted in Heaven and Earth’s circulation through the eight directions, and all numbers reach their fulfillment at Ten.

Perfected One, do you now understand this?

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed. Such profound grace is received—yet you must not express gratitude. Why? The merit of master and disciple is vast and weighty, comparable to parents giving birth to a child, which cannot be repaid or undone. What does this mean?

Before parents give birth to a child, if the foolish merely cast their essence into the wild, it takes root in the earth and becomes grass or trees, unaware that it was meant to become human. How could such blind bestowal ever be spoken of? Thus it becomes mere vegetation. Only when yin and yang unite does a human take form—how different from becoming grass or trees!

Once born, if a person, though naturally endowed, does not seek a worthy master but instead follows a base and ignorant teacher, they are taught evil ways, led into depravity, and may even bring about their own destruction. Their sins persist beyond death, consuming their entire household. Some are born yet never pursue learning, remaining fools. Such ignorant ones suffer in life and die in sorrow, yet their transgressions follow them below. Their souls, denied joy, cannot even become benevolent spirits after death.

Now, a virtuous master teaches the foolish and lowly, transforming them into good people. Goodness pursued without cease leads to ever greater virtue; virtue pursued without cease leads to sagehood. Sagehood pursued without cease leads to profound understanding of the true Dao/Way. Guarding the Dao/Way without cease leads to immortality as a transcendent. Transcendence pursued without cease leads to perfection as a Perfected One. Perfection pursued without cease leads to divinity. Divinity pursued without cease leads to virtue/power equal to Heaven. Divinity pursued beyond divinity leads to virtue/power equal to the primordial qi. The primordial qi envelops Heaven and Earth; all eight directions receive its breath and come to life. Its virtue/power then blankets Heaven and Earth in all directions, and spirits draw sustenance from it. All under Heaven partake in its offerings, yet still fear they cannot fully honor it.

Such is the merit of a virtuous master who cultivates a worthy disciple—how could one ever express sufficient gratitude? How astonishing! My foolish words have touched upon taboos and overstepped—yet why do you persist in humility, Perfected One? You have made me understand whether gratitude is fitting or not.

*Assenting, assenting.*

Here concludes the explication of the fundamental and ultimate principles, the essential text on the merits of father and son, master and disciple.

Among the conduct of common people and the governance of kings, what is most excellent? To extend compassion without harm—this, like the movement of Heaven, is most excellent. Your words may be said to grasp the intent of the Dao. Yet in governance, nothing surpasses emulating Heaven. Even so, there must be an order of precedence.

What does this mean? Though this foolish one may speak once, I shall not repeat myself. May the Heavenly Master expound it.

Now, in the conduct of common people and the governance of kings: the most excellent is to constantly desire the joy of life, ever thirsting for it as one parched—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in delighting in accomplishment, ever yearning to bring things to fruition as if grieving for one’s own body—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in benevolent giving, seeing others in poverty and want and sorrowing for them as if grieving for one’s own hunger and cold—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in establishing laws, not delighting in harm but merely acting from fear—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person errs, nothing is better than governance that does not ensnare them in crime—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person has already fallen into crime, if the heart does not desire to deeply harm them—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person’s transgression incurs a capital offense and nothing can be done, if one can avoid implicating their family and neighbors—only then is it fitting. Next, when the crime extends to family and neighbors, if one wishes to single out the guilty and takes care not to exterminate the human kindred entirely—only then is it fitting.

For humans are the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth. Extermination is called severing the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth, causing grievous injury to the body of Heaven and Earth. The harm runs deep, and in time, Heaven will exterminate the human race in turn. It is no easy matter to become the ancestor of a family. One ought to consider posterity and not impose the calamity of inherited burden upon descendants.

Thus, the sage in governance constantly contemplates Great Peace, ensuring that punishments are prepared but unused. The reason for this is to consider posterity. Now, Perfected One, have you seen the subtlety of these words?

*Assenting, assenting.*

The celestial writings, sacred texts, and words of sages and worthies of ancient and modern times are already fully sufficient, yet I worry that each excels only in one matter. If we now apply the methods of a single school, we cannot entirely eliminate the calamities and transformations of Heaven and Earth. Thus, flowing disasters persist without end, passing on and inheriting one another. Those born later suffer ever-increasing afflictions and illnesses, and so the Heavenly Lord of Compassionate Virtue continues to bear their *chengfu*.

Heavenly harmony cannot arise for those born later; this accumulation of disasters and faults lies truly in the fact that the former sages and worthies each excelled in one area yet all had their incomprehensions and shortcomings. Heaven, knowing their insufficiency, thus periodically produced the writings and diagrams of the Yellow and Luo Rivers, as well as other divine texts—each differing in their words. The great sages and worthies, appearing in different eras, each accomplished one matter, and their words likewise differed. Therefore, each had their inadequacies, each had their strengths and weaknesses.

So it is. Clearly, none could fully comprehend the ultimate and profound meaning of the *Utmost Profundity*. Thus, between Heaven and Earth, residual disasters persist, ceaseless from beginning to end, varying only in severity.

Therefore, Heaven calculated and determined that now, with the writings and texts above and below, all is fully and completely prepared. Even if sages were to arise again, there would be nothing more to create, nothing more to add, no room for further words, nothing more to contribute to the lord of great virtue and power of Heaven and Earth. If Heaven were to produce another sage, their words would still excel only in one endeavor, and residual flowing disasters and poisons would persist without end—no different from the former sages and worthies.

Thus, Heaven commanded me to deeply instruct the Perfected One and entrust the lord of virtue and power with these writings, to show them to the many wise ones. Gather and collate all the texts and spoken secrets of the world, supplementing above and below, removing redundancies, and preserving the essential words, essential texts, and secret matters. Thus, Heaven commanded me to gather and collate them.

My writing does not merely imitate words—it imitates verification.
