The officers, soldiers, and ranks of this company, when they reach desolate and unclean places, are scarcely covered with earth before foxes and dogs devour them. Their remains ungathered, cast aside by the roadside, both soul and spirit suffer without respite. Some cling to grasses and trees, consumed by the six livestock—when shall they be reborn? Punishment for evil and reward for good are known to all; why not reform oneself? Heaven repays merit and withholds from the virtueless. Ponder this, ponder it well. Rewards and punishments are clear.

One may die in solitary agony, yet the span of life for good and evil must ebb and flow. Examine this carefully, be cautious, and you may avoid blame. Thus, this solemn warning is given to prompt repentance. The convergence of fortune and misfortune lies worlds apart. Therefore, this text is set down to admonish and caution: do not blame Heaven or fault the earth, for good and evil must be distinguished.

The text records one’s allotted fortune, teaching that evil may turn to good, though the soul and spirit labor to exhaustion. Fools remain ignorant, so the words are repeated, reiterated, and passed on, lest later generations incur blame. By this, one may verify for oneself—what grievance remains? No resentment lingers, for each receives their due.

This text must be transmitted without cease. The wise may shorten their years, but fools will copy it themselves. Those who disregard its words bring only suffering upon themselves.

**The One Hundred and Eighteenth Admonition on the Bridge of Punishment for the Dead with Transgressions**

In the age of antiquity, divine sages foresaw the future and governed in harmony with Heaven. They were deployed across the four directions, above and below, and at the center, each with their appointed ranks and duties. High and low regarded one another, and order was achieved without coercion—all acted with goodness. Fearing any lapse, all shared a single heart.

Heaven’s messengers hastened to carry out their tasks, riding chariots of cloud and vapor, drawn by flying dragons. Divine immortals followed in ranks, each bearing ledgers. Without movement, they aligned themselves, fearing any disruption. Their actions followed rules, and they fulfilled their duties. In spring, they nurtured the qi of life; in summer, they fostered growth; in autumn, they oversaw the harvest, ensuring the people had offerings; in winter, they stored surplus grain, maintaining continuity without lapse.

The blessings of the spirits extended to all, bestowing glory. Even the crawling creatures and grasses and trees received their grace—was this not the benevolence of the above? Each received what was due. When they ate, there was always surplus, the new and old sustaining one another. How could one forget this? Having received the people’s aid, they ensured the spirits held no resentment.

Good people were repaid, each supporting the other in sufficiency. Heaven willed it so; hoarding was forbidden, lest people suffer hunger and cold. Thus, the wealthy were commanded to lend to the poor, exchanging the old for the new, enabling life and growth to be passed to descendants. The spirits protected and aided them—was this not the vast dissemination of benevolence?

Yet fools, lacking understanding, refused to repay or give thanks, assuming it their due. Their hearts grew unbalanced, and they seized others’ possessions to adorn themselves, lacking any thought of repayment or regard for hardship. They believed themselves capable of living out their full span. Thus, the text was written again.

Divine and perfected beings seek the good, those who transmit and apply the text’s teachings. Such people may extend their lives, increase their years, and harmonize with Heaven and Earth, transforming into spirits. They may ride forth, traversing above and below, the center, and the six directions—is this not good? Why not reflect deeply and keep it within? The dwelling of the spirit observes human actions. Knowing one’s due, one should serve and comply, turning from misfortune toward fortune. Even slight discord with Heaven’s will is unwise.

The myriad spirits and officers of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the five phases record human lives. How can one fail to revere them, to contemplate repaying their grace? Those who refuse to do good acts against the celestial spirits. The celestial spirits cause wind and rain to fall unseasonably, altering the flow of qi. When it should be cold, it grows warm; when it should be warm, it turns cold. Planting and sowing occur at the wrong times, and farmers grow resentful, unwilling to tend the land for others. They scorn the grains, feeding them to dogs and swine, then abandon their fields for lands of virtue.

Where they sow, the harvest is meager; trees wither and shed their leaves. The people lack surplus grain, turning to predation and strife, competing for dominance alone. Forgetting truth, they later become the impoverished, reaping nothing, drifting as refugees. Before reaching the lands where grain is scorned, they starve by the roadside, dizzy and blinded, staggering wildly. After days without food, they die of hunger, unburied. No one in their household, great or small, escapes disaster, yet they curse Heaven for their misfortune.

Their land grows desolate, granaries empty of grain, meat scarce, and no coins stored. Year by year, the crisis deepens, leaving nothing to supply the court. Exemptions increase, granaries remain unfilled, and the Minister of Agriculture holds only empty documents. There is nothing to distribute, no salaries to pay, and the central lands lack resources. The people look to the state, yet no aid is given, and a time of great hardship arises.

All this is what Heaven abhors. The earth cannot long sustain such people—do the wicked not understand? Perfected beings must urgently transmit this text to lands of virtue, urging all to reflect and awaken. Only then may they live out their full span. The ignorant are no different from beasts; life cannot be forcibly prolonged. It is attained through one’s own conduct, with no cause to blame Heaven.

Ponder the text carefully, constantly cultivating filial piety, loyalty, trust, benevolence, and generosity. Acknowledge your faults, and you will have descendants. The text does not speak in vain. In lands without virtue, Heaven offers no protection. The celestial balance moves swiftly, and the sun and moon hasten, their light dimmed.

In lands of virtue, the celestial balance slows, and the sun and moon shine brightly—this is Heaven’s way. The celestial balance, the sun, moon, and stars all favor the good and bright. If they dim, it is the result of one’s own actions—what cause is there for blame? They are one with Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars.

Those who witness Heaven’s retribution see its clarity. When the five planets deviate from their courses, weapons and war rage, barbarians invade, and rebels rise. The state dispatches generals and armies; those with fate return, those without perish. This is the fault of the great.

chunks.original_text: 为子不孝，国少忠臣，行不纯，故令相克，卒岁乃止。 故施洞极之经，名曰太平。 能行者得其福，不者自令极思，聚身无离，常报应不枉，人所不者，施恶施人。 常言人无贵无贱，皆天所生，但录籍相命不存耳。 爱之慎之念之，慎勿加所不当为而枉人，侵克非有。 是天所不报，地所不养，凶神随之，不得久生乐生念。 自令自忽者，勿望生，殊无长生之籍，强入神仙斋家，所有祠祭神灵，求蒙仙度，仙神案簿籍，子无生名，祷祭神不享食也。 走行乞丐，复诸神灵，其神怒之。 猛兽所食，骨肉了已，狐狸所啮，不归故乡。 同县比庐，反言得仙，殊无信报，何用自明。 以是言之，难可分明。 当有报信，众人见之，乃为已升。 不者苦其刑，为言得略少，其人狂邪可下，反以为真。 俱入死部，下归黄泉，不得自从。 有德度者，生时有簿，年满当上，辄有迎者。 童蒙无知，何从得往，但费资用，弃家捐身旷野。 道自然人相禄，不可强求。 倘自苦，不治生养亲，妻子相见为贤士，但恐不孝不忠少信，可得竟年耳，地下无罚乐而已。 有余财产，子传孙，亦当给用，无自苦。 子孙贤不肖，各自活，无相遗患，是为善行。 故记此文示智者，愚人忽之妄怒喜，远罚避患为贤者，三谏不中且可止。 天佑善人，不与恶子，各自加慎，勿相怨咎。 各为身计行宜，人人有知，无有过负於天，录籍所宜，慎勿强索，索之无益。 所以然者，恶逆之人，天不佑也。 无离舍宅及城郭，骨节相连为阡陌，筋主欲生坚城郭，脉主往来为骨络，肉在皮内为脉衣。 神在中守，司人善恶，何须远虑，七政司候神门户。 求道得生，无离舍宅，变化与神合德，道欲复何索，故置善文於天籍。 神仙籍与俗异录，当升之时，主籍之神及保人者来，乃知所部主奉承教化，各有前后，辄当进有所去，不得自可，众神共治，务取合天心者。 先生之人，皆心明视，无有界意，所行所生，人未知之。 皆先天地，变化上下，皆不失其道，神不悉具。 乃置纲纪，岁月偏傍，各置左右，星辰分别，各有所主，务进其忠，令使分部。 见善当进，见恶当退，何有所疑，行各自力，无为神所误。 故得成，得称天君。 主天之人辄簿领，亦不失度，部主诸神故四方。 方有孟仲季，更直上下，名为太岁。 太阴在后，主知地理。 复置四时，生成所有，分居於野，有晚早谷草。 近人不寿远人民，然亦复长久，丛社之树小得自矣。 易世被诛，延及孙子。 所以然者，所居不安，去故就新，神复得还。 人有命树生天土各过，其春生三月命树桑，夏生三月命树枣李，秋生三月命梓梗，冬生三月命槐栢，此俗人所属也。 皆有主树之吏，命且欲尽，其树半生，命尽枯落，主吏伐树。 其人安从得活，欲长不死，易改心志，传其树近天门，名曰长生。 神吏主之，皆洁静光泽，自生天之所，护神尊荣。 但可常无毁名，天有常命，世世被荣，虽不下护，久自知精。 所以然者，去俗久远，当行天上之事，不得失脱。 诸神相检，如绳以墨，何复自从，故不下耳，宜勿怪之。 功劳当见，不与俗等，人以为无益於家，内被其荣，岂不善邪？ 故示后生，令心觉悟，出书无藏，藏之有罚。 无与佞欺，不孝顺为心，宜皆为不副书言，复见责问，可不慎焉。

Those who are unfilial as sons produce few loyal ministers in the state; their conduct impure, they invite mutual conflict, which ceases only at the year’s end.

Thus is revealed the *Scripture of the Utmost Cavern*, named *Great Peace*. Those who practice it receive its blessings; those who do not bring upon themselves the utmost suffering, their bodies bound without escape. Retribution is ever just, never unjust. Those who do not act as others do inflict harm upon them.

It is often said that none, whether noble or base, are not born of Heaven—only their recorded destinies differ. Cherish this, be mindful of it, and take heed: do not impose upon others what you ought not, nor encroach upon or oppress the innocent. Such deeds find no recompense in Heaven, no sustenance on Earth. Malevolent spirits follow, and one cannot long enjoy life or delight in existence.

Those who neglect themselves should not expect to live. Without a name in the register of long life, they forcibly enter the halls of the immortals, offering sacrifices to the gods and beseeching transcendence. Yet when the immortals consult the ledgers, they find no name for them—their prayers and offerings go unanswered. Wandering as beggars, they implore the gods anew, only to incur divine wrath. They are devoured by fierce beasts, their bones and flesh consumed, gnawed by foxes and jackals, never to return home. Even neighbors and kin claim they have attained immortality, yet no sign or response confirms it—how can they prove themselves? By this, it is clear: verification is difficult. Only when retribution is witnessed by all is ascension confirmed. Otherwise, they suffer punishment, their claims of partial success mere delusion. Such people are mad or base, yet they take their own words as truth. Together, they enter the realm of the dead, descending to the Yellow Springs, powerless to choose their fate.

Those of virtue who are destined for transcendence have their names recorded in life. When their years are fulfilled, they are received above, and escorts come for them. The young and ignorant, however, know not how to proceed. They squander their wealth, abandon their homes, and wander the wilds in vain. The Way naturally bestows rank upon people—it cannot be forcibly sought. If one inflicts suffering upon oneself, neglects to care for parents, or forsakes family to be seen as a worthy scholar, yet remains unfilial, disloyal, and untrustworthy, they may live out their years, but beneath the earth, they will know no joy or ease. With surplus wealth and property passed to descendants, one should provide for their needs without self-imposed hardship. Whether descendants are worthy or not, each lives their own life, free from mutual harm—this is good conduct.

Thus is this text recorded to enlighten the wise. Fools disregard it, indulging in reckless joy and anger, while the wise avoid punishment and evade misfortune. If three admonitions go unheeded, one should desist. Heaven aids the good and does not favor the wicked. Each must be vigilant, refraining from mutual blame. Let each act in their own best interest, for all possess understanding. None should transgress against Heaven, nor force what is not recorded in the ledgers—such efforts are futile. The reason is this: Heaven does not protect the rebellious and perverse.

Do not abandon your dwelling or the city walls. Bones join to form the paths, sinews govern the desire for life and fortify the walls, vessels direct movement as the skeletal network, and flesh within the skin serves as the vessels’ covering. The spirit within guards and oversees human good and evil—what need is there for distant concern? The Seven Governors stand watch at the gates of the spirit.

Those who seek the Way and attain life do not leave their dwellings. Through transformation, they unite with the spirit in virtue. What more does the Way require? Thus are good deeds inscribed in Heaven’s records. The ledgers of immortals differ from those of the mundane. At the time of ascension, the gods who oversee the registers and the guarantors arrive, for each knows their charge and the teachings they must uphold. There is an order to advancement, and each must proceed accordingly, not by their own will, but as the host of gods governs, ensuring all align with Heaven’s will.

Those who precede others in cultivation possess hearts of clarity and vision, free from partiality. Their conduct and birth remain unknown to others, for they existed before Heaven and Earth. Their transformations above and below never stray from the Way, though the gods do not fully manifest. They establish the framework, the cycles of years and months, each with attendants to left and right. The stars and constellations are distinguished, each with its charge, tasked with advancing the loyal and assigning divisions. When good is seen, it is advanced; when evil is seen, it is withdrawn. What doubt remains? Each acts by their own effort, never misled by the gods. Thus do they succeed and earn the title *Heavenly Lord*.

Those who govern Heaven’s affairs keep meticulous records, never straying from the measure. The gods who oversee the four directions and their divisions—each direction has its first, second, and third, rotating in sequence above and below—are called the *Great Year*. The *Great Yin* follows behind, overseeing the patterns of the Earth. The four seasons are established, governing all that is born and completed, dwelling in the wilds with their early and late grains and grasses. Those near do not live long, while those far endure, and the trees of sacred groves grow small of their own accord.

When dynasties change, punishment extends to descendants. The reason is this: those who do not dwell in peace, who abandon the old for the new, find their spirits unsettled. Each person has a life-tree planted in Heaven’s soil, its type determined by the season of their birth. Those born in spring’s third month have mulberry as their life-tree; those born in summer’s third month, jujube or plum; those born in autumn’s third month, catalpa or *Platycodon*; those born in winter’s third month, locust or cypress. These are the trees of the common people, each overseen by an official. As life nears its end, the tree withers halfway; when life ends, it withers and falls, and the official fells it. How then can the person live? To seek long life and avoid death, one must transform their heart and will, transplanting their tree near Heaven’s gate, where it is called *Long Life*. The divine officials oversee it, keeping it pure, radiant, and lustrous, born of Heaven’s domain, protected by the honored spirits.

If one can but preserve their name from ruin, Heaven’s constant mandate ensures generation upon generation of glory. Though they may not descend to protect, in time, they will naturally attain refinement. The reason is this: having long departed from the mundane, they engage in Heaven’s affairs and cannot falter. The gods examine them as a carpenter’s line and ink—how can they act of their own accord? Thus do they not descend, and one should not find this strange. When merit is due, it is recognized, for they are not like the common folk. Though others may see no benefit to their families, they are inwardly honored—is this not good?

Thus is this revealed to later generations, to awaken their hearts. Do not conceal this text, for concealment invites punishment. Do not associate with the deceitful or those whose hearts lack filial piety and loyalty. All should act in accord with the text’s words, lest they face reproach. Can one not be cautious?

This record is for the wise. The foolish disregard it, indulging in reckless anger and joy, while the wise avoid punishment and evade misfortune. If three admonitions go unheeded, one should desist. Heaven protects the good and does not favor the wicked. Each must be vigilant, refraining from mutual blame. Let each act in their own best interest, for all possess understanding. None should transgress against Heaven or force what is not recorded in the ledgers—such efforts are futile. The reason is this: Heaven does not protect the rebellious and perverse.

chunks.original_text: 传当传其人，令可保举。 勿犯神书，勿试神言，慎神之辞，皆天报焉。 勿轻犯之，后有患，小犯才谪，大过不救。 故使诸神更相司便宜上之，有不实者，当复见治。 事当相关，不得私。 故使诸神转相检持，今悔其后何须疑，中复为止，亦见考之。 不首情实，考后首便见下，故进止亦见考之。 不者如故，此之谓也。 不可轻犯，无所狐疑。 神法大重，故当慎之详之，念之思之，长生久活之道，可不重之。 故下此文以示，当施补空者，为设善事，辄相承无有通亡。 为善有功年益长，无所复疑。 自然之道何极时，但觉寤转相治，失如铢分辄见疑。 天有倡乐乐诸神，神亦听之。 善者有赏，音曲不通亦见治。 各自有师，不可无本末，不成皆食天仓，衣司农，寒温易服，亦阳尊阴卑，粗细靡物，金银彩帛珠玉之宝，各令平均，无有横赐，但为有功者耳，不得无功受天衣食。 前文已有言，今为复道，令无怨恨，无所嫌疑，是天重神灵之命也。 岁尽拘校簿上，山海陆地，诸祀丛社，各上所得，不用不得失脱。 舍宅诸守，察民所犯，岁上月簿，司农祠官，当辄转相付文辞。 大阴法曹，计所承负，除算减年。 算尽之后，召地阴神，并召土府，收取形骸，考其魂神。 当具上簿书，相应不应，主者为有奸私，罚谪随考者轻重，各簿文非天所使，鬼神精物，不得病人。 辄有因自相检饬，自相发举。 有过高至死，上下谪作河梁山海，各随法轻重，各如其事，勿有失脱。 各有府县邮亭主者长吏，察之如法，勿枉夭克鬼神精物。 如是上下，合通行书，各如旧令。 衣履欲好诫第一百八十九 自古及今，各有分部，上下傍行，有所受取。 辄如绳墨不失，何有不睹死生之诀。 各且自慎，勿犯神灵，各如其职，慎勿忽忘命。 可疏记，善者当上，恶者当退。 吉凶之会，各其所愿。 但可顺从，不得逆意。 心意不端，反怨神使，行自得之，何所怨仇。 人有难化，知有不足，皆被其殃。 枉行所不及，反自誉，满口出人事，殊无知虑，而见当前，不顾其后，合祸离爱，谤讪善人。 以天亡上，地不在下，不知鬼神。 有疏记之者，解人怨仇，多施酒脯，甘美自恣。 当时为可，后为人所语，轻口骂晋，咒诅不道，诈伪诽谤，盗人妇女，日夜司候。 邀取便者，卖以自食，衣履欲好，竞行斗辩。 不从道理，欲得生活，何从得久。 愚人可为名恶子，长吏闻知，属吏捕取，急刑其身，祸及亲疏，并得其咎。 贫当自力，无为摇手，此人命簿，生所禀受。 恶鬼随之，安得留久。 此辈众多，有前后会，当相得不中止。 所以言者，恶鬼所取，慎之小差，不慎自已，恶不可施，人所怨咎。 当时自可，不念其后，见戒当止。 可复小生，竟其余算。 有故记善恶，寿所起，增年之期，要当善矣。 不见贤圣，知虑有余，念生恶死，上及仙士，寿可长年。 何为弃世，殃流从生，胞中之子，反言我同从父母生耳。 是皆怨天咎地，言恶当别，不可杂厕，清浊分离，如君与奴使。 故得行大道者生，不行为土，古今相似。 亦有善，亦有恶，世世相传，未尝止，多与少耳。 天知多逆，故出此文重之耳。 知戒之后，可无有疑，十百相应，何有脱时。 不忘诫长得福诀第一百九十 惟天地亦因始初，乃成精神，奉承自然，生成所化，莫不得荣。

Let transmission be to those worthy of it, that they may safeguard and elevate it. Do not violate the sacred texts, nor test the divine words; heed the admonitions of the gods, for Heaven metes out retribution. Do not lightly transgress, lest calamity follow—minor offenses invite reprimand, while grave faults admit no salvation. Thus do the gods oversee one another, reporting transgressions above; those who act falsely shall face judgment. Matters must be interconnected, not kept private. The gods inspect and uphold one another, so why doubt the need for later remorse? To halt midway is to invite scrutiny; failure to confess the truth will lead to examination, and only then will the guilty be brought low. Thus, all actions are subject to review. Those who persist in wrongdoing shall remain unchanged—this is the meaning. Do not transgress lightly, nor harbor doubt. The laws of the gods are weighty; one must be cautious, deliberate, ponder, and reflect upon them. Is not the Way of long life and enduring vitality worthy of reverence?

Thus is this text revealed to fill the void, to establish good deeds, and to ensure unbroken succession. Those who do good shall see their years lengthen, with no cause for doubt. The natural Dao knows no end; only through awakening and mutual correction can one avoid even the slightest misstep, which invites suspicion. Heaven delights in music to gladden the gods, who in turn listen. The virtuous receive reward, while those whose tones and melodies falter face judgment. Each has their own master; none may lack origin or end. Those who fail to cultivate virtue consume from Heaven’s granaries and wear the robes of the Minister of Agriculture, yet their cold and warmth shift like garments. The yang is honored, the yin debased; coarse and fine, all things—gold, silver, brocade, pearls, jade—are to be evenly distributed, with no arbitrary bestowals. Only those with merit may receive Heaven’s clothing and sustenance. As stated before, this is reiterated to prevent resentment or suspicion, for Heaven holds the commands of the gods in great esteem.

At year’s end, ledgers are gathered and reviewed. From mountains and seas to lands and waters, all shrines and communal altars submit their records; nothing may be lost or omitted. The guardians of dwellings observe the people’s transgressions, submitting monthly reports. The Minister of Agriculture and the officials of the temples then relay the documents in turn. The Great Yin Legal Bureau calculates debts and liabilities, deducting years from one’s lifespan. When the tally is exhausted, the yin spirits of the earth and the administrators of the earthly treasuries are summoned to reclaim the physical form and examine the hun and po souls. Detailed ledgers are submitted, verifying whether deeds align with records. Those found to harbor deceit or private schemes face penalties commensurate with their offenses. If the ledgers do not bear Heaven’s mandate, the spirits and numinous beings may not afflict the living. Each must inspect and correct themselves, exposing their own faults. Offenses grave enough to warrant death result in demotion to labor at river crossings, mountains, or seas, each according to the severity of their transgression, with no omissions. Each locale—prefectures, counties, post stations—has its overseers and magistrates to enforce the law, ensuring no unjust harm befalls the spirits or numinous beings.

Thus do the upper and lower realms circulate documents in accordance with established decrees. **On the Desire for Fine Clothing and Footwear, Admonition 189**
From ancient times to the present, all have their allotted stations, moving upward, downward, or laterally, each receiving what is due. Like a line drawn with inked cord, nothing strays—how could one fail to discern the boundary between life and death? Each must be vigilant, not offending the gods, and fulfill their duties without neglecting their fate. Record these admonitions: the virtuous shall ascend, the wicked shall be demoted. In the convergence of fortune and misfortune, each receives what they desire. One may only follow, not defy. A perverse heart that resents the divine messengers reaps its own consequences—whom else can it blame? Some are difficult to transform, their knowledge deficient; all suffer the consequences. Those who act perversely beyond their station, then boast of it, spewing worldly affairs from their mouths, utterly lacking wisdom—seeing only the present, heedless of the future—shall meet with disaster and separation from loved ones, slandering the good. They invert Heaven and Earth, oblivious to the gods.

Those who keep records to resolve enmities should offer abundant libations and fine meats, indulging freely. What seems acceptable in the moment later invites reproach, as others speak lightly, cursing and uttering unfilial words, engaging in deceit, slander, and theft—even of others’ wives—day and night lying in wait to seize opportunities. They sell what they seize to sustain themselves, coveting fine clothing and footwear, competing in disputes and arguments, disregarding reason in their pursuit of livelihood. How can such lives endure? Fools become notorious villains; when magistrates learn of them, their subordinates arrest and swiftly punish them, bringing calamity to kin and stranger alike, all sharing in the blame. The poor must rely on their own efforts, not idly fold their hands. These are the life ledgers, the endowments one receives at birth. Evil spirits follow them—how can they linger long? Such people are many, their fates intertwined, never ceasing. Thus it is said: evil spirits claim them. A moment’s carelessness, if unchecked, invites ruin; one’s own actions invite the resentment of others. What seems acceptable in the moment is heedless of the future. Heed the warnings and desist, that one may live out the remainder of their allotted years.

Records of good and evil determine the span of life and the time of its extension. One must cultivate virtue. Those who fail to perceive the worthies and sages, whose wisdom is abundant, who cherish life and dread death, and aspire to the ranks of the immortals, may yet prolong their years. Why abandon the world, inviting misfortune to flow from birth, even to the child in the womb? They say, “I am born of the same parents as others,” yet they blame Heaven and curse Earth, claiming evil should be separate, not mingled—pure and impure divided like lord and servant. Thus, those who follow the great Dao live, while those who do not become dust. This has been so from ancient times to the present. There are the good and the evil, passed down through generations, never ceasing—only varying in number. Heaven, knowing the prevalence of rebellion, has thus reiterated this text. After understanding the admonitions, let there be no doubt; ten or a hundred shall align—when could one escape?

**On Not Forgetting the Admonitions and Attaining Blessings, Admonition 190**
Only Heaven and Earth, from their primordial beginnings, formed the spiritual essence, upholding the natural order and giving rise to all transformations. None fail to receive glory.

chunks.original_text: 因有部署，日月星辰，机衡司候，并使五星，各执其方，各行其事。 云雨布施，民忧司农事，元气归留，诸谷草木，蚑行喘息蠕动，皆含元气，飞鸟步兽，水中生亦然，使民得用奉祠及自食。 但取作害者以自给，牛马骡驴不任用者，以给天下。 至地祇有余，集共享食。 勿杀任用者，少齿者，是天所行，神灵所仰也。 万民愚戆，恣意杀伤，或怀妊胞中，当生反死，此为绝命，以给人口。 当死之时，皆恐惧，近知不见活。 故天诚矜之怜愍，为施防禁，犯者坐之。 六畜尚去明爱，不忍中伤，人反不自惜，更为贼虏，所取非一，妄行金刃，杀人不坐也。 虽不即诛者，天积其过，杀败不止，灭尸下流未生，是者亦不得逢吉，鬼神憎之，司候在前，何有脱时。 故记善恶重之，即不犯耳。 神人真人，以此文示众民，义不隐藏，使知不自怨，故随俗作字分明。 可知圣贤不犯，恐愚不息。 师有前后，无忘其本，念本就新，恋慕如初，是生之道也。 功有小大，所受不同。 当为发觉未知之诀，未知之意，不知其念，未知之言，未知之志，两分明，是天意也。 生成之道，从此出矣。 取信於天，取信於地，取信於中，取信於四时，取信於五行，是皆天所得报信也。 不失铢分，知之不乎？ 是委气无形，自然之所服化也。 故三台七星，辅正天威，日月照察是非，使有自然，然后无有中悔之者。 故复申敕诸所部主，名令分明，受罚不怨，此之谓也。 无得是非，他人还自直也。 戒无小大，可法则也。 不忘此言长得福，宜慎用行之，不失节也。 以故言自杀试也。 书当未用，帝王未信也。 佞者在侧，书不见理也。 灾害并生，民何所止？ 太平之书，三甲子乃复见理，不如十谏令知耳。 且念活求知，贤圣有知可及矣。 圣人当升贤，随后求生，不恶复次之。 神仙之录在北极，相连昆仑，昆仑之墟有真人，上下有常。 真人主有录籍之人，姓名相次。 高明得高，中得中，下得下，殊无搏颊乞丐者。 先生为师，尊之为君，称之为父。 故师君父不可不明，臣不可不忠，弟子不可不顺。 敬从其上，转上及。 故天不忘先生之恩，地不忘先生之养，人不忘先生之施。 故有忠孝信，思生不恶，以自近，以自明。 天明下照黄泉之下，土明照上天间，中和之明上下合同。 故三明相得，乃合和。 天以三明名日月星，下照中和及地下，无有懈息。 无德之国，阴气蔽日，令使无光。 人民恐惧，谷少滋息，水旱无常，民复流客有谷之乡。 天实怜之，令至活乡处，有明君国，得昌流客，还耕农休废之地，诸谷得下生之成熟，民复得粮，更奉先祖，鬼神得安。 中有圣智，求索神仙。 簿书录籍，姓名有焉。 当复上为天之吏，案行民间，调和风雨，使得安政，以此书示后生焉。 故当作善，有益於天，自是之后，可戒子孙，延年之期，可不及焉。 书虽复重，天大爱人，欲使得竟其年，丁宁反覆，属於神。 善辄疏上，恶亡其名，无违此书，思善心鬲念，常不废意，当索生，志常念成。 所以然者，以人志所当及也。 努力精之，各随其愿，天亦不强不欲也。 地下傍行四方亦然。 无极之天，无极之地，无极之境亦然。 无极之明，无极之光亦然。 然小竟是天之大分也，欲理念天上之事，天上理念中和，中和安之。

Whereupon the celestial bureaucracy was established: the sun, moon, and stars; the celestial pivots and balances governing the seasons; and the Five Stars, each assigned its quadrant and duty. Clouds and rain are dispensed, the people’s cares are overseen by the Office of Agriculture, and primordial qi gathers and lingers. All grains, grasses, and trees; all creatures that crawl, pant, or wriggle; all that flies, walks, or swims—each contains primordial qi, enabling the people to use them for sacrifices and sustenance. Only those taken for harm may be used for one’s own needs. Oxen, horses, mules, and donkeys unfit for service are offered to the realm. When the earth spirits have abundance, they gather to share the feast.

Do not kill those fit for service, nor the young of tooth—this is Heaven’s decree, revered by the divine spirits. Yet the people, foolish and reckless, slaughter wantonly, even those with child in the womb, turning life to death to feed the mouths of others. At the hour of death, all tremble, knowing they will not live. Thus Heaven, in its compassion and mercy, enacts prohibitions and bans; violators are punished.

Even the six livestock shun the sight of bloodshed, unable to bear injury—yet humans, who should cherish themselves, instead act as bandits and butchers. Their predations are many: wielding blades without cause, killing without consequence. Though not immediately executed, Heaven accumulates their transgressions. Their slaughter never ceases; their corpses drift downward, unborn. Such ones shall never encounter fortune. The gods despise them, the overseers stand before them—when could they escape?

Thus the record of good and evil is weighty; only by not transgressing can one avoid it. Divine persons and perfected ones reveal this text to the people, its meaning unhidden, so they may not blame themselves. Hence it is written in the vernacular for clarity.

The wise and worthy do not transgress; the foolish must be admonished without cease. Teachers come in succession, yet none should forget the root. Cherishing the root while embracing the new, longing as in the beginning—this is the Way of life. Merits vary in greatness, and rewards differ accordingly.

This is the method for awakening the unknowing: the unknowing intent, the unknowing thought, the unknowing word, the unknowing aspiration—when both are made clear, this is Heaven’s will. The Way of generation and completion emerges therefrom.

Gain trust from Heaven, gain trust from Earth, gain trust from the Center, gain trust from the Four Seasons, gain trust from the Five Phases—these are all the faithful rewards Heaven bestows. Not a fraction is lost—do you not understand?

This is the commissioning of formless qi, the natural submission to transformation. Thus the Three Terraces and Seven Stars assist in rectifying Heaven’s majesty; the sun and moon illuminate right and wrong, enabling the natural order, so that none may later repent.

Hence the edict is reiterated to all underlings and overseers: names and commands are made clear, and those who receive punishment bear no resentment. This is what it means to avoid righting others’ wrongs. No precept, great or small, is exempt from being a model.

Not forgetting these words brings long blessings. One should act with caution, not losing moderation. Thus words are tested by self-sacrifice. When writings remain unused, emperors and kings do not believe. Flatterers at their side prevent the texts from being understood. Disasters arise together—where can the people find refuge?

The *Scripture of Great Peace* reappears only after three *jiazi* cycles; better to admonish ten times so they may understand. Strive to seek knowledge while alive—even the worthy and sagely may attain it. The sage promotes the worthy, then seeks life thereafter, not despising those who follow.

The register of divine immortals lies at the North Pole, linked to Kunlun. Within Kunlun’s ruins dwell the perfected ones, their ascent and descent governed by constancy. The perfected ones oversee those recorded in the registers, their names listed in order. The exalted attain the exalted, the middling the middling, the lowly the lowly—none are left to beg or plead.

The first to arrive become teachers, honored as lords, addressed as fathers. Thus teachers, lords, and fathers must be clearly understood; ministers must be loyal, disciples obedient. Reverence flows upward, ascending ever higher.

Thus Heaven does not forget the teacher’s grace, Earth does not forget the teacher’s nurturance, and people do not forget the teacher’s generosity. Hence loyalty, filial piety, and trust arise, fostering life without malice, drawing near to clarity.

Heaven’s light shines down to the Yellow Springs; Earth’s light shines up to the heavens. The clarity of the Center harmonizes above and below. When the Three Clarities align, harmony is achieved.

Heaven names the Three Clarities as the sun, moon, and stars, which illuminate the Center and Earth below without cease. In lands devoid of virtue, yin qi obscures the sun, leaving it without light. The people live in fear; grains scarcely multiply. Drought and flood strike without pattern, and the people flee as refugees to lands with grain.

Heaven pities them, guiding them to live in enlightened realms, where wise rulers prosper the refugees. They return to cultivate abandoned fields, and all grains grow to maturity. The people regain their sustenance, once more honoring their ancestors, and the ghosts and spirits find peace.

Among them are the wise and discerning, who seek divine immortality. Their names are recorded in registers and ledgers. They may ascend to become Heaven’s officials, patrolling the mortal realm, harmonizing wind and rain, and governing in peace. This text is shown to later generations.

Thus one should do good, benefiting Heaven. Thereafter, admonish your descendants to extend their years—how could they not attain it? Though the text is repeated, Heaven deeply loves humanity, desiring that all fulfill their years. Its exhortations are earnest and reiterated, entrusted to the gods.

Good deeds are promptly recorded above; evil ones erase one’s name. Do not defy this text. Cultivate a mind of goodness, ever mindful, and seek life with unwavering aspiration. The reason is this: human aspiration should attain its aim. Strive with diligence, each according to their wish—Heaven neither compels nor forbids.

The same holds for the four directions beneath the earth, for the boundless heavens, the boundless earth, the boundless realms, the boundless clarity, and the boundless light. Yet even the smallest completion is Heaven’s great division. To govern and contemplate the affairs of Heaven above, Heaven governs and contemplates the Center’s harmony, and the Center brings peace.

chunks.original_text: 欲念求贵，贵神荣之，欲念求富，富神富之。 苦乐之间常思之，详慎所言。 天道亿万，在人所为，不夺人愿也。 生养之道审可观，死亡之道，鬼所患也。 凶神不安，辄受之难为文也。 天上有文，求生根也。 人所愿，故挺此文，使可思也。 有过自悔，案此文也。 不者亦已，无妄言也。 神灵在汝前后，无解时也。 右天上昌兴国降逆明先师贤圣道天地喜神出助人治令人寿四夷却。 太平经卷之一百一十二竟 太平经卷之一百一十三 乐怒吉凶诀第一百九十一 请问太平气俱至，人民但当日相向而游，具乐器以为常，因以和调相化，上有益国家，使天气和调，常喜国家寿，天下亦被其德教而无咎。 其乐得与不得，以何为明哉？ 和与不和，以何为效乎？ 欲不及天师具问其事，恐固固有不口口者，故前后重问，不敢懈怠，恐天怒也。 善哉，子为天问事，日益闲习，得天意。 真人必益年寿无穷，天所佑也。 诺。 安坐，复为诸弟子具更道其意，使其察察，令可知也。

Seek nobility in thought, and the gods of nobility honor it; seek wealth in thought, and the gods of wealth enrich it. Between suffering and joy, ever reflect—weigh carefully every word.

The Dao of Heaven spans myriad eons, yet rests in human action; it does not thwart mortal aspirations. The Way of life and nurturance may be clearly observed; the Way of death is what ghosts dread. Malevolent spirits find no peace, and swiftly incur calamity—such is the pattern inscribed.

In Heaven above, there is a pattern: the root of seeking life. Human desires gave rise to this text, that all may ponder it. If one errs and repents, consult this text. If not, then desist—speak no reckless words. The divine spirits stand before and behind you, without respite.

Above: *Heaven’s Prosperity, the Flourishing State, the Descending Luminous Former Masters, the Worthy and Sage Dao, the Joyous Spirits of Heaven and Earth—Emerging to Aid Human Governance, Extending Longevity to All, Repelling the Four Barbarians.*

**End of Scroll One Hundred Twelve of the Scripture of Great Peace**

**Scroll One Hundred Thirteen of the Scripture of Great Peace**
**Method of Joy and Anger, Fortune and Misfortune, One Hundred Ninety-One**

We ask: When the qi of Great Peace arrives in full, should the people but face one another daily in leisure, ever equipped with musical instruments as the norm, thereby harmonizing and transforming one another? Would this benefit the state above, causing Heaven’s qi to harmonize, perpetually delighting the state with longevity, while the world is embraced by its virtue and teaching, free from fault?

How is it made clear whether joy is attained or not? How is harmony or disharmony proven?

Thus, when the *Upper Horn* tone is attained, it transforms the upper; when the *Middle Horn* tone is attained, it transforms the middle; when the *Lower Horn* tone is attained, it transforms the lower—each attained to bring about transformation.

The *Zheng* tones of the southern direction, great and small, all in harmony, cause all things to delight in growth. In the southern direction, virtue and power know no joy unmet; what is harmful is dispelled, what is good advances entirely, and the crimson qi rejoices wholly. The crimson spirit comes forth on its journey, the heart remains free from illness, and the spirit of the heart emerges to appear, awaiting the arrival of the crimson-clad jade maidens who bear wondrous prescriptions to bestow upon humankind—this is its great proof.

Thus, when the harmony of the yellow qi and the *Gong* tone is attained, the good of the *Gong* tone likewise comes entirely, while what is harmful dissipates entirely. When the harmony of the *Shang* tone is attained, the good of the *Shang* tone likewise comes entirely, while what is harmful dissipates entirely. When the harmony of the *Yu* tone is attained, the good of the *Yu* tone likewise comes entirely, while what is harmful departs entirely.

Perfected One, ponder deeply the essential meaning of what brings about these effects and their fundamental practice.

The reason the five directions are not exhaustively expounded is that their profundity is vast. The superior person, upon glimpsing them, naturally grasps their meaning, using the one to encompass the myriad. The middling person, upon attaining them, might grow overly exuberant. The petty person, upon gaining them, might speak recklessly. Thus, they are not fully revealed, allowing each person to contemplate their meaning for themselves.

The superior person, moreover, uses the one to encompass the myriad, thoroughly understanding their meaning—there is no need to expound them fully. The middling person, too, may gradually come to know them—there is no need to expound them fully. The petty person, if they attain them, might speak recklessly—there is no need to expound them fully.

Therefore, with measured restraint and careful consideration, the outline is briefly raised to reveal the matter to ordinary people, allowing each to contemplate its meaning. In this way, high and low may communicate and penetrate without error.

chunks.original_text: 故上士治乐，以作无为，以度世； 中士治乐，乃以和乐俗人，以调治； 下士治乐，裁以乐人，以召食。 此三人者，各谕意，太平气至，听其所为，从其具乐琴瑟，慎无禁之。 则乐气不出，治难平。 难平则气斗讼，而多刑。 夫乐者致乐，刑者致刑，犹影响之验，不失铢分也。 凡乐者所以止怒也，凡怒者所以止乐者也，此两者相伐，是故乐则怒止，怒则乐止。 是故怒者乃生刑罚，斗之根也，喜乐者乃道德之门也。 故当从之，使生道德之根，勿止之也，止之反且生刑祸之门也。 此者吉凶之所出，安危之所发也。 故乐者阳也，刑罚者阴也，阴之与阳，乃更相反，阳兴则阴衰，阴兴则阳衰。 阳者君也，阴者臣也，君盛则臣服，民易治，臣盛则君治侮乱，此天自然之法也。 故当从其君乐也，以厌其民臣，止其数怒也。 下古之人愚，不深知其意，反多断绝之，故使阴气盛，阳气衰也。 阴气盛则多盗贼，罪人不绝。 凡万物不生也，多被阴害，大咎在此。 乐气兴则阳气盛，以断此害。 君气盛则致延年益寿，则上老寿。 夫缓与乐者，上属天也； 急与怒刑者，下属地。 兴行其上者，万事理，兴行其下者，万事乱。 真人戒之，此言可不深思乎？ 唯唯。 子可谓深知之矣。 传之以示下古之人，使各思其意，慎无闭绝也。 乐则五方道德悉出，怒则五方恶悉出也。 乐则天地道德悉出也，怒则天地恶悉出也。 故天地乐者，善应出也，天地不乐者，恶应出也。 故五方乐而和者，五方善应出也，故五方不乐而怒者，五方恶应出也，是非小事也，故言毋断绝也。 令凡人共惟思其意，俱一觉悉出之，然后悦乐气至，急怒气去也。 善哉善哉。 行，子已知之矣。 右天上分别乐与怒所生吉凶诀。 太平经卷之一百一十三竟 太平经卷之一百一十四
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, the superior person governs with music to enact non-action and deliver the world; the middling person governs with music to harmonize and delight the common people, thereby regulating and ordering them; the petty person governs with music merely to entertain others, thereby summoning sustenance. These three kinds of people, each understanding their intent, when the qi of Great Peace arrives, allow them to act as they will, following their use of lutes and zithers—take care not to prohibit it. If the qi of music does not emerge, governance will be difficult to pacify. When governance is difficult to pacify, qi contends and disputes arise, leading to many punishments.

Music brings forth joy, and punishments bring forth penalties, like echoes and shadows, not deviating by even a fraction. Now, music is that by which anger is stilled, and anger is that by which music is stilled—these two oppose each other. Thus, when there is music, anger ceases; when there is anger, music ceases. Therefore, anger gives rise to punishments and penalties, the root of contention, while joy and delight are the gateway to virtue and the Dao. Hence, one should follow it, allowing the root of virtue and the Dao to grow—do not suppress it, for suppression will instead give rise to the gateway of penal misfortune.

From this emerge good and ill fortune, from this arise safety and danger. Thus, music is yang, and punishments are yin. Yin and yang are ever opposed; when yang flourishes, yin wanes, and when yin flourishes, yang wanes. Yang is the ruler, yin is the minister. When the ruler is strong, the minister submits, and the people are easily governed. When the minister is strong, the ruler is treated with contempt and disorder arises—this is the natural law of Heaven.

Therefore, one should follow the ruler’s joy to subdue the people and ministers, curbing their frequent anger. The people of later ages are foolish and do not deeply understand this intent, instead often cutting it off, causing yin qi to flourish and yang qi to wane. When yin qi flourishes, there are many thieves and bandits, and criminals never cease. All things fail to grow, often harmed by yin—great calamity lies here. When the qi of music flourishes, yang qi prevails, cutting off this harm. When the ruler’s qi flourishes, it brings extended years and added longevity, so that the highest elders live long.

Now, ease and joy belong to Heaven above; haste, anger, and punishments belong to Earth below. When that which belongs to Heaven is put into practice, all affairs are ordered; when that which belongs to Earth is put into practice, all affairs are disordered. Perfected One, take heed—can these words not be deeply pondered? Indeed, indeed. You may be said to understand deeply.

Transmit this to show the people of later ages, so that each may contemplate its meaning—take care not to obstruct or sever it. When there is joy, the virtue of the five directions emerges in full; when there is anger, the evil of the five directions emerges in full. When there is joy, the virtue of Heaven and Earth emerges in full; when there is anger, the evil of Heaven and Earth emerges in full. Thus, when Heaven and Earth are joyful, good responses emerge; when Heaven and Earth are not joyful, evil responses emerge.

When the five directions are joyful and harmonious, good responses emerge from the five directions; when the five directions are not joyful and are angry, evil responses emerge from the five directions—this is no small matter. Therefore, it is said: do not sever it. Let all people together contemplate its meaning, all awakening to it in unison, so that the qi of joy and delight arrives and the qi of hasty anger departs. Excellent, excellent! Go forth—you have understood it.

Above: The Heavenly distinction between the good and ill fortune arising from joy and anger.

chunks.original_text: 某诀第一百九十二#1 （前文原缺） 行有疾苦，心中恻然，叩头医前，补写孝言，承事恭敬，以家所有，贡进上之，敬称其人，医工见是，心敬其人，尽意为求真药，新好分部，谷令可知，迎医解除。 常垂涕而言，谢过於天，自搏求哀，叩头於地，不避瓦石泥涂之中，辄得令父母平安。 教儿妇常在亲前，作肥甘脆，恣口所食，父母商家所有，不致苦其子孙，令尽家所有，殊私心孝於前。 亲属比邻，见其孝善，知无所有，更往给饷，为其呼迎医工，蒙荐席，相与日夜数劳，知其安危问养，视其复闻小善言，心为之喜欢，是孝之所致也。 天见其孝心，令得愈，更如平素，心中乃喜欣。 复身得能食谷者，斋戒市卖，进所有上於天，还谢先人，诸所得祟，辄卒香洁，不敢负言，是孝子所宜行也。 俗闻知是善，而不能行之，能行之者，性出自然。 天禀其命，令使孝善，子孙相传。 治生有进，不行侵人，有益於亲，宾婚比邻，孝者还报，不忘其恩，是之善者也。 父母之年，不可豫知，为作储待，减省小费，岁岁有余，藏不见之处，勿使长吏及小吏闻知。 因缘征发，尽人财产，为孝心未尽，更无所有。 父母年尽，无以饷送，复为不竟孝之意。 行孝之人，思成其功，功着名太上，闻帝廷，州郡所举，一朝被荣，是非孝所致耶？ 子孙承之，可竟无极之世。 此念恩不忘，为天所善，天遣善神常随护，是孝所致也。 其家一人，当得长生度世，后生敬之，可无祸患，各以寿终，无中夭者，是不善邪？ 善之中所致，何所不成，何所不就，何所不得，何所不通乎？ 努力行之，勿以为懈倦也，是善人之福也。 孝善之人，人亦不侵之也，侵孝善人，天为治之，剧於目前。 是为可知，欲知善之为善也，知孝之为孝也，苦不能相效也，是出自然。 天与善籍，善孝自相得传，相胜举，亦何有极心。 善孝之人，人自从崇之，亦不犯克人。 流闻八远，州郡县长吏，有空缺相补。 豫知善孝之家，县中荐举，长吏以人情，欲闻其孝善，遣吏劳来。 又有用心者，以身往来候之，知闻行意荐之。 岁岁被荣，高德佩带，子孙相承，名为传孝之家，无恶人也。 不但自孝於家，并及内外，为吏皆孝於君，益其忠诚，常在高职，孝於朝廷。 郡县出奇伪之物，自以家财市之，取善不烦於民，无所役。 郡县皆慈孝，五谷为丰熟，无中夭之民。 天为其调和风雨，使时节，是天上孝善之人，使不逢灾害。 人民师化，皆食养有顺之心，天不逆意也。 是善尤善，孝忠尤孝，遂成之。 使天下不孝之人相效，为设孝意，有大命赦天下，诸所不当犯者尽除，并与孝悌力田之子，赐其彩帛酒肉，长吏致敬，明其孝行，使人见之。 傍人见之，是有心者可进爱，有善意相爱，此皆天下恩分，使民顺从。 此本善致善，本孝致孝，本不孝其末不孝，本恶其末恶。 善者其愿皆令其寿，白首乃终。 上至百二十，下百余岁，善孝所致，非但空言而语也。 不但天爱之也，四时五行、日月星辰皆善之，更照之，使不逢邪也。 其善乃如是，可不重邪？ 天生人民，少能善孝者，身为之独寿考。 复得尊官，皆行孝所致。 不但佑言，故出此书，以示生民。 其欲法则者，天复令寿，可传子孙相保书出，必当行孝，度世孝者，其次复望官爵。

**Section One Hundred Ninety-Two**

*(Preceding text lost.)* When one suffers illness and hardship, the heart aches with sorrow. Kneeling before the physician, one humbly offers filial words, serving with reverence, presenting all that the household possesses, and addressing the healer with utmost respect. The physician, seeing this, honors the person and devotes all effort to seeking true medicine—fresh, fine, and properly apportioned—so that the ailment may be known and the healer summoned to bring relief.

One constantly sheds tears, speaking to Heaven in repentance, striking one’s breast to beg for mercy, kowtowing to the earth without shunning mud or broken tiles, thereby securing the well-being of one’s parents. One teaches sons and daughters-in-law to remain always before their elders, preparing rich and delicate foods, allowing them to eat whatever they desire. One does not begrudge parents the family’s resources, nor let children and grandchildren endure hardship, but instead expends all the household possesses, cherishing a singularly filial heart in their presence.

Relatives and neighbors, witnessing such filial goodness and knowing one has nothing left, come to offer provisions, summoning physicians on one’s behalf. They spread mats, laboring day and night, inquiring after the parents’ condition and care. Upon hearing even a small word of improvement, the heart rejoices—this is the result of filial devotion. Heaven, seeing such a filial heart, grants recovery, restoring health as before, and the heart is filled with joy.

When one regains the ability to eat grain, one fasts and purifies, selling possessions to offer all to Heaven, then repays the ancestors. For every blessing received, one burns pure incense, never daring to break one’s word—this is the conduct proper to a filial child. The world may hear of such goodness yet fail to practice it; those who do act thus do so by nature’s own inclination. Heaven endows their fate, enabling filial goodness to be passed down through generations.

In managing livelihoods, one advances without encroaching on others, benefiting one’s parents. In marriages and neighborly relations, the filial receive reciprocity, never forgetting kindness—such is the excellence of this way. The years of one’s parents cannot be foreknown; one prepares in advance, reducing minor expenses to save year after year, storing surpluses in hidden places unknown even to local officials. When levies and requisitions deplete a family’s wealth, if one’s filial heart remains unfulfilled and nothing is left, and if the parents’ years come to an end without proper offerings, this would be an incomplete fulfillment of filial duty.

Those who practice filial piety strive to perfect their merit. When their deeds become renowned and ascend to the highest courts, when commanderies and prefectures recommend them, and in a single day they receive honor—is this not the result of filial devotion? Their descendants inherit this legacy, perpetuating it for limitless generations. Such gratitude, never forgotten, is favored by Heaven, which dispatches good spirits to constantly guard and protect—this, too, is the result of filial piety.

Within such a household, one member may attain transcendence and long life, while later generations honor them, free from misfortune. Each lives out their years without premature death—could this be anything but goodness? From goodness, all things are accomplished, all goals achieved, all desires attained, all paths opened. Strive to practice this without slackening—such is the fortune of the good.

The filial and good are not encroached upon by others; should anyone harm them, Heaven swiftly punishes them before one’s eyes. This is knowable: to understand goodness as goodness and filial piety as filial piety, yet find it difficult to emulate, is a matter of natural disposition. Heaven grants the register of the good, and filial goodness is transmitted of itself, surpassing and elevating one another—how could there be an end to such a heart?

The good and filial are naturally revered by others, who do not offend or oppose them. Their reputation spreads to the eight distant regions, and when vacancies arise among prefectural and county officials, those who know of such filial households recommend them. Local officials, moved by human sentiment and wishing to hear of their filial goodness, send envoys to inquire. Those with discernment visit personally, learning of their conduct and recommending them. Year after year, they receive honors, wearing tokens of high virtue, their descendants inheriting the name of a "house of transmitted filial piety," free from evil people.

Not only do they practice filial piety at home, but it extends to all within and without. As officials, they are filial to their lord, enhancing their loyalty, and thus remain in high office, filial to the court. When commanderies and counties produce rare or counterfeit goods, they use their own wealth to purchase the finest, sparing the people from labor and corvée. Where commanderies and counties abound in kindness and filial piety, the five grains flourish, and no one dies prematurely. Heaven harmonizes wind and rain for them, ensuring timely seasons—this is the protection Heaven grants to the filial and good, sparing them from disaster.

The people follow their example, nourishing and obeying with devoted hearts, and Heaven does not oppose their will. Such goodness is supremely good, such filial loyalty supremely filial—thus it is perfected. Let the unfilial of the world emulate them, cultivating filial intent. When a great mandate pardons the world, all improper transgressions are absolved, and to the filial, the fraternal, and the diligent farmers, silks, wine, and meat are bestowed. Officials pay them respect, making their filial conduct known so that others may witness it. Those who see it, moved by sincerity, may advance in love, cherishing one another with goodwill—this is the grace Heaven bestows to guide the people in obedience.

This is the principle: goodness begets goodness, filial piety begets filial piety; lack of filial piety at the root yields lack of filial piety in the end, and evil at the root yields evil in the end. The good receive their wish for longevity, living to white-haired old age. Some reach one hundred and twenty, others over a hundred—this is the result of filial goodness, not mere empty words.

Not only does Heaven love them, but the four seasons, the five phases, the sun, moon, and stars all favor them, shining upon them to keep them from encountering misfortune. Such goodness is of this magnitude—how can it not be esteemed? Among the people Heaven creates, few can be good and filial, yet those who do so alone enjoy long life and attain high office—all through the practice of filial piety.

This is not mere empty praise; thus this scripture is revealed to instruct the living. Those who wish to follow its model will be granted extended life by Heaven. It may be transmitted to descendants as a safeguard. Those who practice filial piety to transcend the world, and those who aspire to office and rank, must first fulfill filial duty.

chunks.original_text: 天下之事，孝为上第一，人所不及。 积功累行，前后相承，无所有失。 名复生之人，得承父母之恩，复见孝顺之文。 天定其录籍，使在不死之中，是孝之家也。 亦复得增度上天，行天上之事，复书忠孝诸所敬，为天领职，荣宠日见，天上名之为孝善神人，皆为神所敬。 有求美之食，先上遗其孝行，如是无有双人。 其寿无极，精光日增。 上见无极之天，下见无极之地，傍行见无极之境。 复知未然之事，诸神皆随其教令，不逆其意，共荐举白。 太上之君，见其孝行无辈，着其亲近内外，神益敬重之。 故言天所爱者，诸神敬之，天所憎者，诸神危之。 是为可知，余者各自用意，自择其便，从其所宜。 书辞小息，且念其后，得善复出，不令遗脱。 九君太上亲诀第一百九十三 惟太上之君有法度，开明洞照，可知无所不通，豫知未然之事。 神灵未言，豫知所指，神见豫知，不敢欺枉，了然何所。 复道太上之言，何有不动乎？ 人同敬畏，心不悉行，是且得知，不照其意。 所以然者，太上皆神，所生所化，当生当活，皆可知神录，相次道其尊卑，何有不从者乎？ 九皇之上则九君，九君者，则太上之亲也。 各有所行，恩贷布施诸神从者，诸神敬其所为，靡有不就者也。 小神食，不能知九皇之意，何言俗间之人乎？ 心圣耳聪，财可观其文章禄策。 当直录籍文辞，自生精光，皆以金为简，银成其文章。 此簿在天君，内中极有副，其余曹文书辞，皆以奏简，自生文章，精神随字，名之光明。 每有语言，辄照有所知，不逆所言。 神人真人得天君辞，便具言神人上下，皆知民间。 天君知神所言，不失文墨规矩之中。 自然之道，何所不知，何所不化，动错自无所私。 饮食天厨，衣服精华，欲复何求，是太上之君所行也。 大神小神，自有所行，皆相畏敬，不敢有私。 恣意见所从求，动摇有心之心，知其所为可成，以不惑迷其意，使其人各随至意。 言汝皆受於仙箓，寿得无极。 金银紫文之绶，封侯食邑，复肠彩帛金银珠玉，心想所得。 是非神仙道，知人坚与不，或赐与美人玉女之象，为其作色便利之，志意不倾。 复令大小之象，见其形变，意相随，念其后生，此为不成之道。 或作深山大谷中，多禽兽虎狼之处，深水使化人心。 或有虫毒之物，使其人杀之。 或恐不敢上高山，入大谷深水之中，亦道不成。 是象戒人，是在不上之中，殊能坚心专意。 见迷惑不转志，坚随其入出，上下深山大谷之中，水深大，心不恐惧。 见其好色，志不贪慕，家人大小之象，更相拘留。 不随其人言，但得主道，进见太上，尽忠孝之心，无所顾於下，是为可成。 戒大众，多取其要文。 天亦信善人，使神仙度之也。 其人自善，天何从欺之。 所以有欺者，其人狐疑，强索神仙，无益之用，无功而求安，何从不见欺邪？ 是天重生，爱其情，尤志坚，念生要三明。 三明者心也，主正明堂，通日月之光。 名三明成道，心志自不顾，亦有录策，不可强求。 白日升天之人，自有其真，性自善，心自有明，动摇戒意不倾邪，财利之属不视顾，衣服粗粗，衣才蔽形，是升天之人行也。 天善其善也，乃令善神随护，使不中邪。 天神爱之，遂成其功。 是身行所致，其人自不贪世俗，大营财物。
chunks.translated_text:
The affairs of the world place filial piety above all else—none surpass it. Through accumulated merit and layered deeds, past and present are seamlessly linked, leaving nothing amiss. Those reborn as humans receive their parents’ grace and encounter the teachings of filial devotion. Heaven inscribes their names in the celestial registers, placing them among the deathless—such is the household of filial piety. They may ascend to the heavens, performing the work of the celestial realm, their loyalty and filial reverence recorded among all that is revered. Appointed to heavenly offices, their glory and favor grow daily, and in the heavens they are named "Filial and Virtuous Divine Beings," honored by all spirits. When fine foods are sought, their filial deeds are first offered above; none compare to them. Their lifespan knows no limit, their radiance ever increasing. Above, they behold the boundless heavens; below, the boundless earth; and in their travels, they witness the boundless realms. They foresee events yet to come, and all spirits follow their commands, never opposing their will, all joining to recommend and proclaim them. The Supreme Sovereign, seeing their unmatched filial conduct, draws them near, both within and without, and the spirits hold them in ever greater reverence.

Thus it is said: what Heaven loves, the spirits honor; what Heaven detests, the spirits endanger. This is plain to see. The rest must each apply their own discernment, choosing what suits them best, following what is fitting.

The text pauses briefly here, yet its later teachings remain to be revealed, ensuring nothing is omitted.

**The One Hundred and Ninety-Third Secret Transmission of the Nine Lords and the Supreme Sovereign**

Only the Supreme Sovereign possesses the law and order, illuminating and penetrating all, knowing all without exception, foreseeing events yet to unfold. Before the spirits speak, their intent is already known; before their forms appear, their actions are foreseen, leaving no room for deception. How could the words of the Supreme Sovereign fail to move all? Yet though people revere them, their hearts do not fully enact them—this is known, though their intent is not fully reflected.

The reason is this: the Supreme Sovereign is wholly divine, governing all that is born and transformed, all that lives and thrives. All is recorded in the divine registers, their ranks and stations clearly ordained—how could any fail to comply? Above the Nine August Ones stand the Nine Lords, who are the kin of the Supreme Sovereign. Each has their own domain, bestowing grace and favor, and all spirits follow their lead. The spirits honor their deeds, and none fail to comply. Lesser spirits, unable to grasp the intent of the Nine August Ones, how much less can worldly people?

With a sagacious mind and keen ears, one may perceive the patterns of fortune in their writings. The celestial registers, inscribed with radiant words, are etched on tablets of gold, their texts formed of silver. These records reside with the Heavenly Lord, with duplicates kept in the innermost chambers. Other documents and memorials are written on jade slips, their characters infused with spirit, their names shining with luminosity. With every utterance, illumination follows, revealing all that is known, never contradicting what is spoken.

When divine beings and perfected ones receive the Heavenly Lord’s decrees, they fully proclaim the affairs of spirits above and below, all knowing the matters of the mortal realm. The Heavenly Lord, aware of the spirits’ words, ensures they adhere to the rules of script and measure. The natural Dao—what does it not know? What does it not transform? Its movements and actions are free from partiality.

They partake of the celestial kitchens’ fare and wear garments of pure essence—what more could they seek? Such is the conduct of the Supreme Sovereign. Great and small spirits each have their roles, all revering and respecting one another, never acting with selfishness. They follow their desires, moving with purposeful intent, knowing what can be achieved, never allowing confusion to cloud their minds, guiding each person according to their deepest wishes.

They declare: "You have all received the immortal registers, and your lifespan shall know no end. Adorned with purple cords inscribed with gold and silver, you shall be enfeoffed as marquises with domains to govern, your intestines filled with silken brocades, gold, silver, pearls, and jade—whatever your heart desires shall be yours."

Yet this is not the path of immortals. They discern whether a person’s resolve is firm or faltering. Some are granted the semblance of beauties and jade maidens, crafted to test their composure and advantage. If their will wavers, the forms of great and small shift before them, their thoughts trailing after them, their minds fixed on posterity—this is the way of failure.

Some are placed in deep mountains and vast valleys, among beasts and tigers and wolves, or in deep waters, to test their hearts. Others encounter venomous creatures, compelling them to act. Some fear ascending high mountains, entering deep valleys, or venturing into deep waters—such is the path to failure.

These trials warn the unwary, for only those with unwavering resolve and single-minded focus can withstand delusion and remain steadfast. They traverse mountains and valleys, deep and vast, waters profound and wide, their hearts unafraid. Though they encounter beauty, their will does not covet it. Though the semblances of family, great and small, seek to restrain them, they do not heed their words, holding fast to the Dao. Advancing to meet the Supreme Sovereign, they fulfill their loyalty and filial devotion without regard for lesser concerns—this is the way to success.

Thus we admonish the multitude, extracting the essential teachings. Heaven trusts the virtuous, allowing the immortals to deliver them. If a person is inherently good, how could Heaven deceive them? Those who are deceived harbor doubts, forcibly demanding immortality, seeking ease without merit—how could they not be deceived?

Heaven cherishes life, favoring those of sincere intent and steadfast will, urging them to grasp the Three Illuminations. The Three Illuminations reside in the heart, governing the Hall of Light, channeling the radiance of the sun and moon. When the Three Illuminations attain the Dao, the heart’s resolve remains unshaken, and the records are inscribed—not to be forcibly sought.

Those who ascend to heaven in broad daylight possess true essence, their nature inherently good, their hearts inherently luminous. They move with caution, their will unwavering, unmoved by wealth or profit. Their garments are coarse, barely covering their forms—such is the conduct of those who ascend to heaven.

Heaven cherishes their goodness, sending benevolent spirits to guard and protect them, shielding them from harm. The celestial spirits love them, ensuring the completion of their merit. Such is the result of their own conduct. They do not covet worldly affairs or amass wealth, and thus their deeds are perfected.

ple Heaven creates, few can be good and filial, yet those who do so alone enjoy long life and attain high office—all through the practice of filial piety.

This is not mere empty praise; thus this scripture is revealed to instruct the living. Those who wish to follow its model will be granted extended life by Heaven. It may be transmitted to descendants as a safeguard. Those who practice filial piety to transcend the world, and those who aspire to office and rank, must first fulfill filial duty.

chunks.original_text: 天知其至意，按次簿名真，自有善星。 其生日时，自不为恶，天复善之，贪化以助天君，治理天上文辞，使通彻，行无私隐。 见行有岁数，上竟荣簿有生名，可太上之意，能说其功行，助其不及，是亦神当所拥护也。 天信孝有善诚，行无玷缺。 故使白日辄有承迎，前后昭昭，众民所见，是成其功，使人见善。 白日之人，百万之人，未有一人得者也。 能得之者，天大神所保信也。 余者不得比尸解之人，百万之人乃出一人耳。 功有大小，更相荐举，其人当使天爱重之。 内为得太上腹心，荐举其为有信效，各成其功名，是不善邪？ 天君出教之日，神不枉其言。 是天君得善信效，深知未然，不可有毛发之欺。 皆令寿命尽少，尽小解於后，复念语未卒意者，复念道之。 不孝不可久生诫第一百九十四 惟古今世间，皆多不副人意。 苟欲自可，不忠任事。
chunks.translated_text:
The heavens recognize their utmost sincerity, recording their names in the celestial ledgers as true beings, each accompanied by a benevolent star. From the moment of their birth and the hour of their arrival, they refrain from evil, and the heavens further favor them, transforming their greed to aid the Heavenly Lord in governing the celestial documents, ensuring their clarity and unobstructed flow, their actions free from selfish concealment.

Their years of conduct are witnessed, their names inscribed in the honored registers of the living, aligning with the will of the Most High. They can articulate their merits and deeds, assisting where others fall short—such individuals are rightfully cherished and protected by the spirits. The heavens trust those who are filial, sincere, and whose conduct is without blemish or flaw. Thus, they are met with celestial escorts in broad daylight, their arrival and departure resplendent, visible to all people, their merit complete, inspiring others to witness goodness.

Among those who ascend in daylight, not one in a million attains this. Those who do are greatly trusted and safeguarded by the celestial deities. Others cannot compare to those who achieve liberation through *shijie*; even among millions, only one emerges. Though their merits vary in magnitude, they recommend and elevate one another, and such individuals are deeply cherished by the heavens.

Within, they gain the trust of the Most High, who recommends them as proven and faithful, each achieving their merit and renown—could this be anything but good? When the Heavenly Lord issues decrees, the spirits do not distort his words. The Heavenly Lord, having witnessed their faithfulness, knows what is yet to come, allowing not even a hair’s breadth of deceit. All are granted extended lifespans, even those who achieve minor liberation later. If their thoughts or words remain incomplete, they continue to contemplate the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 所言所道，乐无奇异，见人为善，含笑而言，何益於事？ 轻言易口，父子相欺。 当目无声背去，随后而言，或善或恶，不可法则，无益世间。 世间但为尘垢，言谈自动，无应善书者。 心言我善，行不相副，无有循谷，语言浮沈，不可信验。 名为不慎之人，何可久前，不可与善心有志之人等乎。 求生难死之人，不欲见是恶人，而不自知，以为我健，少能相胜者。 反晨夜候取无义之财，而不攻苦得之，以为可久在中和之中，与人语言也，傍人见之， 非尤其言。 神灵闻知，亦占其所为动作，其心知其恶，不能久善，还语天神。 言中和有轻口易语之人，不能久善，须臾之间，恶言复见，无有信效。 但佞伪相责，何益於人。 令食诸谷，衣缯布，随冬夏易衣服，食欲快口，衣欲快身。 市有利入，不肯求之，而可养老亲，明旦下床，未知所之。 衒卖所有，更为主宾，酒家箕踞，调戏谈笑，歌舞作声，自以为健，交头耳语，讲说是非，财物各尽，更无以自给，相结为非，遂为恶人，不可拘绊，自弃恶中，何有善半日之间邪？ 无益家用，愁毒父母，兄弟妇儿，辄当忧之，无有解已。 攻取劫盗，既无休止，自以长年，复见白首。 不知天遣候神，居其左右，入其身内，促其所为。 令使凶，当断其年，不可令久，其扬声为恶，不欲止。 上至县官，捕得正法，不得久生。 与死为比，安得复生？ 或为鬼神所害。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who speak and teach delight in nothing extraordinary; when they see others doing good, they smile and speak—yet what benefit does this bring? Their words are careless and reckless, deceiving even father and son. They turn away in silence, then speak behind others’ backs, whether of good or ill, setting no standard to follow, offering no benefit to the world. The world is but dust and grime, where speech stirs on its own, and none respond to virtuous writings. Though their hearts claim goodness, their conduct does not match; lacking steadfastness, their words drift and sink, unworthy of trust. Such are the reckless—how can they endure long? They cannot be equated with those of good heart and resolve.

Those who seek life and dread death wish not to see such wicked men, yet fail to recognize their own nature, boasting of their strength and few who can surpass them. Instead, they lie in wait day and night to seize wealth without righteousness, avoiding toil to obtain it, believing they may long abide in harmony, speaking among others. Yet those beside them see through them and reproach their words. The spirits, hearing and observing their deeds and movements, know their hearts’ wickedness and that their goodness cannot last. They report to the heavenly gods: "Within the harmony of the Dao, there is one of reckless speech and careless words, whose goodness cannot endure. In but a moment, their evil words reappear, devoid of trust or proof. They only engage in flattery and deceit—what benefit do they bring to others?"

They are granted the grains to eat and silks and cloth to wear, changing garments with winter and summer, seeking food to please the palate and clothes to please the body. Though the market offers profitable gain, they refuse to seek it, yet claim to support aged parents. At dawn, they rise from bed, not knowing where they go. They peddle all they possess, shifting between host and guest, lounging in taverns with legs splayed, jesting and laughing, singing and dancing, making merry, boasting of their vigor. They whisper among themselves, spreading gossip and slander. When their wealth is exhausted and nothing remains to sustain them, they band together in wrongdoing, becoming wicked men beyond restraint. How could they find even half a day of goodness? Their actions bring no benefit to the household, only sorrow and poison to parents, siblings, wives, and children, who must ever bear this grief without relief.

Their plundering and theft know no end; though they see their hair turn white, they remain unaware that the spirits sent by Heaven stand at their side, enter their bodies, and hasten their deeds. They are made to meet misfortune, their years cut short, for their clamor of evil cannot be stilled. When their crimes reach the authorities, they are seized and lawfully punished, their lives not spared. Compared to death, how can they live again? Or they may be harmed by ghosts and spirits.

chunks.original_text: 父母念之，常见其独泪孤相守，无有辅佐之者。 老更弃捐，饮食大恶，希得肥美，衣履空穿，无有补者。 是恶之极，岁月年长，空虚日久，面目丑恶，不象人色。 如是为子，乃使父母老无所依，亲属不肯有之。 此恶人之行，灭乃上，亲属患之，名为蔽。 子死不见葬，无有衣木，便见埋矣。 狐狸所食，骨弃旷野，何时当复见汝衣食时乎？ 是为可知善恶之行，人自致之，何所怨咎乎？ 天下之人何其甚愚，不计其死生之间殊绝矣。 生为有生气，见天地日月星宿之明，亡死者当复知有天明时乎？ 窈冥之中，何有明时。 愚人不深计，使子孙得咎，祸不可救，殃流后生，是谁之过乎？ 人不化，自致亡失年，不当善仙士之行邪？ 动作言谈，辄有纲纪，有益父母，使得十肥，衣或复好，面目生光。 是子孝行，力非恶人，亦独不当报父母哺乳之恩邪？ 为子不孝，汝生子当孝邪？ 汝善得善，恶得恶，如镜之照人，为不知汝之情邪？ 故有善恶之文，同其文墨，寿与不寿，相去何若？ 生人久视有岁数，命尽乃终，后为鬼，尚不见治问。 恶人早死，地下掠治，责其所不当为。 苦其苦处，不见乐时。 是为鬼，何以独不有赦时。 是恶之极，为鬼复恶，何所依止。 家无食者，乞丐为事，逐逋亡之气，自不可久，地下亦欲得善鬼，不用恶也。 如是宜各念善，不失其度，才可矣。 不者，亦欲何望乎？ 人当同其计策，与生同愿，天不善之邪？ 而反为恶乎，恶行之人，不可久视天地日月星辰，故藏之地下，不得善鬼同其乐，得分别也。 文书前后复重者，诚憎是恶人，不可久生耳。 性善之人，天所佑也。 子孙生辄以善，日下无禁忌，复直月建，日月星光明之时，用是生者，何忧不寿乎？ 是为善行所致也。 善恶分别念中，可行者自从便安，天不逆人所为也。 念之复念之，思之复思之，可前可却，自不贪生者，无可奈何也。 书辞可知，分明疑之。 自令苦极，念生勿懈，致慎所言。 辞复小止，使念其后，有不满意，乃复议之。 见诫不触恶诀第一百九十五 惟夫圣德之人，各有所言，各有所语。 各分别其能，各自第其功，各成其宜，使有可信，而重天言。 使天爱人，而有盛功，得天之腹心，是圣德之愿也。 夫人皆欲承天，欲得其意，无有怨言。 故令各从其志，勿有非言而自可，是为富得人情，使报信同其知虑，而从所宜。 人居世间，大不容易，动辄当承所言，皆不失其规中，而不自责，反怨言人言，是为不平行之。 各有怨辞，使天忿怒而不爱人，言寿命无常。 故天下有圣心大和之人，使语其意，令知过之所由从来，各令自改。 乃为人寿从中出，不在他人。 故言司命，近在胸心，不离人远，司人是非，有过辄退，何有失时，辄减人年命。 为知不相善之人，欲闻其戒，使得安静，过失之间，使思其意，令其受罚亡年，不令有恨。 天大宽柔忍人，不一朝而得刑罚也。 积过累之甚多，乃下主者之曹，收取其人魂神，考问所为，不与天文相应，复为欺，欺后首过，罪不可贷。 是故复勑下晓喻，为说行恶，灾变所致，使自改耳，不用其言，亦安可久久在民间为人乎？ 故分别善恶，各使不怨耳。 天为设禁，使不犯耳。 而故犯之，戒命於天神，可以久与人等也。
chunks.translated_text:
Parents ever think of them, seeing only their solitary tears and lonely vigil, with none to aid or support. In old age, they are cast aside, their food foul and meager, rarely tasting anything rich or fine. Their clothes and shoes are threadbare, with none to mend them. Such is the extremity of evil—years and months pass, days stretch empty and long, their faces grow hideous, bearing no semblance to human countenance.

As sons of this kind, they leave their parents in old age with no one to rely upon; even kin refuse to acknowledge them. This is the conduct of the wicked, whose offenses rise to the heavens. Their kin suffer for them, their names shrouded in disgrace. When such a son dies, no burial is seen, no shroud or coffin provided—he is simply interred. Foxes and jackals devour him, his bones cast upon the wilds. When shall he again know the comforts of clothing and food?

Thus are the deeds of good and evil made plain: men bring these fates upon themselves. Whom can they blame? How profoundly foolish are the people of the world, failing to weigh the vast gulf between life and death! While alive, they possess the breath of life, behold the radiance of heaven and earth, sun and moon, and stars. But in death, shall they again know the brightness of heaven? In the depths of darkness, when shall light return?

Fools do not ponder deeply, bringing calamity upon their descendants, disasters beyond remedy, misfortunes that flow to later generations. Whose fault is this? If men do not reform, they forfeit their years—should they not then emulate the conduct of the virtuous and the immortal? In every action and word, let there be discipline, bringing benefit to parents, ensuring their well-being, their food rich, their clothes fine, their faces aglow with vitality.

Such is the filial son’s conduct, his strength not that of the wicked. Ought he not alone repay his parents’ nurturing care? To be an unfilial son—when you have children, will they be filial? Good begets good, evil begets evil, as a mirror reflects a man. Do you not know your own nature?

Thus the records of good and evil share the same script, yet the span of life or its absence—how vast the difference! A living man’s years are numbered; when his allotted time is spent, he becomes a ghost, no longer subject to inquiry. The wicked die young, and in the underworld, they are seized and interrogated, held to account for their misdeeds. They endure suffering without respite, never knowing joy. As ghosts, when shall they find pardon?

Such is the extremity of evil: even as ghosts, they remain wicked, with nowhere to turn. Those without sustenance at home take to begging, chasing the fleeting breath of the fugitive, their days numbered. The underworld, too, desires good spirits, not the wicked. Thus, let each reflect upon goodness, not transgressing the proper measure—this alone suffices. Otherwise, what hope remains?

Men should share a common purpose, aligning their wishes with life. Does Heaven favor the unvirtuous? Why then do they persist in evil? The wicked cannot long endure beneath the gaze of heaven and earth, sun and moon, and stars. Thus are they hidden away in the underworld, denied the company of good spirits, bereft of joy or distinction.

Where the text repeats itself, it is to earnestly detest the wicked and deny them long life. The virtuous, favored by Heaven, beget descendants who are likewise good. Day by day, they encounter no taboos, their lives aligned with the moon’s phases and the radiance of sun, moon, and stars. For those born thus, what fear of not attaining long life? Such is the reward of virtuous conduct.

In the contemplation of good and evil, let each follow what brings peace. Heaven does not oppose men’s actions. Ponder again and again, reflect deeply—whether to advance or retreat, those who do not cling to life have no recourse. The words of this text are clear; doubt them not.

Let not suffering reach its extremity. Be mindful of life, never slackening, and heed these words with care. Though the discourse pauses briefly, let its lessons linger. If any point remains unclear, reconsider it.

**Admonition Against Transgressing Evil Precepts, One Hundred and Ninety-Five**

Of those endowed with sagely virtue, each has their say, each their discourse. Each distinguishes their abilities, ranks their merits, and fulfills what is fitting, so that trust may be placed in them, and Heaven’s words revered. Heaven loves mankind and bestows great merit, winning the heart of Heaven—this is the aspiration of sagely virtue.

All men wish to align with Heaven, to grasp its intent, without complaint. Thus, let each follow their resolve, avoiding baseless words, for this is to gain the people’s favor, ensuring their trust and shared understanding, adhering to what is proper.

To dwell in the world is no easy matter. In every action, one must heed what is said, never straying from the established bounds, nor blaming others while shirking self-reproach. Such is the conduct of inequity. Each harbors grievances, provoking Heaven’s wrath and displeasure, declaring that life and fate are inconstant.

Thus, there are those in the world of sagely and harmonious hearts who speak their intent, revealing the origins of transgressions, urging each to reform. For the span of a man’s life arises from within, not from others. Hence, it is said that the Controller of Fate resides near, within the heart, not far from man, overseeing right and wrong. At every fault, it withdraws, and how can there be no loss of time, no shortening of years?

Knowing the unvirtuous, it desires that they heed its warnings, finding peace. In moments of fault, let them reflect, lest they incur punishment and forfeit their years, harboring no resentment. Heaven is vastly forbearing and patient, not meting out punishment in a single day. Only when transgressions accumulate excessively does it dispatch the underworld’s officials to seize the soul, interrogate its deeds, and find them discordant with Heaven’s pattern. Deceit follows deceit, and the confession of faults brings unpardonable sin.

Thus, it again commands clear admonitions, explaining how evil conduct invites calamity, urging reform. If its words are ignored, how can one long remain among the living? Therefore, it distinguishes good and evil, ensuring no grievances arise. Heaven sets prohibitions to prevent transgression. Yet men deliberately violate them, defying the commands of Heaven’s spirits. How can they long endure among men?

Thus, the distinction between good and evil is made, so that none may complain. Heaven establishes prohibitions to prevent their breach. Yet men willfully transgress—let them be warned by the gods. Can they long remain among the living?

chunks.original_text: 作行如此，为使人不死之道乎？ 中为天无所知邪？ 俗人之行，不可采取乃如是，安可久置中和之中，使食可食之乎？ 而反善神所护，年尽乃止。 无中天人时，是善之证也。 为善日久，何忧不尽年寿乎？ 是为可知人自不能力为善，而自害之。 是恶之人何独剧，自以为可久与同命。 不意天神促之，使下入土，入土之后，何时复生出乎？ 地下复相引浸，益亡尸，是复不得天福之人，可复计邪？ 行且各为身计，勿益后生之患，是为中善之人。 不者欲为恶人也，天所不佑，地不欲载，致当慎之，勿有愆负，财得称人耳。 可为父母子孙，得续行恩有施，可复得增年，精华润泽，气力康强，是行善所致，恶自衰落，亦何所疑。 从今以来，当详消息，善恶分别，念中何行者，自从便安，天不逆人所为也。 念之复念，不顺作逆，而求久生。 是行当可久见於天神，日月星辰，安肯久照？ 为天神所佑，而争欲危之，是谁过乎？ 不当是善行孝顺之人邪？ 辄有禄位，食於司农，久复子民，使上下相事，是民之尊者也。 是善所致，恶自不全身，相去几何乎？ 视其试书，不用其言，自快可意而行，是为人非乎？ 有恶不能自化，有孝善，有忠诚信之心，而望天报，有病求愈，作恶过多，无解时，为可久贷与不。 故作此文，欲使俗夫之人，各不怨其得罚耳。 念生求活之人，自不为恶行，而亡其年也。 得书见诫，使知避禁，不触恶耳。 如是能自改为善，可得久见天地日月星辰，与人比等，是不善邪？ 而反不惜其命，以为死可得复生。 如人知不自知为恶，自以为可也。 谈语欲与人比等，衣食与部人同，是为可久不乎？ 畏死之人，不敢犯此诫文，是亦禄策所致。 其人相薄少可，宜直命当直之，何所顾乎？ 行，各自慎努力，念所行安危之事，书诫亦自可知也。 天书文欲使人为善，不欲闻其恶也。 故自命簿不全耳，无可大怪也。 详复思之，勿懈也。 天有生籍，亦可贪也。 地有死籍，亦甚可恶也。 生死之间，不可比也，为知不乎？ 知恶当慎自责，不可须臾有亡其年寿，甚可惜也。 与人语言发声，为善行得人心意。 是天善之，无出恶言，而自遗咎。 同出口气，正等择言出之。 无一小不善之辞，可得延命。 殊能思行天上之事，得天神要言，用其诫，动作使可思，可易命籍，转在长寿之曹。 宜复各修身正行，无忘天之所施。 宜置心念，报施大恩，乃为易行改志。 天复追念，使不逢恶，可信天书言，可得生治不用。 书言自不全，择其可行乃行之，不强所为。 各且念身善恶，天禀其性，勿有所嫌疑也。 宜不欺善，而恶人得福也。 是言者明白，何有所疑乎？ 神仙之人，皆不为恶者，各惜其命，是善之证也。 书所言约，勑前后道人之所愿，为道善恶，使思之耳。 不用而自已，勿自怨。 自怨者，但当知怨身少知，而穷老乃极，自咎之耳。 余者自从其意，如欲贪生，不当有恶。 故使自思，知其苦乐，乐独何人，苦亦何人，亦宜自念，勿有怨辞，勿妄轻言出气。 令可思，思生为善，故丁宁相语者。 令语言可知，不失天规矩。 行成自然之道，何所不成，何所不化，人皆迎之，是天自然之恩非邪？ 念下愚之人，不念受天大分，得为人，自以当常得久也。
